PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TITLE.XREF: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (STRENGTHENING OF PROVISIONS RELATING TO CHARACTER AND CONDUCT) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.
Consideration resumed from 18 November 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking last night on the Migration Legislation Amendment (Strengthening of Provisions relating to Character and Conduct) Bill 1997 and the debate was interrupted, I was making a number of simple points on the amendments which we are debating together. I would like to recapitulate because I think the opposition are under a number of misapprehensions about the measures, particularly the amendments they are proposing and the purpose they will serve.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal, firstly, with the matter of setting a time limit on the AAT reaching a decision. I did not mention this yesterday, but it is not unusual for time limits to be set in dealing with matters where, particularly, people might be held in detention—as they are in these character matters in many cases. In section 367 of the Migration Act there is provision that the Immigration Review Tribunal must make a decision and must notify the applicant within a prescribed period. Regulation 426 prescribes a period not of 42 days but of seven days. The reason for this is quite clear: when you are dealing with matters where there is some urgency—where people are detained—the 90‐day period that the opposition is suggesting obviously becomes totally unreasonable.

The second matter we are dealing with, which I would like to recapitulate, is the AAT itself and the way in which these particular matters operate. The procedures which the opposition is seeking to have remain in place are outlined in the AAT legislation. We are seeking in separate provisions—I think it is in 501G—to put in place the same types of procedures dealing with notice. Obviously it is going to be quite difficult in management terms to have two sets of procedures—those that are contained in the Migration Act and those that are in the AAT Act. The opposition are seeking to have those two sets of procedures operating together. Obviously they have not read the bill and do not understand the nature of the procedures and the duplication that they are putting in place.

I want to finally deal with the matter which is of far greater moment in this legislation so honourable members will be aware of it. Over a long period, matters relating to migration and particularly character issues have been determined by the minister representing the government of the day. It is not a matter in which the parliament should abdicate responsibility from the government to unelected tribunals to develop the framework of law and community standards that ought to apply. In the very rare cases that arise—and I indicated that I have only made decisions involving important character issues as minister in something like four or five cases in the time that I have been here—where the minister gets intelligence advice from international agencies about people who are of concern it is not appropriate that the applicant be informed of the nature of the intelligence. It might put people at risk. We are talking about very serious matters involving potential terrorists. We do not think it is appropriate that these matters ought to be dealt with in a way that leaves such people, who pose a risk to the community, at large. In this situation a minister should be given the opportunity with all of the political consequences of that to be able to cancel a visa. The natural justice loop is to be available, but after the visa has been cancelled and the opportunity for a person to be detained has been availed of.

This provision, for which there is a like precedent in section 128, which relates to offshore cancellations, is what we are seeking here. It was a provision that the former government thought was necessary when they were in government to deal with matters of this sort and it is the sort of provision that ought to be available to people who have entered Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been discussing in consideration in detail the issue of natural justice and the opposition's proposed amendments to ensure that the natural justice requirement does not disappear from the minister's responsibilities. There are a number of precedents and I would like to draw to the attention of the House the observations made by the now Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) himself back in August 1995. Speaking on telecommunications interception laws, he pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition, on the basis of natural justice, does have a general reluctance to support retrospective legislation . . .
That is something that this legislation does provide for in part. He quoted one of his colleagues, who is now the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), as saying:

It is a fundamental principle of our legal system that laws are made to have prospective operation and not retrospective operation. It is simply unjust and oppressive to subject citizens to a law they have no means of ascertaining simply because the law has not been conceived, drafted, debated or enacted.

Furthermore, in that same debate he went on to talk about the need for balancing the competing interests of privacy, freedom of speech and law enforcement requirements and expressed great concern that in his view there was in that particular legislation a circumstance where the courts were not going to be able to supervise the activities of those who were being authorised in relation to telecommunications interception. He also talked about the need for the safeguard of judicial oversight, the need for an independent mechanism by which these decisions would be oversighted under the legislation being proposed by the government. So I note that the minister has in the past had regard for natural justice issues, the need for a proper balance in the powers of those who are making decisions and the need to ensure that those decisions are made on a proper basis and that there are proper accountability and proper safeguards against abuse.

I also note that on that particular bill the minister urged the government to accept his amendments and pointed out that the issue would be the subject of further discussion in the Senate. I would encourage the minister on this occasion also, if he is keen to get the legislation through—and I think the legislation, by any yardstick, enhances the minister's powers dramatically and represents a significant change in this area of ministerial powers in terms of character and conduct—to reflect seriously on the opposition's amendments with a view to getting the legislation through. It was noteworthy that this morning one of the Queensland government members had expressed, in the context of the Wik debate, public concern about the government's hard line against amendments, saying that the Senate should not be disregarded in a democratic system. The member said that he was concerned about public perception that the Wik legislation was damaging the reconciliation process and that the prospect of a double dissolution was horrendous.

Just as with the Wik legislation, if the government is concerned about getting a bill through the parliament rather than the politicking of the issue and the political point scoring of the issue, I would urge the government to seriously consider the amendments. I understand that that would not happen now, but I urge it to seriously consider between here and the Senate the prospect of agreeing to the opposition's amendments with a view to getting a piece of legislation which certainly does provide the minister with enhanced powers but also maintains appropriate safeguards in relation to the issue of natural justice, in relation to the right to reasons and also in terms of making the function of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal workable when it is confronted with cases of that kind. Accordingly, the opposition will be dividing once on these amendments, and urges the minister to consider them seriously between here and the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always been prepared to con sider matters, and the shadow minister, the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson), knows that with his predecessor and him I have been and will be quite prepared to talk these matters through. I do not disagree with what the honourable member has said. He has obviously been working overtime overnight looking for quotes from me in relation to obtaining a proper balance. I think this is a proper balance. I would have been grateful if the member who seems to have the carriage of this had been listening to what I had to say and had taken up some of the points I had made, particularly in relation to the precedents that have been established when you were in office to deal with situations which are unusual.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not trying to deal with all the cases of character concern. I have indicated that the numbers of cases where I envisage such a circumstance will arise will be very rare indeed. I would hope that it would never arise. But I think a minister needs to be in a position where you receive credible information from intelligence sources about people who pose a risk to the Australian community where the disclosure of that information might well pose a risk for informants—and if you are dealing with terrorists that might very well be the case—and we have a system of law in relation to somebody of that character who gets into Australia, who actually arrives here, and you cannot cancel the visa and take that person into detention.

Let me stress that I think the balance is being achieved by giving the person the opportunity afterwards to put matters before the minister to enable a reconsideration. But, in the unusual circumstances about which I am speaking, it seems to me that it is a major risk to the Australian community to leave at large a person who we believe poses such a risk to the community, simply because there is a natural justice loop that can be exploited.

I am saying that there ought to be a proper balance. I am not running away from those sorts of comments that I have made in the past or my own record in relation to those matters. A proper balance is posed by allowing for reconsideration by the minister afterwards, when the matter can still be addressed if there is reasonable information that can be put that would satisfy the minister that this person is not the person that our intelligence information suggests he or she is. That is the situation.

I make the point that, if you go back to the provisions in section 128, those were exactly the arrangements that you put in place several years ago, in 1992, in legislation for offshore situations. What we are seeking to deal with here is an onshore situation. Let us understand it. Offshore, the person is not here to pose the risk to the community. Onshore, the same person and the same circumstances can pose a risk, and we have to leave them at large. That is what we want to address. We can come back and look at the matter afterwards, and that is proposed in the legislation. That is the balance, and I think it is the balance that you ought to assume. I am quite happy to talk about it, but I would hope that on these matters you might be persuaded that provisions of this sort are not unreasonable in all the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: That the amendments (Mr Martin Ferguson's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Ruddock)—by leave—read a third time.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (YOUTH ALLOWANCE) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Ruddock:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Latham moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) condemns the Government for:
(a) withdrawing support for 18 to 20 year olds in families with incomes as low as $23,400 per annum; and
(b) abolishing payments for 16 and 17 year olds while also slashing education funding, labour market assistance and job opportunities; and

(2) calls on the Government to introduce education and training opportunities so that every young Australian has access to the education and skills needed for full participation in the workplace and society".

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted I was talking about the need for schools to be attractive to students and parents. I had mentioned some retention figures for years 10 to 12 in the five high schools in Mount Druitt, in my electorate. I thought I would read into the Hansard some more retention rates, bearing in mind that the New South Wales state average is 66 per cent. Bidwill is the best, with 50.4 per cent; Dunheved 30.3 per cent; Mount Druitt 37.6 per cent; Shalvey 38.9 per cent; and Whalan 45.3 per cent. If there is a difference between the government and the opposition on this issue of youth allowance, it is from our perspective that the Labor Party is always prepared to recognise the human dimension and sees investing in education, training and job readiness as being in the national interest, not only best for the individual person but best for the nation.

BREAK.PARA: In my part of the world in particular, and I suspect in others, we have a problem with young males who do not see schooling as being relevant to their needs. That is why we urgently need to change and why I am advocating a vocational component, TAFE courses, in the proposed new senior high school for Mount Druitt. In passing I should mention a Sydney Morning Herald article by the New South Wales Teachers Federation, who say that they believe that the states should do away with the specialist high schools, that is, the elite high schools, the technology high schools and the senior high schools. I disagree with their position. At the end of the day we want to do two things: firstly, provide choice for students and their parents—and, once having tasted choice, I do not think you can go back—and, secondly, make the public sector attractive and competitive. St Mary's Senior High School is reversing the drift from public to private education. I believe that the new senior high school at the Nirimba educational precinct, to be opened in 1999, and the senior high school for Mount Druitt with feeder junior schools will do the same.

I have not spoken about the unemployed 18- to 20-year-olds who will now be subjected to a parental means test. Government members have no consideration, when they run around proudly touting how supportive of families they are, of the impact this measure will have on families. The illustration I like to give, which is applicable in my own electorate and in others, is what the Department of Housing does when a family has a son or a daughter in the workplace. As soon as that happens, the rent they pay is increased to take into account the earnings of the children. The economic rationalists—although this was a measure introduced into my own state by a Labor minister, Frank Walker—would say: `That is fair enough. Why shouldn't that be the case? This reflects a capacity to pay.'

But this measure presents a lot of problems for families. The parents become responsible for the payment of the rent. The children—or, I should say, young adults—incur the liability but do not necessarily pass the money on to their parents. One of the net effects of this brilliant measure is to see people being forced out of home. It leads directly to an early, if you like, not so much breakdown of the family but a shifting out of the siblings. Much as I recognise that economic rationalists will feel particularly keen about that measure, I particularly object to it because of its implications for families.

I have talked about a situation where 18- to 20-year-olds are earning money, but what happens when they are unemployed and, because of a parental means test, are in receipt of no money at all? A lot has been said on our side of the House about these people being the same people who have a right to vote—as they should—to decide who should govern the country, and the same people who can be conscripted in case of a national emergency. But we are saying that, notwithstanding the fact that they get all these rights of citizenship, they should not get unemployment benefits and they are insufficiently mature to be anything other than dependent on their parents. What is that going to be like for family lives?

Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I know that this will have absolutely minimal impact in the leafy suburbs of the North Shore or, indeed, the eastern suburbs, but in western Sydney it is going to provide additional hardships. It is going to mean that young people are going to be more dependent on their parents than they may already have been at a time when their peer group is out there earning and spending money, as is the wont of young people. These will in fact be second‐class Australians. The difference, again, between the government and the Labor Party comes with compulsion. The conservatives say, `We champion individual freedom; we champion the rights of the individual.'

TALK.START.PARA: —We do too.

—And you do too. When it comes to the youth allowance, we are into compulsion. We force young people—16‐ to 17‐year‐olds—who may not necessarily see any relevance in schooling, to go back to school. We give them no choice, as otherwise we take their youth allowance away from them. If they happen to be 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds and unemployed, we say, `You're going to have to go through a parental means test and, if you don't survive that, you get nothing.' We say that skilling people, getting people on the education escalator, is a marvellous thing; we're all for it. But we do not believe in compulsion. We believe in encouraging people via reciprocal obligations. I think that is the starkest contrast between the government members and the Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: I sincerely hope that all the 16‐ to 17‐year‐olds in my electorate and in other electorates in the western suburbs of Sydney understand only too well what is being done to them by this government. I hope those 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds who are unemployed—the group of people with the highest unemployment in Australia: Australia's youth—understand what the government is trying to do to them. The government is not increasing the opportunities for more skills; it is actually cutting back on significant programs, whether they are labour market programs or whether they are student at risk programs. Above all else, we on this side of the House believe that it is entirely appropriate to have public investment; that is, governments recognising the worth of individuals and being prepared to invest in their future and thus guaranteeing Australia's future.

We certainly do not believe that the answer to our economic problems is this compulsion that the government is into or cutting back investment the way the government has in the youth of Australia. We want to see more of it. We do not believe that cutting wages—an across‐the‐board 10 per cent or 15 per cent cut in wages—is somehow marvellous public policy. We believe the future of our nation is in having an even more highly skilled work force, a more highly involved work force and, indeed, having an export culture in this country.

No doubt this bill, although we will divide on it, will get carried. I think it is a tragedy for young people; I think it is rendering young people as second‐class citizens in their own country. It is relying on brute force of government rather than attracting young people into further education or into further training—whether that is with the encouragement of mutual obligations that were a feature of the One Nation policy. The Labor Party stands for reducing unemployment to five per cent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker; it is good to see you in the chair.
—Don't suck up to the Deputy Speaker.

—It is always a pleasure to follow the member for Chifley. I know that his comment was meant in the spirit of the debate, but I do, unfortunately, find some disagreement with the member for Chifley in relation to what he identifies as a problem which he does not wish to address in reality. He is saying that the Labor Party stands for a target of five per cent unemployment. At the same time, to achieve that target, one needs to redirect attention to the private sector and, to do that, one needs to demand a whole of government attitude to it and not focus on one side of the line—that is, the public expenditure side—without looking at the fact that that money has got to come from somewhere. It will come only from a vibrant economy that permits the distribution of those funds to those in need, and those in need are a key and crucial element of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The youth allowance is an income support payment to around 560,000 people, including students and those looking for work. It replaces five existing payments, including Austudy, the youth training allowance, the newstart allowance and the sickness allowance for under‐21-year-olds. The Austudy allowance is for under‐25-year-olds. The youth allowance will be introduced on 1 July 1998. The reason for it is that the government is proposing to help young people make key decisions about education, training and employment and make income support arrangements simpler and more flexible.

The youth allowance is also designed to change the culture—this is what I was going to focus on in my few remarks—of handout. I am referring to the culture that at 15 years of age you can walk down to the CES and expect a handout from there on, never mind the necessity to engage in training, never mind the necessity to look to a greater educa tional perspective, but rather a culture that there is something there from age 15.

To change that culture, I think we also need to set examples at higher levels. It is no good just saying that this is a situation that does need changing. At the same time we have the youth of Australia saying, `Politicians, judges and what have you are also getting a slice of the cake and that is not fair.' I refer, for example, to double dipping. I think it is reprehensible that anyone in public life can receive a pension from the Crown and yet be quite able bodied and go out and work in a full-time job.

Young people are being asked to make sacrifices and to get out there and look for work. Yet they come back to us and say, `Just a minute, you're getting a pension or retired judges are getting pensions and then going out and doing royal commissions and inquiries.' We have seen a plethora of those in Queensland with the CJC. It really does strike a chord in the community. It is unacceptable and it is time that we, as people who should be setting an example, looked at these areas. When you leave public life, if you are an ex‐judge, ex-public servant or what have you, you should not be allowed to double dip. Once you start working again, you should not be allowed to get that pension. I think that is something that we really have to look at very seriously if we are to set an example of expenditure restraint in these other areas. That is part of the total culture and total flavour of the thing. That goes to a lot of areas, as I have mentioned before. It is something that we have to look at.

Also as part of the culture we have to change—I think this bill does go part of the way but we have a lot further to go—we have to change the disturbing paradox we have, which is that if you are hardworking and looking for work, you are going to be hit hard because you are doing well, but if you decide to slip around the edges and be indolent, less than thrifty, avoid responsibilities and so forth, you are going to be rewarded. That is one of the problems that we have in society. More and more, the complaints that come through to my office are from people who are working very hard and who have, for exam ple, just gone over that little threshold level for any particular situation.

Recently, for example, a constituent rang up in relation to the so-called baby bonus. I thought that people collected that bonus irrespective of means. This particular couple were both working. They were not drawing a huge income jointly but it was over the amount to qualify for the so‐called baby bonus. The constituent pointed out to my office that there was never any statement to the effect that they would not be eligible for it. They were not complaining about the fact of non-eligibility but they were generally raising something that is commonly raised—that is, hard workers are the ones who are more likely to pay for indolence. It is that conundrum that we really have to deal with in the culture in this country. It is something that is extremely difficult.

Recently I received a letter from a constituent from Ferny Hills. It was not a particularly favourable pro‐government letter by any means. I will refer to it because it does touch on some of these matters which I think are necessary to touch on. The constituent wrote:

The Coalition's supposed non-interventionist stance is both selectively applied and poorly conceived. The fact is that levels of social, business, industry and rural welfare are higher than ever and exist in direct opposition to this Government's ideology. Personally I am not in favour of any form of welfare whatsoever as it gives rise to a false economy with no real foundation, neither am I in favour of tax avoidance whether by individuals or by multi‐nationals. Welfare recipients should be required to either work for benefits or repay them when work is obtained and scrap the rest. Women should be paid to rear children in a family context only. Not new or terribly popular ideas I'm sure.

Some of those remarks struck a chord with me. I think we all have to realise in this place that there is a limit to the welfare dollar and there is a limit to squeezing those people who are working hard, yet again for them to be told, `Well, you're going to miss out.' We do do this. Unfortunately, we do this across a range of areas. In this particular area we are doing it to a group of people with parental incomes over $41,000 who have children at home aged between 18 and 20. This is a group that we will be targeting with this measure.

I understand that these measures are necessary but, by the same token, it is important to look at that culture and how those people see themselves as being targeted. I am not saying that it is the correct way to look at it, but that is the way they see it—for their thrift, energy and hard work, they are being targeted and kicked yet again. That is what they are saying to me.

It is a message we must heed. We cannot ignore the number of people out there who have worked hard all their lives. A gentleman recently wrote to me and said that he had worked with the PMG for 46 years. In that time, he achieved for himself a self‐funded situation. He had just been a worker in the PMG; he did not have a high flying job, as I understand it. At the end of his 46 years he received his full superannuation pension which he banked every fortnight into a joint account. But he said that this financial year he is going to have to pay tax because the very fact that he put that into a joint account, earning interest of $5.97—divided by two, because it was put into a joint account—meant that he would have to pay tax on that. That is bureaucratic stupidity, in my view. It is again an example of that group of people who have done the right thing being picked at in this way. We have to bear those things in mind.

I had a youth meeting in my electorate office recently, which was very interesting because of the range of views that came across. Many people who were there discussed the proposed youth allowance, and many of them discussed the difficulties they had obtaining part‐time work. There was a range of views. One contributor to the discussion said that she can point to two or three jobs `just like that' when told by others in the group that there was no work for students. Obviously there are a range of views out there, including that work can be found if you look for it.

It is right for the government to encourage people to look for part‐time work when they are studying. There are no free lunches any more. It is important to impart that to the community: the free lunch regime is finished. We have to impart that work ethic to the community. That does not mean by the same token that we can be heartless about it, but I believe that it is necessary to have the sorts of discussions I have had in the electorate to illustrate the range of views one way and the other.

The importance of that discussion was that in a networking sense a number of young people were able to identify areas where perhaps there were jobs that they had not accessed before. That was a very useful aspect of it. But, as a part of all this, it is true that the previous government cultivated this culture to a degree for self‐interest reasons. There were substantial votes from a section of the community which became welfare dependent. Welfare was never intended to be a dependency thing; it was always intended to be a short‐term situation. Unfortunately, over time many people have become dependent on it, and that is not a good thing.

This can flow through into other areas. I refer to the homeless youth allowance. Recently a youth worker said on a Brisbane radio station that more than half of those that he encountered on the streets preferred to be there. When asked why, he said it was because there was no discipline; they do not have the discipline of home. I say this about this sort of thing, the homeless youth allowance in particular: we have heard the reason being given for this allowance is abuse, but that is a ubiquitous word and I have a lot of trouble with the allowance. It should be available only in the most extreme circumstances and then on proof that the abuse is real and continuing, not imagined—we have heard about the tragedy of the Skye Walton case in Western Australia.

I also put this to the House: why is the responsibility for this allowance shifted to the taxpayer? If parents really abuse their children, they ought to be the ones who are responsible. By behaving in that anti‐social, wrong way, they ought not be able to abuse the system and have their responsibilities shifted to the Australian taxpayer. The responsibility should stay with the abusers, if the abusers are real and if there has been proof.

BREAK.PARA: I have had many examples of this in my own electorate. I do have concern that there are young people who have been abused but, by the same token, there are people who are working the system. One tragic example of that came to my attention late last year when I attended a meeting in my electorate of a group called Tuff Love. In this particular group a lady told me a horrendous story. Her daughter basically would not conform to the rules of home. She left home, went to the Department of Social Security and made allegations of serious sexual interference by her mother.

Twelve months later, the girl returned home after living on the streets and in various other places, and living with her boyfriend somewhere—and getting this allowance. She came back and apologised to her mother for all the hurt that she had caused but, at the same time, the taxpayers of Australia picked up the tab for that sort of behaviour. That is unacceptable; the person concerned should have a responsibility. As my constituent said in that letter to me earlier, there should be a requirement to pay back in those circumstances and in other circumstances where the system is being rorted.

It is important to change that culture. Efforts have been made in the United States to change welfare. Changes have been directed at ensuring that welfare is limited to relief—welfare for a term, not dependency. Very significantly, there was an article in the Financial Review some months ago about the successes and the great strides that have been made in some states in America by having caps on welfare. There is a limited time that you can be on supporting parent pension, for example. It is two years in one particular state, but I cannot recall which one.

These systems are working. They send messages out that there is not a free and open slather to live the way you want and the taxpayer picks up the tab, that responsibility needs to be put into this equation. The message coming through in America was that the programs that had been started, which had been going for about 18 months, have done tremendous things. In fact, there was a drop in welfare of something like 24 per cent across the board in the states of the US that had adopted these measures. It is important to look ahead. I do not at all subscribe to following everything that the United States does. But I do believe that it is necessary to look ahead with these things and to take a realistic view.

As I said before, this problem of punishing those who are thrifty and rewarding those who are indolent is a culture that has to change. It flows through into so many areas. It flows into the child support area. Abuses of that system are coming to the fore constantly. Yet again, people who have been the innocent party are finding themselves being punished by the state organised system.

It is important that the measure is brought in, and I urge the House to pass it. I ask all of us to reflect on the need for cultural change in these areas and on the need to take into account the hard workers who are concerned that yet again they will be punished for their hard work.

There has to be a balance in all of this. We have to send messages that cover fairly both the needs of parents—their need to be fairly treated in a taxation sense—and the needs of their children, whom they are trying to put through education and help into training, and so forth. Overall it is a good package, but obviously there is a need to go further in time with these sorts of measures. I urge that the House go down that track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading amendment moved by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). In doing so, I indicate that the intent of the Australian Labor Party clearly is to support moves to simplify income support arrangements, including for young people. We are very much opposed to the short‐sighted decision of this government to withdraw income support from needy people and needy communities.

SPEECH.PARA: We certainly do not support unfair action against some of the most needy people in the Australian community. This is not just about questions of income support; we also regard this as a fairly fundamental debate about equality of opportunity in life and government responsibility.

BREAK.PARA: The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) has said several times in this place that the removal of benefits to 16- and 17-year-olds sends a clear message to them. If anything, it is a continuation of a message from this government that the victims are to blame, rather than there being a willingness by this government to accept some responsibility to intervene and to create a sense of equality of opportunity in life.

The intent of the government, in their terminology, is to send a message that the best way to get a job is to stay at school. This statement implies that 16- and 17-year-olds who leave school early do so as a deliberate, considered and rational choice to gain short-term dollars. How reality is far from the view of this government.

That approach flies in the face of the reality, demonstrated by research, that these people leave school early for other reasons. They leave, for example, because of emotional or family difficulties, for reasons of school disadvantage, or because they are not suited to the school environment. The reasons they leave school early are the very reasons they need extra support.

It should not be a decision by government to actually withdraw support, but perhaps more importantly there should be a requirement by government to consider how they can give more support to these disadvantaged people—members of disadvantaged families and members of disadvantaged communities.

That additional support ought to include income support rather than the extra pressure that this government is now placing on individuals in the Australian community who need a helping hand. They do not need handouts but a helping hand to give them encouragement to stay at school and fulfil their capacity. In doing so, it will create better opportunities not just for them and their families but also for the nation at large.

Removal of benefits will not address the causes of the problem at hand. That is what we ought to be debating today—the causes of the problem at hand and how we as a national parliament can seek to overcome some of those causes, rather than blaming the victims of those causes of disadvantage. I suggest that many people forced off unemployment payments are likely to turn to crime and other sources of income rather than go back into the classroom.

That is what the Australian community ought to be concerned about today: what is potentially the end result of the withdrawal of this assistance, as suggested by the bill before the House today? It is no good blaming the victims of the disappearance of entry level jobs for the fact that these jobs no longer exist, and that is the root cause of some of the problems that currently confront young people in the Australian community today. Twenty or 30 years ago, there were entry level jobs to take up in a variety of occupations in both the public and the private sector and those young people were potentially and, as history shows, exceptionally good workers. They fulfilled the requirements of their employer and also fulfilled the expectations of the Australian community—workers that were willing to put in often not for a higher return when it came to access to decent wages and conditions of employment but people who were satisfied with the employment opportunity that they were given and satisfied with the wages and conditions and the additional assistance given to low income people in the Australian community by successive governments.

The real issue today is not how we withdraw benefits from those people but how we go about creating additional employment opportunities, especially entry level jobs, for those people in the future. It is a fact, whether people like it or not, that not every young person currently has the capacity for or is suited to staying on at school for years 11 and 12. Some of us might like to think that would be an ideal situation for the Australian community to achieve, but the facts are that it will never be achieved. It is pie in the sky for a variety of reasons and, irrespective of our ideals or objectives in life, we have to face up to the fact that, in a community so complex as the Australian community, the responsibility of government is to create a variety of opportunities to suit the needs and aspirations of a variety of people in that community.

I therefore refer to the fact that many young people need, for example, counselling support from qualified psychologists. Properly equipped programs need to be available in and through the school to address these people's family and emotional difficulties and to encourage them to remain at school. Young people need proper work oriented careers education when they are at school, not the withdrawal of benefits; they need expanded work experience opportunities while they are at school. In that context, the type of young person that I am actually talking about is, unfortunately, not the type of person that actually gets those part‐time or casual employment opportunities at their McDonald's—the type of fast‐food activities that the current minister for employment is consumed with.

The reality is that the kids who are going to lose benefits as a result of this bill are the kids that are doing it tough: the kids from disadvantaged homes, the kids from disadvantaged schools, the kids from disadvantaged suburbs, the kids from disadvantaged regions, the people who do not expect the casual and the part‐time employment opportunities that are not normally available to them. It is therefore the responsibility of government to actually create better opportunities for those young people, and that is what the debate today is about. Those young people actually need expanded work experience opportunities while they are at school. They need, for example, expanded school to work transition programs which create pathways for them to enter the work force. They need the expansion of existing programs to occur along the lines of the jobs pathway guarantee program, which was introduced by the Labor Party in government in 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—What it is really about—and I note that some on the other side laugh at that suggestion—is a real reciprocal obligation, not the Howard government's one-sided, narrow‐minded, mean‐fisted concept of blame the victim, which is so much part and parcel of the approach of government in this House to the needs of disadvantaged people in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The jobs pathway program was piloted in schools located in the regions of highest youth unemployment and was earmarked for expansion prior to the last election. What do we get from this government? We get Green Corps. Talk about assisting young disadvantaged people! It is interesting to note that the majority of people who have had access to Green Corps to date have come from the better communities. The majority have either had employment or have just finished studies. The real disadvantaged are offered by this government work for the dole without a real reciprocal obligation and without a two‐way approach: the government offering resources in return for individuals fronting up to their responsibilities.

The Howard government has revamped this program as the jobs pathway program and has expanded it slightly. At least it is to be commended for that. However, the funding increase in the other school to work funding initiatives undertaken by the Howard government has been completely negated by other actions of the Howard government such as, for example, chopping 117,000 places in labour market programs for young people and the decline in case management for young unemployed under the new, chaotic employment services market.

Early school leaving, I suggest, is intimately connected with homelessness amongst young people. Therefore the level of resources for the job placement, employment and training program—which aims to help young people overcome problems preventing them from maintaining stable accommodation and entering into full‐time education, training and employment—must be considered as part of this debate. What was formerly called the young homeless allowance, and other relevant social security payments, must also be considered. General community back‐up measures to tackle the underlying problems of youth homelessness and family breakdown should also be part of the debate.

The approach of giving out McDonald's hamburger training certificates to secondary students who work part time is not the solution. Labor clearly supports properly designated vocational links to schools. We support the part‐time work currently done by many secondary students counting towards appropriate qualifications, but we must be clear that there are several clearly distinct groups among the young unemployed. I go, for example, to the early school leavers looking for full‐time jobs who are most at risk of not making a successful transition to economic independence. I also refer to the young people still at school doing part‐time jobs who have much better prospects. These difficult issues have got to be raised in a debate such as this. You cannot sweep them under the carpet and pretend that they do not exist.

The problem for the more at‐risk groups is that apprenticeships, contrary to what the minister would have you believe, are rapidly falling in number under the Howard government. They declined by more than 2,000 in the last year for which figures are available. This figure is consistently drawn out in Senate estimates. That drop of 2,000 in apprenticeships comes at a time of emerging skill shortages in a variety of sectors—not just the manufacturing sector but also the services sector across Australia. So much for this government's commitment and ability to create additional apprenticeship opportunities in Australia.

On that note, I would also refer to a recent survey which shows, unfortunately, that, because of the poor state of the economy and lack of government incentives, only one in five companies now plans to increase its apprenticeship numbers. The new minister has cut funds for apprenticeships and wasted money on promoting himself. That was even revealed in Senate estimates last week. There was money available to put glossy photos of the minister in promotional material handed out by the department while the actual amount of money for vocational education and training was cut in the last 20 months in successive Howard government budgets.

That is what it is about: the promotion of the minister. Funds were cut for vocational education and training while the minister wasted hard‐earned taxpayers' money on putting glossy photos of himself in government and departmental information kits. So much for this minister's priorities.

At the same time, skill shortages need to be filled and young unemployed Australians desperately want to be properly trained to fill them. In the first two Howard budgets $270 million has been cut from vocational education and training. The rate of growth in traineeships has also dramatically slowed. Labor will boost investment in apprenticeships and traineeships to give quality skills training to those who leave school early and to enhance their future job prospects. We will also commit ourselves to reversing the neglect into which the TAFE institutes are currently falling. We will promote TAFE as just as good an option as university for young people.

For a positive approach to government job creation, Labor will also help make up for this government's removal of the career path which so many young people sought to pursue in the Australian Public Service. A positive approach to get all young people into education, training or work will be pursued, consistent with the active programs of assistance to unemployed Australians previously implemented under Working Nation and based on the real principle of reciprocal obligation, which is entirely different to the watered down, one‐sided approach of mutual obligation which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is so much identified with.

In the debate on this Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill it is important that we put the number of 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who now leave school early into the proper context. In March 1983 the Labor government inherited from the then Treasurer, who is now the Prime Minister, 158,000 young unemployed people. That is 158,000 teenagers looking for full‐time work, the highest number ever in the history of this great nation.

Interestingly, when Labor left office in March last year, that figure had been cut to 91,400, due largely to a massive rise in secondary school retention rates. Only four in 10 young people stayed on at school to year 12 at the time the Prime Minister was Treasurer in 1983. By the end of the 13 years of Labor in March of last year more than seven in 10 did so.

This was partly because of the massive expansion of higher education places under Labor. It was also partly because of the promotion of technical and further education as a viable alternative for those who do not want to go to university. It is a fact of life that not everyone wants to go to university. There is a place in the Australian community for TAFE on an equal footing with university education.

It was also partly a response to the disappearance of jobs for young people, especially those entry level jobs. The rise in school retention rates to unprecedented levels reflected a recognition by these students that they needed to complete their schooling to improve their chances of getting a job. That is what it was all about—the structure of work has changed in Australia. Education and training is the key to the best employment opportunity in the future.

Those who still leave school early in these times of reduced job opportunities for the young are the most at risk of becoming young unemployed people. They are young people for whom socio‐economic, family or personal circumstances have overridden what, in an ideal world, would, rationally, be in their self‐interest—to stay at school.

One more positive, innovative way to help meet the needs of this group is for an expansion of the mentor scheme. These emerging programs enable older Australians to pass on the benefits of their accumulated wisdom and experience to young people. I commit myself as the minister to expanding and consolidating such an approach to assisting young people.

This bill also proposes to means test the unemployment payments of 18‐ to 21‐year‐olds. The intention is to reduce unemployment payments for 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds who live at home, from the moment their parents' combined income rises above—wait for it—the very low level of $23,400. You are hardly going to make a fortune as a family on $23,400 a year, and yet you are now expected to accept that your children are not independent. The bill also proposes to cut the 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds off payment altogether if they live at home with parents whose income amounts to the modest figure of $41,000.

This means‐testing measure will hit many low and middle income families very hard. It disregards the fact that in working class families kids are expected and need to contribute to the household income. It contradicts the legal age of independence for young people being 18. You can vote and fight for the country but you cannot be classed as independent of your parents at the age of 18 by the Howard government. That is, in fact, the real age at which many young people become economically independent. Like so much of Dr Kemp's handiwork, this bill is more about diddling and fixing the youth unemployment figures than it is about helping out with youth unemployment.

Cabinet received a submission from the department outlining the positive measures it needed to take to tackle the problems of early school leavers and youth unemployment. They were the same kind of positive measures I put forward today. This government chose to ignore those positive proposals, independently developed and assessed by the department, and instead tried to push more young people into poverty and despair. That is what this is really about: poverty and despair for young people and their families and difficulties at schools and in disadvantaged suburbs.

I support the second reading amendment moved by the member for Werriwa. The path the government has chosen so far as we are concerned is wrong. We urge an alternative path. We accept there is a problem, but the alternative path is one based on real reciprocal obligation—a real partnership between the community and the government; a real partnership between the community and the young unemployed; a real partnership between the government, the community, the young unemployed and their families—not finger pointing and blaming the victim as this bill seeks to do, but a government actually willing to assist by intervening, going to those homes, schools and suburbs and saying, `We accept there are real problems. Withdrawing benefits is not the solution. It is about the role of government in providing decent school opportunities.' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is as much of a relief to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as it is to me to hear the end of the vitriol, selective recall of history and romanticisation of the things Labor thought it might have done if only it had a fourteenth year in government. The shadow minister seeks to pat himself on the back for things this government has actually done, that this government has put in place and the programs it has initiated, while he seeks to have a revisionist historian look, with a touch of romance sprinkled on top, at the things the Labor Party did.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately, this government is doing things that are needed to address the sorts of things the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) spoke of. For about 18½ minutes he spoke of things unrelated to this bill and things unrelated to the financial support available to young people in this country. He ranted and raved about his hibernation‐like thoughts on what has been going on in the world, because he has missed a lot of things that this government has actually done.

The member for Batman tried to talk up the crisis that is occurring for disadvantaged people in this country and kids that come from disadvantaged schools. For the member for Batman's interest, I am a person who came from a disadvantaged school and I can let him know the sorts of things that are actually being done by this government not to perpetuate the situation of the disadvantaged, but to try and avoid or prevent it and try to encourage young people to think about their futures and look beyond what Labor had left behind.

Under that system you actually got more money for being on the dole. You were financially better off by not investing in your future, not looking for work, not training and not thinking beyond what money you might want to spend in the pinball parlour this week. You were better off if you were not doing those things. If you thought, `I will sit back and receive the income support that the taxpayers in the electorate of Dunkley and the rest of the nation provide. I will not think about what it is that is in my best longer term interests.'

I do not doubt for one moment that the member for Batman feels their disadvantage in a heartfelt manner. Not only do I feel that same touch of grief about some of the people in our country who are not enjoying the opportunities that this great nation has to offer, but I actually think we should do something about it, and not just sit in here and wring our hands as the member for Batman seeks to do.

Thirteen years of Labor robbed many young people of the incentive to take up further study and to take up further training to improve their employment prospects and their prospects for future life, because you were better off not do to those things. Young people leaving school had a confusing array of different payments, but the most disturbing thing is that young people were actually financially better off to go on the dole rather than invest in their future.

We are seeking to change that. Through this youth allowance package before the parliament we are introducing a fairer system of income support for all Australians. It is one that does not discriminate against people who are investing in their future, which is the system we inherited from the Labor Party. It is a system that does not discriminate against those who are unemployed or in education or training. It levels out those arrangements, so that young people will be encouraged to think about their futures and take part in the sorts of opportunities this government is providing for young people and will actually invest in a longer term advantage to them, rather than—as the member for Batman seems to prefer—leave them in a situation of disadvantage and not do anything actively or not encourage them to do anything actively to do anything about it.

The member for Batman talks about the lack of entry level jobs in this country. And what is his solution? To create more unskilled positions for unskilled people in an unskilled economy. What sort of solution is that? That is a solution taking us down the path of economic misery and lost opportunities for this country, but that is the member for Batman's solution. While we are trying to help create skilled jobs and trying to support young people to develop the skills to take on those jobs, the member for Batman is saying, `No. Let's not skill anybody. Let's just create a low‐skill economy with low wages, low opportunity and low competitiveness so the rest of the world walks over us and we all become disadvantaged.' What a wonderful solution!

He failed to mention—and I would be interested to know what his reaction is to this—whether Labor still wants to get away from and abolish junior pay rates. One thing was missed by young people throughout this country when we were having the workplace relations debate. There was an important provision in that bill and that bill—which is now law—said, `We will continue to provide for junior wages in this country.' Labor had junior wages disappearing.

Young people looking for a start in life without work experience and the competencies and skills employers were looking for in areas such as the retail sector were going to be asking for the same rate of pay as seasoned sales personnel who had been in that business and on the shop floor making a productive contribution to businesses for perhaps decades. Labor said, `We will feel good about this. We will play the cruelest trick on young people by denying them access to a junior wage.' It is the cruelest trick because that denies many young people an opportunity to get a start in life.

In the retail sector alone hundreds of thousands of young people would have lost their jobs had this government not understood the cruel hoax those opposite—and those that the member for Batman seeks to romanticise and rejoice—were trying to deny hundreds of thousands of young people a start in life because they thought we would rule out junior wage rates. That is the cruelest hoax.

The rest of what the member for Batman had to say was celebrating what this government is doing. The package before the parliament today is part of a broad‐ranged, multifaceted strategy to give new hope and opportunity to young people. The member for Batman talks about jobs pathways. This government is doing something about jobs pathways. In the electorate of that I represent the Peninsula Institute of TAFE is working with secondary colleges right throughout my electorate to help people make that transition from school to work and to aid them, assist them and support them to take advantage of the opportunities that are there. That is being done. That is happening.

The member for Batman is now retrospectively trying to create the impression that he likes vocational education. Yet he is part of a side of politics that for 13 years said, `If you are not in a university you do not count. If your skills are vocationally based, we will make it as hard as we possibly can for employers to give you a start in life. But if you go to university we will celebrate that and we will keep pouring bucket loads of money into the higher education sector, primarily the university sector.' Meanwhile, vocational education drifted away and we ended up with the lowest rate of apprenticeships and trade qualified people in this country since the war. And he stands up and talks about creating a low‐skilled economy as the answer for young people. You ought to be ashamed of yourself. That is absolutely the last thing young people in this country want: a low‐skill economy where they are not given the opportunity to develop the skills. That is your answer? That is the great Labor Party solution to a problem it turned its back on? What a pathetic contribution.

The only new idea the member for Batman had to offer was a mentoring scheme. I would support him on that. There are an enormous number of mature age people with great skills in the work force who could offer support for young people. I celebrate that contribution, member for Batman. It is a good idea. It is an idea that Lions Clubs in my electorate have been putting in place for almost a decade. Congratulations for catching on; the hibernation must have ended.

The proposition before the parliament today is about designing a system that makes investing in your future more attractive for young people. From 1 July next year, the youth allowance will replace unemployment benefits, Austudy, Abstudy, traineeships, wage top‐ups—I think 13 different payments are being folded into five so you can actually find your way around them. This is so there is no discrimination against people investing in their future. It is intended to ease the transition from study, training and searching for employment, and to recognise that there is some overlap between these different categories of people. It is part of a comprehensive plan for young people. Since the government was elected 18 months ago, we have put in place a plan. This is part of that plan.

I have spoken on other parts of the plan in terms of developing literacy skills so people can read and write. Without those core competencies, how can you participate in the opportunities the government is making available? They are core life skills but, again, the member for Batman did not mention those because Labor turned their back on that. That is why we are doing something about it. He runs down programs like Green Corps, where young people can gain a work ethic, where they can participate in projects within their community, be recognised for that extra effort and get a stipend at the end of it to help them go on to further education studies. He runs that down too. People in my electorate on the Seaford foreshore think it is a wonderful project, and so does the local community.

We have a work for the dole program that Labor hated—then they changed their mind. They must have checked the polls or something. They take a poll driven approach over there—new Labor. It is not new Labor, it is old Labor with a face job and a change of hair colour. They said they hated work for the dole, then they went with it. Why? Why is work for the dole right? Many young people, sadly, come from households where their parents have not worked for many years. You do not pick up a work ethic by osmosis. You need the opportunity to work in a workplace with other people to understand what commitment and contribution to a team are about, working in team areas and getting up on mornings when you do not feel like it, which many of us do every day of our lives. Work for the dole is giving people an opportunity to gain that workplace experience and understanding, and to further improve their employment prospects.

Then there is the celebrated greatness of the Labor Party in promoting higher education. We have created more places in higher education. More people enrolled in universities this year than ever before. More money is being spent in universities than ever before. More TAFE places are available than ever before. And the minister is working with state governments to widen that even further. That is part of a comprehensive plan to make sure there are real opportunities there. This bill is part of that package.

The member for Batman talked about the disadvantaged people and how this is going to discriminate against them. He obviously has not read the bill. He obviously has not understood the things this government has been doing since it was elected 18 months ago. We have a jobs placement, education and training program for people at risk. It operates in my electorate. The Salvation Army operate it through the Burnt Toast Cafe in Mornington. This is a half a million dollar commitment to young people who are at risk, whether they are homeless or have been abused, and where they are the most disadvantaged people in our community. Here is a program through which this government is saying, `We are here to support you in finding employment, further education or training if that is what you need, and to help you deal with some of life's circumstances or those circumstances that led you to be in this disadvantaged situation.' The member for Batman has missed that.

I mentioned work for the dole briefly. We have three projects down in my electorate: Mount Eliza regional park and the Mornington Railway Preservation Society are combining to work on a project at Moorooduc; some shoppers' guide activity—and understand that our economy is very much about the retail sector; and some work at Studio Park, Sweetwater Creek and some landscaping activities. So those opportunities are there.

The thing the member for Batman did not speak of, though, was that if you leave school at year 10 you are three times more likely to be unemployed. What are we trying to do? We are trying to encourage people to understand that and to think about what that means. The area consultative committee in my electorate was so concerned about it that they have conducted a pilot program where they grab young people out of local secondary schools and talk with them about what the real world is like. They are saying to these young people, `You may think school is a drag but if you leave at year 10 you are three times more likely to be unemployed. And if you are looking at buying, as I did when I left school, a Mazda 800 super deluxe coupe, somehow you have to pay for it. If you want to aspire to those things that every young person enjoys as they grow up through life then you need to look at how you can secure the opportunities and the means to do those things.'

They ask young people to think about what it is they have to offer an increasingly competitive workplace. This is the same workplace the member for Batman wants to throw back to an unskilled economy so unskilled people can get low‐paid, low‐satisfaction jobs. But that is not the economy we are working for; we are working for a higher skilled economy. We are supporting people in developing those skills to be a part of it.

You are three times more likely to be unemployed if you leave school at year 10. That is not something that most people think about. That is something that under Labor was rewarded; you got more money when you left school than if you stayed on to study. That is disgraceful. That is what this program is about recognising.

The Australian Council for Educational Research in its Youth profile 3 published last year shows that between the 1980s and early 1990s year 12 completion rates for girls with a father who was born in an English speaking country rose from 49.9 per cent to 59.6 per cent. For girls with fathers born in non‐English speaking nations, the figure rose from 57.8 per cent to 74.6 per cent. You are increasingly seeing an understanding in the community that staying on at school makes sense and developing your skills makes sense because we are in a skilled economy—unlike what the member for Batman wants to create: an unskilled, low paid, poor job prospects, low skilled people economy. That is not the thing we want here.

Arguably some of the relative success of independent schools is because they have understood this connection and have built it into their fabric. We have said also in our program, `Let us not discriminate against independent schools.' What is wrong with a parent deciding that the start in life their young children get, the opportunities that this produces, the teaching practice, the styles, the morality—whatever the case may be, whatever the reason may be—is in their child's best interests in an independent school? What is wrong with that? This government has understood the importance of that choice for parents and is continuing to make sure that resources are made available to them.

I am continually stressing to school students, teachers, parents and employers around the area just how important vocational options are because in the electorate I represent more than 70 per cent of people do not go on to university. That is why I commend what the government has done to open up the apprenticeship scheme to understand that the traditional trades, important as they are, are not the only game in town. We are moving into new aspects of our economy that need to be supported by skilled people.

It is this time of year that we go to valedictory dinners. I am sure that members from both sides of the House do that. You see these young people; they are magnificent, spirited, enthusiastic, intelligent, vibrant and they are looking to get on in the world. We want to make sure that people who are not academically gifted who have all of those attributes can also look forward to that opportunity. That is what this package is about. It is about saying that when you make those choices about leaving school you have to think about the future—consider the prospects for your employment down the track. People in my electorate have written to me saying that this is extraordinary. Ben Rooks of Seaford—where I grew up—wrote to me. He is 19 years old. He said:
You are currently better off not studying and bludging off the dole.
You are better off to the tune of over $150 a week by his calculations. He went on:

It is a sad situation when a young `statistic' is willing and wanting to study, to gain a degree that will arguably keep him employed for the rest of his life, only to be prevented from studying because the government wants to pay him more not to.
That is a 19‐year‐old from my electorate and I understand absolutely where he is coming from. That is why we have made these changes.

The majority report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training chaired by the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), which produced the Youth employment: A working solution report, suggested that they heard a great deal of evidence suggesting that the availability of social security benefits was perpetuating an `unemployment culture'. As Anthony Lee, a student of Nowra, New South Wales, said:
The problem is that you cannot rely on people to work 40 hours per week for $220 when they can get $200 on the dole. That is one of the major problems . . .

As a single income support payment for young Australians, whether they are in education, training, unemployed, sick or homeless, the youth allowance replaces Austudy for full‐time students up to 25 years of age, newstart, youth training and sickness allowances for people to the age of 21 and more than minimum rate family payment for secondary students aged 16 to 18.

As Centrelink's useful Internet site points out, from 1 July next year young people will find the going easier as they will no longer have to change payments when moving from the world of education to the world of employment. Eligibility criteria are relatively easy to understand. Full‐time students, trainees or job seekers over 18 are one group. People under 18 must be in full‐time education or training, unless they are in an exemption category such as being homeless or sick—the very disadvantaged people the member for Batman talked about as being left out in this package. They are not left out. As with many things he says, that is a selective recall of the facts to elaborate on a story which leaves you with a very false impression of what the government is doing. But that is what the opposition are good at—that is what the member for Batman is good at—and they make an art form of it.

Rent assistance will now be available for the first time to about 70,000 students and other young people who have to live away from home to pursue education, training or employment opportunities. Full‐time students will also have access to an `income bank' to accumulate unused fortnightly free areas of income up to a maximum of $6,000. Why? As Mr Rook pointed out in his letter to me, people work over summer. They might get a job in summer down on the sunny Mornington Peninsula, Mr Deputy Speaker—a little bit nicer than your part of the world, although you would beg to differ, I am sure.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got to be joking!

—Down my way they might choose to get summer work or work between semesters. On average the gain to students who qualify for rent assistance is estimated to be $31.30 a fortnight. It is much more for people living in remote and rural areas. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have been celebrating and sharing that greatly. I congratulate the minister on this initiative in dovetailing social security policies and the important tasks of opportunities for young people in our country. (Time expired)
—Order! As the honourable member has obviously never visited Coffs Harbour, I invite him to come and learn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) has forgotten about the rain on the Mornington Peninsula, as well. Like much of this government's legislation over the last 20 months, this Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 denies help to those who most need it. Contrary to its election promise that nobody would be worse off under a Howard government, unnecessary hardship has been imposed on the members of the very sectors of the community most in need of assistance and support. For example, older Australians are being punished by this government in a number of ways, including the withdrawal of the Commonwealth dental health program, the increase in prescription charges, the slashing of expenditure on home and community services, the change in the deeming amounts, the cuts to Australian Hearing Services and by the latest debacle over nursing homes. Aus tralian families who require child care are being punished by the reduction in the child‐care cash rebate, by the caps to access to child‐care assistance and by the abolition of subsidies for community based long day care—all of which mean greater cost for families trying to make ends meet.

SPEECH.PARA: Working people have been punished by the virtual abandonment of Australia's unique award system and other changes to industrial relations law, which have served to increase insecurity in the workplace, to make favourites of creditors and negatives of debtors, who are most of us. Young people seeking to advance themselves through education have been punished through massive cuts to tertiary education funding, by the reduction in Austudy expenditure and by changes in HECS. Those who are out of work have been punished by this government's abandonment of Labor's $1.8 billion worth of labour market programs, which provided invaluable work experience along with the opportunity to retrain for new careers. In addition, the government has cut $183 million from vocational education and training in the 1996 budget and followed it up recently with a further cut of $14.3 million from vocational and industry training and another $72 million from education and training grants to the states. What hope can young people have when the government consistently demonstrates that it has not a care in the world for their interests?

Add to this the severe cuts in schools funding by the South Australian government, resulting in school closures precisely in those areas where they are most needed. This is a direct breach of its election undertaking. These opportunities for young people vanished with the callous closure of these schools. To exacerbate the problems facing job seekers, cuts to public sector employment by both state and federal government have denied young people job opportunities in the one area where young people have traditionally got a start. Fortunately, that was acknowledged in the report by the committee chaired by the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) on employment opportunities.

BREAK.PARA: It is in this climate of continued high unemployment, a lack of any serious legislative program to assist the jobless and a pattern of legislative punishment for those who are most in need that the government has introduced into this House its Social Security Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997. This bill continues the pattern of punishing those who are most in need of assistance. It imposes real and unnecessary hardship on those 16‐ and 17‐year‐old Australians who have not finished year 12 and who are looking for work, on those 18‐ to 20‐year‐old young Australians who are unable to find a job and on their families. These are precisely the groups of young people who already have the greatest difficulty getting a start in the current market; the ones who already face the harshest barriers to participation in education, training and employment.

That is not to say that the current array of income support for young people is not in need of simplification and reform. Some aspects of this bill do deserve support, namely, the increases in rates of payment for some young people, an improved flexibility which allows young people to combine part‐time study with jobsearch and other activities, the extension of rent assistance to full‐time students who are required to live away from home for study related reasons and payment of the higher independent rate for full‐time students in de facto relationships of more than two years standing. The concept of the youth allowance, one designed to simplify the system of payments for young people, to remove disincentives for young people to continue their education and to remove inconsistencies between payments for young people and other social security payments, is not being challenged.

A simplified system is desirable. The problem is that this bill does not achieve these aims. It does nothing to reduce complexity; in fact, it introduces new complexities. For example, it introduces arrangements which exacerbate disincentives to continue education, directly contrary to its stated aims, and arrangements which are inconsistent with the provisions of the Social Security Act. But, most importantly, it fails to do anything about the most serious problem facing this country today—that of unemployment, and youth unemployment in particular. The Victorian Liberal Minister for Training recently said that the former federal Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, now the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), was more interested in his personal publicity than he was in putting young people into a job. What hope does this give young people?

The youth unemployment rate, which John Howard claimed to be his highest priority and which he promised to reduce, has in fact risen since he has been in office. Further, the number of traditional four‐year trade apprenticeships has also fallen by around 2,000. Yet this bill will withdraw income support for 16‐ and 17‐year‐old Australians who leave education without completing year 12. As a consequence, they will not qualify for any of the education labour market assistance or any other program which might assist their transition from school to the workplace. This group of young people has been cruelly abandoned by this government at the very time that it has made substantial cuts to education and labour market programs, at the very time when entry level jobs continue to disappear, particularly in the public sector at state and federal level.
