The government has made no effort to seek a solution to the problems facing these young people. It has simply decided to punish them. If the government cared about the fate of young people, it could have introduced a number of measures along with the youth allowance: for example, measures which support early intervention to prevent young people leaving education before finishing year 12, measures to improve the access or affordability of post‐school education and measures to create entry level jobs for unemployed young people, particularly in the public sector. It has done none of these, which is further evidence that the government is not serious about tackling the problem. Rather, this is a strategy to punish the victim—the unempowered young person.

This bill will force young people to remain at school in order to get an income, yet it has not provided any additional funds to schools to cope with the expected influx of 25,000 to 27,000 additional students. The extra allocation required by schools to help meet the needs of their students would not be so great, at around perhaps $140 million. It would only be a small fraction of the amount the Commonwealth spends each year on the schools program. Yet this bill provides for no additional funding at all—nil, zero. Because of this, schools will have to spread their resources more thinly and additional hardships will be placed on every student in the school system.

The only reasonable conclusion, therefore, is that this bill has been designed to have two main aims: firstly, to artificially reduce the youth unemployment rate by forcing young people to stay on at school in order to get an income and, secondly, to effectively reduce spending on schools. These, as I hope most members in this House would admit, are fairly cynical aims for nothing but political ends, and neither is in the interests of young people.

What young people need from this government is the right training and skills, and properly funded schools to deliver these. They need from the government proper work oriented careers education, expanded work experience, and expanded school to work transition programs to create opportunities for them to enter the work force. When going around to our secondary schools in this country it is quite common to find one careers adviser—and often it is the one who gets the short straw—for 1,200 students. That is just physically and totally unacceptable, and it simply cannot be met. No one person can give careers advice to 1,200 young people; it is simply not possible.

Young people need the government to reinstate and expand the students at risk program, which was specifically designed to identify and assist young people at risk of leaving school early. Young people need the government to restore the specific equity programs for disadvantaged schools, with a commitment of additional resources and specialised programs. People can argue in this place that this is not a resource argument. It is a resource argument, it has always been a resource argument and it will continue to be a resource argument in the future. Young people need the government to guarantee funding for the jobs pathway program and the facilitation of school and industry partnerships at a local level, to assist those schools most likely to be affected by the youth allowance.

Young people need the government to provide additional funding for the school education system so that it can provide customised learning opportunities to encourage students to stay on at school and find avenues into the work force. And young people need the government to make a solid investment in apprenticeships and traineeships so that they can be given quality skills training to enhance their future job prospects. Yet this bill provides none of these measures—just punishment for those young people who will find it most difficult to find a job with decent wages and a rewarding career. It is these very same young people who would benefit most from the assistance which can be provided under case management arrangements. `Case management arrangements'—doesn't it make you pull your hair out. Case management for the young unemployed has been neglected by this government under the new chaotic employment services market, and 117,000 places in labour market programs have simply been chopped.

Another aspect of this legislation which is also of concern relates to the eligibility provisions for the youth allowance—in particular, the question of when young people will be eligible for the independent rate of the allowance. The bill imposes a parental income, assets and means test for young unemployed people aged under 21, with government support for families with young people being reduced if those families' incomes amount to over $23,400 a year.

The government claims that families should support young people until they are independent. But why choose the age of 21? Young people are civilly and criminally responsible from no later than 18 years of age, the legal obligation to pay child support ceases once a child turns 18 and eligibility for the family tax initiative ceases once a child turns 18; yet unless an unemployed person under the age of 21 can demonstrate independence eligibility for payment will be determined on the basis of their parents' means. Measures in this bill make it very difficult for young people to qualify as independent, which will have the effect of reducing the level of assistance available for young unemployed people, particularly in low income families.

These are the very families already struggling to make ends meet in the wake of the government's first two budgets. The young people who leave school early are generally those from lower income areas. Why is this government blind to the needs of these young people? Is it because the government collectively has little idea of the hardships these young people face?

The minister claims that the bill sends a message to young people that to stay at school is the best way to get a job—a claim which demonstrates only that the minister has very little idea, and perhaps little care, about why some young people leave school early. The decision to leave early is not, in most cases, a deliberate, considered or even a rational choice in order to gain a wage.

Early school leaving is generally connected with family or emotional difficulties, or social disadvantage of some description. It is precisely for this reason that they need extra support, including income support, rather than the additional pressure the measures in this bill places upon them. Simply to remove their sources of income support, as this bill does, does not go to the core of the problem. It is not a genuine attempt at a solution.

Some of these young people who will be forced off unemployment payments as a result of this bill will not return to school; they may be tempted to turn to crime and other sources of income instead, with consequent undesirable results for their lives and for the community generally. We acknowledge—and everyone here in this House should acknowledge—that there are very few jobs available for unskilled teenagers and that it is therefore desirable that young people be encouraged to stay on at school as long as possible to realise the benefits of education and training.

Labor's approach to the problem is consistent with the principles of reciprocal responsi bility; that is, that young people should make the best use of the opportunities available to them in education and employment and that the government provides the public services that are required. Labor will broaden the availability and range of opportunities in education and training, particularly for teenagers.

Nobody wants young people to be on welfare—Labor, the government or the young people concerned. However, the answer to this problem is not to wind back the role of government; it is to actively seek to create new opportunities through education and training. Young people need this government to reinstate the $240 million it has cut from the funding of the TAFE system; and they need the government to provide the school system with additional funds to help schools cope with the influx of new students which this bill will cause.

The fact that these and other measures are not being taken is evidence that this bill is not designed in the interests of young school leavers but rather in the political interests of the government itself. It is a cynical attempt to hide the most serious problem this country faces—that of youth unemployment. And it will not work. It will not convince anybody.

This bill—and this is where it is essentially wrong—does not seek a solution. There is no solution sought. It is merely an attempt to cover its tracks as it withdraws. Young people deserve better than this. The government is pulling out of the fight against the very problem its leader in the lead-up to the last election described as his `No. 1 priority'. If youth unemployment was the No. 1 priority, God help us with all the rest because this government—except perhaps for its big bang on the gun laws—has been steadily going downhill ever since. People out there in the electorate are beginning to wake up. Perhaps they welcome the opportunity of a new election to make sure that a government that promised and promised and failed to deliver will get its just desserts. Other governments around the world have finished up with the same fate because they did the same thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elson, Kay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak in support of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill . Like most of the legislation that the Howard government has introduced, it is a very practical, commonsense approach to helping solve the mess left behind by the Labor Party. The previous government failed many sectors of the community—small business, older Australians and families—but none more so than the youth of Australia. Under Labor, youth unemployment reached a staggering 32.3 per cent and, worse still, in many regional areas the level was close to 50 per cent. Under Labor, apprenticeships fell to their lowest ever in 30 years. Under Labor, children were encouraged through financial incentives to leave school and go straight on the dole. Under Labor, literacy levels declined to such a low level that a recent study found that 30 per cent of all 14-year-old children cannot read and write properly—that is, 10 students in a class of 30.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to place on record my support for the stand that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) has taken to improve literacy in order to provide a better future for our children. This minister is steadfast in his determination to tackle a problem the Labor Party left in the too-hard basket for so many years. He can be assured that the many parents in Forde whom I have spoken to in the past few months wholeheartedly support him and recognise the need for national standards.

Under Labor, young Australians, along with their hopes and aspirations, were a very low priority. The saddest thing is that when Labor failed Australia's young people it failed the whole family unit. Contrary to the views of some in the Labor Party, our children do not instantly become adults the moment they celebrate their 16th birthday. The vast majority of 16-year-olds are still part of a caring family unit. That must be remembered when we are making laws in this place. It seems such a simple point, yet it is precisely the point that the Labor Party has ignored for so long.

During the 12 months leading up to the last election I was approached by so many parents in Ford con cerned and angry that their role as parents was constantly being undermined. They felt disenfranchised by the Labor system that sought to replace parents' roles with the local DSS office. It is one of the key reasons why so many traditional Labor voters changed their vote in the last election. The fact that Labor opposes the youth allowance clearly demonstrates that they have not learned from the election results. They are still not listening.

It is against this background that the coalition government has introduced the new youth allowance. This bill is about delivering a fair deal. Put simply, the youth allowance will replace five different payments with one, and 13 payment rates with just five. It simplifies income support payments for young people and removes the incentive they once had to leave school early or to choose unemployment over education and training. Under the youth allowance, young unemployed people aged 18 to 20 will be subject to a parental means test and treated the same way as full-time students. This arrangement gives parents back the responsibility for their children, which I will talk a little more about later. We give them back this responsibility but we remain flexible so that those people who are disadvantaged, married or parents themselves are not affected.

Under the youth allowance, payments to young people under 18 years of age who have to live away from home will be increased, and rent allowance assistance will be extended to students. These measures would particularly benefit those from rural areas. The education leaver waiting period will be abolished, ensuring that young people in lower income families are not left without support for up to three months after they leave school. There are exemptions to the parental means test. In fact, this legislation widens eligibility criteria for independence to make it more realistic and special safety net criteria also ensures that young people over the age of 18 with work force experience will not be disadvantaged.

That is the point of this bill. It is fair and it reflects our commonsense approach to government. Those opposite rant and rave about equality and talk up a scare campaign on this, just as they have done on our nursing home proposals. They have a lot to answer for, given that the misinformation and blatant lies that they spread are causing unnecessary concern to many thousands of older Australians and their families. It is a terrible way to run opposition—if you have no talent, use the vulnerable in our society. While they talk in shrill tones of `cuts', the changes to the youth allowance are not saving measures at all. We are not cutting the overall budget on this. In the first year additional programs costs alone are expected to be around $25 million. We are ensuring that the system is fairer, that it targets those who need it and, most importantly, that it is geared to truly benefit young people in the long term.

I am not talking about the benefits of a milkshake and movie; I am talking about education and training that will lead to jobs. I am also talking about allowing parents to have a greater role in assisting their children, rather than leading those children to believe that the government owes them a living at 16. Like many Australians, I scratch my head and wonder about the comments of the former Democrats leader Cheryl Kernot, who is now jostling for the Labor Party leadership line‐up, when she told Australian taxpayers that they have an obligation to pay for milkshakes and movie tickets for Australia's young unemployed.

This shows that she has lost touch with what is really important to Australian families: things like jobs and real opportunities for young Australians, to encourage them to be self‐sufficient and contributing members of our society. Cheryl's idea of self‐sufficiency is for the Australian taxpayers to give them pocket money so that they do not have to ask their parents. That is not self‐sufficiency; that is the worst form of reliance. That is teaching our young people that the government owes them and has a fundamental duty to provide for them. They are not being taught responsibility for their own future or the value of a strong work ethic. In that sense, Ms Kernot should feel right at home in the Labor Party. Both the Democrats and the Labor Party initially opposed the government's equally sensible and practical work for the dole scheme, with Labor doing a last minute backflip when they realised the extent of community support out there.

Like this new youth allowance, work for the dole is about restoring positive incentives for young people. It is about creating a system where government payment is seen as the `safety net' that it is meant to be, not the primary and ongoing means of support. I am delighted that the government has nearly tripled the number of recently announced work for the dole pilot programs in response to the huge number of applications received. I am also pleased that two hardworking community groups in my own electorate will be supplying work for the dole programs: Boystown, which is a disadvantaged group—a group which the opposition say we never look after—and Phantast who look after street kids. I think that is another terrific angle of looking after the real disadvantaged people. I am so proud that they were given funding to participate in this pilot program.
Just as work for the dole has drawn widespread community support, so too have the common youth allowance changes. On 19 June, the Herald‐Sun editorial said:

The federal government's reforms to youth welfare payments are welcome . . . This age group is much too young to begin life in an environment which could lead them into the mistaken belief that the world owes them a living.
Similarly, in the Sydney Morning Herald :
The change is desirable and overdue . . . In too many cases it has encouraged young people to leave home prematurely and inclined them to welfare dependency.
The Brotherhood of St Laurence recognised the extra support provided with this comment:
We have been asking for better support for this group of young people for many years and finally their needs are starting to be recognised.

In summary, this bill is fair. It establishes a simpler youth payment system which will more accurately reflect community views and values. Is it any wonder that Labor, as out of touch as ever, opposes it? And should we really be at all surprised that Labor's newest recruit believes that self‐sufficiency is the Australian taxpayer paying for young people to go to the movies and have a milkshake? It would be surprising if the Labor Party, the Democrats or those of both minds supported a practical, commonsense measure like this.

I listened with interest to the comments made by the member for Chifley (Mr Price), the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) and the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) and I am quite sure that they believe exactly what they were saying. They have not had first‐hand experience of what it is like to rear children on a low income. They have probably been listening to do‐gooders out there who constantly try to tell our children that the government owes them a living. We hear it in our schools. I guess I would be one of the very few members in this room who could stand up here and talk with first‐hand experience of how to bring up children on an income of less than $25,000. I am proud to say that I have reared eight children through the Labor Party's regime, but it was a constant battle in getting my children to understand that the symbol of life was not just to accept money but to work for it. This was the work ethic that I gave to my children.

When those on the other side talk about rearing children, they say, `How dare you do this to low income people.' I am glad that I have the opportunity, after 13 years of rearing children, to say: how dare you tell young people of Australia that they are entitled to money that they do not deserve? People on low incomes are constantly battling the system to bring up their children in a better way, trying to ensure that they do not fall into the system and become third and fourth generation social security recipients. We have to ensure that children do not expect money for nothing. We should put it back into the hands of the parents who are willing to work hard to ensure that their children have a better future and that they start off with a work ethic that they should work for anything they want in life. The moment we see the younger generation doing that, that is when Australia will get back on its feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have studied with interest the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) introducing the Social Security Legislation Amend ment (Youth Allowance) Bill to the House and it seems clear that it is based on the following principles: a perceived need for simplicity in the way income support is paid to young people; a perceived need to remove a supposed existing incentive for young people to leave education early and go on the dole; and a belief that families should support young people until they have achieved financial independence, although that status is nowhere defined.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to briefly discuss some of the positive aspects of the bill but then move on to the issues that concern me about the impact that these changes will have. The bill will replace the five youth payments of newstart, Austudy, youth training allowance, sickness allowance and family allowance with a single payment to be known as the common youth allowance. Hopefully, the application process will be simpler and the entitlements and rates of payment will be more uniform, understandable and consistent with the rest of the social security system than the current maze of entitlements.

The bill should remove, for example, the common situation where young people who cease working to undertake study or vice versa will no longer have to wait for some time without any income. However, after dealing first‐hand in the electorate with cases which have not fitted simply into the current allowance categories, I must say that there is a reason for having different allowances because of the different needs of different groups of people. As the Aged Care Bill and the Austudy actual means test have shown—and as the social security legislation shows me daily in my electorate—there are always people who do not fit neatly into the slots provided by even the most complex legislation or regulations. I note the absence of Abstudy from inclusion in this youth allowance. Its exclusion suggests that the government too recognises that different people have different needs that cannot always be catered for under one blanket piece of legislation.

The bill will also provide for higher rates of assistance for young recipients, rent assistance for students, pharmaceutical allowance for all those eligible and the family income test appears slightly more generous than that applying under the current Austudy scheme.

Because eligible tertiary students will now receive rent assistance as well as being able to earn up to $6,000 per year before their allowance is reduced, they will be the real winners if this bill is introduced as is. However, this improvement must be viewed alongside the illogical increase in the age of independence for students aged from 22 to 25—that is, of course, if they are able and lucky enough to get a place in a tertiary institution.

The fact that the proposed youth allowance provides more support for those who have to leave home to study or look for work will I hope alleviate some of the extra burden faced by young unemployed people and students who must leave my rural electorate of Calare to pursue employment or studies. However, I note with interest the minister's emphasis that those who `do not need to live away from home' will only be paid an at home rate.

Does this mean, for example, that Matthew Tubman, an extremely talented young trumpeter from Orange, who after going as far as he could with his studies in Orange auditioned and was accepted into the Sydney Conservatorium High School where he is now a student, is only entitled to the home rate of assistance because Austudy is apparently only meant to provide a basic education? Here the case is clear: a country boy is at a disadvantage because he lives west of the sandstone curtain. Sure, if he lived anywhere on Sydney's rail link, he could live at home, but it just so happens that his family lives in Orange so for him in this particular pursuit it is tough luck and it seems he can only get the at home rate. I wonder whether Matthew will now satisfy the needs to live away from home criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will.

—I hope so. If he does not, the government simply will not be sending the right message to those thousands of young people like him who are trying to extend themselves. In principle, I have no problem with encouraging young people to stay in education as long as possible. I agree with the minister that students leaving school in year 12 are much more likely to be employed than young people who leave school at the end of year 10.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill does remove the incentive to leave school early and go on the dole, but does it really provide alternatives to the dole? However, if you are going to force students to stay in school or go to TAFE, you simply must also give the schools and the TAFEs the resources to provide these reluctant students with the type of special attention they need or, in the case of TAFEs, at least the resources to provide enough places for the applicants.

I notice that the government's questions and answers sheet on the youth allowance makes no commitment for more funding, simply saying that it will maintain funding in real terms and that states will achieve growth through efficiencies. Let us get real about this. You cannot increase education incentives and hope to provide the wherewithal with mirrors. It needs a real funding commitment, and that is the missing link in this plan.

Let me briefly digress to some other missing links. While this government is so anxious to try to blame the unemployed and brag about the welfare cheats it has caught, let us not forget that after almost 20 years of rhetoric and labour market programs by governments of both persuasions, topped off by a pathetic `blame the victim' approach in the work for the dole, how about concentrating on our obligations to the young rather than theirs to us?

Youth unemployment is a result of the actions and policies of the adults. In 1980, 84 per cent of 15‐ to 24‐year‐olds were in full-time employment. In 1996 it was 35 per cent. On current trends, there will be no full-time work for 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds by 2001. Quality training is one side of the equation for making kids employable. Providing jobs through a coherent economic policy is the other.

We need tax reform to enable those people who are struggling on $25,000 to bring up their kids. We need tax reform to enable them to do it. We need to look at tax free thresholds perhaps of $10,000. We need tax reform urgently. We need increased investment in social and physical infrastructure, particularly by government, and a maintenance of key job protecting tariff structures, not right across the board. Let us not pull up the drawbridge. We need to look critically and not throw it all open to the questionable benefits of free trade. We need reregulation of the financial system to the extent of promoting more productive investment, directed superannuation investment, greater tax offsets and other support measures for primary industries value adding and an active industry policy.

Industry by and large, especially in my electorate, has abandoned traineeships and apprenticeships. That loss has fallen to the smaller employers who are doing their bit but still find the cost of apprentices a burden. In 1970 apprentice builders got 15 per cent of the adult wage. Today it is 40 per cent. That might be okay if major companies were absorbing those costs, but they are not; it is left largely to the small operator. That is where the new traineeship and apprenticeship program might run aground. Small business cannot afford the costs or the hassles, no matter how flexible these schemes are.

I hope I am wrong, but I can see danger signs after a discussion about apprenticeships that I had last week with small business operators who attended the launch of the new employment placement organisation of the CES, to be renamed something else in the near future. The message I got is that it is still too dear and the impediments to employing young people are still too great.

While larger companies are hell‐bent on dividends and profits, it seems that the responsibility for any employment creation is filtering down to small business at a rapid rate where there is still a conscience about this. As a builder told me in Bathurst the other night, it costs him $61,000 per annum for two apprentices—unrealistic wages plus add-on costs. He is prepared to do it still because he is committed to young people and the future of his industry and his nation. But he is becoming a decreasing factor in this whole equation.

Why don't we require larger companies, which are rapidly downsizing and outsourcing to contractors, to have a ratio of apprenticeships and traineeships on a consistent basis? Then we might have something to offer our young apprentices or tertiary graduates. Then we might prevent that trend to no full-time work for the young. The most excitement I see in the apprenticeship program in my neck of the woods is the now fairly longstanding group apprenticeship scheme. That really is a patchwork quilt. It works well because the small employer can only employ a part apprentice, and so they are shared around to a large degree. We need full‐time apprenticeships like we used to have, but we do not have them now. Although I will support it to the hilt, I am not convinced that the new apprenticeship and traineeship program is going to do it.

According to the House of Representatives committee report on youth employment, some 7,000 skilled tradespeople, managers and engineers will need to be imported to meet skill requirements in Western Australian development projects between 1998 and 2000. That is the tragic fact. The 1997‐98 budget cut vocational and industry training by $14.3 million and took $72 million from education and training grants to the states.

It is a bit ripe to say to 16‐ to 18‐year‐olds, `You have to be in full‐time education or training to get your allowance,' and then limit the number of TAFE places available to these young people. By doing this you are, in effect, saying to these people, `You're obliged to attend TAFE or whatever, but the government is not obliged to provide you with a place.' It is a catch‐22. I read early this year that the Australian TAFEs rejected 60,000 applicants for study this year. I heard the member for Longman (Mr Brough) say in this debate that tertiary places were oversubscribed this year. He said:
Am I correct? I am quite sure that I am. I note that you deliberately decide not to answer that every university place. . .
he was talking to the members on the other side—
. . . was actually oversubscribed. Where is the lack of education? Where is the lack of places?
I fail to see his logic. That they were oversubscribed by a factor of 60,000 is the very point of the argument: the places just are not there.

BREAK.PARA: The nation and our young people are crying out for some openings, some vision from the government, some innovation and some hope for the future. That can come with more education spending for the able, not less, and more case management for the at risk—those unable to cope with traditional education. We have only 10,000 places in the work for the dole scheme, a very skinny Green Corps program, and the blame for this situation is brought about by the economic policies and technological developments which have made our traditional concepts of work and careers redundant.

This bill will punish some young people who are victims of our inability to provide work. It will punish their families by forcing them to support their grown‐up children, whether they are studying or not, until they are financially independent. It is those lower middle‐class families which will be worst hit by this bill; those whose income is right on or just over the benchmarks. It is not as though families with combined adjusted incomes of around $41,000 are rolling in it, and the lower end threshold of $23,400 above which the allowance will be gradually reduced also seems particularly mean.

The notion of independence adopted by this bill is another I find difficult to understand. The minister says the application of the means test for the youth allowance reinforces the government's message that the family should support their young family members until they have achieved financial independence. What is this, and when does one achieve it?

It is clear that the government changes its definition of financial independence in different policy areas to suit its revenue needs, and inconsistent signals are being sent out. For example, under the current Austudy provision a student is not considered independent until they turn 25 or satisfy other criteria, but for the purpose of the family tax initiative and child support, children are considered dependent only up until 18. Even under the proposed youth allowance, unemployed people will be considered independent if they are over 21 but not, it would appear, if they are students.

This is happening when the perception of many in the wider community remains that people become adults when they turn 18; that they are independent at 18 because they are old enough to vote, marry, join the army, go to gaol—you name it. How can the government on the one hand be implementing policy telling parents their children are not independent until 25, but on the other hand maintaining the age of independence at 18?

If we take the child support case, if a child turning 18 goes on to study, the non‐custodial parent who was forced by law to support them until 18 is no longer legally obliged to support them. This bill relies on some sort of moral obligation. The fact is that many parents who can afford to, do not share the government's moral view that they are obliged to support their grown‐up children and, as much as we want to force it, it is not going to happen. I think there is a real and genuine issue that deserves to be debated: when does a young person cease to be dependent?

I would be interested perhaps to see some sort of survey taken to get an idea of the community feeling on the issue. I know many parents feel their children are adults and can fend for themselves when they turn 18. I am very concerned for those in the 16 to 18 age group who may find themselves in this situation and cannot get money from their parents, but at the same time cannot really prove they are homeless.

We would be very ignorant to pretend that there are not cases such as these. Exactly how these young people will support themselves in the future is worrying. Dare I say it will be through theft and teenage prostitution? It may only be a very small minority but it is a significant one. I don't know that the youth allowance addresses this. I certainly hope it will not come to that but if they cannot get the money from their parents they will have to get it somewhere—we can only guess where.

Another concern I have is how the new allowance and its actual means test will be comprehended by applicants and their families, given the problems I have personally seen with Austudy. The test has dumbfounded many accountants, let alone parents and kids from lower socio‐economic groups and lower education backgrounds.

While I hope the government's promised reforms to the Austudy AMT iron out the ludicrous anomalies, inconsistencies and complexities which have plagued its operation so far, I remain sceptical about whether this test can work in the youth allowance context.

The fundamental inequity is that the bill is premised on the caring, sharing, utopian, white picket fence families so idealised by some members in this chamber. The bill ignores that many young people—if not the majority—whom this bill will adversely affect, do not come from such model families. They come from disjointed, struggling, less than ideal families. I am sure members of this House have also been faced by the Austudy applicant under the age of 25 whose parents simply refuse to support them. There is simply nothing that can be done for them. The hardship provisions do not seem to be able to deal with such cases.

How do we deal with 16‐ or 17‐year‐olds needing intensive support for whom school is an irrelevance? In evidence to the Senate committee on this bill, the Brotherhood of St Laurence called for special case management where some 16‐ to 17‐year‐olds receive this allowance through agreeing to pursue forms of suitable activities rather than full‐time study.
I applaud such an approach. As a former teacher in the dim distant past of so-called general activities kids in junior high school, I can relate to those very kids and those very needs.

I firmly believe we are tackling this problem from the wrong end. The unemployed young are suffering from the consequences of economic change—technological and rationalist. The lack of job generation is our problem and not theirs.

Until we introduce the social factor back into our economic policy and planning, where employment is an economic obligation and not purely a cost, all the independence criteria, youth allowances, work for the dole places or traineeships will not really be worth a cracker unless there is something permanent at the end of the line. The government claims these measures will encourage families to support young people until they are financial ly independent, but we need jobs for financial independence, and that is the missing part of the equation.

Inasmuch as the youth allowance attacks one end of the equation—encouraging greater schooling or training—and inasmuch as it significantly assists rural students, especially those studying away from home, I give my very guarded support to this bill. But I look forward to amendments that I believe inevitably will be introduced in the Senate, and I will be studying them with great interest. I support the second reading amendment that has been moved by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my support to the common youth allowance bill of 1997. There is no doubt that young people do draw strength and support, as well as a boost to their morale, if there exists a healthy relationship with their parents, as a recent article quoted in the Australian . The article by Anne Henderson, which appeared on 1 October, said that there is increasing evidence that young people may effectively be forced into a close relationship with their families because they cannot afford to leave home. Nobody mentions that there are families who expect and want to look after their own.

SPEECH.PARA: This government has introduced the common youth allowance to simplify income support for young people and to help them to make the right decisions about their future. Further, it removes the disincentives which stop young people from continuing their education.

It has been well documented—and it is a cause of constant complaint in my electorate of Gilmore—that young people on unemployment benefits were treated differently to young people who received subsidies whilst they were studying. I am constantly being asked by my electorate to justify, and be accountable for, the funding allocated to social security income support.

In fact, I believe we must ask ourselves: how long can we as a government further promote the attitude of the previous government that it is okay for people not to contribute to society and that we believe you are much more valuable to us unemployed than you are with a job? That is the message we are sending by paying more for those who are unemployed than for those who want to improve their skills and become employable.

It is also well known and a much publicised fact that only 30 per cent of our school leavers go on to tertiary education in one form or another. We know that the other 70 per cent are often ignored by the system, which classes university education as the only way to get a career. Therefore, it is important that we as a government recognise this and provide the extra finance to families to encourage our young people to continue further education or training or whilst they are actively looking for work.

This is done by the introduction of the common youth allowance. The allowance puts together the best possible income support measure for young people and the community as a whole. Before that, we received submissions from welfare groups, community organisations, youth groups and parents, who were all consulted. They confirmed that the young people who drop out of school at the end of year 10 and who are unable to get a job are three times as likely to remain on the long-term unemployed list as those who continue in further education or training.

A recently released report on youth employment by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, called Youth employment: a working solution, quotes a submission by DEETYA. It states:
In May 1996 the unemployment rate for young people 20 to 24 years who did not complete the highest level of schooling was 21.3% compared with 11.5% for those who completed year 12.

The report also notes that there is indisputable correlation between an individual's level of education and his or her social wellbeing and economic security. A well educated population is also a more adaptable and more socially productive population within a more efficient economy.

Australians want to see young people encouraged to work. They are tired of the message we are sending, that it is okay not to want to work and not to want to improve your skills. There are whole families—three or four generations in some cases—whose only source of income is welfare benefits. This has not just happened. We inherited it from the Labor government.

Australians have also said that they are now tired of paying for people who can support themselves. A recently released Clemenger report titled The silent majority indicated that one of the two top concerns of Australians in the 1990s is alleged dole bludgers. Twenty years ago the two concerns were the length of power cords on domestic electrical equipment and the short lifespan of library books.

In an effort to assist young people to tackle not only disincentives to continue education and training but also the stigma and difficulties associated with receiving social security benefits, the government has introduced a streamline system of payments known as the common youth allowance. It will replace five different payments and 13 levels of payments with one form and one office to deal with. That is something which certainly has been welcomed by both young people and their parents in the two public forums that we have held in Gilmore.

Youth workers have also welcomed the streamlining and simplification of income support for young people, while still being concerned about those young people who may slip through the system. Those young people in that last group are already slipping through the system. Again, whole families have not been able to get the assistance they need over the past decade. We acknowledge that there will be some people who, for whatever reason, cannot find work or an appropriate training place.

There is still a need for a form of social security income support to guard against the reduction in the qualities of self‐dependence and self‐respect, which Australians are so ferociously proud of. That is why we have introduced, along with the common youth allowance, a range of exemptions which will give young people the flexibility to still receive income support. These exemptions include illness, homelessness, independence and the lack of a suitable employment or training place. These exemptions protect those who need it the most. The safety net is still in place.

However, we must also recognise the real fear that many youth workers have pointed out in the forums I have attended in both Nowra and Ulladulla that, whilst the common youth allowance recognises that parents have a responsibility to care for their children, where they are able to do so rather than the taxpayer, it is not always possible to do that. There are too many young people, even in Gilmore, for whom home is not the place where they find the support they need; many young people are forced to live independently from an early age and therefore we have those exemptions.

One thing that must be pointed out is that, while we are looking to be accountable for our social security system, the common youth allowance is not a cost cutting measure. In fact, it will cost the government an extra $25 million in the first year alone and it will provide a fairer, simpler system of income support for young people. Under some of the other measures which will be introduced as part of the common youth allowance, the education leavers scheme will be abolished, which means young people who leave school without a job and are eligible for the allowance will no longer have to wait up to 13 weeks before they can receive benefits. This move was given strong support at the recent Nowra forum.

Rent assistance will be given to young people who need to live away from home for study or employment so they can follow their career dreams, which they may not have been able to do before because of financial hardship; and in my electorate, of course, the lack of everyday transport is a very common problem. This initiative alone will benefit about 70,000 young people throughout Australia, particularly those in regional and rural areas like Gilmore.

The common youth allowance also increases the amount of funding available to families with unemployed children—these facts are readily available, certainly to the families in my electorate, where the scaremongering has already occurred. The bottom line is that, without further skills or education training, young people will find it much harder to find work, and with disincentives in place to stop young people from gaining those skills and tuition there is little likelihood of change in the circumstances of these young people.

For the former government to sit over there and continue to fight an issue which will provide support for those who need it, protect those who cannot help themselves and encourage a more productive, more highly educated young population which is motivated to helping its own is indicative of its attitude towards the residents of this country over the past 13 years. The community will no longer accept it.

It is fair to say that youth unemployment is still the No. 1 issue facing not only our young people but also society as a whole. Recent statistics released by the Department of Social Security show that the youth unemployment rate dropped by 0.4 per cent last month, which is good news. But try telling that to the 26 per cent of young Australians who are still without work! The statistics are frightening and an indictment of how we, as a whole community, and our governments have failed our young people. The statistics also have a face. They are our children, grandchildren, nieces, nephews, relatives and friends. For the first time in several generations, this is not something which just happens to someone else.

Many families in the Gilmore electorate are affected by youth unemployment, as are many families throughout Australia. These families are supporting a young person, if not necessarily financially, certainly emotionally, for the cost of unemployment is not only in monetary terms. Young people who do not have a job lose a major way of networking in the community. They lose access to the normal interactions of a society which spends at least 40 hours per week—and, in many cases, more—in not only work situations but also social environments which have their own sense of rules and regulations and their own hierarchies. These are the places where young people can continue the learning process, developing their own identities in the way of the world.

BREAK.PARA: In a society which places more than a monetary value on having a job, young unemployed people are the big losers in terms of low self‐esteem, few social skills and little self‐respect. While the doom‐and‐gloom picture must be acknowledged, I feel it is more important to address the ways in which we, as a community and as a government, can improve young people's visions of their employment opportunities and therefore their future. We are doing this through the introduction of the common youth allowance.

One of the main issues I would like to see considered is the way in which the whole community—particularly the opposition sitting on the other side of the chamber, who are responsible for the 30‐plus per cent youth unemployment rate which hit our young people as a result of the past 13 years of their ignorance and neglect—talks down the role of assisting young people, whether through negative stereotyping or maybe simply telling young people, `No, there is no hope for you; there are no jobs out there.' And all of us hear this every day. Yet most young people still have a very positive attitude to finding employment. I believe that the common youth allowance gives all young Australians a chance to decide where they want to go and what they want to do.

In conclusion, I would like to point out another issue which will have a big impact on Australian communities. Already in my electorate of Gilmore, local people have taken the initiative to host public forums to discuss the impact that these changes will have when they are introduced in July next year. Several issues were raised and I have outlined them previously. However, these were not the only areas of concern in Gilmore and I would like to highlight some of the main ones for you: the level of income cut‐off points for the parental means test and the age of children that is considered in the parental means test. I have already brought these issues to the attention of the minister. I thank the youth centres in both Nowra and Ulladulla for their initiative in organising these meetings.

I am also proud to say that in Gilmore we did not wait for the government to assist the community to tackle issues of unemployment. The recently announced work for the dole pilot program—two of which were granted in Gilmore to give more than 270 people placements throughout the Shoalhaven—was very well received by the whole community. It needs to be remembered that it was Labor who originally voted against the work for the dole program. They are now complaining that they have not received any programs. The most impressive point is that in Gilmore we already have our own work for the dole program through the Shoalhaven Earning a Living projects, which were established through the Shoalhaven Area Consultative Committee and were used as a model for the work for the dole program. I am proud that the Gilmore communities are willing to work in partnership with the government to take ownership of the problem of youth unemployment and I welcome the announcement of the Gilmore work for the dole programs as a recognition of the great work being done in the Shoalhaven.

The common youth allowance is supported by members of the Gilmore community as an example of the way we are assisting young people to break the cycle of youth unemployment by removing disincentives to further education, by simplifying the means of income support for young people and by making the social security system more accountable. Once the opposition see the assistance this will give to young people to become more interactive members of the Australian community, I am sure they will also do the right thing and support the legislation as well.

However, the role of this government does not stop there. We have allocated an extra 220,000 places for trainees and apprentices throughout Australia. In the Illawarra area alone, we have received an extra 2,800 places at a cost of $7 million over and above the national allocation to cater for those young people who may not wish to continue on at school.

In what little time I have left, I would like to comment on the success of our recently commenced Green Corps program at our national icon and tourist attraction known as Bundanon in Nowra. Nine young men and one young woman are taking part in the program. These 10 young people are so proud of what they have achieved so far. They have displayed ownership not only of the work they have done but also of the problems of environmental degradation. The fact that they volunteered and were accepted for the program was a huge boost for their own self‐esteem.

Our work for the dole scheme will be a similar success. As I said, two programs have been allocated to Gilmore. They will see 270 young people in a program where the onus will be on our youth to exhibit, exceed and excel in the numerous talents they possess.

I am proud indeed of the young people in my electorate of Gilmore. I will do all I can to see that jobs are produced for the many people who really do want to work. The common youth allowance will go hand‐in‐hand with our employment programs to give our young people a real choice and to give the community a real chance to change its attitude about our young people and the present social security system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commenting on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill before the House today, I would like to remind the honourable member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash) that, while we welcome the right of employment for young people, I think it is very discriminatory that only certain young people in her community have the right to work. What about the rest of them? That is what I believe is so wrong about work for the dole. I think a piece of legislation which would even contemplate giving the right to work to just a few rather than to all is an obscene piece of legislation. If we are going to have payments go out like that, let us make sure that everyone is covered.

SPEECH.PARA: Meanwhile, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) said just five months ago in this House that the youth allowance was designed to send a `clear message' to young Australians that they should remain in school or at some other training institution as opposed to looking for work and relying on some level of income support in that process. However, only 18 months ago, in direct contradiction of that, the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said, in what can now be described as one of his non‐eventful headland speeches:
It's not an acceptable response to the youth unemployment crisis to tell young people to stay at school.

So we are provided with a glimpse of the utter confusion and hypocrisy that characterises the Howard government on the issues of youth unemployment and making sure that the youth of Australia and their families have an adequate social security safety net to meet their needs. The youth allowance is borne of that confusion and hypocrisy.

This bill does contain some positive and useful elements. The increased rates of payment for some young people is one of those and the increased flexibility of payments is another. I also acknowledge that one of the government's stated intentions in introducing this bill is to reduce the complexity of the arrangements which surround income support for young people. I commend that. However, abolishing income support for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who are neither studying nor at work and applying a parental means test to the payments of those aged between 18 and 20 undoes that good work. It is going to make life very difficult for thousands of struggling young people and their families across Australia.

Against the government's stated objectives, nor does this bill reduce the complexity surrounding income support for young people. Indeed, in some areas it actually adds to the confusion. Unfortunately the negative aspects in this bill far outnumber the positives. It is these negative elements which are going to cause so much pain to so many Australian families.

We in the opposition want Australian young people off welfare, but, unlike the government, we can see that punishing them and their families by cutting off or reducing their level of income support while they look for a job is not the way to go about it. I advise even government members to read the Senate minority report prepared by Labor and the Australian Democrats on this legislation. It makes it clear that the young Australians to whom this bill denies help are precisely the young Australians who most need our assistance. When young Australians who are in desperate straits need help in finding work, the last thing we in this parliament should be doing is making things more difficult for them. This bill does exactly that.

At least 30,000 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds will lose all income support from this piece of legislation. Thousands of 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds will have their benefits reduced the moment their family's income exceeds $23,400. For some, that will not be a problem. They will have families who are financially comfortable enough and emotionally stable enough to offer their young people their support. However, for a great many others this will be a source of unremitting friction and antagonism.

Many Australian families not only do not live financially comfortable lives; they also experience a great many social and emotional problems. Those problems either lead 16‐ to 18‐year‐olds to want to leave home and not rely on their parents' support or indeed lead parents to want to not offer their support.
When the youth allowance was first raised, the editorial from the Australian quite rightly pointed out:

It is a fact of life that some parents reject their offspring—materially and emotionally—and vice versa. Under the changed scheme, the consequences of such conflict will have to be so drastic as to make a youngster homeless before help is available. And families are simply required to endure within the home all the stages of anguish which build to that point.

The new rules governing the youth allowance do not take these sorts of families into account. On the contrary, they will go a long way to fostering the antagonism that is unfortunately already there, setting many families on the road to irretrievable breakdown and even placing some of our young people in danger of physical and mental assault at the hands of their parents, and vice versa. It happens.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his colleagues sitting on the government benches must be living in a fool's paradise if they think that saying, `It's time we threw the responsibility of supporting young out‐of‐ work‐people back on their parents,' is really going to be as simple and clear cut as all that.

As our shadow minister for education and youth affairs pointed out in his speech on the second reading debate, the Howard government, as typified by this bill, does not appreciate the diversity that exists in Australian families. This legislation makes the presumption that the arrangements contained in the youth allowance will be acceptable to all Australian families and that all Australian families have the same welfare needs when quite obviously they do not.

The Howard government has shown once again just how limited and how blinkered its vision is when it comes to understanding the needs and concerns of Australia and Australians in the 1990s. Were it a case that every Australian family offered the financial and emotional support to pick up the slack when their 16‐ to 20‐year‐old child either has their income support reduced or completely cut off and were it a case that they could support these children while they returned to school or to some other training institution, there would not be a problem, but of course—as I have repeatedly said—not all Australian families are in this position.

The professionals whose job it is to care for dysfunctional families and whose job it is to pick up the pieces when these families disintegrate know it is not as simple as the Howard government has fooled itself into believing it to be. The Australian Council of Social Services has stated that the new arrangements will just exacerbate family conflict. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has said that many families will now face added pressures. The Anglican Home Mission's executive director, Howard Dillon, has stated that taking income support away from 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds would put `substantial financial, emotional and relational pressure on families who are already doing it tough'.

Ms Anne Hollands, the director of services at Relationships Australia, a counselling and advice service used most recently by the federal government as an integral part of its marriage guidance strategy for Australian couples, states:

BREAK.PARA: There is no question this will create difficulties in some families. In families where relationships are extremely difficult and the young person needs to get out, it will be much harder for the person to establish themselves independently.
Apart from the emotional and relationship problems these measures will cause, taking money away from families which are often already facing financial hardship is cruel and obviously ill‐conceived.

A family on a combined income of $23,000 is not by any stretch of the imagination privileged or living on easy street, nor indeed is one on $33,000. The income support which a 16‐ to 20‐year‐old living in such a household brings in is sometimes an essential part of keeping that family afloat. It is not money that is spent on luxuries or indulgences. It is money that is spent on food, rent, paying bills and clothing.

By introducing the means test at such a low level many families in my electorate, and in others like it across Australia, are going to find their backs pressed even harder against the wall. That is really where this legislation is going to do the real damage. It is not going to damage the comfortable areas of Sydney's North Shore or the eastern suburbs, nor in the bou tique environs of Toorak Road in Melbourne, but in western Sydney and areas like western Sydney. The housing commission estates of Villawood and Fairfield in my electorate is where this is really going to hurt. They are the families that will be affected by this legislation.

The perimeters of the means test also raises questions about the government's view of when a young person is actually considered independent. Young people start to become civilly and criminally responsible after they reach the age of 16 and most definitely from 18 years onwards. They are actually given the vote in this country at 18. However, this legislation penalises those aged between 18 and 20 by regarding them as dependent on their parents. Young adults who are looking for work are independent and this legislation needs to be changed to recognise this fact. They should not be forced by the imposition of a means test to rely on their families for support, especially if their family subsists on a low income.

The high hypocrisy of it all is that, while the Howard government preaches extra education and training as a way out of youth unemployment, it has done all it can to reduce funding and the number of student places in institutions offering vocational education and training. The hypocrisy of it all is that in my electorate alone the Howard government is willing to keep over 500 extra young people in school, or force them back into education, but it will do nothing to provide a single drop of extra funding to cope with this influx.

Telling Australians that they have to do more with less has become a demand synonymous with this government, but this is something which the families and schools in my area will not be able to endure. Making up stories about training places and apprenticeships has also become something of a hallmark of this administration. I am sorry to say that, but it is a fact.

Dr Kemp—and as we all know the title stems from his talent at doctoring the figures he uses in this House—says that under this government we will see 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships, when in actual fact this year we will see at most only an extra 3,000 across Australia. Growth in government apprenticeships has also declined under the present administration. It has been cut by two‐thirds.Then the minister talks about the $4 billion extra which the Howard government earmarked for TAFE in the last budget—$4 billion extra? This is a complete fabrication. That $4 billion is not extra money at all; it was money that had already been allocated by Labor when in government. The only thing the minister has done is cut the figure originally decided upon by $72 million.

If the Howard government is going to abrogate its responsibilities in providing an adequate social security safety net for Australia's young people and if it is going to force them to stay at school against their wishes—because, let us face it, no matter how much some kids are cajoled into it, there will always be a few who do not want to stay at school—then it must provide the additional educational resources. Here again, we are provided with an insight into this government's limited capacity for appreciating the diverse problems and needs of Australian young people and their families.

This legislation displays a government which completely fails to understand why some young people give up on education prematurely and why some young people are unable to remain in education until matriculation. Young people do not leave school because they have better things to do. Young people do not just leave school because they want to receive unemployment benefits for the fun of it. More than likely, if a young Australian is leaving school prematurely it is because he or she has severe emotional problems, could be a victim of sexual abuse or violence, could be involved in drugs at school, suffers from alienation and depression, or has serious learning difficulties. All reports point to these concerns.
I refer again to comments made by the Brotherhood of St Laurence about young Australians:

They flee the school system because for them school has for some years been an experience with which they are not coping. More young people flee the school system because . . . they feel they do not belong there and because they feel they are not wanted there, then they flee the school system seeking income support.
Forcing young people to stay at school in order to get an income . . . is a dubious, incomplete and probably counterproductive approach to the problems of youth unemployment and early school leaving.

Yet this government simplistically and naively says to these young people, `Get off income support and get back to school. We are going to wash our hands of you and your family.' Where is the sense in that? Where is the understanding of what many of these young people are going through? Forcing children with learning difficulties and social problems back to the environment from which they long to escape is a recipe for disaster. It is a recipe for compounding their problems and the problems of their families.

Worse than being a simplistic or naive move, it is an action that smacks of a government almost falling over its own feet to divest itself of any responsibility it may have towards these young Australians or their families. Why is the government not contemplat ing an alternative approach—an alternative to letting these young people remain on income support or simply shoehorning them back to school? These young people would stand a greater chance of finding work and removing themselves from the welfare line if they were to be offered intensive case management. What about early intervention policies, which would help ascertain why these children want to leave school in the first place, find out what problems they have which are an impediment to their education and then set about solving them? Either the government is so lacking in imagination and intelligence that it has completely failed to canvass these options or it has rejected them in the process of shrugging off any responsibilities it has to these young people.

It is no good telling us, as we have heard time and time again from speakers on the government side, that these young people may be exempt from having their income support taken away or reduced in certain circumstances. As the Senate minority report makes very clear:

There is no provision in the bill for the making of guidelines to inform the Secretary's decision about this exemption. On the basis of evidence presented to us, we are not confident that the exemptions will be sufficiently flexible to allow for payment in the full range and diversity of circumstances which might lead a young person to leave education without finishing year 12.

To back up its rhetoric and to provide a little equilibrium to this hopelessly unbalanced legislation, the Howard government must provide immediate extra funding to cope with the influx of 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who will be forced back to school because of the youth allowance—especially in electorates like mine, which will bear the brunt of the 20,000 students who will remain in or return to education if these measures are introduced.

The government must reinstate and expand the highly successful students at risk program, which was specifically designed to identify and to assist young people at risk of leaving school early. It must guarantee the jobs pathway program beyond the current financial year. It must resume the pattern of growth funding for TAFE, established by Labor when in office. It must also restore the earnings credit scheme, which it abolished soon after taking office in 1996. Without doing these things the Howard government, more than just being seen as short‐sighted in instituting the youth allowance in the first place, will then correctly be seen as two‐faced and extremely cold‐hearted. It will be seen, Pontius Pilate‐like, washing its hands of the responsibilities which it carries, unquestionably, in relation to the welfare of thousands of young Australians and their families.

I condemn this bill in its present form. We are not talking about the one or two cases that are often reported to the electoral offices; we are talking about the young across the length and breadth of this country. Those people need help at the moment when their emotional lives are on the drawing board; they do not need it later on. This is when a government should act and this is when a government should intervene to assist and help, otherwise where do we give regard to what we proudly consider to be the future of this country? I condemn the bill in its present form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard some fantastic rhetoric from the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) before but nothing quite to match that speech. The member finished off by saying she condemns the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill, but the opposition has indicated that it is going to support the bill. I am not quite sure whether that means you are going to vote differently to what the opposition has indicated an intention to do or not.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition have moved an amendment but, again, it is a pious amendment because it does not give us any indication of what sorts of practical solutions the Labor Party might have to some of the problems that have just been enunciated in such terms by the member for Prospect. They indicate that they will support the bill in the House but they condemn the government for doing some things, and I will address those issues in a moment. They do not have the courage of their convictions by seeking to amend this bill in a constructive way, indicating what alternatives they might bring in. They simply want to condemn the government for doing certain things, calling the government to do other nebulous or broad things without defining them, such as introducing education and training opportunities so that every young Australian has access to the education and skills needed for full participation in the workplace and society.

What do those words mean? That sort of amendment means nothing. I would challenge the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), if he wants to play a constructive role in this very important debate—and we all acknowledge the importance of talking about jobs for young people and educational opportunities for young people—to come back into this place and move some substantive amendments to the legislation that actually give us an indication of what the Labor Party might do if it were ever to have the opportunity to do something as a government of this country again.

The fact is—and I do not want to harp on it too much—that we had 13 years of Labor government and in that 13 years they had lots of opportunities to fix up the problems. In the event, as we saw, all they did was create problems and then attempt to solve those problems by introducing all sorts of programs, the results of which proved to be a great deception. Many people were misled by the former government's attempts to create jobs and educational opportunities because that did not happen. Over 13 years of Labor government we simply had the situation going from bad to worse.

So I do not take the rhetoric of the member for Prospect seriously. I do not doubt her good intentions, but I do not take seriously her criticisms of this bill. The plain fact is that this bill is not a savings measure. That ultimately gives the lie to any serious criticism of this bill. It is not a savings measure. It might well be a savings measure because we have been forced as a government to embark on a process of making substantial savings, essentially because we were left, as we frequently remind the opposition is this place, with a job to do to get the country's finances into shape. It is just as well we did. When we look at what is occurring around us in Asia and other places we need to give the Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the government as a whole a very big tick and pat on the back for having taken the hard decisions that it has had to take. If those decisions had not been taken, then we might well have had the International Monetary Fund knocking on our door as well. We have had to take a lot of hard decisions and each of us on this side of the House knows that in government when you take hard decisions they are inevitably unpopular and impact on some group of people who are obviously unhappy about the decision having been taken. I have often said that it is much harder being in government than being in opposition. My first six years in this place were in opposition and it was very easy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You worked that out.

—I am pleased that the member for Wills, at the table, recognises the problem. When you are in government you have to take hard decisions. The temptation is to do what is popular but not necessarily what is right. This government, to its credit, has taken many of the right decisions even though in the short term they may not be seen to be entirely popular. The opposition has a valuable role to play. There is no doubt about that. Having been in opposition for six years prior to coming to government, I began to understand more clearly that the opposition does in our system have a valuable role to play and it needs to be a constructive role.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not seen from this opposition, and it is demonstrated in their contribution so far to this debate, a constructive criticism or approach to being in opposition. We have seen a populist approach; an approach that jumps on any bandwagon that happens to come by that might have a few voters in it in an attempt to gather support. Whether or not that is in Australia's best interests or not is not an issue for the opposition. The only issue in their response to most of our policies has been whether there might be a few votes in it for them if they oppose it.

I do not entirely dismiss the speech of the member for Prospect other than I think she protesteth a little too much and overstates her opposition rather than recognising that the Labor Party is supporting this legislation because it is essentially good legislation. The amendment the opposition has moved is not a serious amendment because it does not attempt to make any substantive changes to the legislation. It is what is called a `pious amendment'. The opposition might be able to run around outside and tell people who do not understand how this place works that it tried to amend the legislation, but it was not serious about it because it has not made a proper attempt to do that. We may well see some serious attempt to amend the legislation in substantive terms in the Senate, but that remains to be seen.

The youth allowance is not a savings measure. It will cost the government an extra $25 million in its first year of operation. In the current economic context, I can tell you, having been very much on the receiving end of the process in a lot of respects in my electorate, there are not many ministers' departments where the government has had the luxury of actually spending more. We have, as I said at the outset, been faced with the very difficult task, which has been achieved to a very great extent, of trying to get the government's finances back into line from where they were when we came into government. The extra $25 million means that, of the 560,000 recipients of youth allowance, 64 per cent will be unaffected by the changes, 27.5 per cent will actually get more money, six per cent only will get less money and only 2.5 per cent will have their payments cancelled.

It is very easy for the opposition to do as the member for Prospect did and concentrate on the six per cent who will get less money and the 2.5 per cent who will have their payments cancelled. But our assessment of the situation is that those people were not in the broad scheme of things entitled to continue to have a payment because of the means tests that were being applied or, because of those means tests, were entitled to less money. Fundamentally we believe that welfare should go to those who are most in need. Inevitably, if you start with that principle, which I think is broadly supported, you will need to draw lines. Wherever you draw a line in this sort of argument, you will find some people who are on what they see as the wrong side of the line and they will therefore have something to argue about.

Let me deal specifically with some of the matters that were raised by the member for Prospect and make clear that, firstly, youth allowance will not—and I emphasise not—abolish the dole for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds. That is just not the case. Young people who finish year 12 are much more likely to get a job, and therefore it is important to encourage young people to get an education. That is why youth allowance will only be paid to under‐18s who are studying or training. Families will be financially better off, too, because parents will still be able to claim the family tax initiative. The other issue that was raised was in relation to 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds. We just do not accept that the youth allowance will treat 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds unfairly, nor do we accept that it penalises low income families, for a number of reasons.
