I have not been able to follow the whole debate, but what I have seen so far from the Labor Party is to a very large extent another example of its back to the future approach to solving our nation's problems. Except, I must say, for the shadow minister who is at the table, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), there is not much evidence of new Labor in the policy prescriptions we are hearing from the Labor Party. It is the old Labor Party that is still in control, and consequently we see those old prescriptions. We had 13 years of those old prescriptions and clearly they just did not work. You would have thought that in some of the speeches by opposition members there would at least be a tinge of contrition for the fact that they brought about, on balance, a great deal of angst and a great deal of disappointment for young people who were promised jobs and outcomes which we now know were not delivered. But, as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) pointed out yesterday in question time, the socialist dream lives on. It is still written into the Labor Party manifesto, and that is what is being acknowledged there.

BREAK.PARA: What we have seen as a result of 13 years of Labor government is the creation of a welfare dependency in our society which is endemic. They still believe on that side of the House that the government should solve every problem. The damage to the fabric of our society that has been caused by that is immeasurable. I heard the member for Forde (Mrs Elson) on our side speaking earlier on, and she outlined in very eloquent terms how that had caused so much damage to our society. The Labor Party clearly is good at spending other people's money. They still believe that they can actually solve all of our problems with the sort of interventionist solutions that they have inflicted upon us in the past. But I think there is a growing realisation in the Australian community that there is no such thing as a free lunch for us as a nation.

Some of the speakers in the debate that I did listen to earlier I think made a very good contribution by recognising the realities that we are faced with as a nation. There is a huge unemployment problem, and it is an unemployment problem which has become very difficult to solve. I think there is a need for us as a nation in a bipartisan sense or a multi‐partisan sense to really come to grips with the extent of the problem and not merely use these debates as an opportunity for an ideological slanging match. There were some contributions that were intended to actually recognise the reality of the situation. But the fact is that there are not enough jobs to go around, and the facts are clear: the better educated are more likely to get the jobs that are there.

That is an underlying principle of this particular legislation, because it provides the incentives—and I use the word `incentives' in the sense that it provides the motivation—for individuals to gain education and training opportunities rather than taking what was in the past, whether we like it or not, an easier option, which was simply to go on the dole and sit back and navel gaze about what was happening in the world. So the incentives that we are talking about are the sorts of incentives—not the sort of incentives that I heard the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) talking about; when people on the other side talk about incentives, they are talking about handouts and programs and things that do not lead anywhere—that essentially will provide people with the motivation to undertake training opportunities, because the better trained and the better educated will have the jobs that are available.

The bigger problem of job creation is a matter of concern to all of us. If we are honest and realistic about it, I think we all realise that that is going to become more and more difficult to do. In fact, the forecasts that we see indicate that there will be less and less people doing the available work. Even now, there are many companies in Australia that admit that they are overemploying, for a whole range of reasons. What we do need to face up to as a nation is the real challenge of redefining work and looking closely at what will provide fulfilment for people. Until now, work has clearly been a major factor in providing that fulfilment. That is why long‐term unemployment in particular is so demeaning to so many people. So we need as a society and as a parliament to think more about what the alternatives to paid work might be, and we need to ensure that people have the opportunity to be fulfilled in a situation which we will inevitably face where there are less and less jobs available.

Ultimately, the youth allowance is positive and good news, and it is disingenuous of members opposite to attempt to cloud the issues by talking about a whole range of other things which are not relevant. Youth allowance is about providing consistency, efficiency and flexibility. It is important, I believe, that young people are not better off on the dole than in education or training.

What was occurring before was wrong in that there was a disincentive for people to continue in education and training. We might argue about the training or the education they were receiving—and there are some problems, as have been mentioned, with people staying at school perhaps when they do not need to; and there is the fact that I still think senior high school is, in some respects, not appropriate to the needs of young people who are staying on. But the fact is that previously the wrong message was being sent out to young people—that they were better off on the dole than attempting to undertake training or education.

This particular legislation addresses that issue because it makes it at least equally attractive and, in many respects, more financially attractive for young people to remain in education and training. Students now will have the opportunity, by virtue of this legislation, to access benefits to which they were not entitled before—and those things include rent assistance, pharmaceutical allowance, $500 interest‐free advances, and so on. So this legislation does contain some major incentives for young people to remain in training.

There has been some criticism of the parental means test. I think that criticism is understandable up to a point—in particular, that parents should maintain some responsibility for full‐time students up to their 25th birthday. Once again, this is a matter of where you draw the line in these issues. You can argue, as did the member for Prospect, that young people can get drivers licences when they are 17, they can vote when they are 18, and I suppose they can go to war when they are 18. But in the end, in dealing with this matter, I think there has to be an understanding that parents in a lot of cases want to assist—and understand that they do have some responsibility for assisting—young people until they can become financially independent. Therefore, the line is drawn at that particular point in time.

As far as the means test is concerned, there was criticism of the previous Austudy actual means test. It was complex, but essentially it was right. I do not know that there was much argument from the other side about that, other than with the complexity and the way it was brought in. But it was right, because it attempted to get to the bottom of many of the so-called rorts that were occurring with benefits where people were managing to contrive their income situation, particularly where they were self-employed.

Madam Deputy Speaker, my time has almost expired. Therefore, let me say to you and to the House that this legislation is overwhelmingly positive. I commend it to honourable members for their support. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill and to support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I do so more in sorrow than in anger because it really, I believe, is a sad reflection on the Howard government's approach to the people of Australia that this legislation abolishes the unemployment benefits that would have been payable to 17- and 18-year-olds, and has assets tests inflicted on parents of children 18 years old and over.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be easy to get very angry with such a mean‐spirited government. However, I think sorrow is the appropriate emotion to feel, as we observe the economic rationalist policies attacking the welfare of our young people and low income families within our community. I say `sorrow' again because the govern ment has, once again, got its social security policies wrong—just as it has got them wrong relating to child care, aged care and, of course, the increased costs that are being imposed on older Australians.

The provisions of this legislation clearly implement the coalition government's economic rationalist philosophy that parents should support young people until they achieve financial independence. This is a great way to help battling families, I must say!

But I just want to make this point in this debate: I would argue very strongly that 99 per cent of all school leavers want to work. I will never accept the argument that has been put by some people on the other side that, because we do have a safety net social security provision, somehow or other young people would prefer to receive social security than to work. That is not the case, and I believe that is where the government's legislation is wrong. I think, as was said by the previous speaker, the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), the major problem is that there are simply not enough jobs to go around—and I will address that issue a little later.

BREAK.PARA: This legislation continues the pattern that has permeated the whole government in its short history of winding back government's involvement rather than meeting the needs of a nation with high unemployment by active government intervention. The government has, in its short term, abolished labour market programs; increased fees for higher education; removed income support; and really hurt low income families. I believe that the government has misunderstood the nature of the problem. It is throwing the responsibility of overcoming youth unemployment entirely on our education system.

With a decline in full‐time jobs by 50.2 per cent for 15‐ to 16-year-olds over the past 15 years—no matter how many unemployed people are encouraged back into the school system, or how many potential school leavers are encouraged by this legislation to stay on in the education system—you will simply not find all the jobs necessary to reduce unemployment by any significant degree. In the main, I do not believe that high youth unemployment is caused by our young people's lack of education or training, or their lack of willingness to work.

The causes of high youth unemployment are set out in a recent report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, entitled Youth employment: a working solution, which has been referred to by several members in this debate already. The report states:

Changes in the composition of the labour market have seen the most severe declines occurring in entry level jobs, once the domain of teenagers entering the labour market. Employment growth for teenagers in skilled trades has been strongly negative, falling more than 33 per cent in about ten years. Banking was once an industry which gave large numbers of teenagers their first job as a teller but technology has transformed the industry and the entry level jobs have disappeared.

In the insurance industry, the proportion of employment for under 21 year olds has fallen from about 18 per cent of the work force to about 5 per cent since 1987. Technology and policies favouring privatisation, corporatisation and outsourcing have also transformed the state and federal public sectors at the cost of large numbers of entry level jobs.

This report has been accepted by the government. The last sentence gives us a clear indication of where the major problem is. The issues highlighted in this quotation need to be addressed before we overcome youth unemployment. Let me talk a little more about the problem. We have a nation that daily confronts stagnant youth unemployment and parents are now facing the added burden of having their income and assets included in a means test as their children seek government assistance. Many of these parents are not high income people. They do not enjoy family trusts to avoid taxes, as do some 19 members of the government's front bench. Where this legislation does authorise the secretary to the department to grant exceptions, these are not subject to any scrutiny. Why is this so? The community might well ask this important question. They are entitled to be not only sceptical but also cynical in their view that the unscrutinised exemptions will not assist the low income families and their needy kids.

This legislation is to force some 27,000 unemployed youth back to school. Has there been any examination by the government as to why these young people left school in the first place? This legislation shows a complete lack of understanding by the government of why people leave school prior to completing their higher school certificate. In most cases it is because they have lost interest in the school environment. This attitude comes about because of a range of issues such as change of school, emotional problems, difficulties at home and drug addiction. I fell into part of the above group as a young person when as a school student I moved to a new school. I did not settle into the new school and my academic performance deteriorated considerably. It was only when my father directed me into a railway apprenticeship that I again started to take an interest in my studies.

The lesson to be learnt here is that once young people have prospects of employment their attitude, and particularly their attitude to study, improves. I believe the appropriate way to overcome youth unemployment is for the government to research the skill requirements of the future and then to fully finance four‐year apprenticeships in those skills in federal government departments, state government departments and appropriate private industry. I again refer to the youth employment report quoted earlier. In relation to skill shortages, the report said:

Despite this background of high unemployment and substantial structural change in the labour market, Australia continues to experience significant, and in some cases severe, skill shortages in some industries and occupations. Some submissions and presentations to the inquiry flagged prospective skill shortages in particular industries. The Committee sought further information from industry associations about current and prospective skill shortages but did not obtain many responses. What information is available, particularly on prospective shortages, does not cover a comprehensive range of occupational areas. It is a concern to the Committee that young people are not, in most cases, aware of the opportunities indicated by the available information.

The report goes on to refer to some 4,000 unfilled jobs Australia wide in the hotel industry and the acute shortage of some 1,000 chefs Australia wide. The report also found that there was a shortage of welders and other skills in rural areas of New South Wales, and some employers told of difficulties in filling apprenticeships and traineeships in some rural and remote areas. In the manufacturing industry, the MTIA has reported a wide range of skill shortages in occupations such as technicians, engineers, several trades and trades people with technical backgrounds.

As a constructive suggestion, what this government should be doing is matching these skill shortages with our school leavers and potential school leavers. I consider it soul destroying to force young people who have already made a decision to leave school back into the classroom. This move will cause enormous problems for the various education systems, with disruption in the classroom, and will require additional resources to educate the extra students. What this mean‐spirited government of bean counters seeks is a chance, by sleight of hand, to lower the unemployment figures by removing the income support for young people, forcing them back to school and then exclaiming, `Great. We have achieved our objective. A miracle has happened. Unemployment is down.'

I am advised that the government seems to be working from DEETYA advice on some sort of New South Wales data that appear to be flawed in three major areas. They have assumed that half of the current recipients, 15,000, will be exempt and therefore will not seek to re‐enter education and training. This would appear to be an overstatement. A better guesstimate, I am advised, would be closer to a quarter. The government has assumed that nine persons will return to the school system for every one to TAFE. Bearing in mind that many left school because of bad experiences, it must be highly questionable to now say that only 10 per cent would opt for TAFE. In fact, it is expected that up to some 65 per cent would rather go to TAFE than back to school.

The government has assumed that, by the withdrawal of social security benefits and the availability of Austudy, this will be a strong incentive for people to go back to school. However, for 18‐year‐olds this is now means tested, and many are likely to lose any entitlements to Austudy. Accepting that 15,000 young people between the ages of 15 and 19 will be affected by the Commonwealth changes in New South Wales, and assuming that two‐thirds return to study—and one-third do nothing—and that 65 per cent of these returnees go to TAFE and 35 per cent go to school, some 6,435 would be returning to TAFE and some 3,466 would be returning to school. This is in New South Wales.

Based on full-time attendance costs, these figures would mean an extra cost of $51.48 million for TAFE and an extra cost of $24.26 million for schools—a total of $75.74 million. All of this is going to place a severe strain on the funding of both schools and TAFEs in New South Wales. While the federal government is claiming that the cost will be only $36 million and New South Wales is claiming that it will be $75.74 million, it is obvious that there is going to be an unfunded cost to New South Wales.

With this change and the expected outcomes that will flow from this legislation in an economic sense, it seems quite peculiar for the government to then expect states to pick up the tab for policies over which they have no say or input. Sixteen‐year‐olds and 17-year-olds will be forced to stay at school or go back to school because they have no other income support options, and some will obviously be unruly and disruptive.

I am advised that within my electorate of Greenway some 308 children will be forced back into the school system. While this in itself may not seem a large figure, I am sure that, if I went to all the principals in my electorate collectively and said to them, `You have to find places for another 308 children,' they would collapse with fear. As we know, schools are already overcrowded. To take that argument a bit further, it is not only the kids who are affected but also the families. If you add to those 308 children the mothers and fathers who are also affected by this extra pressure, you are looking at close to 1,000 people who are affected directly and indirectly by this legislation within my own electorate of Greenway.

Receipt of income support should certainly be tied to a range of alternative activities—not just school education—which help young people to get work and reach their full potential. To abolish unemployment benefits while also slashing education opportunities is the wrong way to reform the welfare state. This is the negative approach of a government more concerned with winding back the role of government than creating new opportunities through the possibilities of education and training.

Young adults who are old enough to vote, to go to war, to get married—and many do the latter—and who are looking for work are clearly independent. They should not be forced by the imposition of a parental income, assets and actual means test to rely on their low income families for support. I believe young Australians who are looking for work should be encouraged to take up work opportunities by the restoration of the earnings credits scheme, mirroring the student income bank arrangements.

It should be noted that the government has failed to provide additional funding for sufficient relevant school and post‐school education. I emphasise that the ALP is determined to broaden the availability and range of opportunities in education and training, particularly for teenagers. The Howard government has quarantined some parts of the Commonwealth budget from funding cuts, but it is appalling that it has made education and training the major part of its fiscal consolidation program.

As stated earlier, with the introduction of this legislation called youth allowance—which is a misnomer; it should be called the youth non-allowance—an estimated 27,000 young people will be forced back to school next year. The impact of these new or ongoing enrolments will not be shared uniformly. They will be concentrated in areas of high unemployment, such as Prospect, Greenway, Chifley and other areas in western Sydney.

I urge the government to reinstate and expand the students at risk—STAR—program, which was specifically designed to identify and assist young people at risk of leaving school early. I urge the government to restore the specific equity programs for disadvantaged schools with a commitment of additional resources, specialised programs and Labor's initiative for a parents as educators program.

It is clear that many young people need counselling support from qualified psychiatrists available in and through the school to address their family and emotional difficulties and to encourage them to stay at school. They need proper work oriented careers education when they are at school. They need expanded work experience opportunities while there. They also need expanded school to work transitional programs which create pathways for them to enter the work force.

The government, for some unfathomable reason, gives some funding improvements for vocational education and training and then totally negates such actions by other government actions. It chops 117,000 places in labour market programs for young people and reduces case management for the young unemployed, adding chaos to the employment services market.

It is important to remember that early school leaving is also connected with homelessness amongst young people. Therefore, the level of resources for the job placement, employment and training program, which aims to help young people overcome problems preventing them from maintaining stable accommodation and entering into full-time education, training and employment, must be considered—I emphasise `must be considered'—as part of this debate.

The ongoing effects of this legislation will not only affect the 27,000 who are forced back to school; it will not only affect the many thousands of 18‐year‐olds and over and their parents who will be forced to take on the financial responsibility that many cannot afford; the ongoing effects of this legislation will also affect the thousands of young people who would always have intended to stay at school. Their lives and classes will be disrupted by unwilling participants. This must, in the long run, lead to a lowering of our educational achievements among young people, and it is another criticism of this legislation and this government.

We on this side of the parliament acknowledge that the learning needs of young Australians are exceptionally diverse. One of the challenges this government has is to cope with this diversity of our society, especially in the area of education and training. Clearly, one size no longer fits all the constructions of learning methods. But it is obvious from this legislation that the government simply has no idea and no care for young people. It adopts an ideological approach that says that all kids should be at school and, irrespective of the income of their parents, should stay at school and will not get any financial help from government in this time of massive unemployment.

The legislation continues to put in place a sad, uncaring policy that only has consideration for economic rationalist views of balancing budgets and never ever having the well off contribute to assist the not so well off. Who could have believed that a government that promised so much to the voters and received so much goodwill in the ballot box could have descended so low, so quickly and so permanently?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to support a reform that is long overdue in our social welfare system: the enactment of a single income support payment for our young people. After listening to the speech of the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield), I, like previous government speakers who have risen today, wonder exactly where the opposition are coming from in terms of their amendments to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 .

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the very things which they have argued this government is not doing are covered not only by this particular bill but also by other corresponding initiatives which this government has undertaken. That is the essence of it all. We on this side are looking at the solutions that our young kids are after—not in some form of compartmentalised nature, where one initiative in isolation from another will resolve the issues, but rather in the form of building on various initiatives which other ministers are also undertaking.

I refer specifically to the great initiatives that have been introduced by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) through the jobs pathway program and the one‐stop shops that have been successfully created in my electorate. I will speak more about that a little later.

I, along with the member for Greenway, was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. He and I certainly had some very good times as we moved around Australia listening to young kids. I know that he shares—as I and other members of the committee did at the time—the despair and the frustration which our young kids have today about their future. This bill is at the heart of what the kids are after.

The objectives of this bill are the simplification of the current system; increased flexibility for our young kids; and an investment in the future of these kids to provide them with the opportunity to invest in their future—something which is so highly demanded. It is interesting that the member for Greenway and I have reached different positions on this issue, even though we both listened to the same evidence, the same despair and the same frustration that took place—whether that was in metropolitan Australia or in rural and regional Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The common youth allowance recognises that young people's circumstances often change more rapidly than do the circumstances of people of my generation. They commence and finish study or training, they move in and out of work and, quite often, they juggle a combination of the two to get by. Sometimes they get sick and can neither work nor study. The bill we are debating today will provide for young people in all these circumstances, and it will make it easier for those who need financial support to receive it when they are moving from one to another. More importantly, it will leave 137,000 young Australians—or almost one in four young people on income support—better off than they are now. I emphasise that: better off than they are now.

As I have mentioned, the reasons for this reform are obvious: simplification, flexibility and investment. I want to expand on each one of those points in my contribution today. Firstly, on the surface we desperately need to simplify the complex web of payments available to young people and make it easier to get the support they need when their circumstances change. Under the current system, some payments have a qualifying or waiting period, while others take several weeks before the money starts to come through.

Under the youth allowance, five payments—Austudy, youth training allowance, newstart allowance, sickness allowance and some forms of family payment—will be rolled into one. The current 13 rates of pay applicable to people in varying circumstances will be simplified to just five—13 down to five—without ignoring the needs of disadvantaged people. There will be no waiting periods for young people who get sick or get better and start or finish study, training or job seeking.
Welfare organisations have lobbied hard for this simplification of the current system. A recent open letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) supported the concept of a youth allowance that:

. . . offers the opportunity to simplify aspects of the income support system, to remove anomalies in the treatment of unemployed young people and students, and to offer greater flexibility to pursue different pathways to employment and adulthood.

This letter was signed by representatives of Anglicare Australia, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Australian Education Union, Relationships Australia, the YMCA, the YWCA and 15 other community service organisations. Could they have all got it so wrong? While they have reservations about some aspects of the government's youth allowance structure—which I will address shortly—there is clearly widespread support for the basic thrust of this new system.

The open letter also raises a second factor behind the introduction of a common youth allowance: greater flexibility for our young adults. Times have changed since most honourable members grew up. Part-time work is more common, new career paths and forms of training have opened up and, perhaps more fundamentally, the vast majority of young Australians complete year 12 before leaving school. The increase in the number of students staying in school until year 12 has been phenomenal. From single figures in some states in the 1940s and 1950s, retention rates rose to 46 per cent in 1985 and now stand at about 73 per cent around the country.

Our increasingly complex and technological society is a partial explanation, as is the corresponding drop in the number of jobs previously done by unskilled labourers. More and more people are finding that they need specific training to find work at all. This means that many young people are still studying at an age when their parents were married and possibly even had a mortgage and children. The average age for first-time marriages is now close to 30 for both men and women—although in my case it was much older than that.

Another key change to our work force is the emergence of part-time work. Since January 1990 the number of full-time jobs in Australia has grown from 6.2 million to 6.3 million. Over the same period, the number of part-time jobs has boomed from 1.6 million to almost 2.2 million. So, for the 120,000 new full-time jobs created, another 600,000 part-time positions have also opened up. The Australian Council of Social Service says that these changes have been emerging over the past 20 years. In a discussion paper issued earlier this year, ACOSS reported:

The basic structure of the present system of youth payments was laid down in different circumstances to those faced by today's young people. Major changes in the labour market and in family relationships over the past two decades necessitate basic structural changes in youth payments. Further, the new system should be sufficiently flexible and robust to adjust to ongoing changes in the circumstances of young people.

There is widespread support for this bill not only from this side of the House but also by community groups—those community groups who traditionally have been reluctant to acknowledge the good work of this government. The government's new youth allowance meets all of these concerns. The bill is above all about flexibility. Young people who do not fit the so-called norm will be taken care of. Young people who complete year 12 at 16 or 17, as is common in most states, will be protected, as will students who are not able to study full time because of illness, disability or other trauma. Young people who cannot find full-time work and whose parents cannot afford to support them will be protected. For the first time the government will recognise that many young people take on responsibilities often shunned by adults and care for ill or frail parents or siblings. These people, too, will be supported through the youth allowance.

Perhaps one of the most important features of the common youth allowance is that it will stop giving our young people more money to be unemployed than to study. At present, young unemployed people receive up to $155 a fortnight more than their peers who are studying. One witness told the employment, education and training committee during our inquiry into youth unemployment:
The problem is that you cannot rely on people to work 40 hours a week for $220 when they can get $200 on the dole. That is one of the major problems.

This witness was a student from a New South Wales high school—not an adult, not an ideologue, not a member of the government, but a kid; one of those kids that are looking to a better future for themselves in terms of their career prospects. They can see the disincentive in the current system. Kids are looking for an opportunity to invest in their own future. They want the incentive to invest in their careers, education and skill development.

The current major disincentive to study is a legacy from the former Labor government—a government that was very fond of glib phrases about the clever country, but a government that also said to young people, `We will pay you more to be unemployed than to study,' `Improve your skills and help create that clever country,' or of course that ultimate promise, `You will never need to live in poverty.' Under the guise of being a paternalistic, caring, sharing government, it created in fact an environment that has potentially destroyed these kids' incentive and chances of having a meaningful long-term career. Our kids deserve better, not the platitudes they received for 13 years under Labor.

Because of the changes to our work force, it is now necessary for most people to undertake some kind of training or study. Unemployment among 19-year-olds is around 27 per cent for those who have left school early, compared to 18 per cent for those who completed secondary school. What is more, just seven per cent of 19-year-olds who have completed some form of further education or vocational training are unable to find work. Other studies show that young people who have not completed secondary school are twice as likely to remain out of work for a year or more than their high school graduate peers. This is why the government wants young people to obtain a certain level of education.

However, this government is also concerned with protecting needy students. There are young people who sometimes are forced out of study. We acknowledge that. Needy families in such circumstances will not be turned aside. The youth allowance will be available to 16- and 17-year-olds who are unable to study because of circumstances often out of their control—illness, homelessness, substance abuse, traumatic home circumstances, inability to secure an appropriate place in education at that time or some other exceptional circumstance. That is real protection for the needy, while at the same time creating the incentive to invest in their own future.

Labor brought this situation about, Labor allowed it to continue and opportunities for our young people have suffered as a result. But these kids which Labor abandoned will not be forgotten by us. They will be protected under our provisions. Importantly, homeless people, arguably the most disadvantaged in our society, will no longer be able to fall through the net as they do at the moment. Studies from both state wide and local organisations in my electorate of Deakin suggest that youth homelessness is a growing problem in Melbourne's outer east, with up to 500 young people homeless in our region at any one time. Homeless kids are 46 times more likely to try suicide than their peers, and almost all will smoke cigarettes, marijuana or both.

These are the people that governments are often accused of putting into the too‐hard basket. They will not be forgotten people under the youth allowance, with young homeless people eligible to receive up to $265 a fortnight, plus rent assistance of up to $98 a fortnight in some circumstances. I am also very proud that, under the Prime Minister's youth homelessness pilot project, in the eastern suburbs we have the Ringwood Extended Family Services, which, with a grant of $220,000, is actively working to help these young kids. This is the whole of government approach that I was talking about earlier on, rather than compartmentalising the responses that our community is seeking. The bottom line result is that the youth allowance will provide a much needed boost to thousands of lower to middle income families, not just those in the most traumatic circumstances.

The new income test, around $41,000 for families with one child at home, is more generous than Labor's $37,000 for the same family. We will also abolish the rule that cuts off Austudy for students entitled to less than $1,000 a year. It might seem like a small thing, a trivial amount; but ask a family earning less than $34,500—the current cut‐out for many families—whether an extra $20 a week will be welcome, and see what they say. What is more, once a student is entitled to Austudy, they also receive concessions for their health needs.

The new youth allowance also recognises that living away from home, whether to seek work or to study, costs the same for everyone. Up until now, under‐18s received less to live away from home than those aged 18 or over. I challenge anyone to demonstrate that a landlord, a utility company or a supermarket gives such a discount.

In the vast majority of cases, parents do have a responsibility to provide for their sons and daughters. Gone are the days when young Australians were working full time at 16 or 17, married by 21 and parents themselves soon after. It is no longer uncommon for people aged 18, 21 or even 25 to still be living at home and in full-time study. Many young people still live at home until they are married, but marry up to 10 years later than their parents did. In these cases the government believes that, if a family is affluent enough to support that son or daughter living at home, they have a responsibility to do so.

While it may sound harsh, the concept of parental responsibility versus parental self-interest must be clearly distinguished. The responsibility of parents who have the means does not end when their kids reach the age of consent, the age of being licensed to drive a car or the age when they can legally buy their first alcoholic drink. That is parenting through abdication. That is what the Labor government promoted, and we have made parenting by abdication rather than by responsibility a norm in our society. This scenario holds true for an increasing number of middle Australian families. But the government is also aware that in other families young people become independent much earlier because they are married, are living with a partner, have worked for a year or two before going back to study, or have supported themselves on a part-time wage for an extended period.

Allow me to give an anecdotal example of one of my constituents in terms of how this new youth allowance assists the independence which young kids are after. I recently came across a constituent, who we will call Anna. She is a 21-year-old nursing student. She has lived away from her parents since she was 16 because of irreconcilable problems at home. She spent over two years on the dole before deciding she wanted something better in life. She finished her VCE and began her nursing degree, assisted by the youth homeless rate of Austudy.

A little over a year ago Anna began living with her boyfriend, an apprentice. After they had been living together for a year, Anna told the Austudy office about her relationship, as she was required to do. Here her problems began. Anna was advised that, as she was living with her partner, she was not homeless anymore and that, because she was not 25 yet and had been on the dole for two years, not three, she was not considered independent yet. The Austudy office gave Anna a parental means‐test form to give to the parents, whom she had had virtually no contact with in six years, to see whether she was eligible for Austudy. They refused for the same reasons they had not supported her for the past six years—the abdication of parental responsibility. So her application was rejected.

I am sure honourable members would appreciate Anna's frustration. By her own admission, she could have lied about her boyfriend or dropped out—after all, the dole currently pays more than Austudy. But this articulate, determined young woman does not want to trade in her textbooks. She says that nobody is going to make her lower her standards or change her ambitions. Instead, Anna has paid her way this year by working a part-time job that brings in less than $100 a week. She earns so little that her earnings would not even affect her Austudy entitlement if she could receive it.

However, under the youth allowance, people in unusual circumstances like Anna's will no longer be allowed to fall through the holes in the safety net. Under the provisions being debated here, a de facto relationship of two years is regarded as grounds for independence from parental means. Under the new rules, Anna will be considered independent of her parents' means once she and her boyfriend have lived together for two years and because she has spent two years searching for work. I think most honourable members would agree that, after five years of support ing herself through job searching and study, this young lady is quite independent of her parents now and has been for some time.

Like 70,000 other students around the country, she will also become eligible for rent assistance for the first time under the common youth allowance—something which was not available under the previous Labor government. My constituent is just one of 137,000 young people who will receive more money under the youth allowance—more money, not less money, as the other side keeps claiming. For 67 per cent of young people on income support, payments will not change; but they will benefit from increased flexibility as they progress through study to seeking work and in the event that they fall ill. I am more convinced than ever that this long‐overdue reform will better look after young people in financial need, give them the opportunities to invest in their future and give them the flexibility that they are after in their careers. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speakers and other conservatives would have us believe that they have the power of divinity in creating loaves and fishes. They would have us believe that they can deliver savings measures through the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill and other cuts delivered in the last two budgets and, at the same time, improve the lot of young people who depend upon income support. Clearly that proposition is fallacious.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of conservatives in this debate have talked about the desire to stamp out dole bludgers. They have said that people do not want to work. The coalition would have us believe that unemployment is caused by the unemployed themselves. They ignore the fact that unemployment has got worse during the term of their office, and they now want to scapegoat the unemployed for the consequence of the last two budgets. That is what this legislation does.

Nearly one‐third of young people currently receiving income support will be worse off under the common youth allowance. It will slug low income families with unemployed kids living at home. It will make life a lot harder for the kids who cannot live at home. It will make many of them destitute. I have met a number of young people in my electorate who will be made destitute by this legislation explicitly.

The government heralded this package of changes by saying that it would simplify all of the payments which young people are eligible for—it will roll them into one payment. The common allowance is, of itself, not a bad thing. When it is attached to a savings measure, however, it becomes a problem. This legislation is a savings measure, despite coalition assertions to the contrary. The overall costs and savings for 1997-98 and the out years were not released with this legislation, as they usually would be. The government have already cut Austudy by half a billion dollars in the last budget. That is a fact that is not lost on the students of this nation.

The government confessed that around 11 per cent of young people will be completely cut off from support under the new arrangements. This is because all young people under 21 who would be entitled to payments under the current allowance conditions will be subject to parental means tests. The government's own figures indicate that 7,700 of those young people who will be cut off from income support live away from home—that is, they live without parental support and they will not be provided with support from the state. And yet coalition members come into this place and argue their attack on youth incomes is not a savings measure.

I turn to rent assistance. The bill introduces rent assistance for all independent students. This was not previously available under Austudy, that is true, however there have been cuts in other areas. In their announcements the government touted figures of up to $98.80 per week for rent assistance. However, in order to obtain this amount a young person would have to be a sole parent with three children. Not even the prodigious efforts of the Lyons Forum would see most young people falling into that category! Most people would be single and living in a group house, in which case they would be eligible for up to $50 per fortnight—just over half the maximum rate.

BREAK.PARA: There are a number of problems with the definition of homelessness in this legislation. One of the major difficulties in providing adequate income support for young people has been the definition of homelessness so that young people who are unable to live at home are not disadvantaged. Earlier this year I raised a number of issues relating to homeless students in my electorate who are unable to prove under the Austudy guidelines that they are genuinely homeless. Those guidelines were tightened so that the government could make good their half a billion dollar cut to Austudy. Indeed, I have been advised of cases where a young person has had an injunction order out on their parents arising from violence and Austudy has promptly turned around and told them that they do not fit the guidelines for being independent and that they will be assessed against their parents' income.

This government's safety net for the young homeless hardly exists. The government would rather force young people into less than satisfactory circumstances than support them through education and training or into employment. This proposal does not address the problems that have been previously identified in assessing young people as homeless. The criteria for homelessness are very strict. There are many young people who, for various reasons, cannot live with their parents. However, the government refuses to acknowledge these reasons and maintains that these people have `chosen' to live away from home, that people `choose' to have a life on the streets in preference to an idyllic family version.

Unfortunately, the reality for many young people in Australia is that the idyllic nuclear family that obviously a lot of coalition members have in mind simply does not exist and that they do not have a choice but to live away from home. That is why they live away from home. That is why they choose poverty over a home environment. It is the government's role to ensure that these young people complete their education or at least support them through their education and their efforts to get into employment.

Previously, those students assessed as not being homeless would not be eligible for Austudy. Many of these students would drop out of school because they could not afford to support themselves. Under the previous arrangements, if they tried to find work and were unsuccessful they could at least qualify for some assistance from the Commonwealth in the form of the youth training allowance or newstart allowance; that is, they would not be left utterly destitute. However, under the new arrangements they will get nothing because there is only one payment. Young people will fall through the cracks, and there will be no safety net underneath those cracks to pick them up if and when they fall through.

At best, a lot of these kids will get $72.50 a week, which will start to reduce once their parents' income reaches $23,350 per year. For a one-child family, the allowance will be cut out completely once the family income reaches $41,576 if the child lives at home or $58,791 if the child lives away from home. For young people under 18 who live away from home but whom the government refuses to recognise as being homeless, their income support will be paid to their parents. So, in the case of a number of young people in my electorate whom the government refuses to recognise as being homeless but who absolutely are homeless, the money will go to their parents. This means that, even if someone has good reason for not living at home, the government will maintain the fiction that they are at home and thereby leave them destitute.

If a young person is able to be assessed as being homeless, which is very difficult indeed, they would be entitled to $144.65 per week—nearly double the absolute maximum rate for those people whom the government refuses to acknowledge as being homeless, at $72.50 a week—nowhere near the $200 that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Barresi), talked about.

It is important to remember that the rate for a person assessed by the government as being homeless is not reduced according to the parental means test. I believe the parental means test is unfair. It is not fair to assess a young person's income support needs based on their parents' income when they are living away from their parents.

The Commonwealth definition of `independent' is very strict and will not be satisfied by a large number of young people currently living away from their parents. The Commonwealth has conceded this and has even put a figure on the number of people who will be knocked off benefit. The government estimates that 12,800 young people under 21 will no longer receive any form of income support because of the parental means test, and a further 33,960 will have their payments reduced once their family's income reaches $23,350 per annum.

The final effect of this means test is that nearly a third of the young people currently receiving income support will be worse off under the youth allowance. That is a country mile away from the sorts of figures that various government members were touting as evidence that lots of young people will be better off under this legislation. This is a budget savings measure. The government is making good on ripping income support from young people. It is nothing more than that.

In addition, the parental means test will be based on the Austudy means test—that means test created quite a few problems earlier this year; you might remember, Madam Deputy Speaker, the debacle with the government's previous means test—and will consist of a parental income test, a parental assets test and an actual means test. The latter test, the actual means test, is the same one which caused huge problems for students earlier this year and which was a complete embarrassment for the government. It meant that many young people did not take up their eligibility for places in education because they were told that they would not be eligible for income support. Later on, when the government changed its mind, they missed crucial enrolment points, had already withdrawn or would not be able to catch up on their studies. Many students did not get determinations until April—three months after the commencement of the academic year for secondary students.

So basically we have a situation where many homeless secondary students who were not granted homeless status by the government will have to complete their secondary studies with a maximum of $72.50 in their pockets per week. If they do not go to school they will get nothing, even if they are trying to find work. That is the bottom line of this legislation.

Also, they will not be eligible for rent assistance. For every dollar their parents earn over $23,350 per annum, their income will be reduced until it cuts out completely once their parents' combined income reaches $38,340. To make matters worse, the government will pay this money to their parents. It is just beyond comprehension how young homeless people will get that money when there has been a dramatic family breakdown.

Young people under 18 who do not have year 12 or the equivalent will be required to be in full-time education or training unless they are specifically exempted from this requirement and, if they are not, they get nothing. In the ACT we have one of the highest retention rates to year 12 in the country. However, there are some students in the ACT and in my electorate for whom year 12 is simply not appropriate. They do not want to be in the classroom. It is not appropriate that they be in the classroom. They would prefer other options, such as vocational education, apprenticeships and the like. Many people who do not complete year 12 as an 18-year-old go back and study later, when it is better for them to do so.

It is a cynical exercise to reduce unemployment statistics without creating jobs. That is, in large part, what forcing students back into year 12 when they do not want to be there is about. It is about taking over 33,000 out of the jobless statistics without creating any jobs. This is an utter smoke and mirrors trick.

Where is the extra funding for the education system to support those students? The government has made no provision for additional funding to assist these students, particularly those who must surely be assessed as having special need. Teachers and educational experts across the country have expressed grave concern about the impact this will have on the quality of education. They fear the impact on students who want to study by students who are forced to study.

The reduction in the amounts of money that students are able to earn will also create a lot of problems. There are explicit disincentives in this legislation for students to find part-time work. Remember that part-time work or any work for students, whether they be secondary or tertiary, is often seasonal in nature. That is why examining their income on a per annum rather than per fortnight basis is so important.

The proposed allowance will assess students' income on their gross income rather than their taxable income. This means that, for every dollar that students are able to earn over the tax threshold, they will lose some of their entitlements to income support without regard to any legitimate deductions that they may have.

The coalition, contrary to its rhetoric, wants to stop young people from working to their full capacity. Currently, students receiving Austudy are able to have their income assessed on their gross annual income and the entitlements over the year. This bill will see students' income assessed on a fortnightly basis, which will create very real problems given the seasonal nature of students' working lives. It means that a student who starts the year as qualifying for income support will not be able to earn more than $230 per fortnight before they start to lose their entitlement. But with the coalition's youth wage plans maybe that is not such a danger. We all know what the youth wage plans are. They were enunciated in Fightback in 1993, and they were brought out again and dusted off earlier this year.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) maintains that this will not be a problem as students will be able to accrue an income bank of $6,000 per annum so that when they earn less than $230 per fortnight they will be able to gain credit for weeks where their income is higher than $230 per fortnight. This will be a bureaucratic nightmare. There is no doubt about that.

However, the experience of many tertiary students is that the first two months of the year are the months where they are most able to maximise their income earning opportunities, as this is when more casual work is available and they are able to fit work in with their studies. Many students use these oppor tunities to finance their studies for the rest of the year. For many students who will qualify for the youth allowance for the first time when they enter tertiary education their first weeks of entitlement will be during January, a time of the year when income earning opportunities are nearly optimum for most. This means that a student qualifying for the youth allowance for the first time in January will have no income bank accrued and, if they earn more than $230 per fortnight during that month, their Austudy will be reduced, regardless of the fact that they may have little or no income earning opportunities later in the year.

The concept of an income bank is basically the same as the earnings credit scheme, which the government abolished last year because it was a failure, it was unworkable. This proposition of an earnings bank will similarly be unworkable and it will create an absolute bureaucratic mess at the start of the year, when students are on benefit, kicked off benefit and then have to reapply for benefit. Many of those students will arrive in backbenchers' offices to complain about the inadequacies of the Austudy system. In this legislation we have a disincentive for young people currently receiving income support to find work.

The proposed legislation has a provision to allow young people who were receiving income on or before 17 June 1997 to continue to receive that support through the implementation period and after 1 July 1998. This is reasonable as it ensures that the young people who are currently in receipt are not cut off. However, there are still some problems for the cohort of young people who are currently in receipt of income support. If a young person in receipt of income support gets a job before 1 July 1998, they will lose their entitlement to receive income support after 1 July 1998, unless they are able to maintain themselves in paid employment for 18 months. That is clearly impossible for the majority.

With the government's attack on security of tenure under the Workplace Relations Act, moves to contract work and the peeling away of protections against unfair dismissal, some young people may not be confident of holding a job for extended periods. The polls show that most people are concerned about security as the No. 1 issue. That is a pretty fair observation. Who can blame young people who believe that their best option for securing an income to feed, shelter and clothe themselves is to stay on income support when the government introduces such a bureaucratic, complex nightmare where you are kicked on benefits, kicked off benefits and have to reapply to get back on benefits—and around the merry-go-round we go?

Essentially, the government is implementing this ideological agenda that assumes most families in Australia provide good support for their offspring and that there are a couple of minor exceptions to that—and they have some policies characterised in this legislation to take care of the so-called homeless. But the reality is that most homeless students will not be caught by the safety net of this legislation. That is a real problem for us.

The contention of the government that this is not a savings measure, that they are making the lives of young people better with this legislation, is extremely difficult to contemplate when it is a savings measure, when there are real dollars being ripped out of income support by this legislation and by the budget. Coalition members cannot continue to pretend that they are delivering the loaves and fishes for young people. They clearly are not.

Let us return to some of the assumptions enunciated by previous speakers on the coalition side where they talked about getting the dole bludgers. The challenge for government has to be to stimulate jobs growth. It has to be about providing employment opportunities for those who want them and supporting them through the education systems so they are able to secure employment opportunities that are available. The priority of government should not be about making young people scapegoats, ripping income support away from them and pretending that young people do not want to work to cover up the government's own inadequacies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman, Lou, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting legislation which at last tackles the huge problems in Australia dealing with the myriad of policies of previous governments that dealt with youth and family allowances and support systems. The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill legislation introduces a very courageous and appropriate reform of the wide range of confusing and often conflicting allowances, which were often embedded with great anomalies, across Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of those allowances worked against the interests of young people and families and created much resentment and antagonism—even between families in the one community who saw their next‐door neighbours receiving allowances—and set up controversy and rivalry. Unfortunately, in the last few years, the allowances even promoted cheating and people said, `Well, if they're getting an allowance next door, then we want it too and we will cheat to get it.' That is a fact of life, and honourable members of the opposition should acknowledge that.

The youth allowance policy is one of a number of measures which will be designed to tackle some very serious problems in this country. We inherited from the last government's bad policies—in some cases because of economic change and social change in this nation—unacceptable levels of youth unemployment. It is our responsibility in government to do all we can to tackle some of the problems causing youth unemployment. One of those is that there has been in Australia too many young people leaving secondary schools in Australia before attaining adequate training and education up to year 12. We all know that by obtaining a good sound secondary education young people will be better equipped to get employment in Australia and the rest of the world.

Thirty per cent of our young unemployed people can be directly traced as people who have left school early and not completed their secondary education. They then find that they cannot get work because they are not adequately educated and trained and become very depressed. Regretfully in Australia we have a terrible youth suicide toll, particularly in country Australia. I know these things; you know them. We are all members of parliament, and we have to see them too often. I have had people come into my office for many months and years asking that the parliament address these issues. This legislation simplifies the youth allowances and treats young people the same way and gives them the same incentives and encouragement.

Let me give some examples of what will happen. As a member representing a part of regional Australia, I and a number of other members have fought for years to assist families with young students going away for further education—to Melbourne, Sydney or wherever else—because there is not a university or training facility available in the country or region, to get some further assistance on top of Austudy for their accommodation. I am delighted to see that the work of my colleagues—and perhaps to some small extent my own—has brought about in the new government a willingness to introduce from 1 July next year rent assistance for eligible students from country towns in my electorate and elsewhere in Australia who go away to pursue their further studies.

That is a fantastic reform. I am sure that even members of the opposition know in their hearts that it is going to be a tremendous help. It is a great burden for families in country areas to bring up their children in the home, still have children in secondary and primary schools and have one of their children, or in some cases two or three of their children, finishing secondary and wanting to go on to university and other studies away. Families have been doing without in many cases—and I know many of them—in order to cope with the extra costs their family incurs to provide for the board, lodging and rent of their student children in the capital cities. Being a father myself and having had children go away to receive their university and other education after secondary school, I have some idea of the huge financial burden that country parents and families have to bear.

This legislation provides a rent assistance program to eligible students, and it is a wonderful reform. What it also does is make it less attractive for young people to give up secondary school. Many of us know—as parents or as friends of those with children—that there have been instances in Australia where young people have come home to their parents and said, `Mum, Dad, we're leaving school. We're not staying on. Furthermore, if you don't let us do what we want, we know that we can access, if we leave home, certain support allowances and even apply for the dole.' Fortunately, that did not happen in my case. Although I do remember my eldest son saying that he wanted to join the police force—he thought that was better. But he was four years too young anyway. We had to persuade him to stay on at school—and he did, thank goodness.

We also know that, in some cases, students in Australia have been saying for a long while—and we have all heard it; be honest—with the pressure and stresses of study and the commitment and sacrifices students have to make, `It's not really worth me putting effort into my studies and giving up the good life and the other things I see some of my friends enjoying. After all, their unemployment benefit allowances are more than I get if I am a student.' Students on Austudy or part Austudy have often said that. We know that is the case. There are a large number of young people who have actually dropped out of school and, unfortunately, put pressure on their families, challenged their families, and gone out and gone on welfare support and gone on to become long-term unemployed—not all, but a lot. That has to be addressed in Australia.

This youth allowance policy will encourage students who are so inclined to stay at school and help them. This policy is not our only policy to address these problems. For example, we are implementing in secondary schools across Australia the very new apprenticeship and training programs, which I have been associated with for a long while now. We are going to introduce more interesting and challenging curriculum choices in secondary schools. Seventy per cent of secondary students in Australia do not wish to pursue university education because, in many cases, they have found the curriculum not challenging and engaging and thus lose interest in school.

Next year we will introduce vocational education and training policies where students can start their apprenticeship training while at secondary school. So when they stay on and are stimulated by this, they will be able to do work experience during their holidays and get experience with tradespeople, make contacts and friends for the future. When they graduate in year 12, their certificate will show that they are partly qualified in their apprenticeship training.

So when they go and ask for an apprenticeship opportunity with businesses—small business and medium sized enterprise in Australia particularly—they will be much more attractive to the small business because they will have part qualifications in their VCE certificate for their training and they will also have shown a commitment because they will have achieved. This is a fantastic policy. It is part of the whole refreshing approach of this government to youth policy and improves our performance in education and training and tackles the problem of long-term youth unemployment in Australia.

We will also be introducing the very interesting program where schools will become involved in employment programs through the jobs pathway program. I had the pleasure of launching a program, which involved 11 secondary schools in my electorate, the other day where the Albury‐Wodonga Continuing Education Centre as the broker, with a number of schools in my electorate, will work with schools to help the students find a pathway from school into employment. I recommend members have a read of those policies because they are fantastic policies. There is a lot of enthusiasm about this policy. In fact, I have had schools ring me and say, `Lou, we weren't included in those 11 schools. How can we get into the list?' I have told them that they can apply in the next round. That is an indication of the enthusiasm that is coming about in this country due to these reforms.

I want to also say that an estimate of 70,000 young students will benefit from this legislation by becoming eligible for the rent assistance I referred to earlier in my contribution, which means an average of an extra $31 per fortnight in many cases. We are also improving some of the Austudy allowances that are available to our young students in Australia. For example, 41,000 students will benefit from the abolition of the $1,000 per annum Austudy minimum entitlement requirement. It was a stupid anomaly that should never have been there and it has been removed.

Sixteen thousand students will benefit from independence criteria, which are more lenient than those which currently apply when seeking Austudy under the age of 25 and 19,900 former students will gain from the abolition of the education leave awaiting period. Time does not give me the opportunity to explain fully those matters, but members can obtain details of those policies. Above all, many parents will find with the family allowances that they will also be able to better cope with the costs of bringing up young children while they are still at secondary school.

The youth policies deserve the full support of all members. I noted with interest a lot of the comments of members of the opposition. They seem to be wanting to support it, but they have obviously been restrained somewhat by their shadow minister for education and youth affairs, who wants to grandstand and appear to be taking some different role in this matter.

I would just say to members of the opposition: give the government a go. Do not frustrate this legislation. You had 13 years in government and you failed miserably. We have the worst unemployment level for young people in Australia. We have an unacceptable number of young people leaving secondary school before attaining year 12. We had a very low performance level in apprenticeships. In fact, the Labor government has almost destroyed the apprenticeship system in Australia.

I say to the Labor opposition: get out of the road, you had your chance and you blew it. The government deserves the opportunity to implement programs for our young people—our greatest asset in this nation. We want to see those programs available to them from the new year so there is no further delay in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister still stand by his view that Campbelltown Telstra workers, Rebecca Trichter and Kylie Neal, are reminders that he is more in touch with traditional people when today's Daily Telegraph reports Kylie as saying that while she voted for him at the last election she honestly thinks she made a big mistake?

—I do because what the Leader of the Opposition did not do in his question was to quote the other part of the article, the part of the article where one of the young ladies in question said that it was absolutely terrific that people could own shares in the company they work for. She went on to say that it was absolutely outstanding that she had an opportunity to buy the shares. In other words, nothing alters the fact and nothing can alter the fact that the sale of shares in Telstra has been a resounding success, and 92 per cent of the employees of Telstra have bought shares. That is a thumping endorsement of the policies of the Howard government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Sport and Tourism. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the press reports today regarding Athletics Australia's coaching appointee, Dr Ekkart Arbeit? What is the minister's reaction to the claims that Dr Arbeit's contract may have to be paid out with taxpayers' money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson, Andrew, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport and Tourism;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. Yes, I did see this morning's newspaper reports of fresh revelations apparently from files released from the former Republic of East Germany. Some of the allegations in them are very disturbing, not to say very lurid. The House will be aware that the review on foot, established by Athletics Australia, has terms of reference. This is a review that is independent of government. But, that said, I would like to state once again that this government is committed to Australian sport not only being drug‐free but being seen to be drug‐free. In these circumstances, it is important to examine some of the facts of this case.

ANSWER.PARA: The first of those is that no appointment has been made. I am advised that there is no contract between Dr Arbeit and Athletics Australia and that therefore the issue of termination of any such contract simply does not arise. But when you look, more importantly, at the terms of reference of the review, the fourth element of those terms of reference has it that the review shall take into account any substantiated evidence coming to light about Arbeit and recommend whether he would be an appropriate person to fulfil the position of director of coaching.

In the light of these allegations this morning, it is plain that Athletics Australia, in their review, have a responsibility to take into account in their assessment of that element of the terms of reference any of these apparent facts that have come to light this morning. I have asked the Australian Sports Commission, through its chief executive whom I met this morning, to make it clear to Athletics Australia that, in the interests of both the athletes of Australia and the reputation of Australia, there be a prompt resolution of this matter.

I have also made it clear that no taxpayers' money will be used in the employment of any individual whose presence is contrary to the government's position on drug‐free sport. Further, no taxpayers' funds will be used in the unlikely event of any payout being made to Dr Arbeit should the review find against him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister that yesterday he dismissed expert advice about the dangers of switching between anti‐depression drugs as `insubstantial' and described his higher drug charges as `fair' and `responsible'.
—No, I did not.

—Prime Minister, have you changed your mind in the last 24 hours or were you unaware that your health minister was about to announce the second major backdown on your dangerous and unfair pharmaceutical policy by exempting these very drugs—the anti‐depression drugs—because he has been forced to accept that these drugs are not of equal clinical value?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recollect saying the first bit attributed to me, but I will have a look at the Hansard record. I do recollect saying to the House that the member who has just asked the question had a lot of things to say about how desirable it was not to allow the thing to get out of control. He also said that it was important to remember that four years ago this country allocated $500 million in taxpayers' money to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and in the last financial year the allocation was more than $1 billion.
—I raise a point of order on relevance. The question was not about generic drugs; it was about whether the Prime Minister knew his health minister was about to announce another backdown.
—There is no point of order and I remind the honourable member for Dobell about my cautions to members yesterday about frivolous points of order.

—And, of course, the member who has asked the question was not alone in 1990 because, at that particular time, Senator Richardson weighed into the argument. Senator Richardson seems to be weighing into a lot of arguments lately, including arguments on native title. This is what Senator Richardson had to say in 1990:

ANSWER.PARA: No government could responsibly continue the PBS in its current form in the face of the fact that the cost of the scheme has doubled in the last four years and was to have doubled again over the next three years. The survival of the scheme depended on action to rein in these escalating costs.
Once again, whatever it takes—one argument in government; a totally different one in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, can you advise the House of the impact that the secondary and primary boycott provisions of the Workplace Relations Act have had in the workplace since its introduction? Are you aware of any plans to change these provisions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Macquarie for his question. I am aware that the Labor Party's recently announced policy proposes the abolition of the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act. It is a quite incredible proposition when you think of the implications of this policy from the Labor Party.
