You only have to look back over the last six or 12 months to see the operation of the secondary boycotts part of the Trade Practices Act, discouraging people from taking unreasonable industrial action which otherwise would be at great cost to export income and to jobs in the Australian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: It was only the other day in the coal industry that the expected 72-hour national industrial action to be taken by the CFMEU was shortcut by the fact that they knew that they would be facing a section 45D action if they did so. As a result, we preserved jobs and preserved export income for Australians, including rank and file members of the CFMEU. It is only this year that we had the Transport Workers Union going off to the Industrial Relations Commission after having done a deal with some big employers trying to use the Industrial Relations Commission to force big pay increases on small operators in the transport business, which would have meant increased costs right across regional Australia, both in businesses and in living costs. That was defeated by the Industrial Relations Commission.

We have since seen the TWU run an industrial campaign by way of secondary boycotts against a whole raft of small and medium sized businesses. Fortunately, because of the operation of the Trade Practices Act, the ACCC has been able to come in on behalf of small business and take legal action to prevent the thuggery of the TWU.

These people in their policy want to give a green light to unlawful illegal industrial action. If you want a classic case not just from the last 12 months since we have been in office and since these provisions have been in effect, go back to the time when Labor was in office and they were trying to sell ANL. This country had to suffer a week of industrial action by the MUA preventing the then government of the day fulfilling and implementing a policy it had outlined. The reason it was unable to do so was because the MUA was running secondary boycotts all around the country, again at the cost of Australian jobs and at the cost of Australian exports. Now these people have the cheek and the gall to suggest that we would be better off if we repealed the secondary boycott provisions.

Lastly, the other point to be made about secondary boycott provisions is that they discourage more strike action. Before we were elected, the Labor Party was saying, `Well, if the coalition gets in, there will be a third world war and a lot of industrial strife.' Has there been more industrial strife? No. If anything, there has been less. The figures that came out yesterday showed that rather than there being industrial chaos and mayhem, the reality is that these provisions and others that we have introduced have discouraged illegal industrial action and have worked towards a much more cooperative attitude in the workplace. This is a crazy policy that the Labor Party has announced. They deserve to be condemned from one end of the country to the other.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that a nursing home in a Melbourne suburb was officially opened and blessed by the Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne, Dr George Pell, this morning? Is the minister also aware that the Villa Maria Society in charge of the home said today that the opening ceremony would be `a Clayton's affair because of the Prime Minister's recent changes to nursing homes that have led to so much confusion?'

QUESTION.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Members on my right!

—Because of this confusion, the society has been forced to renege on places for 18 of the 20 applicants for the nursing home. Is the Prime Minister aware that at the opening Archbishop Pell said that he fully supports the Australian Catholic Health Care Association's position on aged care, which is that reforms should be driven by access to care for the frailest and sickest, not the government's bottom line? When will you truly listen and scrap this nursing home policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not examined those reports, but I will. I say to the Leader of the Opposition: are you now in favour of accommodation bonds? It would appear that the Leader of the Opposition wants us to go back.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no, you want us to go back to the accommodation bonds system, do you?
—No! N‐O!
—I warn the member for Hotham.

—You want us to go back to the former policy. I say again to the House that we are in favour of a system that is driven by a concern for the disadvantaged in the Australian community. In relation to the comments attributed to His Grace, the Archbishop of Melbourne, it is a very sound principle that the concern for the disadvantaged ought to drive this system. It is precisely because of that that we have adopted the very fair principle that those who can afford to make a contribution to their care should do so.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Recent surveys by the Australian Stock Exchange show that Australia has a large and growing spread of share ownership. Can the Treasurer advise the House how this trend has increased following the listing of Telstra? Can the Treasurer further advise the House as to the cultural and economic implications for Australia as a result of average Australian citizens owning our businesses and our industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for La Trobe for his question. I know how much he has an interest in employee share ownership schemes and the profitability of the Australian business sector. Probably all Australians will be glad that Telstra has now been floated with such overwhelming support from the Australian public, with nearly five times the subscription applications than the number of shares on offer. Nearly 1.8 million Australians wanted to be part of this and 92 per cent of Telstra employees tried to be part of it. I think all Australians will be happy, possibly with the exception of the Australian Labor Party. Good news for Australia, bad news for the Australian Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the estimates that was given out by the Australian Stock Exchange was that maybe 300,000 new shareholders have begun to own shares in Australian equities as a result of the Telstra privatisation. The Australian Stock Exchange estimates that this may well have taken Australian direct share ownership to 22 per cent and indirect share ownership to 36 per cent. That would in world terms be quite high, certainly of the level of the UK, higher than Canada and maybe a little less than the United States—one of the highest in the OECD.

This fits in well with the government's plan to encourage employee share ownership plans. In our first budget, we changed the tax law to encourage employee share ownership plans by lifting the tax exemption from $500 to $1,000 a year. The coalition believes that it is important for employers and employees to work together and for employees to have a stake in the financial enterprise of their business and the opportunity to participate in equity in those ways. That is why I leapt for joy when I saw the ALP platform in relation to industrial relations. It contained this statement:
Workers must be able to participate in and share the benefits of the success of the enterprise or industry for which they work.
There it is—in the ALP platform. I looked for an asterisk that would say `except workers at Telstra', but there is none. I repeat the statement:
Workers must be able to participate in and share the benefits of the success of the enterprise or industry for which they work.
Why would an Australian Labor Party, if it believed in that, deny Telstra employees the opportunity to participate in the success of their enterprise? Why would it?

TALK.START.PARA: —They owned it already.

—Ah! One of the thinkers of the socialist left interjects, `because they owned it already.' They did. Just as they owned the Commonwealth Bank; just as they owned Qantas—all of those great shibboleths of the Australian Labor Party which you decided to sell back in the days when you had a policy. Here we have a completely opportunistic opposition. They could not take a serious decision if their life depended on it. They would, if they had the opportunity, throw the budget back into deficit, run up debt, turn the clock back on industrial relations, run up interest rates and operate a nationalised phone company.

ANSWER.PARA: As one of the serious thinkers of the left said of the Australian Labor Party, `A trip down memory lane with Pauline Hanson'—back to the nationalised telephone companies, away from industrial relations reform, turning their back on productivity improvement, no to taxation reform, against productivity increases, against budget repair, against lower interest rates, against the monetary target—a complete band of opportunists who live by one credo `whatever it takes'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware that some parents are paying up to $9,000 a year for child care, more than the cost of some top private schools? Does the minister realise that these high child‐care fees are taking away choices from Australian families? Is this part of the government's cradle to grave attack on Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's question is indeed surprising, because it was only in this House yesterday that the new Child Care Payments Bill, which was subject to detailed consultation with the child‐care sector in this country, was passed with amendments from the Senate with the support of the Labor Party. The new major changes to child‐care payments arrangements in this country were passed yesterday with the support of the Labor Party. The reason the bill was passed is that it gives $4.9 billion over four years for child‐care assistance in this country; an extra 83,000 places over four years for additional child‐care places in this country; a $1.2 billion allocation this year, which is an increase of 18 per cent over two years; a school‐age care policy with an increase of $11 million over four years; better planning—I heard the shadow minister herself say that the better planning processes were absolutely necessary for future stability in the child‐care industry in this community—and continued commitment to quality. These are the issues that are important.

ANSWER.PARA: The concerns that she has related are matters that were raised yesterday regarding a survey conducted at the New South Wales government's expense. It was a survey for half a day: if you have a problem, ring up Bob Carr so he can stand up on the evening television and make a big person of himself.

You know that the child‐care payments legislation passed was far better for this nation than what you did. You had 13 years to deal with these issues and you did not do that. You ignored it. This is part of your approach to politics in this country—now we are going to pick on the children.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Can the minister provide the House with details of trading in Telstra shares since they were listed on Monday? Can the minister also inform the House as to what information is being provided to retail investors about their shareholding?

—I am sure all honourable members of the House along with the honourable member for Stirling would be interested to see the activities that have occurred on the stock exchange since Telstra was listed on Monday. Trading amounted to about 308 million shares on Monday and about 260 million shares on Tuesday. There seems to be some slackening, as is expected, some stabilisation, and at about 1.30 today about 78 million shares were traded.

BREAK.PARA: I have seen a considerable amount of speculation as to who was involved in the buying and selling of these shares in the initial period after the listing. One thing I do know is that a number of the trade union investment funds have invested in the Telstra shares.

Notwithstanding the fact that the Labor Party did not want the Australian people, including trade unionists, to acquire shares in this great Australian company, and notwithstanding the fact that Telstra employees—all 92 per cent of them who are eligible—invested in this particular offer, we have seen the trade union movement, on behalf of its members, whom the ALP purports to represent, investing in a significant fashion. In fact, I think in the top 20, at about No. 3, is Axiom, which is the New South Wales public sector superannuation fund, now in private hands.
They know, for the benefit of their members, that this is a good investment. They know that privatisation very much assists the way in which this country can expand.

What we now have is total confusion in the Labor ranks on privatisation. We see that the Labor Party here in Canberra, despite what it said in government, is now opposing all privatisation. It sought to stop the sale of one-third of Telstra, despite the fact that the unionists and employees wanted those shares.

Also, the New South Wales government wants to sell off the power generation in that state. Who is opposing it? The trade union movement. Of course, we know that most of the decisions here that have been taken on privatisation come from the fact that there is now some Democrats infiltration into the ranks of the Labor Party, and we know that they oppose privatisation at all times.
It would probably help members opposite to avoid this confusion, to overcome this difficulty, if I referred them to the editorial in today's Australian. It stated:
. . . there is compelling evidence that the Australian capital market is now sufficiently sophisticated to fund essential infrastructure.
That could have been a quote from the current Leader of the Opposition a couple of years ago. He said those sorts of things on a regular basis. The editorial went on to say:
The Australian believes governments do not have the intrinsic capacity to manage infrastructure assets more efficiently than the private sector.
Of course, before Telstra went to the market, we had the Labor Party telling all who wanted to listen to them that the Australian capital markets would not be able to absorb one-third of Telstra.

Just to overcome any difficulties that might exist, whilst I have the Australian editorial in front of me let me go on to say what it said about the way in which this particular float occurred on Monday under the guidance of the government. It said:
. . . evidence of Monday's float shows it got the Telstra listing parameters just about right.

I go to the second part of the honourable member's question. Considerable information will be mailed to all retail investors on 1 and 2 December. That information will contain relevant details about the instalment receipts. There will also be an information sheet which will respond to the questions that were most asked through the telephone share information centre.

Anyone who has shares—the 1.9 million small Australian investors—and who is seeking information at this stage can obtain that by telephoning the Telstra share information centre on 1800 18 18 18. We have already put full advertisements in newspapers around the country. The refund cheques will also be sent—that is, the cheques for those amounts that were not able to be satisfied from those small investors.

We know that 75 per cent of all small Australian investors got what they asked for—up to 2,000 shares and 20 per cent of the residue. I inform those members of the Labor Party who I am sure have purchased Telstra shares that, just before I came into question time, the shares were trading at $2.57.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and concerns the matter of Robert `Dolly' Dunn.
—Oh!

—May well you `oh'. Attorney, yesterday you told the House that normal processes were followed by the Australian Federal Police and your department. But it was the 60 Minutes TV crew that took a punt to find Dunn. Attorney, did it ever occur to you to follow Dunn's money trail? Is it a fact that for nearly all the period he remained at large, including his time in Honduras, Dunn was in receipt of an Australian pension paid to him in his own name?

—The member for Banks knows full well, as I have already explained yesterday, that in matters relating to police operations details are not offered. They have not been offered by anybody occupying my office as a predecessor or as a Minister for Justice. I am not going to break that principle; it is a very good principle that is not going to help fugitives escape. There is a whole range of steps taken in the course of any police investigation; there are special steps taken when somebody is overseas and there are even more special steps taken when they are overseas and not staying in one country but moving from one to another. I am not going to detail what happened in this particular case while matters are still before the court and we have not even completed the extradition proceedings from the United States.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, the ACTU has, over several years, attempted to force subcontractors to become union members. What would be the impact on the housing sector within the economy if subcontractors were forced to become union members?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. It is a very serious matter that the Labor Party is now proposing reforms to the industrial relations system that will have a very serious impact on the housing industry and the nature of employment in the housing industry. This country has, for residential purposes, a very efficient and highly competitive housing industry which has meant that many more Australians have been able to enjoy their own home.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party, in its recent policy announcements, announced that:
. . . the protections of the industrial relations system should be extended beyond a narrow definition of employees to include those in employment‐type relationships.

This is an old favourite within the Labor Party. They basically want to take people who are independent—small business people working on their own—and force them, through the award system, to be employees and thus within the reach of the trade union movement.

It is a step basically to coerce people into the trade union movement and to overturn what has been a tremendously successful system for the benefit of literally hundreds of thousands of Australians. This policy of theirs, which also includes the abolition of the Employment Advocate, removes one of the protections that we built into the system so that, if you are being bludgeoned or coerced by a union to join a union, there is a government body to whom you can go and it can give you some protection.

What does the Labor Party want to do? They want to abolish the protection! Why do they want to do it? Because the CFMEU, which has got a very strong grip on the commercial building sector, wants to be able to widen its reach into the residential sector, to the cost of every Australian family. This proposal would crush any sense of initiative and entrepreneurial flair which we have in the building industry; it is the modern day equivalent of press‐ganging.

The consequences of this so‐called reform are very grave indeed. We have been in communication with the Housing Industry Association. This is not a new issue to them because they have been fighting Labor Party proposals similar to this one for years. They have given us some figures which give you a sense of the extent to which the subcontracting system in Australia would be affected. They make the point that in this industry alone this proposal could directly affect something like 140,000 people. In terms of the costs which could be imposed on the building industry, this is what they have said to me in a fax which we received yesterday:

Labour costs in the housing sector would rise by up to 30 per cent through the application to trade contractors of award conditions and other industrial add‐ons mandated by unions such as C+BUS and ACIRT, without any offsetting productivity gains.
They also said:

As labour costs represent about 50 per cent of the cost of a new house, this would push up the cost of an average house by $18,000 (30 per cent of 50 per cent of $120,000 being the house component of a typical $220,000 house and land package).

This brings home to ordinary Australians the potential impact of this crazy policy. The subcontractors in the housing industry of Australia have done a fantastic job for Australian families. It is a great system. In that industry, it is the heart and soul, if you like, of small business and all that the small business community represents to this country. You in the opposition have announced a policy which is basically to undermine, to erode and to set the trade union leadership on to these good Australians who are doing a great job for our country. You deserve to be condemned for this. This is a mad policy, a crazy policy, that all Australians who want to own their own home or want to add on to the home that they have got will roundly condemn. I say that on this issue alone this government will campaign all the way to the next election, whenever it is, and you will regret the day such a policy was ever announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. It follows the question just asked of the Attorney‐General and the circumstances of the Attorney‐General's answer and that of, in the strange vicissitudes of his representative in the Senate, the Minister for Justice. Will the Prime Minister now concede that the time has come for an appropriate public inquiry into this matter?
—No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Can the minister advise the House of progress with agency bargaining in the Australian Public Service and confirm the certification in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission of an agreement covering Centrelink staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for her question. The House would be aware that Centrelink is the government's new one‐stop shop for services from five Commonwealth government departments, including the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service. The aim of Centrelink is to provide services that are easy to use and much simpler to access by members of the public.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform the House that yesterday the Australian Industrial Relations Commission certified an agreement for the 26,000 staff of Centrelink. The staff of Centrelink make up 20 per cent of the total APS.

The agreement is a win for employees, it is a win for the employer, Centrelink, and, most importantly, it is a win for the clients of Centrelink. What this means is that clients—members of the public—will be able to access services from Centrelink after hours and on weekends. This confirms the government's commitment to providing better service to the general community. This is the object of the Public Service reforms which are being promoted by the government: to ensure that members of the public get the kind of service from government agencies that they are entitled to.

I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate all those involved in the development of this agreement, an agreement which has been overwhelmingly endorsed by some 75 per cent of Centrelink staff. It provides for an overall pay increase for staff and for the simplification of allowances. Above all—and this is very important—it provides a family friendly environment which facilitates part‐time work for flexibility and provides a school holiday care subsidy.More flexible hours is an example of the innovations in service delivery to the community which Centrelink is pioneering.

I think members of the public have already been impressed that when they walk in the door they are now frequently greeted by name because they have been able to make an appointment and there is a staff member there waiting to receive them and provide them with services. There is a focus within Centrelink on providing clients with decisions on the spot rather than forcing them to wait for months. One of the indicators of the importance that is being placed on client service provision is the fact that some 1,200 of the most experienced officers in the agency have been put on the front desk to serve clients.

This is an example of the new Public Service, which the government strongly supports. It is there to serve the public. It is a Public Service which will be greatly enhanced by the new Public Service legislation which is now in the Senate. It is deeply regrettable that the Australian Labor Party is taking such a negative attitude to improving service to the public in this legislation by the amendments that it is using in the Senate. But this government is going to continue to persist in ensuring that government services are there for the general public of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Malawi, led by the honourable speaker. On behalf of the House, I extend to you a very warm welcome to Australia.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the foreign minister. Can the foreign minister explain why it is in the national interest for Australia to provide foreign aid to countries which have promoted military officers responsible for the murder of Australian citizens, as in the case of the Indonesian army officers who killed Australian journalists in East Timor and in the case of the former Khmer Rouge officer whose troops murdered David Wilson in Cambodia? How does this contrast with the reactions of the governments of the United Kingdom and the USA following the murder of a British policewoman by a Libyan embassy official and the promotion by Colonel Gaddafi of military officers responsible for the Lockerbie bombing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the honourable member for Oxley's basic view of the world is that we should disengage from it almost totally and become a country in complete isolation from the rest of the world and the universe, but that is not a proposition. I also appreciate that the member for Oxley is totally opposed to Australian foreign aid, with the sole exception of North Korea as I understand it, from a press release she put out calling for more aid to be given to North Korea. Why the member for Oxley should be so interested in North Korea and nowhere else, I am not sure. If the member for Oxley is so concerned about linking human rights with aid—and I will come back to that—you might like to reflect on why you are so much in favour of giving aid to North Korea, which is not a country with an astounding record on human rights.

ANSWER.PARA: But the government does not link human rights to development assistance. There are exceptions to that, but in the normal course of events we do not do that. The reason we do not do that is that this country provides development assistance essentially for humanitarian reasons.

In the case, for example, of aid to Indonesia, we provide aid to Indonesia. That aid is concentrated significantly in the eastern part of Indonesia. The member for Oxley might be interested to know that the average per capita income in Indonesia is somewhere, I think, off the top of my head, in the vicinity of six per cent of the average per capita income in this country.

I think I probably reflect the views of the vast majority of Australians when I say that in this country not only do we believe we have a moral obligation to assist people around the world in need as best we can—and we happen to think that is not a bad thing to do—but also we think that as a country it is in our national interest to be seen to be doing so and to be improving living standards in countries like Indonesia and Cambodia, which you mentioned. We happen to think that is in the national interest in this country, and morally we are proud of the fact we do that. You may not like that, but, when it comes to morality, I do not put you on a pedestal.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Alex for PM! I won't refer to your stockings again, Alex.
—I warn the member for Batman.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Could the minister advise the House of the signifi cance of the historic rail agreement reached with the state transport ministers last Friday. How will this lead to continuing reform and growth in the Australian rail industry and how does it contrast to the mismanagement of Australia's rail industry under the previous Labor government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable for Hinkler for his question. We should note the interest of the member in the rail industry in Australia. I will answer the last part of the question first in regard to how that contrasts with the Labor Party's record on rail. They were never able to achieve this sort of an agreement with the states, whereas the Howard/Fischer government has.

ANSWER.PARA: After 142 years of the operation of freight rail in Australia, we have finally reached an agreement where there is going to be one organisation controlling access to the national track network from Perth right through to Brisbane. That agreement was reached last Friday in consultation with all the states and with the agreement of all the states, those states being New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland where the honourable member's seat is located.

This process was begun earlier this year in Melbourne by the former minister, the member for Hume, who had the foresight to get a focus on a national vision as far as rail freight in Australia is concerned, and tried to get a far more efficient industry with on‐track rail services. With the development of this agreement we now move forward with the establishment of the Australian rail track corpora tion which will control and negotiate track access and train paths all the way from Perth, right through the eastern states and up to Brisbane.

The new company will operate commercially and will generate freight growth on rail. It will create a more efficient rail network and long‐term jobs in rail. Most importantly, it will create uniformity in operating regulatory systems within the rail network in Australia. It was an historic achievement by the Howard/Fischer government.

We should contrast that with the Australian Labor Party's record as far as rail in Australia is concerned. They do not have a very good track record on rail. The policy they had with regard to AN saw the loss of 7,000 jobs. We have turned that around. We have privatised the operations of AN and stemmed the flow of jobs out of AN which was bleeding under Labor. That is not just the view of this government; that is also the view of some high profile people within the Labor Party.

It was interesting to note some comments made by Senator Schacht in a Senate estimates committee hearing last week. When they were talking about the sale of AN, he said with regard to the arrangements set up under Labor:

. . . and all I can say in my weak defence is that I got outvoted in the caucus of the Labor Party on that crazy decision. Those of us who had our hands up saying, `This is crackers' have all been proven 100 per cent right.
The managing director of AN, Mr Andrew Neal, said that that was the reason why AN's demise occurred and Senator Schacht responded:
Absolutely. And I can tell you who the guilty parties are: two state rail systems aided and abetted by the Railways Union of Australia. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —And is that the federal government's fault?
—Senator Schacht is talking about your policy as it was in the previous government. Senator Schacht went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . `This is the way we will rob money from the federal government for a new national rail corporation.' Based on what they wanted they were successful, but of course they rooted the whole system. Neil O'Keefe and I and a few others all voted against it, but we got done by the vested interests of those three groups. And you—
that is AN—
are the poor victim.
They were Senator Schacht's words last week. That has come from that side of the political spectrum.

It is important to note in closing in response to the member for Hinkler's question, that the Howard/Fischer government has achieved a great national goal in establishing a corporation that can manage the track network for freight across the Australian rail network, instead of it being run by five or six parochial fiefdoms of the states. All parties should acknowledge that and it would go a long way towards improving the efficiency of transport in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. How many trainees from the South Pacific Cruise Lines debacle have been marooned in Sydney because DEETYA did not bother to do checks on the Richells Shipping Line? Is it true the owner of the Sydney cruise line paid the unfortunate trainees with dud checks and one trainee was hauled in by police when he innocently tried to cash one of those dud checks? How much money has DEETYA put into the Richells Shipping Line venture to relocate the trainees and back the new program? Can the House be assured the cruise line farce has now come to an end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the member for Batman's question, I am advised by the department that it is not aware that any funding at all has been provided to the Richells Shipping Line to train or provide wage subsidies for employees of a passenger service between Sydney and Melbourne. Vacancies for the shipping line were lodged with the CES by a Mr Richard Elliott. A number of people were referred to the vacancies, including job seekers who were former participants of the South Pacific Cruise Lines' training program. I understand the matter is currently before the courts and therefore it is inappropriate to provide any further comment.

—My question is also to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm that the states and territories have failed to sign a new ANTA agreement due to the Commonwealth's refusal to commit growth funding? Is it not true that, despite the minister's meaningless rhetoric about his concern for students who do not pursue higher education, the Commonwealth is imposing cuts of $28 million on New South Wales TAFE, $18 million on Victoria, $21 million on Queensland and $28 million on other states and territories, plus breaking the previous government's commitment to growth funding for a decade. Does this not represent, as your Victorian colleague Phil Honeywood has said, the biggest cost shift to the states since federation, leaving your claims to the contrary as nothing more than the work of a spin doctor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —What a Kylie Minoguer: I should be so lucky!

ANSWER.PARA: The member for Werriwa has to learn to do his research. I have said this to you before in question time. I met with the states and territories last Friday and the states and territories, with their ministers, signed off on a new Australian National Training Authority agreement to cover the next three years. The terms of the agreement, and I quote from clause 29, say:
The Commonwealth and the states/territories will continue to provide funding stability for the national VET system and growth will be achieved through efficiencies.

This, of course, is what I have been telling the House month after month. The member for Werriwa down there—the young and the restless—could not be bothered listening to the answers and cannot be bothered finding out what is actually going on in relations between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. He did not even know—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you pass him, Professor?

—He would be a fail—definitely a fail—at any level of the educational system. He could not even be bothered finding out that there had been a meeting and an agree ment between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. The tactics committee is not going to allow you to get up again if you are going to perform like that.

ANSWER.PARA: This government is all about expanding education and training opportunities for young Australians. Not only are there 50,000 new places in the TAFE system this year, 43,000 of which are funded by the Commonwealth, but also the states and territories agreed in this meeting last Friday to continue to grow their systems through efficiencies. This is one of the major differences between the government and the opposition. The opposition, as we know, has absolutely no compunction at all in reaching its hand into the pockets of the taxpayers year after year, taking out tens of millions and hundreds of millions of dollars, plunging the country into debt and ripping that money away from Australian families to spend it on schemes when growth can be obtained through efficiencies.

The Australian National Training Authority, as you well know, has done an analysis which demonstrates that if every state were to operate its TAFE system at the level of the most efficient, which is Victoria, there would be efficiency gains of some $300 million to be obtained. The Commonwealth is not going to continue to pour hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money down the drain until that growth can be brought forward out of savings from those efficiencies. The ministers of the states and territories agreed to that last Friday. Mr Aquilina, from New South Wales, was unable to be present.

TALK.START.PARA: —How could he agree to it if he was not there?
—So they haven't signed.
—I am assuming that New South Wales is very eager to conclude this agreement and that he will be more than willing to agree.
—So they didn't sign it, you lying thing.
—The member for Werriwa! Order!
—Let us get it quite clear. Are you saying New South Wales will not be agreeing to grow their TAFE system through efficiencies next year?
—You said they already had. You said they had!
—Are you saying that?
—You said they had.
—You absolute liar! You absolute liar!
—The Labor party is opposed to this—
—Order! Withdraw that remark.
—Is that your view—that the Labor Party is opposed to this?
—Order! The honourable member for Werriwa will withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, it was signed off by the states and territories.
—Minister, resume your seat. The honourable member for Werriwa has withdrawn?
—I withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think the minister is asking you a question. The minister is asking you a series of questions. Perhaps you would answer them for him.
—I thank the honourable member for Newcastle. The minister is aware of the conventions of the House.
—The ministers of the states and territories, having signed off on the new ANTA agreement, will be submitting that agreement to their cabinets for acceptance.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer the minister to his announcement in March this year of the new commemorative program `Their Service—Our Heritage', designed to particularly encourage regional centres in rural communities to participate in commemorative activities, including the preservation, restoration and updating of regional war memorials. Can the minister inform the House how this initiative has been received throughout regional Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for McMillan for his question. I can assure him that `Their Service‐Our Heritage' has been very enthusiastically received throughout regional Australia. Large centres and small centres, including very remote communities, have displayed great enthusiasm for this program. They are particularly keen to commemorate their local veterans in their own communities through this commemorative effort.

ANSWER.PARA: The culmination of much of this year's activity was the widespread observance this year of a minute's silence. I commend all those members of this House who encouraged their own communities to observe that minute's silence on Remembrance Day.

In just over six months, approval has been given for 100 war memorials throughout regional Australia to receive financial assistance from this government through `Their Service—Our Heritage'. That is 100 memorials in communities in locations as diverse as Oakey, Rainbow, Kimba, Jabiru, Bendemeer, Flinders Island and Yarloop which will all now be preserved or restored. In some cases, they will have a new memorial in their community. I am also pleased to announce that that 100 figure is about to become 101 because I know that, in the member for McMillan's electorate, the West Gippsland Vietnam Veterans Association are about to construct a post‐Second World War memorial in their community in the town of Drouin.

Regional memorials and memorials, wherever they are, are indeed a very valuable resource. They are also invaluable for recording the service and the sacrifice of veterans in local communities. Many of these memorials were built after the First World War and those in many of the communities that we found through this program are in need of restoration and, in some cases, updating. They are very much a focal point for commemorative activities, not only on Anzac Day and Remembrance Day but also during other events through the year.

In addition to the 100 regional memorials for which grants have been approved, over 250 local community commemorative events have also been assisted, including two very recently in the federal electorate of McMillan. The regional memorial travelling art exhibitions are also travelling around Australia—an initiative of this government funded through `Their Service—Our Heritage'. They are four exhibitions which are bringing some of the works of art from the Australian War Memorial to communities right around Australia. They have been to places such as Townsville, Renmark, Hamilton in Victoria and the Northern Territory. One particular art exhibition, `Too Dark for the Light Horse', travelled to many remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. They certainly have been appreciated by those communities.

`Their Service—Our Heritage' is a very important commemorative activity program funded by this government. I would urge all members of this House to get behind the program and make sure that the ex‐service community in their own electorates are aware of the grants that are available, because we should continue as a nation to honour the service and the sacrifice of veterans throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Has the minister seen the Treasurer's dismissive comments on proposals to restore research and development incentives where he said, `There has only been one resurrection in the last 2,000 years'? Is the minister also aware that, according to a report from his own department, business research and development will fall to a 10‐year low this year following the government's gutting of the 150 per cent tax concession? Minister, do you agree with the Treasurer, and how many more clever Australian ideas have to go offshore before you reverse your job destroying research and development policies?

—I am surprised at the member for Hotham. I have not heard from him for so long I thought that he must have been missing in action. I have not heard from him. These guys down here have been looking at your proposals for industry policy and they are not too impressed with what you have had to say and the stuff that—
—The department rang and they asked me for a copy.

—Yes, I am sure. They want to see what is going on. The government's commitment to R&D is very well known. In the 1996 budget we started the START program of $520 million, which provides grants and concessions to small and loss making companies. On top of that there is the 125 per cent tax concession, which is usable by companies in Australia. We introduced this year the innovation investment fund, which is a new concept which encourages the commercialisation of research and development in Australia. In the very near future we will be moving to announce those first funds under the scheme. I am anticipating a very great success in that area.

BREAK.PARA: All of this contrasts with what the Labor Party managed to do in 13 years. They had R&D expenditure in this country ranking 18 out of 24 of the OECD countries—a tremendous performance! Business expenditure on R&D was 25 per cent less in terms of GDP than in other OECD countries. That is why in their term we were importing $20 billion worth of technology from overseas every year just to meet the demand. And this was for the Labor Party's clever country. Remember all that talk about the clever country? We had to import $20 billion worth of technology to meet the demand at that time.

What they were really experts in was R&D syndication. Remember the rorts? Therefore, I am very surprised that the member for Hotham pops along for the last question of the day just to provide a bit of colour and movement, not to be forgotten—you know, the old empty suit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Is the minister aware of a report commissioned by the New South Wales government on child care and the immense concern this report is causing to families? Can the minister inform the House of the Commonwealth's commitment to child care and how this compares with the New South Wales level of commitment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Richmond for his question. As I mentioned, I have heard of the NCOSS survey. It was a half‐day survey—a phone‐in. It does give me concern and it gives sensible people concern because the outcome of that survey is misleading. It will cause a continued level of undue concern to some families in New South Wales. The approach taken was to run it for half a day and just ask people to ring in and say what their immediate problem might be. It did not offer any assistance whatsoever. Indeed, it is claimed in the NCOSS survey that the fee increases are between $15 and $40 per week per child. That is grossly overstated. The national data of August 1997 indicates that community sector fee increases average around $14 per week compared with $1 per week increase for the 70 per cent of families using the private centres. The Commonwealth, under my department, has provided $8.3 million to help community service providers identify ways to restructure their operations to minimise the impact of fee increases on parents—a very commendable decision taken by the government.

ANSWER.PARA: If community services choose to have more staff than required by state government regulations and/or pay above award wages, that is a legitimate service decision to make but it is not one that should be funded by the broad range of taxpayers. We are providing them with support to address their management structures and they should take advantage of that. The Commonwealth, as I mentioned earlier, has provided $1.2 billion this year—a significant increase on last year—and for the next four years, $4.9 billion—a huge amount of money for child care in this country. In New South Wales the Commonwealth support is over $300 million.

You asked in your question how New South Wales are dealing with child‐care issues. I think this is important, because it underlines the hypocrisy of the phone‐in that they conducted. I was surprised when I became minister and took advice about these issues—because personally child care is important to me, as it is for the member for Richmond and any other sensible member in this place—at the lack of progress by New South Wales to implement the jointly funded Commonwealth‐state national child‐care strategy to increase the supply of places. It is indeed quite interesting, because there is a total lack of commitment by the New South Wales government to do so. They rely on Commonwealth funded child care for child development, but New South Wales is the only state in the Commonwealth that does not have a universal policy for access to preschool year for four‐year‐olds. So many New South Wales families rely on Commonwealth funded child‐care services to meet the development needs of their children—all the more reason why this strategy is so important to New South Wales.

As I mentioned earlier today, we passed that in this place yesterday, with the support, I might say, of everyone in the parliament. I think that was a major achievement for the government. Almost 60 per cent of the outstanding places under the growth strategy for child care are in New South Wales, and fewer than 10 per cent of those centres allocated to New South Wales have in fact actually been established. So New South Wales have not committed, as the other states have, to providing the level of places that is available under the growth strategy.

There is another point I would like to make to honourable members. I think the demographics with regard to child care are important for members to understand. There are 3.4 million children in Australia aged 0‐12. Six hundred thousand of these children use Commonwealth funded child‐care services—that is about 18 per cent—and 330,000 Commonwealth funded child‐care places were in place at June 1997. Around 300,000 families—over 70 per cent of those accessing care—receive child‐care assistance. As part of the bill that was announced yesterday, the new arrangements will start after Easter, which I thought was an appropriate time for parents for that to commence, and 395,000 families as at June have actually claimed child‐care rebate. So the number of families accessing the $1.2 billion that is provided by the Commonwealth is a very substantial number. In the issues that I outlined earlier today, the assistance that we provide is quite enormous.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should tell us about the funding that is now provided and that they have to pay more.

—You should listen; I understand you have got children. It is important for parents to get good information. We have provided a detailed information service. Information has been provided to every member in this House and has been circulated right around the community. There is a 1800 number that will run Monday to Friday and all day Saturday—a proper service to help families find out about the best child‐care arrangements to suit them and to get details about the fees.

ANSWER.PARA: These issues deserve our universal support in this parliament. They do not deserve the cheap shots that have been taken by Bob Carr yesterday and that cheap survey that he ran. I think it was an appalling stunt that he pulled yesterday. It does not underpin the detailed consultation that I and my department have undertaken with the community. All the detailed subordinate legislation is being provided to every interest group, including the unions, in this country to provide us with further information as we work through and develop a policy which is fundamental to the families of this country, which I intend personally to champion, along with my colleagues in this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is he aware that on 5 November 1997 the Port Kembla office of the Australian Customs Service asked the Wollongong shark patrol to provide a surveillance flight for one of its officers at no charge because they lacked the funds to pay for it? Is it also the case that the Australian Aerial Patrol shark watching flights regularly report suspicious meetings between small boats and large cargo vessels to the Australian Customs Service but that Customs is unable to respond because of resource cutbacks? Prime Minister, in the light of these facts, how can you honestly claim your government is doing everything it can to fight crime when it is left to shark patrols to do the job for you?

—The answer to the question is yes, I am aware of such an incident, but it is not quite as described by the member for Cunningham—not quite. The situation is that, based on information from a New South Wales police officer that a vessel was acting suspiciously in waters south of Moruya, the Port Kembla office of the Australian Customs Service did approach a local aerial service company, Wollongong Aerial Patrol, on 5 November 1997, which I think was the date quoted by the honourable member, to establish whether an aircraft was available for surveillance purposes if necessary. I point out to the honourable member that for a long time, straddling, as I understand it, periods of office of both sides of the House, Customs has had mechanisms in place whereby Coastwatch can engage civilian aerial services for surveillance purposes. This is, let me say, on a fully paid basis. During the course of further Customs inquiries regarding the vessel, it was established that the vessel was undertaking routine fishing functions and that Customs intervention was unnecessary.
—Oh!

—I might also point out to the honourable member that I have been informed that, had the incident turned out to be a high priority tasking, appropriate aerial services would have been engaged on a fully paid basis.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I refer the minister to an article in the Australian today relating to refugees sailing to New Zealand. Given the concerns expressed by me and by leaders of the Torres Strait community about illegal immigrant activity in the Torres Strait region, would the minister advise the House whether there is a new pattern that is emerging in relation to the movement of boat people in our region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Leichhardt for his question. I did see the report today, and the member is right in observing that there appears to be emerging a new pattern in relation to the illegal movement of people. It obviously will cause concerns within the region, and it is a matter that I have been endeavouring to address over a period of time with governments in neighbouring countries, that we need to have a coordinated approach to dealing with the movement of people who are intent upon immigration outcomes rather than perhaps alternatives which might be protection claims.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that two boats have been detected recently in the Torres Strait over the last two months. Neither of the boats landed in Australia or on Australian shores. One is now in New Caledonia; and the other, as I understand it, is on its way there.

On 20 October, Coastwatch sighted a boat with 39 people approaching the Torres Strait. The vessel was intercepted, and the people were asked about their intentions. They were advised that, if they did not have a visa, they had no authority to enter Australia. But, interestingly, one of the immigration officials who was there recognised some of the people as having unlawfully entered Australia at an earlier point in time and who then had been removed from Australia. This group, however, said that they did not want to come to Australia.

This pattern was repeated on the second occasion. There was another boat sighted in the Torres Strait on 5 November; it had some 70 people on board. They, again, were intercepted. I think a report that I saw suggested that it was not seen by Customs. I think, for those folks in the honourable member's area, I ought to say that it was seen—they were not watching the Melbourne Cup; they were out and able to intercept it. The people, again, were quite adamant that they did not wish to come to Australia.

We do not shirk our international responsibilities in relation to those who have protection claims. Generally, if they are able to meet such requirements, they are able to stay; if they are not, we remove them.

There is ongoing cooperation between countries within the Pacific rim, including New Zealand. There have been a number of conferences held already. New Zealand obviously—if it is the destination that these people have in mind—will have to look at the way in which its systems are able to meet the demands. I have met with the minister; I have discussed with him the movement of boat people. My department is certainly keeping New Zealand officials abreast of these developments.

But I think the clear implication is that, in relation to those people who have been seeking to come to Australia before, the message is getting through; and that those who do not have bona fide claims are obviously thinking that they ought to look at other opportunities.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting Edinburgh, United Kingdom 24-27 October 1997 and Visit to Indonesia 28‐29 October 1997

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The continuing relevance and value of the Commonwealth to its members is well demonstrated by the fact that 51 member states attended the Edinburgh meeting, 43 of them represented by their head of government or head of state. It is a particular pleasure to record that Fiji was among those members, taking its place again at the Commonwealth table with the wholehearted support of my government and other members of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: This was my first CHOGM meeting, and it reinforced for me the strengths of the Commonwealth:
. it spans a broad diversity of nations, developed and developing, from all corners of the globe and representing a quarter of the world's population
. its members share a common heritage of language, traditions and values, which forms the basis for the Commonwealth's ability to reach consensus and work constructively on many issues

. it has perhaps the widest grassroots support amongst its member countries of any international body, with a vast network of associated organisations bringing together people from all walks of life—these personal and professional links are the lifeblood of the modern Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth also complements our key bilateral relationships and our focus on regional forums such as APEC and the South Pacific forum. It is the major avenue for our engagement with many Commonwealth countries beyond our immediate region. As the third largest financial contributor to the Commonwealth, Australia has a positive role in promoting the economic and social development of those countries.

The outcomes of the Edinburgh meeting were good—for Australia and for the Commonwealth as a whole. I should say at the outset that the meeting's success—and its harmonious and constructive atmosphere—was greatly aided by the capable chairmanship of the British Prime Minister, Mr Blair. I was pleased to be able to work closely and effectively with him. The United Kingdom was an excellent host, and the people of Edinburgh and Scotland gave us all a warm welcome.

For the first time, CHOGM focused its discussions on a theme—`Trade investment and development: the road to Commonwealth prosperity'. That economic focus was reinforced by the inaugural Commonwealth Business Forum, held immediately before CHOGM. I was one of several heads of government asked to address that forum. It was an opportunity for me to argue the case for Commonwealth member countries to open their markets and economies if they are to maximise the opportunities that globalisation can offer.

The outcome of CHOGM's discussions on its economic theme was the Edinburgh Commonwealth economic declaration, `Promoting shared prosperity'. The declaration expresses the economic principles shared by Commonwealth members and is the companion to the 1991 Harare declaration, which set out the core political and human rights principles of the Commonwealth.

The declaration is significant in the degree of common ground reached among developed and developing members on the need for continuing trade liberalisation, the importance of encouraging investment flows—especially through sound macro-economic policies and financial systems, strong regulatory and supervisory frameworks and good governance—and the crucial role of the private sector in achieving economic growth.

While this good outcome reflected wide support for trade liberalisation, the meeting showed that we have some way to go in winning universal acceptance of the value of a new round of global trade negotiations. As I said in my address to the Business Forum, Australia believes that a new global trade round should be launched by the end of the century. There is support for a new round among other Commonwealth members—but it is not unanimous.

The declaration recognises that some countries need help in adjusting to and taking advantage of globalisation. Governments need to facilitate the sometimes difficult adjustments required, and explain and manage reforms in a way which ensures community understanding and support.

I am pleased to advise the House that Commonwealth leaders welcomed and strongly endorsed Australia's initiative to respond to this need by establishing a Trade and Investment Access Facility under the Commonwealth umbrella. The facility will help Commonwealth members manage the potential economic and social impacts of trade and investment liberalisation. My announcement of Australia's contribution of $1.5 million over three years to start the facility was backed up by funding pledges from Canada, Britain and New Zealand. I see this not only as a practical and constructive response to the concerns of many developing countries about the impact of opening up to the global economy but also as a means of helping generate the momentum of trade liberalisation worldwide and opening up markets for our exporters.

The outcome on climate change was particularly good from the point of view of Australia's national interest. Against many expectations and dire predictions of Australia being isolated on this issue, the economic declaration advanced our interests by recognising that:
. as a general principle, the costs of protecting the environment should be borne in accordance with shared and differentiated responsibilities
. both developed and developing countries have to play a part in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in order to solve what is a global problem

BREAK.PARA: . a successful outcome at the climate change conference in Kyoto would involve realistic and achievable goals.
I shall have more to say in detail about that issue tomorrow.

The Edinburgh meeting also reinforced the importance attached by the Commonwealth to the principles of democracy, good governance and human rights set out in the Harare declaration. Heads of government confirmed the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group's mandate to respond to situations where the Commonwealth's principles are seriously or persistently violated.

We bluntly told Nigeria that it must improve its human rights record and return to democracy. Nigeria remains suspended from the Commonwealth, with the Ministerial Action Group authorised to invoke various measures if it considered these would encourage a return to democracy and respect for human rights. If Nigeria's transition to democratic government is not completed by 1 October 1998, heads of government will consider its expulsion and further sanctions. We also condemned the military coup in Sierra Leone and agreed to continue its suspension from Commonwealth meetings.

The outcome on membership was also positive in maintaining the integrity of the Commonwealth by emphasising the common threads which unite an otherwise diverse group. Leaders agreed that, to qualify for membership, countries should have a constitutional association with an existing member, comply with the Harare declaration and accept Commonwealth norms and conventions.

As well as our contribution to these outcomes, Australia's strong commitment to the Commonwealth was demonstrated in my announcement of an expansion of Australia's assistance for Commonwealth sport.Australia is the Commonwealth's largest sports donor, seeing the social, health and economic benefits for young people of participation in sport and the important role of sport in strengthening all Commonwealth ties.

We will continue the successful Protea sports program in South Africa, which was due to wind up next year, and work with South Africa to extend it to other parts of Commonwealth Africa, with funding of $1.8 million. We will also extend support for junior sports development in the Caribbean, with funding of $1.35 million. And, subject to a review, our sports development program in the South Pacific, ASP2000, will be extended until 2006.

Australia's support for the Commonwealth was also expressed in my offer—which was warmly accepted—that Australia host CHOGM in the year 2001. It is very fitting that Australia's Commonwealth friends will be able to join us in our celebration of 100 years of the establishment of the Australian nation. One of the great values of CHOGM is the opportunity it provides for formal and informal discussions with a range of leaders, establishing the personal contacts which are such an important part of strong bilateral relationships. It was, of course, a particular pleasure for me to meet President Mandela for the first time—he kindly invited me to visit South Africa and I reiterated how welcome a visitor he would be to Australia.

My discussions with Mr Blair in London, building on our meeting earlier this year, set the tone for our close cooperation in Edinburgh on a number of issues, including climate change. We also had a useful exchange on what is one of the few irritants in our bilateral relationship—the indexation of pensions paid to former residents of the United Kingdom who now live in Australia.

My meetings with Mr Goh Chok Tong and Dr Mahathir allowed a very useful discussion about the financial instability in South‐East Asia, including appropriate action at the forthcoming APEC leaders meeting. It was also good in the lead‐up to the Vancouver meeting to talk with this year's chair of APEC, the Canadian Prime Minister, Mr Chretien, and to discuss the Ottawa Treaty on landmines which the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, will sign on Australia's behalf.

My meeting in Edinburgh with Mr Haiveta, the Deputy Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, allowed me to hear about the drought afflicting our closest neighbour. I repeated Australia's determination to help the govern ment and the people of Papua New Guinea get through this very difficult period.

My subsequent visit to Indonesia—my second as Prime Minister—coincided with developments of crucial importance to Indonesia's future, and to the future of the region. Given the timing, it was both inevitable and in keeping with Australia's deep and abiding interests in the bilateral relationship that the financial situation in the region and its implications for Indonesia were a focus of my meetings with President Soeharto and his ministers. My offer that Australia was ready to participate in any International Monetary Fund package to assist Indonesia underlined the strength of our commitment, as a friend and neighbour, both to the partnership with Indonesia and to the Asia‐Pacific region whose future Australia and Indonesia share.

Australia is not a fair‐weather friend. Our offer showed that we are a reliable neighbour and member of our regional community, prepared to help out during difficult periods. Moreover, our response has been warmly welcomed by leaders in the region and demonstrates that Australia should be confident about her place in our region and the regard in which it is held by her neighbours. It is in our national interests that the significant economic progress made by Indonesia over the last 30 years—progress which has meant better lives for the majority of Indonesian people—is continued. Stability and prosperity in Indonesia and the wider region are important for Australia, for our economic prospects and for the living standards and jobs of Australians.

The government is confident that the measures Indonesia has agreed with the IMF will help stabilise Indonesia's currency and lay the basis for good growth in the medium term. While I was in Jakarta, I launched a joint venture between the Commonwealth Bank and Bank Internationale Indonesia. This enterprise is a timely and strong expression of confidence in Indonesia's economic future. It is also a measure of the growing commitment of the private sectors in both our countries to work together for mutual benefit.

Our commercial relations with Indonesia are now very significant. Our two‐way merchandise trade grew by 20 per cent last financial year to $5.2 billion, and two‐way services trade grew to $1.3 billion in 1996. The numbers of Indonesians and Australians travelling in both directions are also growing strongly. About 360,000 Australians went to Indonesia in 1996 and 150,000 Indonesians came here. There were more than 16,000 Indonesians studying here in 1996.
Our commitment to strengthening the relationship with Indonesia was also marked during the visit by my announcement of:

. the opening of six new honorary consulates, four of them in eastern Indonesia—the region covered by the Australian Indonesian Development Area—which will give a boost to our trade and investment links
. the provision of a further $44 million over the next five years to fund short‐term training courses under the aid program

. a further contribution of $360,000 for ground firefighting training and equipment for the Indonesian fire services—as well as funds for drought relief in Irian Jaya announced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

When I was in Jakarta, I had the opportunity of meeting the Australian firefighting personnel from various states of Australia who have been performing such a magnificent service to the Indonesian people in their recent responses to the disastrous fires in the region.

The strong, constructive and broad based relationship we have with Indonesia provides a solid foundation for us to talk about any differences which we have, and it is important that this be stressed. On the issue of East Timor I said that, while Australia recognised Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor and would act consistently with that, we thought it desirable, both for Indonesia and for Indonesia's friends, for further progress to be made in dialogue and greater control over their own affairs by the people of East Timor.

We talked about the need to agree expeditiously on arrangements fair to both sides on the exploitation of LNG in the Timor Gap. Progress was subsequently made at a meeting between Senator Parer and his Indonesian counterpart, Mr Sudjana. President Soeharto and I also discussed the forthcoming APEC meeting and the importance of working together to strengthen APEC and to achieve its goals of free and open trade and investment.
I would like to conclude by expressing my gratitude to President Soeharto and the government of Indonesia for the hospitality extended to me and my travelling party. I present the following paper:
Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting Edinburgh, United Kingdom 24-27 October 1997 and Visit to Indonesia 28‐29 October 1997—Ministerial Statement, 18 November 1997.
Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) views the outcome of his trip with a great deal of personal relief. He does so because this is the first trip that he has made overseas when he has not made a complete botch of it. This is the first trip that he has made overseas when he can come back from it to a reasonable set of headlines instead of `The Last Train to Klutzville', which represented an appropriate analysis of his previous trip overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: But as trips go, for a Prime Minister, it was pretty garden average both in its outcomes and in its achievements. With some of those outcomes—at least his interpretation of them, if not the actual words associated with ultimate decisions of that body—we have some degree of disappointment. Nevertheless, there are outcomes associated with this trip with which we wholeheartedly agree, so let me start with them in the spirit of some degree of bipartisanship.

The first was in terms of the decisions that he took on a bilateral basis in terms of mutual development of a variety of schemes such as the consulates, which should deepen our involvement in the affairs of that nation. The second, and more important, was the guarantee that he gave the Indonesians of a preparedness to participate in any rescue package for the Indonesian currency got together by the IMF to the tune of some $1 billion. The Prime Minister, I and others need to be careful about the way in which we represent that. There is an opinion abroad that somehow or other a $1 billion cash donation has been offered to Indonesia. That is not the case; it is a currency swap. Unless circumstances which go beyond thinking in fact occur, the chances of the Australian taxpayer having to `ante up' anything is very remote indeed.

Those who feel that there are domestic programs and other elements of government activity that are in some way or another at risk, have suffered or have not been appropriately supported as a result of a decision to go down this road, ought to have their fears set at rest. That is not at stake and nor was it at stake with the package that was put together recently by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in relation to Thailand.

Nevertheless, the sense of relief that we feel in relation to the performance of the Prime Minister on his second visit to Indonesia has yet to wipe out in the region the consequences of the government's extraordinary indecision, backing and filling and malapropisms, or whatever you like to describe it as, in their relationships with the region around us that have manifested themselves in the 18 months or so that this government have been responsible for the portrayal of Australia to what is now, as correctly identified by the Prime Minister in the case of one country, the region of our most important trading partners, both South-East Asia and North Asia.

We have a very long way to go. The role as far as the Prime Minister is concerned is central to the outcome that we all desire. He has not managed to overcome the consequences of his persistent and repetitive erecting of a straw man, which ultimately was a straw man which his hosts found incredibly offensive when he denied 16 times on his first visit to Indonesia that Australia was not an Asian country, a proposition never put forward by any government. We used to define ourselves as part of the Asia-Pacific region, which is a manifest truism in geographic terms and also in economic terms. By putting that forward persistently, he put a question mark in the minds of many of his interlocu tors as to whether or not he was trying to be offensive on the point.

At least on this occasion the Prime Minister did not conduct his visit to the region with a megaphone aimed basically at Australian domestic opinion or what he thought Australian domestic opinion to be. On this occasion he actually tried to address himself to what the realities were in the countries immediately around us. He might well do so. While in the long haul there are enormous benefits for this country and there have already been enormous benefits for this country—enormous benefits that are of an economic nature apart from security concerns and concerns for our long-term survival in the region—in an enmeshment with the region, with a dialogue with the region on all levels of our society, for the next few years there is going to be a marked impact on the Australian economy of the economic troubles they are experiencing.

The IMF is pointing out to a number of these nations the road that they need to go to get themselves out of this situation. They will in their various ways no doubt address what is being put to them, and it is important that those points are made to them. In the interim, they are going to throw up for this country not a small number of economic problems which are going to have to be addressed by us. This is going to impact on many aspects of Australian domestic policy as well as our foreign policy. How it might impact on our foreign policy we have already seen.

As to how it might impact on our domestic policies, you are going to find a greater requirement for activist government in industry policy as industry confronts the possibility of a decline in export markets in the region, as industry confronts the possibility of large‐scale dumping in this country from the region and as we try to get that in balance with a continuing close relationship with the region. Underpinning their currencies in that regard is not a bad start in terms of ensuring that we have not lost too much competitiveness in relations with them, but we are going to have to look to those other developments as well.

The Prime Minister also made reference in his remarks to CHOGM, which was, after all, the main purpose of his visit to the area. Again, we join the Prime Minister in welcoming the decision of his colleagues at CHOGM that they should conduct the meeting in 2001 in Australia. It would be appropriate to have CHOGM here as part of some celebration of 100 years worth of Australian history.

We on this side of the House have devoted a good deal of attention to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting over the years. It has had an important influence in a not insubstantial way on a number of international issues where we have sought to play a role as the years have gone by. Nobody can forget—certainly Nelson Mandela does not—the role that the Commonwealth played ultimately in pressure over the years to bring an end to the apartheid regime that existed in South Africa.

There were steady diplomatic initiatives over a lengthy period of time and a steady holding of the hands by all of us to the wheel on various boycotts that were put in place, both in the sporting area and the economic area, to keep the pressure on and to secure those changes. I guess that, as the Commonwealth did that, nobody would have believed that the outcome which ultimately did occur, would occur in the way in which it did. I think most of us foresaw over the years a picture of bloody horror as likely to be the consequence of a change to that system. But that was not to be the case. One of those international miracles occurred and there was a change of heart. I think the Commonwealth played a substantial role in assisting that process to come to a conclusion.
