It kept an open arm out there for those who wanted to conduct a dialogue to solve the problems and kept out there a reward for a successful conclusion.

So the Commonwealth is not some sort of antediluvian organisation left over from an era of international politics best forgotten. It has transformed itself into one of those useful organisations in the international community that can from time to time take up issues successfully and provide an umbrella for a series of useful initiatives. Indeed, the Commonwealth has done that.

Likewise, we welcome again the fact that the umbrella has been utilised by the Prime Minister to extend a number of those small programs that we have in place—they have been in place since before this government came into office—which have enhanced our relationship with a number of African countries and a number of others in the sporting area, for example. Those initiatives announced by the Prime Minister today were also welcome.

The Prime Minister's principal concern, apart from the trade issues that he mentioned—we have no basic disagreements with the position that he adopted on that—was one he took some comfort in: the decision taken by CHOGM on issues such as international commitments, targets and so on on greenhouse gases. This was the only banana skin on which the Prime Minister slipped in the time that he was overseas on this occasion.

He came out with a most extraordinary interpretation of that position on differentiation. He implied support for the notion and establishment of an international target, despite the fact that he accepted a degree of differentiation. He sought to welcome that with the most extraordinary statement of his appearance, talking about `differentiation in our time'.

It was perhaps, in the imperial history of this century, one of the most unfortunate allusions that he could conceivably have made, with all the overtones of failure in relation to the last time a Commonwealth—then empire—statesman made such a point when he talked about affairs in similar terms. As Gerard Henderson pointed out:
`Peace in our time' pledge had an expiry date of just under 12 months.

The gentleman who made it disappeared ultimately from British politics, but when he made that statement he was saved only by the goodness of his country's citizens and the willingness of the Americans to step into the breach.

I rather suspect in this area the outcome is going to be much the same. The Prime Minister's position, as far as greenhouse issues are concerned, is such that he will be saved from the consequences of it only by the goodness of citizens and the intervention of the Americans. The Prime Minister's position in this area has been a matter of continuing embarrassment to this country. He likes to associate himself with the fact that what is going on internationally at the moment is a bargaining process. People are moving off hardline positions and moving on to agreement and compromise. Yes, that will occur; it should occur; it is very necessary that it occur. It is a process which is inevitable and has absolutely nothing to do with stands that he has taken—but it should have something to do with stands that he has taken.

What the Prime Minister ought to be doing in international affairs on this particular issue—for the last 18 months he should have been doing it—is taking out a position internationally, waving Australian tickets and saying, `We don't want a set of targets imposed on us that we cannot meet. We don't want a set of targets imposed on us where, if we find ourselves with various mechanisms in place which could produce an outcome satisfactory in terms of greenhouse gas emissions, you ignore our processes. We don't want that situation. So take a look at our ideas and take a look at what we have done.'

If the Prime Minister invites them to take a look at what we have done—and they have taken a look at what we have done—they will see a slaying of a whole range of greenhouse initiative related environmental research programs and initiatives associated with business. They have noted that.If he also invites them to take a look at suggestions we have that make it easier for us to conform, they will see nothing in his rhetoric about things like carbon sinks which we could readily conform with and nothing in his rhetoric about exchanges in relation to the fact that we have energy efficient production of energy intensive goods and we ought to get some degree of credit for that. We have not had a government out there waving Australia's tickets and therefore enhancing our credibility. We will have more of a chance to talk about this tomorrow, so I will conclude here. But that was a most disappointing feature of his visit and we got no comfort as a nation as to any outcome that the Prime Minister managed to secure.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — I have received a letter from the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The government's failure to take all necessary steps to secure the earliest return of Mr Robert Dunn to face justice in Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, I wish to make a submission that this debate not proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard this as a very serious matter. I have not been able to identify any precedent for the situation that currently confronts the House. On that basis, it requires very careful consideration. The process of debate of matters of public importance is well known and the sub judice convention is reasonably known by that term. However, its terms are not so well known and I think they do require some care and focus in this particular case. The origin of the convention appears to have been a desire on the part of the parliament, according to the third edition of House of Representatives Practice :

SPEECH.PARA: To prevent comment and debate from exerting an influence on juries and from prejudicing the position of parties and witnesses in court proceedings.

There are a number of cases in which this has been raised, but the essential point is that the restraint is a restraint imposed by parliament itself in order not to prejudice rights that are to be vindicated outside parliament. The situation with regard to Mr Dunn is that he is the subject of some 91 charges in the New South Wales courts and, in respect of those charges, warrants have been issued. The matter of the criminal charges is very much before the Australian courts.

BREAK.PARA: The next step in the process, going in reverse, is that Mr Dunn has been arrested in Honduras and deported from Honduras to the United States. In the United States he was arrested again and brought before the United States courts on a provisional application for extradition by Australian authorities. He is currently, therefore, before the United States courts and he is due—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that I regard this as a very serious matter, and I think it is setting a precedent that parliament might go to regret.

BREAK.PARA: The matter is currently before the United States courts for the purpose of determining whether he should be extradited to Australia. I have been informed today that Mr Dunn has advised the United States court that he intends to contest the extradition process, and the basis upon which he seeks to do that is an abuse of the process by which he ended up before the courts. So there is an issue before the United States courts which is directly relevant to the continuation of the proceedings before the Australian courts as to whether what has occurred in relation to his arrest, deportation, arrest and extradition has been an abuse of process.

Looking in broad terms at the possibility of prejudice, I think there are two basic areas in which the possibility of prejudice arises. The fact that the allegations against Mr Dunn are the subject of such notoriety is generating debate and media comment. No doubt it is the wish of the opposition that there be debate in this House on the very issue.

That has the prospect of influencing people within Australia who might end up dealing with the issues before the court if Mr Dunn is extradited and brought to face charges here. They might be members of courts or they might be jurors. That is one possibility. I do not know what the member for Banks (Mr Melham) is going to say, but he is not known for temperate expression.

The next point, the second point, is where the matter becomes quite crucial. What is being sought to be debated by the matter of public importance raised by the member for Banks is, `The government's failure to take all necessary steps to secure the earliest return of Mr Robert Dunn to face justice in Australia.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The cover‐up.
—Cover-up in DFAT; that is where the cover-up is.
—There is a cover-up!
—Under Gareth Evans.

—Order! The member for Makin is not helping things here. The member for Hotham is not helping things either. This is a very serious, complex issue, and the Attorney has the right, unfettered, to argue his case. I call upon members to respect that convention.

—In order to canvass the subject of whether the government has failed or not failed to take all necessary steps to secure the earliest return of Mr Dunn to face justice in Australia, we have to canvass the very facts and allegations that relate to whether there has been an abuse of process by which he finds himself in the United States facing an extradition order. In order to debate that issue, we have to go into the very issues that the United States court is going to be confronted with because Mr Dunn is going to raise them in the court.

BREAK.PARA: There are other ways of dealing with an issue if the issue is of such importance to the opposition. I have not been asked, nor has the Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone), to my knowledge, been asked, by anybody on behalf of the opposition for a confidential briefing. I am prepared to offer someone responsible and appropriate from the opposition—like the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) or the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), should he so wish—a confidential briefing as to what has occurred.

What we do not want is to prejudice the proceedings in the United States by doing anything that will help Mr Dunn defeat the Commonwealth attempt to get him back to face justice here. Nor do we want to do anything that will help Mr Dunn defeat the public interest of him facing a trial in Australia.

On that basis, Mr Speaker, I submit that you ought to exercise your discretion by ruling this out of order under the sub judice convention. Given the significance of the matter, I would invite you, if you are so minded at the conclusion of submissions in relation to this point of order, to take the advice of the clerk or to reflect upon it in an appropriate way.

There is no precedent to which I can refer of any direct relevance. There are precedents for discussion of issues relating to extradition, but I am not aware of any precedent where the very issue sought to be debated in the House is the subject of process before a court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —One would hope that members are all aware that I am driven always by the need to make decisions in the best interests of the parliament. The application of the sub judice convention is subject to the discretion of the chair at all times and the chair should always have regard to the basic rights and interests of members in being able to raise and discuss matters of concern to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, regard needs to be given to the interests of persons who may be involved in court proceedings and to the separation of responsibilities between the parliament and the judiciary. I have examined the words of the proposed matter of public importance and I see before me issues that are essentially mechanical in nature. The Attorney alluded to the process, and to take cognisance of the wording that I am about to put before you—and I put them before you—I would ask members to refrain from any comment which goes to the innocence or guilt of the person named in the proposed matter for discussion. I therefore propose, in the light of my comments and the reflection I have made on this issue over the last hour or so, that the matter as determined be debated. I call the honourable member for Banks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker. I should put on the record, in view of the comments made by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), that I am a practising barrister of the New South Wales Supreme Court and the ACT. I have practised exclusively in the criminal jurisdiction since 1979 defending people. I know exactly the limitations in the presumption of innocence. We do not go to the merits of the case; we go to the failure of this government. It is about this government; it is about the ineptitude of this Attorney-General. This Attorney‐General, when it comes to extradition matters, is a repeat offender. This Attorney-General is a recidivist when it comes to extradition matters. This is the Attorney‐General who called off the chase for Skase until he was overruled by his Prime Minister (Mr Howard). In effect, as far as Mr Dunn is concerned, Mr Dunn is on the run and the Attorney‐General is left at the start.

SPEECH.PARA: The position is that, as a result of a number of answers to questions, material that is in the public domain and transcripts of evidence with Mr Broinowski, we now know that this inept, incompetent government has been blustering for months on this issue. We have a situation where the Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone) attempts to discredit Mr Broinowski on an ABC radio program this morning—a disgraceful attempt—yet the DFAT e‐mail actually corroborates what Mr Broinowski was asked to do. We now know that the AFP was aware of Mr Dunn's possible presence in Honduras as early as January.

TALK.START.PARA: —He admitted it.

—The Attorney‐General admitted that in the House yesterday. Mr Dunn had been positively identified by a member of the Canadian police force visiting Honduras, and the Australian Federal Police had been advised. In response, the Attorney‐General's Department got in touch with the department of foreign affairs, which tasked the Australian Ambassador to Mexico and Honduras to take up the issue of Dunn's possible extradition with the Honduran authorities. That was confirmed by the Minister for Justice today when she went on ABC radio. Former Ambassador Broinowski rightly took this very seriously, and he is on the record as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Look the urgency of the request to me, the instructions were quite clear indicating that the department itself was quite concerned about the matter, needed follow‐up taken—I mean it took me quite some time to get around the traps and make the appoint ments from Mexico and when I got to Tegucigalpa—going and seeing all the people and I wouldn't have done that if I felt that this thing wasn't being taken seriously. I took it seriously myself professionally, my staff did and I expected Canberra would too.
Ambassador Broinowski, as he was then, found the Honduran authorities both cooperative and very concerned that they should have such a person in their midst. He says:
I saw the Acting Foreign Minister. I saw various ministers and I also went to see a chief magistrate in the Palace of Justice, had a long talk with her.

That was in March. The ambassador reported directly to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and his minister. He sent a lengthy report. He followed that up with a phone call and, when it appeared that his earlier report might have gone astray, he sent a second copy. He took the matter seriously. No‐one could fault the ambassador's action. What was the response from DFAT? There was no response to the ambassador. In his own words: `All I got was a cone of silence.'

What had happened? We now know, from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) yesterday, that the minister simply passed the parcel; he passed the buck. There is a very telling article in today's Daily Telegraph by Malcolm Farr, Chief Political Reporter, on page 17. It is worth quoting:
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, that most aristocratic of government functions, cannot shake the accusation that it is soft on child sex abuse.
And nor should it be allowed to.
The revelations by former ambassador Richard Broinowski that he had reported Robert Dunn's presence in Honduras 10 months ago will help see to that.
Mr Broinowski sent at least four reminders to Canberra from his post in Mexico City and the response was, bafflingly, a bureaucratic silence . . .

And we have a cartoon in today's paper that has the foreign minister basically tapping around, blind to what is going on around him. The problem is that they flick‐passed it to this Attorney‐General, who has form. This is the Attorney‐General, as I said earlier, who abandoned the Skase chase. This Attorney‐General has form, and part of it is a result of the cuts that this government has made in these areas. This is ineptitude. We had the inept Minister for Justice on the radio waves this morning attacking, by inference, Mr Broinowski:
Yes, well. Why then do we have the ABC saying: "Rick Broinowski hit the airwaves today" that's yesterday, "

revealing the Federal Government had sent him to Honduras in February to find out if Dunn was there and if without an extradition treaty the Honduras authorities would cooperate in sending him to Australia." Why do we have the ABC running that line yesterday?
Kelly replied, `Well', and Senator Vanstone went on:
Because Mr Broinowski encouraged and allowed them to run that line.

I have in front of me the instructions Mr Broinowski was given. Referring to Mr Dunn, they say, `His whereabouts are at present unknown, although officers of the Attorney‐General's Department told me today that they had heard he might be in Honduras.' That confirms Mr Broinowski's claims. Senator Vanstone went on:
And then he was asked to make some general enquiries as to the general extradition climate in Honduras.

The point is that what we have is ineptitude. What we have today is an Attorney‐General again ducking and weaving. These are not matters that will prejudice hearings in the United States or in court. They are matters that go to the Attorney‐General's ineptitude and his department's ineptitude and the ineptitude of Foreign Affairs. They go to the ineptitude of this government.

The Attorney‐General claims that this might prejudice a fair hearing in Australia. That is not what we are after. We do not prejudge. There is a presumption of innocence. But, with matters in the public domain, we are entitled to test this government as to their competency and their resolve to bring people back before our courts. What we see is that there was no resolve. What we see is a sitting on the hands. What we see is ineptitude by this Attorney‐General and this foreign minister. This is a matter of public interest and public importance. This is a matter that should have been given priority and followed through. We now have from within the department material that shows ineptitude—saying one thing and doing another.

Yesterday we had different accounts from the Minister for Justice. She was trying to put it onto the New South Wales Police and was having a go at Minister Whelan in New South Wales. But she could not get the line straight with the Attorney‐General, because the foreign minister quite rightly, in answering the question yesterday in this House, pointed out that these responsibilities belong to the Australian Federal Police. And the Attorney‐General is the senior minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police in this chamber.

Senator Vanstone is now the minister responsible in the other chamber, but we do not blame Senator Vanstone because she is only a recent comer to the ministry for justice. This Attorney‐General was the relevant Minister for Justice at the time. This Attorney‐General is the person with whom the buck stops. Our Prime Minister knows, because he had to overrule this Attorney in relation to the resources that were going to be allocated to the continued attempts to bring Mr Skase back before our courts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong, wrong, wrong!

—You were overruled by your Prime Minister. That is what the public record shows. You are a recidivist when it comes to pursuing these people. The public record will speak for itself. That is why there is a concern. I asked a legitimate question today, and again this minister ducked and weaved. Those questions do not go to operational matters. Those questions can be simply answered in this parliament. Yes, it is the case or no, it is not the case that he continued to receive the pension.
—You know the answer to that.

—The Attorney interjects that I know the answer. If I know the answer, let him put it on the public record so that the parliament and the people of Australia can see in the official records whether this person was receiving a pension or not or when it was cancelled. These are fundamental matters that expose the negligence of this government, this minister and other ministers in this government, who say one thing and do another.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a serious matter, because this government and this minister are not up to government. In a short space of time they have betrayed the trust that the people of Australia placed in them at the last election and they have showed an incompetence that has been unparalleled in the history of this nation. The people of Australia know it. The opinion polls are all one way. The trend is one way. We know that we have an Attorney‐General who cannot even get his submissions up with this cabinet.

This is a cabinet and a government that prides itself on family values, access to justice and chasing down law and order issues. What do they do? Slash and burn the authorities charged with those responsibilities. They do it in a backdoor way and in a sinister way, just as this government is now attempting to cover up its ineptitude and incompetence with an allegation that this will prejudice a fair trial.

History and the parliamentary record will show that over the years this parliament has raised matters because they are in the public domain and has done that in a sensitive way that does not prejudice fair hearings. The presumption of innocence is important. Nothing that I have said today can be said to prejudice a fair trial. We are not going after Mr Dunn; we are going after you, for your ineptitude and incompetence.

We are going after the foreign minister, who is now a joke, nationally and internationally. He knows that he is now the subject of cartoons that accurately depict what this government has done in relation to bringing people back to Australia to answer charges. It is an insult to this parliament and to the people of Australia for this government to attempt to cover up its ineptitude by claiming this will prejudice a fair trial.

I remember the persecution of Lionel Murphy through the Senate hearings. I remember the persecution by this government when in opposition of a current member of parliament when matters were before royal commissions. There is one rule for them in opposition and another in government. I know that the Prime Minister has his fingerprints all over everything that this government does. The responsibility ultimately has to be sheeted home to him because all these matters are in the public domain. I think it is getting to the stage where this minister no longer has the confidence of his Prime Minister. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in taking a point of order before the matter of public importance was ruled to be in order by the Speaker, there are very important restraints on any debate of this subject—extremely limiting restraints. I suppose one should be grateful that the limit of the focus by the member for Banks (Mr Melham) was as it was, although I wonder whether that would have been his original intention.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask that that comment be withdrawn. That is a reflection on me. There is nothing on the record in this parliament that has ever shown that I have breached what he infers I would breach.

—I do not believe that the Attorney indicated that you were going to breach something. I would remind members of the House that, if they care to look at pages 475 and 476 of House of Representatives Practice , the decision on whether anything is unparliamentary or offensive rests solely with the chair. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I express the hope that the fact the opposition seeks to make this an issue for public debate will not generate a debate that will get out of control and have the possible consequences that I foreshadowed.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no public interest issue being raised for the opposition by the member for Banks. If you seriously thought there was an interest that needed to be pursued, you would take up the offer I made of accepting a confidential briefing on the subject. You would be able to know operational details that you know I am not in a position to reveal. It takes the focus away from an MPI that might be on the benefits to Australia of Telstra's recent sale or on the benefits of the debt reduction that will flow from the application of the proceeds.

You do not want to talk about tax reform, except in a negative way. You do not want to talk about the benefits of other measures that the government has taken, such as workplace relations reform, and you do not want to talk about the government's balanced approach to greenhouse. You want to talk about some issue which you simply seek to politicise.

This matter is before the United States courts, and I am not going to comment in any detail on any matter that might affect those proceedings. I am not going to breach the convention that we do not comment on operational matters relating to police investigations, and that is what this is really about. Nor am I going to make any comment that will offend the presumption of innocence to which Mr Dunn is entitled. The fact that this issue is being raised shows the bankruptcy of the thinking on the part of the opposition as to what is a matter of public importance at this time.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left!

—There is a number of things that can be said about the proceedings. One of them I raise with some care but with some deliberation: that is, the credibility of what has been said by the former ambassador Mr Broinowski. Mr Broinowski has been discussing this issue in a number of media outlets. He does not seem to have access to any of the documents he had as an ambassador, and that is understandable given the restraints that apply to public servants talking about matters relating to government that they are concerned with in office.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me try to put some of the factual background in order that public consideration of the issue can be on a proper basis. Mr Broinowski was the Ambassador to Mexico in March 1997. Mr Broinowski was also accredited to the Republic of Honduras. He was communicated with by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and advised that the department had received a letter from the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Depart ment concerning Mr Dunn, who was identified as a person wanted in Australia to face a number of serious charges of sexual assault—and I will say no more about that.

His whereabouts are at present unknown, the missive said, although officers of the Attorney-General's Department said that they had heard he might be in Honduras. This is the same message that the Minister for Justice referred to in her media interview this morning. The department advised that Australia has no extradition arrangements with Honduras either through a modern treaty or through one inherited from Britain. The department indicated that in those circumstances they had some questions which they wanted to put to the ambassador.

The first question asked was whether he could give a snapshot of the Honduras legal system. That is, whether it is one which operates fairly from a criminal justice point of view in a human rights' sense and can be expected to give a fair hearing to an extradition request. The second question asked whether he knew if Honduras would be willing to extradite a person without a formal extradition treaty. The department recognised that this might not be an easy question to answer but that extradition on this basis was not uncommon in some parts of the world. A response by a particular method was requested.

The ambassador apparently did make inquiries and then forwarded a reply to those questions. It is not known to me whether the ambassador had any communication other than in the formal reply, and the formal reply did not refer to the issue of the presence of Mr Dunn at all. He certainly did not confirm his presence, he did not query his presence and he added no evidence as to whether or not he was there. In those circumstances, suggestions that have been permeating the media that the ambassador advised the authorities in Australia that Mr Dunn was present in Honduras seem to have no foundation at all.

The member for Banks, in his just completed address, referred to the ambassador asserting in the media that there had been silence from the authorities. I have been provided with information that there was a reply to Ambassador Broinowski and, in the reply, his cable was acknowledged. What action had been taken was referred to. He was asked if, in the meantime, anything else should come to his notice about the whereabouts of Mr Dunn that it would be appreciated very much if that news could be conveyed. This was just prior to the ambassador leaving Honduras and leaving the department. That seems to be the end of the story. This does not fit terribly well with what Mr Broinowski has been telling the media. On that basis, it is understandable that, until perhaps now, the member for Banks has not had access to information that corrects what Mr Broinowski has been saying. He might have been misled by the media reports of what Mr Broinowski has been saying.
I would suggest that the member for Banks might get some information from Mr Broinowski on what he knew by contacting him directly, because Mr Broinowski plainly, in more recent information—

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that's not appropriate.
—Mr Broinowski seems to regard himself as being free to talk to the media. If he is free to talk to the media, I do not see why he could not talk in the same vein with the same consequences to you.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of assertions were made by the member for Banks. One was that the ambassador received no response whatsoever. I have just answered that and explained that there was a response to the ambassador before he left his post. It was suggested by the member for Banks, in reading out a newspaper article, that the ambassador had reported the presence of Mr Dunn in Honduras. That is false. The member for Banks should have known, on a proper reading of other material, that what he was reading was false.

The member for Banks also referred to funding cuts, presumably to the AFP, which he asserts have the consequence of the AFP not doing all that was necessary. Let me say quite plainly that the funds available in early 1997 to the AFP for the AFP liaison services were identical to the funding provided by the previous government for that purpose. There were no cuts whatever. The funds available to the AFP for the financial year ended 30 June 1997 for Interpol liaison were identical to the funds made available by the previous government in the year 1995‐96. There has been no cut in the principal areas of operation of relevance to the chasing of a fugitive.

The member for Banks sought to suggest that there are differences between the Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone) and myself in relation to our attitude to the role of the New South Wales Police. There is no difference whatsoever. The New South Wales Police have responsibility for the charges. The New South Wales Police have brought charges and they have obtained warrants. The process involved is that the New South Wales Police then contact the AFP, which has responsibility for Interpol liaison for all police services in Australia. From that point on, the AFP is responsible for dealing with Interpol. But it is not done in isolation. The AFP does not act alone; it acts on the instructions and in consultation with the New South Wales Police.

Between January 1997 and when Mr Dunn was arrested in Honduras, the New South Wales Police did not send anybody to Honduras; nor, to my knowledge, did they send anybody from any of their offices to any of the other countries in which Mr Dunn was reported to have been sighted. It is not common practice, if someone is reported as sighted in a particular country and that person is the subject of warrants for arrest, for the police to send officers to that country to seek to bring them back. The processes involve the normal Interpol communication and then the person, once identified and apprehended on a provisional arrest request by Australian authorities, is the subject of extradition proceedings in the foreign country.

All appropriate proceedings in relation to Mr Dunn were followed in this case. The New South Wales Police produced the warrants and were in close contact with the AFP. The AFP dealt with Interpol and Interpol was in contact with the Honduran authorities. As I said to the House yesterday, prior to the identification of Dunn by 60 Minutes, the local authorities had not identified Mr Dunn, nor had the AFP or New South Wales Police been able to follow up any further leads.

Where does that take the matter? The fact of the matter is that 60 Minutes spent considerable resources in looking for Mr Dunn, resources that were not available to the Honduran authorities. They acted properly in contacting the Honduran authorities as soon as they thought they had identified him. What was done was done in consultation with the authorities in Australia, principally the AFP, which did send an officer to Honduras in those circumstances. It was all done properly and I hope it will continue to be done properly and that the result will be that Mr Dunn will face trial in Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting this matter of public importance. I find it extraordinary—and we have seen it in the address of the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams)—that the government shows no sense of urgency at all about this matter. Listening to him was like watching paint dry, if I can mix my metaphors. It is as if there is no motivation at all to deal with this issue. I find it extraordinary that he thinks that this is not a matter of public importance. The Australian community clearly do and they have reason to. We have just seen the Wood Royal Commission amongst others report on the seriousness of this matter. This is a matter of public importance and something the parliament should debate, particularly when the government appears to be doing so little and so late. It is a matter of grave concern to all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney‐General claims to take the matter seriously and then proceeds not to. I intend, as the member for Banks (Mr Melham) did and as requested by the Speaker, to make no reference to the innocence or guilt of Mr Dunn. That was my position before his direction. We do not prejudice the case; we do not seek to and we will not go to the merits of the case at all. But we will go to the merits of the government's action, as has the member for Banks.

We have seen here the signal failure on the part of the government to expedite the extradition and arrest of Mr Robert `Dolly' Dunn. It is now clear that the government has failed dismally in its responsibility to take all the necessary steps with an appropriate sense of urgency to extradite and arrest the alleged pederast, Mr Robert Dunn. I use the word `pederast' advisedly because the alleged offences against children have none of the loving character the word `paedophile' implies. I never used that. Sexual exploitation of children whenever it is alleged is a violent betrayal of the most vulnerable in our society. That is why people are concerned about it and that is why the parliament should be concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the member for Fremantle of the strictures on the debate.
—I am very clearly speaking in general terms, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I do encourage you to continue to speak in general terms on the government's failure to take `all necessary steps', which are the terms of the MPI, not the alleged crimes of the individual.

—I shall and I do. I am simply pointing out why this is a matter of importance for the government. Children deserve our protection and prompt action, not our indifference. I would think that this alone, and compassion for the alleged victims, would inject some sense of urgency into the government's actions and compel them to devote the necessary resources and effort into achieving a result—again, something conspicuously lacking in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead, we have seen a comedy of errors culminating in Mr Dunn being initially confronted and tracked down by a current affairs program to provide infotainment, not by officers of the law through the proper channels reasonably available to the Australian government. People are entitled to ask why that is so. If it had not been for the whistleblowing by former ambassador Broinowski the government's ineptitude would still be hidden from the gaze of the Australian people. The Attorney‐General attempted to cover it up further today.

We have since been subjected to the unseemly image of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his senior ministers, including the Attorney‐General, passing the buck and denying either knowledge of or responsibility for the chaotic treatment of this very serious issue. But we have noticed. The Prime Minister wants us all to keep our mouths shut—a view apparently shared by the Attorney‐General—on the spurious grounds that criticising his government will somehow prejudice the prosecution of Mr Dunn. Far from it. This, from the same Prime Minister who has been prepared to stand idly by while Mr Dunn continued unperturbed in the Honduras with Australian justice unable to fully run its course.

According to Mr Broinowski, the government has known for at least 11 months of the whereabouts of Mr Dunn. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) reluctantly confirmed yesterday, Mr Broinowski was asked to go to the Honduras explicit ly to determine their attitude to the possible extradition of Mr Dunn. It was not, as Senator Vanstone claimed, incidental to the ambassador's farewell tour of the region. As Broinowski put it in an interview with Gerald Tooth:
. . . they—
that is, Foreign Affairs—
were interested in me doing this, and it was top of their agenda. And I must say it was on top of mine too.

At least initially. This was not a likely request if it was, as Senator Vanstone flippantly claimed, only one of a number of sightings and not worthy of concerted AFP action. That is what she was saying yesterday. To compound the grossness of her response, Senator Vanstone went on to compare the sightings of Dunn to those of Elvis Presley. The Prime Minister should remind the senator that, while Presley was a popular entertainer, Dunn's alleged activities hardly have that character, even to the sickest of minds.

Broinowski's reports to the minister and the foreign affairs department initially failed to spark a response, as they did subsequently. He was so disturbed by this that he made further contact by phone and was told, `Well, we think we've got it'—a response which clearly alarmed the then ambassador. So to be `on the safe side', as he put it, he sent his report for a second time. He needed to send it twice and also phone them. He concluded, and this is very important:
There's no doubt that my report, with all my conversations had been received in Canberra.
However, what happened? Nothing. The ambassador heard nothing further about it before he left his post. It had, he said, `dropped into a hole'.

When questioned yesterday, the Minister for Foreign Affairs disclaimed greater responsibility than acting as a postbox. He just received it and passed it on—nothing to do with him. He handballed the problem to the Attorney‐General, who claims that the `normal processes were followed'—as if this was not a matter of some urgency—using Interpol and the Honduran police and that there was no confirmation, according to the Attorney‐General yesterday and today, of Mr Dunn's whereabouts until the 60 Minutes team found him. What a joke.

Broinowski is clear, however, that when the case first came to him there was a `very definite view that he was there'. This was not on spec; there was a very definite view that Mr Dunn was in Honduras. It seems probable that the 60 Minutes team received their tip‐off about the whereabouts of Mr Dunn from Australian police officers who were frustrated by the lack of government resolve and resources. That is why an inquiry is needed. There is no doubt in my mind that cuts to the Australian Federal Police have affected their ability to investigate and monitor alleged pederasts. The organisation now does not have a single full-time officer working on Operation Mandrake, the operation that monitors about 1,300 known offenders with a further 400 being added each year. For members' information, Operation Mandrake is currently staffed by two part‐time police officers and one part‐time staff member. As a result, the Commonwealth's commitment to the national fight against paedophilia is a joke, as has been said by our shadow Attorney‐General.

It also appears that the nearest AFP office in Washington only has a travel budget of $12,000. The Attorney‐General would have us believe that it is only television stations that can mount reasonable pursuit. Despite the excuses by the Attorney‐General and the Minster for Justice, it was, as former Ambassador Broinowski correctly states, perfectly possible, given the attitude of the Honduran government, for more direct action to be taken. They did not have to wait around for Interpol. The ex‐ambassador says:

If we were more determined about this, we could have, through me, through the embassy in Mexico, with instructions, have gone in with the police and found the man. There's no doubt about that, we could have done it.
Why wasn't it done? Like many of us, he expresses the bewilderment of the whole community about why there was no vigorous pursuit of this matter. To quote Mr Broinowski again:
If we have such moral outrage at this man and what he's alleged to have done, then I would have thought that something could have happened to speed up the process.

Mr Broinowski is not the only one who thinks that. The government must now tell the Australian people, through a proper inquiry, why and how nothing was done about this matter for nearly a year; and then only as the result of the actions of a current affairs program. It is not sufficient for the Prime Minister to wring his hands in apparent moral outrage at the alleged perpetration, as he puts it, of this most appalling crime. We want action and we need answers.

I must say that all of this reminds me of the cartoon characters Big Ears, Noddy and Mr Plod. The physical characteristics are not too dissimilar either. Big Ears, Noddy and Mr Plod: Vanstone, Downer and Williams. And Mr Plod could not even raise his own posse—60 Minutes had to do the job on their own. This is a disgrace from an incompetent government who are indifferent to this matter, who have shown themselves to be irresponsible and negligent in such an important matter of community concern. They deserve everyone's condemnation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to rise in this matter of public importance debate to support the position taken by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) and the government. If one listens carefully to the contribution from those opposite, one fully understands why the Attorney‐General took a point of order when this matter of public importance was about to be debated. When one listens to the words of the honourable member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), one can see the very reason why this debate today is unhelpful and why the words uttered by opposition members could well prejudice not only a trial in Australia but also the possibility of extradition to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly disappointed in the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham). The member for Banks is, as he said, a lawyer who has practised in the criminal jurisdiction. He is a person who fully understands the importance of the sub judice rule and the need for the parliament to be exceptionally careful to ensure that we do not prejudice the trial of any person. He also ought to be aware that the parliament must be very careful not to undermine the chances of extradition to this country. Yet, despite that, he fails to look adequately at House of Representatives Practice and take into account what could be the consequence of his actions in the parliament today.

The extradition of people to face charges in Australia should be a matter totally above politics. This man is facing 91 charges. He is entitled to a presumption of innocence and he is entitled to his day in court. This government is prepared to do everything possible within the law to ensure that this person is entitled to face charges in an Australian court. The honourable member for Banks, however, instead of being statesmanlike, instead of standing up for the integrity of the law, instead of working with the government to try to make sure that this person is brought back to Australia, has decided to stand up in the parliament and seek to score some cheap political points.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cheap political points?

—You ought not to interject. I say advisedly that you sought to score cheap political points. I listened here very carefully as an objective person and you did not lay a glove on the Attorney‐General. You did not in any way, shape or form cast adequate doubt on the performance of this government. You completely failed on this occasion. I dare say that upon reflection, being a reasonable lawyer, you will probably wake up in the morning and you will regret this action. You will realise that you allowed your dispassionate legal training to depart and you decided to play cheap politics.
—He decided to be a member of parliament; that's his job.

—Well, he ought to be a responsible member of parliament. All of us ought to be responsible members of parliament. This government did hear a report in February 1997 of the possibility of Mr Dunn's presence in Honduras. Although we heard of that possibility, confirmation was not obtained for some time. We did seek from the accredited diplomatic representative to Honduras details about the possible extradition from that country. The ambassador replied to us pointing out that he was not positive about the prospects of extradition, as distinct from Honduras merely expelling Dunn.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite that, this government sent to Honduras a request for Mr Dunn's provisional arrest for extradition. But what happened was that he was expelled, not extradited, from Honduras, and he is now facing extradition proceedings in the United States. Mr Dunn has indicated that he will not come to Australia quietly, he will not consent to his extradition and he is not prepared to return to Australia voluntarily. His extradition hearing is set down in Miami for 6 January 1998.

It is obvious that the accusations brought forward by the opposition might well obtain publicity in the United States and could undermine not only the chances of a fair trial in Australia but also the chances of extradition. I think the honourable member for Banks would be absolutely appalled if his shocking conduct in this place today in fact meant that Mr Dunn might not be given his chance of answering charges in Australia.

The honourable member for Banks has ridden roughshod over conventions. He has not shown any sincere attempt to get to the bottom of this matter. Had he done so, he would have taken advantage of a briefing from the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General is prepared to sit down with the honourable member for Banks, or an appropriate person from the opposition, and give that person a full, complete and total briefing on the legal situation concerning this matter.

The fact of the matter is that you really ought to have approached the Attorney-General to ask for a briefing. Did you do that? No, you did not. You raced onto the airwaves, you submitted this matter of public importance, with complete disregard for the impact that that would have on the possible return of Mr Dunn to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —He won't give me a briefing because I'm not the shadow minister. It's Bolkus and Brereton. Get the convention right.

—Why don't you stand up and apologise? Your conduct has been absolutely disgraceful. I think you ought to apologise to the parliament. This parliament deserves members of parliament who are responsible. The Labor Party in this matter has been anything but responsible. We are dealing with delicate matters, we are dealing with matters which are before the courts and, indeed, there have been 91 charges laid against this particular person. Mr Dunn is, however, entitled to justice and he is entitled to a presumption of innocence at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has sought to hide nothing. The government acted expeditiously when the first sightings were made of Mr Dunn in Honduras. We cannot send police officers to any place in the world where any individual may or may not have been sighted. What we have to do is to take every necessary action to verify the presence or otherwise of a person there. But, if indeed we were to send someone—say, police officials—to any part of the world at any time when someone may or may not have been sighted, our budgetary facilities obviously would soon be exhausted.

The government, by sending the ambassador to Honduras to ascertain what the law was and to make inquiries, took appropriate action. And we dealt with the response of the ambassador in an entirely appropriate way. We have spoken to the United States, which arrested Mr Dunn upon arrival in Miami. He is now facing extradition to Australia and, as I have mentioned, that extradition hearing will take place in Miami on 6 January 1998.

So, on the one hand, you have a government here determined to carry out its obligations; we have a government which is committed to ensuring that persons accused of offences are given the opportunity to answer those charges in Australian courts. We have a minister who has taken all appropriate action, an Attorney-General who has acted with all due expedition. We have an Attorney-General who has done, in this matter, everything that is entirely appropriate. Yet we ought to contrast that with the actions of the Labor opposition. They have been prepared to undermine the attempts of this government to bring this person back to Australia to face trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you undermine an attempt when there is no attempt?

—I believe that the people of Australia will condemn you, my friend, for your actions. What we as members of parliament have to do is to facilitate the administration of justice. I think it is tragic that you have been prepared to ride roughshod over convention, ride roughshod over justice, and that you have been prepared to seek to score cheap political points in the interests of political debate.

SPEECH.PARA: If for any reason the extradition to Australia of Mr Dunn is not granted, the Australian Labor Party will bear a very heavy responsibility for that failure. You stand condemned—absolutely condemned—in the eyes of the Australian people. I think what you are seeking to do is terrible. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I just rise, if I may, to contribute to this particular debate, bearing in mind the admonitions of the Speaker. The member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) I think is making almost a reflection on the Speaker's ruling in saying that members are acting irresponsibly in participating in this debate. The Speaker made his ruling. He allowed the MPI to go ahead on the basis that, in his opinion, the generalisations in relation to the process amount to a matter of public importance. I would say also to the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) that when he says, `I'm offering a briefing to the opposi tion,' there are three elements in this place—the government, the opposition and the independents. The assumption is that somehow we have no interest in this particular matter.
—Long may they reign.
—Thank you very much for that.
—Have you applied for a briefing?

—I have never been offered one, but I am going to right now. I make the observation as follows: quite clearly, this matter, as the result of a 60 Minutes program, has become a matter of public importance to Australians. I would have thought it would have been incumbent on the minister to have made a statement on the matter—not to have restricted himself merely to answers to questions without notice. I say that because obviously there will be considerable numbers of members of the public in this country who will want to know what on earth has happened during that period.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this says a lot more about the extradition process than anything else. For instance, it says a lot about the fact that Australia does not have an extradition treaty with Honduras and the problems that arise as a consequence of the absence of a treaty of that sort. Ronald Biggs has been on the run from about 1964. He is still in Brazil. There has not been an extradition treaty for some time between Britain and Brazil. No doubt 60 Minutes could have chased after Ronald Biggs and interviewed him in Rio de Janeiro, as I am sure the BBC's Panorama program did.

The point about all this is that, if 60 Minutes could find Mr Dunn in Honduras, surely it is not beyond the wit of the Australian Federal Police, as directed, to have been able to locate Mr Dunn and tail him to make sure that he did not leave. I understand that there are difficulties in getting a process with a country that has no extradition treaty with Australia. I compliment the Attorney-General for the government's continued support for the importance of Australia's contribution to Interpol. As members would know, the government is supporting the candidature for the international executive of Interpol of Australia's Federal Police Commissioner, Mr Palmer, which is a tremendous step forward for Australia's position vis-a-vis Interpol. As we know, Interpol is under some threat by the creation of regional police intelligence bodies, such as Europol and others, that are perhaps crossing over the role of Interpol and may result in a decline in the resources available to this important body.

I have called on Australia to beef up its contribution following the visit of the former Secretary-General of Interpol, Mr Kendall, to Australia last year. He called on Australia to take a much stronger role in our region in relation to Interpol's work, particularly as there is perhaps a lack of resources in the Pacific region, an area there have been some considerable concerns of money laundering, drug trafficking assistance and the rest.

It is one thing to say that the process is under way, and former Ambassador Bruinowski has said that he was concerned that there appeared to be nothing going on. Clearly, that would cause concern to the Australian community in relation to this issue because the matter has attracted so much public comment with the recent Wood royal commission and other discussion in the public domain about matters relating to paedophile activity within Australia. Mr Dunn is entitled to a fair trial. He is entitled to a fair process. But what has been brought to the forefront is the problems that seem to be associated with the process, not only of identifying where the person is but of then bringing him to the process of Australian justice. Nobody in their right mind would want to see Mr Dunn's trial—unless somebody were being mischievous—thwarted or in any way perverted so that the matter could not be dealt with promptly and justly.

I make the following observation. The member for Fisher alluded to this when he mentioned not being able to send Australian Federal Police to Honduras. He talked about resources. He would know, as a member of the government who has followed the tradition of the opposition in recent years of cutting back on the AFP's resources, that sworn federal agents are now at manning levels almost equivalent to pre-1984. I would say that is a matter of much more serious concern. I appreciate that the government, in response to considerable community clamour and the work of members who have brought these matters to the attention of the government, has responded to the drug problem by announcing an $84 million war against drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 7½.

—Well, whatever it is. There was some doubt originally about exactly how much it was. I commend the government for that. I am not for one minute suggesting that that is not welcome as an addition to the armoury in law enforcement. But back in 1984, which is when the AFP's sworn agent levels were similar to the present situation, there was a problem. Justice Kirby in 1984 said quite prophetically:

SPEECH.PARA: Until very recently, crime in Australia was virtually exclusively a State Police concern. But in the past decade there has been an increase in Federal involvement in the criminal law which can only be described as dramatic. In little more than a decade the volume of cases arising under the Federal Crimes Act has trebled. Within that time the authorised strength of the Force—
the AFP—
only doubled.

That was a cry of concern back in 1984 regarding the situation that had developed up to that point. Clearly, it has got worse. It has become a matter of serious concern. Now there is, in effect, a rate of sworn officers only equivalent to 1984. In the aftermath of the cuts that have occurred in the last two budgets, budget cuts that the government says were necessary because of the previous government's financial incompetence, the Labor Party shares guilt in this matter because it had been pursuing cuts in the federal law enforcement agencies up until the election of this government.

As to resources—the member for Fisher has acknowledged that maybe it was beyond the resources of the AFP to send AFP officers to tail Mr Dunn in Honduras; I am sure that would not have been an extremely difficult proposition to undertake—one would have assumed the AFP had the resources to find out exactly where Mr Dunn was so that he could not escape from the long arm of the law.

BREAK.PARA: I say to the minister: I would appreciate a briefing too so that I can inform my constituents why the government feels relaxed, or certainly not as concerned as the opposition, about the Dunn affair. I would certainly like to learn what has been undertaken in the period between Mr Dunn's original sighting and when he was expelled from Honduras and then apprehended in the United States.

In conclusion, it is interesting that, when the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority was doing an inquiry into organised paedophile criminal networks, there was some evidence from World Vision which was considerably disturbing. The evidence was that World Vision was concerned that its donor scheme was being infiltrated by people who wanted to access children in their target countries for sexual purposes. World Vision said at the time that they got little response from the authorities when they made their complaints in the first instance, and they were surprised at what they saw as a lack of interest. The Australian Federal Police Association gave evidence to our committee that they were disappointed that no on‐site inquiries were done in Cambodia. There is a sense of deja vu—although it is a little different in this case—in the complaints that have arisen, and all I can hope is that, if a briefing is available, the actual process has not been in any way hindered by the lack of resources on the part of the Australian Federal Police.
