SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House insists on disagreeing to the amendments insisted on by the Senate.

I will make a few brief comments about the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996, and that is to say again that this is a landmark development in regard to the way in which elections will be conducted in the future. There is no doubt about that. The charter of budget honesty will change the way in which policies are implemented—it will give a basis on which elections can be fought with a much clearer understanding as to where the finances of the country are at. At this stage, we do have to reiterate for the Australian people that it was debated and discussed throughout the last election. The government of the day—the Labor Party—were saying that Australia's books were balanced, that everything was okay and that things had been paid for, but the fact is that when we opened up the books there was a $10,000 million debt. In other words, the Labor Party left this country putting everything on the bankcard. They were prepared to leave this debt there for future generations.

It was not the coalition that caused that debt, but the coalition has taken responsibility to bring the finances of this country back into shape and into order, and it has done that already. In other words, we are faced with a huge debt which the government of the day was not prepared to tell the Australian people about, and we have taken responsibility to sort that debt out so that future generations—our children and our grandchildren—will not have to cope with it.

This charter of budget honesty is about trying to prevent that ever happening again, because elections will have to be fought on well‐based financial information coming out of the Treasury if we get this legislation through. But, of course, the Labor Party are opposing opening up honesty in regard to the books of this country when it comes to an election. They want to keep it all hidden. They are opposing the charter of budget honesty. I think we need to reflect on the fact that the federal government's debt was $16 billion when Prime Minister Keating came into power. When he left it was $93 billion—an enormous blow‐out of money by the previous Labor government. By using their numbers in the Senate, they are trying to defeat this legislation in the Senate so that they can continue that reckless approach to the financial management of this country.

This charter of budget honesty is, as I said, a landmark approach to how we deal with debates during an election. I have to congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Costello) for his work in bringing this forward to the parliament because it will mean that, when the next election is held, the Australian people will know what the state of affairs is. That is quite distinct from the state of affairs at the last election. When we were told that the books were balanced, they were not. Next time we hold an election, the Australian people will know the basis on which the financial circumstances of this country rests. It will be clear, it will be open and the Australian people will be able to judge much more carefully and more fully the merits of both the opposition and the government.

It is beyond belief that the Labor Party would want to keep things secret from the Australian people. This is a charter of budget honesty. They are opposing it, the Democrats are opposing it and other senators in the Senate are opposing it, yet this is about opening up the books so that the Australian people know what the circumstances are. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that the government is not prepared to accept the Senate amendments reveals the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 for the sham, the fraud and the stunt that it is. Let us look at some of the provisions of the bill and see why this is so. In the first place, the government has rejected the proposition in the Senate that the charter ought to be legally binding. We are left with an optional charter of budget honesty. What happens if the government does not follow the charter of budget honesty? Nothing. Is this going to make governments more honest? Not at all. It is an absolute sham, an absolute fraud, an attempt to deceive the Australian people. It is a load of old cobblers—simply a political stunt.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there is no estimate of the effect on national savings of the provisions to be set out in this charter of budget honesty. You would think that it is a fundamental objective of budget policy that we increase the level of national savings. That was the second thing that the government would not support in the Senate. Indeed, the government got the support of the Greens senator, Senator Margetts, who I dare say thinks that national savings is a matter of economic rationalism and therefore should not be supported. What an unholy alliance!

The government was not fair dinkum about increasing the level of national savings, just as it has not been fair dinkum about increasing the level of national savings in its attacks on superannuation, in the 15 per cent superannuation surcharge, in reducing Labor's proposal for 15 per cent retirement incomes through the superannuation guarantee, in its opting out provision and its `choice of funds' proposal. All of these things show that it has no commitment to national savings. When we put forward in the Senate that the charter of budget honesty ought to have some commitment to national savings, it would not support that either.

I turn to the specific amendments that are the subject of disagreement between the government and the position in the Senate. The Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) said that we are opposing this bill and we are opposing the charter. This is completely untrue. The parliamentary secretary has misled the House in relation to this. We have not opposed the bill at all. We voted for the bill in both the House and the Senate. In refusing to support these amendments, the government is running dead. If you think that the charter of budget honesty is so important and so worth while, support these amendments and get the bill through the House and through the Senate. The government is running dead; it does not want to see the charter of budget honesty implemented at all.

Let us look at some of the areas of disagreement. The first amendment proposes that the principles of sound fiscal management to which the bill refers should include the achievement of full employment. The government come back and say, `No, we don't want that in a charter of budget honesty. We don't want to have a commitment to full employment.' Like everything else they have done in relation to this issue, their refusal to set the objective of full employment for the Reserve Bank, their refusal to set any targets for employment and unemployment and their miserable lack of action in relation to employment—it is a national scandal, a national disgrace that unemployment has risen during their period in office, with the number of long‐term unemployed rising—reflects the fact that we need to have a commitment to full employment amongst the principles of sound fiscal management. Is that an attempt to scuttle the charter of budget honesty? Not at all. It is an attempt to improve it.

The second amendment requires the Commissioner of Taxation and the Secretary to the Treasury to provide a report on any material threats to the integrity of the taxation system. We say that there is a need to protect the revenue and to maintain the current tax base. The government says, `Oh, the tax base is in a state of disrepair,' so we are all going to have to have a GST and pay taxes on food and many other essentials that previously we have not had to pay because the tax base is in a state of disrepair. Is it not reasonable against that background that the Commissioner of Taxation and the Secretary to the Treasury provide reports on things which threaten the tax base?

What the government is saying in refusing to accept this amendment is, `We like the secrecy. We like the present arrangement where these things are reported to the Treasurer but he doesn't have to act on them and he doesn't have to tell the public that he has received reports on those matters.' If we are talking about budget honesty, we should not be supporting this kind of secrecy. The second amendment is one which would improve and enhance the charter of budget honesty and make it a fair dinkum charter of budget honesty.

In particular, we have seen the family trusts tax rort which the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has allowed to continue. (Extension of time granted) The Treasurer made an announcement on 13 May this year, embraced in legislation which we debated in the House subsequently, allowing for the continuation of an exemption for injections of income by non-beneficiaries in family trusts, enabling them to, in effect, traffic in trust losses and pay no tax on income derived by them in completely separate circumstances from those relating to the trust itself. That is an extraordinary and indefensible example of tax avoidance and a loophole which has been left open by the Treasurer. That sort of thing went manifestly against the advice of the Treasury and the tax office. We note that it may well have something to do with the fact that up to 19 members of the government's frontbench do have family trusts.

Of course it will be the case that future treasurers will still be able to refuse to act on the advice of their revenue authorities, but they will not be able to hide their action or their lack of action. They will not be able to hide the nature of that advice and the fact that they are not complying with that advice. They will not be able to hide that from the Australian people.

If you are serious about a charter of budget honesty, that is precisely the kind of provision that ought to be in it; that is precisely the kind of provision that the Labor opposition has put forward. If the government were fair dinkum about this charter of budget honesty, they would be supporting it.

The third area of disagreement between the Senate and us relates to intergenerational reporting. The amendment proposed by the Senate would change the frequency of the proposed intergenerational fiscal reports from five years back to three years. That was moved by the Democrats, and it ensures that there will be a report during each normal parliament. Parliament customarily serves for three years so, in the life of each parliament, we would get one intergenerational fiscal report. We think that that is a reasonable proposition, and it is eminently reasonable for the Senate to insist on it.

Amendments Nos 4 and 5 relate to the pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report which the legislation proposes to require. Amendment No. 4 proposes that, instead of waiting until an election is called, reports be published in the normal way two years and nine months after the first day of sitting of a new parliament. We argue in our amendment that, if an election is called prior to that time, the report should be produced not within 10 days but five. We do not want to see a system set up in such a way as to enable this kind of report to be used as a political tactic by the government of the day during an election campaign period simply to advance its own agenda. Obviously, the later such a report is released the less real campaign time or real opportunity oppositions have to respond.

It would not be good enough to have the opposition, other non‐government parties and Independent members being denied a reasonable time in which to respond to the issues and possibly adjust policy in light of the issues that such a report would raise. We have concerns and have moved amendments concerning the nature of the outlook report.

Amendment No. 5 proposes to ensure beyond doubt that ministers be forbidden from participating in the preparation of a pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report. This bill suggests that what is required with a charter of budget honesty is not a political document but a genuinely objective assessment by capable bureaucracy of the economic outlook. If that is what the government is proposing, if it is genuine about a charter of budget honesty, then why would it reject making that clear in a bipartisan way by agreeing to this amendment? The government, in opposing this amendment, is making clear to the parliament and the public that it supports the possibility of political interference. Once again, that is utterly at odds with the concept of a charter of budget honesty and the purported function of this bill in improving the quality of government in this country.

Amendments Nos 6 and 7 raise major concerns with what this legislation is really all about. (Extension of time granted) These amendments are concerned with requests about the costing of election commitments—whether the legislation is really about improving the quality of public administration and democratic debate in this country or simply about giving partisan political advantage to the government of the day.

Let us have a look at what the government have done in framing these provisions in part 8 concerning the proposed costing regime. The government pretend that they are improving access to the costing resources of the bureaucracy—the economic departments—when in fact they are endeavouring to perpetrate a sting on the opposition. The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill says that only publicly announced policies can be costed. That is to say, the opposition has to formally announce its policy before it is entitled to get a cost estimate from the bureaucracy during the caretaker period. There is no provision to get costing advice earlier than during the caretaker period.

It may be that official costing indicates that the financial impact of a policy is considerably different from that which any opposition had assumed. Even the most competent opposition with the resources available to it finds it very difficult to produce estimates of financial and economic impact with the same kind of precision that is possible for a bureaucracy. That is simply day to day reality. The government and the opposition both depend on publicly funded resources. No‐one could seriously argue—least of all, us—that the opposition should get an equal share of them. In the nature of things, it is simply not reasonable to force an opposition to publicly announce a policy when the precise fiscal implications of it are a matter of uncertainty.

The further political dynamic is that if the opposition has publicly announced its policies, the mere existence of this particular clause in the legislation will create—and I am sure is designed to create—a source of political pressure for the opposition to seek a costing for it from the bureaucracy. No‐one will be able to be sure of the outcome of that costing or the political consequences of a costing that does not conform to the opposition's own estimates.

I am absolutely sure that the government has deliberately crafted this legislation to try to produce that effect. If that is not the deliberate intention, if the government is serious about this being a piece of legislation which will improve the overall quality of public administration, democratic debate and government accountability, then it would not be creating a legislative regime which has these kinds of in‐built traps for the opposition of the day. We happen to be the opposition at the moment but, based on some recent data, that may not be for long. In due course, the coalition will find itself in exactly this situation and will understand that this is inherently unreasonable.

The government are not in the same situation. They are able to refine to their heart's content proposed policies, with the assistance of costing advice from the departments concerned, without any suggestion that these policies might have to be publicly announced. So they can go through and test them against various models and cost them without being forced, as they would force the opposition, to publicly announce them. Clearly, even if we are talking about the caretaker period, any government, even one lacking in competence, would have these tasks catered for and accomplished by the time that it called the election.

Our amendments, which the Senate has supported, simply seek to inject some equity and fairness into matters of costing. Amendment No. 8 goes to the question of pre-election costings as well. It seeks to remove from the Prime Minister the discretion in the present bill to decline a request from the opposition for a costing to be made by the relevant departmental secretary and to eliminate the proposal in the original bill that the Prime Minister should be given a copy of the opposition policies concerned.

If we are talking about budget honesty, we say it is entirely inappropriate that the government, through the Prime Minister, should have a discretion on whether opposition policy costings are in fact to proceed. (Extension of time granted) If this is about budget honesty, we think that the matter should be free of government interference, free of the perception of political interference and in the interests of proper, open, national debate. It should not be a question about what suits the government of the day.

We recognise that there are some formalities to be observed and that access to economic department secretaries is still via request to the Prime Minister. But we do not support, and the amendment does not support, the requirement that the Prime Minister be provided with a copy of the policies to be costed.

Amendment No. 9 adds subclauses which would grant the responsible secretaries a discretion to decline to provide advice where this would include policy advice. I think that demonstrates pretty clearly the opposition's good faith on these matters. We are not proposing that we should be able to get policy advice on the sly or under the guise of costing advice. We understand that it would be inappropriate for policy advice to be provided to the opposition in that way. So that is a further amendment that we have put forward.

Finally, amendment No. 10 talks about how policy costings ought to be prepared, requiring that the assumptions upon which costings have been made be spelled out when a costing is provided. That simply represents an improvement in the transparency of the costings process. Once again, if we are talking about budget honesty, the assumptions on which costings are made ought to be spelt out.

The parliamentary secretary talked about the $10 billion black hole. That is all in the assumptions. That is all in the changed assumptions which the government made regarding the budget once it came to office. So we regard it as important that these assumptions be made public so everyone can see how a policy has been costed, not merely what the cost of it is.

If the government are serious about getting the bill through—I very much doubt they are; I think they are looking for a political stunt, not a bill that gets through the parliament—they will support these amendments which are genuine charter of budget honesty amendments. They are not designed to scuttle the bill but to make it a fair dinkum charter of budget honesty.

I note that this is not the only example of the government being more interested in the political advantage rather than the legislative solution. In the last couple of days government members have expressed concern about the government's hardline position on the Wik legislation—its refusal to accept amendments in the Senate—and it is becoming increasingly clear that the government is interested in the partisan, grubby, political aspects of this rather than the national public interest solution.

Even the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) has told the Age that he is worried about the government's hard line against amendments, saying that the Senate should not be disregarded in a democratic system. Mr Bradford said he was concerned about the public perception that the Wik legislation was damaging the reconciliation process and that the prospect of a double dissolution was horrendous.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going to cost us money.

—Absolutely. In conclusion, we will be supporting the Senate amendments. We believe that if the government is fair dinkum about a charter of budget honesty it would agree to these amendments; it would accept the idea of full employment as part of the considerations; it would accept the idea that the charter ought to be legally binding, rather than the stunt that it is now; it would accept the idea that national savings ought to be a relevant objective; and it would stop running dead on this bill and refusing to work with the Senate towards the production of an appropriate piece of legislation. We will be supporting the Senate amendments and dividing accordingly.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments, particularly on the legally binding aspect which has been raised in debate on the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . It is the assumption that the Labor Party wants to have something that is legally binding in regard to taxation measures, budget honesty and openness.

BREAK.PARA: I want to remind the House that the previous government in 1993 said, `Yes, we'll make it legally binding. We'll make the overall taxation burden less—$14 billion in tax cuts—and we'll put it into law.' We put that legislation through the parliament. They told us that these taxes were legally binding. They said, `Yes, these tax cuts are coming—$14 billion worth of them.' That is what Prime Minister Keating said.

The Labor Party are in here today talking about making something legally binding. Why would you trust them? They will do anything. `Whatever it takes' I think was the saying of former Senator Richardson, wasn't it? Yes, it was. They promised legally binding tax cuts of $14 billion, and what did they do to the Australian people? They put on a tax hike of $13.4 billion.

They increased the Medicare levy, they increased tax on motor vehicles, they increased company tax, they increased tobacco tax and they increased PAYE tax payments—and in here today they are whingeing about the fact that this legislation about budget honesty is not legally binding. Let us get to the heart of the matter. The essence of this is to ensure that the Australian people, come the next election and future elections, will have the information on which to judge both sides. They will be able to judge the policies and the public commitments financially at the next election. This is about openness, transparency and honesty in regard to the budget. We did not have it at the last election; we are going to prevent that situation in the future. This is a landmark piece of legislation. I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I just draw the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) and, indeed, the House to section 3 of `The Charter of Budget Honesty' and subclause 2 of the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 :

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in the Charter of Budget Honesty creates rights or duties that are enforceable in judicial or other proceedings.
So how fair dinkum is this government about this bill and about this charter?
