TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (YOUTH ALLOWANCE) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The youth allowance arrangements will hurt low‐income families. They will take away income support from 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds looking for work if they have not finished year 12 and reduce payments to unemployed 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds by introducing a parental means test.

BREAK.PARA: There is a real world out there and you cannot assume that by setting these extremely stringent rules you can successfully interfere in the lives of and relationships in our families. Like the picket fence view of family life held by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), he and the government appear to have a similar view that, if you interfere and force young people to stay at school longer, they will happily and successfully emerge from that process as well qualified, happy and successful and they will automatically walk into jobs and careers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incentivate.
—That is right. My colleague says `incentivate'. What a clause from the old.
—Order! The honourable colleague should not be making remarks from other than where he normally sits.

—Prime Minister, we do not live in the same world that you do. We happen to live in the real world. We accept that the current array of income support for young people is complex and in need of reform. In fact, we welcome some of the aspects of the bill. But the improvements come at a price, to be paid, unfortunately, by 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who have not finished year 12 and who are looking for work, and by 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds who are unable to find work. Their families will also be paying that price. I do not find this acceptable at all and neither do the vast range of people in my community with whom I hold conversations about this issue.

BREAK.PARA: Some of the government speakers I have heard today on this bill have been boasting that there is protection for some young people in this bill; for instance, if a family cannot afford to support them financially. I would point out that the parental income test clicks in at $23,350 per annum. It is not exactly a king's ransom, is it?

The government is saying that the removal of benefits to 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds sends a clear message to them that the best way to get a job is to stay at school. This statement implies that 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who leave school early do so as a deliberate, considered and rational choice to gain short‐term dollars. It flies in the face of the reality, demonstrated by research, that these people leave school early for other reasons. They leave because of family or emotional difficulties or social disadvantage, or because they are not suited to the school environment. The reasons why they leave school early are the very reasons they need that extra support, including income support, rather than the extra pressure that this government is now planning to put on them.

Removal of payments will not address the causes of the problem. Many people forced off unemployment payments are likely to turn to crime and other sources of income rather than go back into the classroom. The government is creating a pressure cooker situation for some of these young people. It is no good blaming the victims of the disappearance of entry level jobs for the fact that these jobs no longer exist. It is a fact that not every young person currently has the capacity for, or is suited to, staying on at school for years 11 and 12.

Many young people need counselling support from qualified psychologists, available in and through the school, to address their family and emotional difficulties and to encourage them to remain at school—to give them reasons they can accept for remaining at school. They need proper work oriented careers education when they are at school. They need expanded work experience opportunities while there. They also need expanded school to work transition programs which create pathways for them to enter the work force.

Expansion of existing programs should occur along the lines of the jobs pathway guarantee program, which was introduced by Labor in 1995 and piloted in schools located in the regions of highest youth unemployment and which was earmarked for expansion prior to the last election. The Howard government has revamped this program as the jobs pathway program and expanded it slightly. However, this funding increase and the other school to work funding initiatives undertaken by the Howard government, such as more money for vocational education and training in schools, and school based apprenticeships, have been completely negated by other actions of the government. These include the chopping of 117,000 places in labour market programs for young people and the decline of case management for the young unemployed under the new and, I am afraid to say, chaotic employment services market.

Early school leaving is intimately connected with homelessness among young people. Therefore, the level of resources for the job placement employment and training program, or JPET, which aims to help young people overcome problems preventing them from maintaining stable accommodation and entering into full‐time education training and employment, simply must be considered as part of this debate. What was formerly called the young homeless allowance and other relevant social security payments must be considered. General community back‐up measures to tackle the underlying problems of youth homelessness and family breakdown should also be part of the debate.

Let us look for just a moment at what we are talking about when we refer to the withdrawing of income support for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who leave education without completing year 12. In this legislation, under proposed subsection 543A of the bill, 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who are not in education and who have left school without finishing year 12 or who have not been exempted from this requirement by the secretary will not qualify for an income support payment. As a consequence, they will not qualify for any of the education, labour market assistance or other programs which might assist their transition from school to the work force.

I understand that under subsection 543A(2) these young people may qualify for a youth allowance in some circumstances. The Department of Social Security provided some indication to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee in its recent inquiry into this issue of what these circumstances might be—I say `might'—for example, homelessness, family violence or abuse, no education place available and so on. But I also understand that the guidelines under which this will operate are not much further advanced, if at all, than in the original submission to that inquiry. I pose the questions: how will the exemptions work? What will be the final list of acceptable exemptions? What evidence will the young person involved need to provide to receive exemption? How will they gather that evidence? There are a lot of questions surrounding exemption when we look at the legislation in relation to youth allowance.

I imagine that if a young person is in a position where exemption may apply they would already be in a situation of extreme stress. This government intends to increase that stress by expecting—we are not, at this stage, quite sure what—that that young person will somehow deal themselves out of it by providing evidence for exemption clauses, none of which we are quite certain about at this stage. I find this appalling.

In the current climate of youth unemployment, access to education and the day‐to‐day pressures that our young people are facing, we should not be considering putting a young person and their family under more pressure than they are already facing. I am afraid that, whatever comments come from the other side in this place, I am not convinced that putting these young people in this position is a good, positive and constructive thing for them or their family. The situation is just appalling.

This government has already done terrible things, such as saving $90 million by reducing the number of children who can qualify for child disability allowance—in another piece of legislation, admittedly. The whole theory of this government is to save money. We do not know what the projected savings of this whole piece of legislation are; they have not been made known. I cannot for one moment imagine that there will not be savings attached to this. There is not one thing that this government does that does not have a savings motive. But we do not know what the savings are; the government has not confessed to the level of savings measures. I wonder what our poor young people will be doing in the meantime to survive in the real world—not the Howard world—facing the pressures that exist each day. I do not know how they are going to get through this and survive well.

There is no doubt that Labor wants to see young Australians off welfare—we have no question about that—but not in the way being proposed by the Howard government with its common youth allowance. To abolish unemployment benefits for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds whilst also slashing educational opportunities is the wrong way to even begin to imagine how to reform the welfare state.

In relation to the income test being placed upon families with 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds, members opposite made the comment earlier in this debate, `Don't worry, if families can't financially afford to support them then that will be okay.' That income test begins to come into effect at $23,350. That is pretty drastic—an 18‐ to 20‐year‐old who is somehow trying to make their way in life having to go cap in hand to a financially stretched family.

I do not know about your electorate, Madam Deputy Speaker Crosio, but I know that in my electorate there are an enormously unacceptable number of families who are financially strapped. They are finding it very difficult. The economy and security around those families is very tenuous. In my electorate and in the ACT at large the number of people who, if they are in employment, have no future job security at all is far too high. They have fairly pessimistic views towards their ability to gain employment in the future should they be unemployed right now.

Youth unemployment in this town is very high. It bounces between 30 and 50 per cent. It has not been up to 50 per cent for a few months but it is bouncing around 30 to 40 per cent consistently. And what do we see? We see the government say to these young people, `If you do not want to stay at school, we are going to force you to. If you need financial assistance to survive, you go to your family. We are not interested in the circumstances of your family. We do not want to know whether there are reasons why it may be difficult for you to do that. We do not care whether you believe that your family may already be facing financial stress. We are just going to withdraw that support, immediately. We are going to save money. We are not yet telling how much. In the meantime, you get back to school. You'll be happy during it and you'll be successful at the end of it.'

I deplore the government for their actions on the youth allowance. As I have said, there are some clauses of this bill that we welcome, there is no doubt about that, and we are on record as saying so. But I deplore the major thrust of this bill: the withdrawing of financial support for those aged 16 to 20 in our community. I condemn the government for it and I predict very strongly that it is going to come back to bite them on the tail in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nairn, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 is yet another example of this government's good policy and of the much needed reform that only a coalition government is prepared to embark on.

SPEECH.PARA: When we came into government we had to deal with the most horrific fiscal situation left to us by our Labor predecessors. I do not have to remind people—but I will anyway—of just how horrendous that $10.3 billion deficit, which was supposed to be a surplus, was. It is not chicken feed; it is not $10 it is $10.3 billion. We were confronted not only with the horrific fiscal situation but also with a particular culture in the social welfare area that had got progressively worse over the previous 13 years. The genesis of this culture can be traced back to the Whitlam years in government. This culture of dependency on the state, of not accepting your responsibilities, is part of the reason we have seen the share of the federal budget spent on social security rise from about 20 per cent nine years ago to over 30 per cent today. What that means is that a smaller percentage of Australians are increasingly having to pay for everyone else. That cannot go on.

Labor's answer was to just keep on spending, putting it on the bankcard, putting it on the never‐never, for the future generations to pick up the tab. We are taking a very different course. Through good fiscal management, we will turn that $10.3 billion loss into a profit within three years. This is producing a solid foundation for growth, which we are now starting to see is translating into investor confidence and wealth creation and therefore jobs; that is the only way you will create real jobs. We are providing some real hope for our young people, not the false hope we have witnessed during particularly the Keating years of government.

Speaking of hope, I have returned only half an hour ago from attending a very sad affair, a memorial service for the two schoolgirls who were murdered in Bega just recently. Probably the positive thing that came out of what was a very sad few hours for many of us in the community of Bega was that people talked about hope and hope for our young. They could see that things are changing and that there is hope and that there is great confidence in our young people, who were there in force at that particular service.

Let me come back to the legislation, and in particular the contribution of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), who moved an amendment. It is interesting that I mentioned the Whitlam years being the genesis of this welfare dependency culture, seeing that is where the member for Werriwa got his political training. The member for Werriwa said:
The welfare state needs reforming.
At least he admits that Labor created a welfare state. It is nothing to be proud of, though, I might say. Then he goes on to say:
We need to move from a residual system of income support to whole‐of‐life support. We need to move from passive to active systems of welfare . . .

I am not really sure what all that means. I hope it does not mean that he wants government to actively provide whole‐of‐life welfare support for all and sundry. But maybe he does. It seems to fit with Labor's actions of the late 1980s and early 1990s where they actively—I say `actively', remembering the recession we had to have—brought people onto welfare dependency. However, perhaps I am too tough on the member for Werriwa, because he does go on to talk about encouraging risk and rewarding effort as well as improving skills. Looking positive, isn't it? He must have read some of our literature, because risk and reward are not words you would usually find in Labor Party rhetoric. This might be new Labor, although there seem to be a few versions of that.

Moving a bit further along, the member for Werriwa also gives an interesting insight into how he saw society in the 1960s and 1970s, and probably therefore how he sees things now and for the future. The interesting quote about the 1960s and 1970s is this:
A young male would probably aspire to the career path that his father held.

That is certainly not how I saw those years. In fact, the mums and dads of that era were a generation who wanted their children to have something better than they themselves had. That certainly was the case in my family. I know my father did not want to see me starting work at 4 a.m. at the fruit and vegetable markets in Sydney as he did throughout his working life. No, that generation wanted a better education and better employment opportunities for their children, and they got it. It is very different from the 1980s and 1990s, where for the first time in many generations we saw a generation that was not handing on a better standard of living and more opportunities to their children.

The member for Werriwa does talk about choice. He talks about broadening educational opportunities and catering for diversity. I support that, because that is the area that we have been moving towards since we came into government, and the proof of the pudding is in the eating. It is interesting that the word `incentive' is used at various times not only by the member for Werriwa but by other members who have spoken in this debate on this particular bill. But it seems that it has a variety of definitions. Part of the problem that we inherited, that culture that I talked about before, was the fact that there was an incentive there for young people to drop out of school and go on the dole. It was so easy to do. There were rent assistance and all sorts of things virtually thrown at them. The number of people in various communities that will attest to that is quite incredible.

We see incentive in a different way. We see incentive as something that must be more positive, not a negative. But it has been used as a negative for far too long, and I want to see that work the other way. Certainly many of the things that we are doing in education and training are providing that incentive in a positive way. I do not think it is such a bad thing that if a 16‐ or 17‐year‐old is not in school, not in education or training or not in employment, that it should be their parents' responsibility to be looking after them. That is what we are saying in this particular bill. But currently a 16‐ or 17‐year‐old living in a family situation which can quite easily support him or her, can drop out of school, walk down the street, get on the dole and get all sorts of assistance. All that has done has been to add to the number of family break‐ups that have occurred.

Of course there will be exceptions to the rule. But there are safeguards in this bill that will pick those people up. It is possible to have 16‐ and 17-year-olds receiving assistance in circumstances where it is really necessary. But there should not be an incentive there for 16‐ and 17-year-olds to walk out of home, walk out of school, simply because they can get a whole heap of money from the welfare system.

One aspect of this bill that I particularly want to speak on is assistance to rural students. As my electorate is predominantly a rural electorate, except for the area of Queanbeyan, it does not have the universities which are taken for granted by people in the big cities: `Which university will you go to? Will it be Sydney or New South Wales or Macquarie? Which particular type of vocational education course will do you?' There are enormous opportunities for people in cities which do not exist for people in rural areas. So many people who live in rural areas are required to move away from home to continue their study.

Under the changes that we propose with this youth allowance, those rural students will be the ones to benefit greatly from the changes. For those students, Austudy disappears and they come into the youth allowance. But they will be eligible for rent assistance. I will give an example of how this will help a family living in rural and regional Australia. Fred is a 17‐year‐old student living in Cooma, Bega, Batemans Bay, Moruya or Narooma—it could be any of those towns. He is enrolled in a full‐time TAFE course in Sydney and has found a house to share, costing him $80 a week. Under Austudy, he could get up to $240.07 a fortnight. But under the new youth allowance, with the new rate for under‐18s living away from home, he can get up to $265.50 a fortnight; also, because such students will be eligible now for rent assistance, he can get the sum of $49.80 for that purpose.

That was a great inequity which existed previously. Many of my families in rural areas would say to me, `It's okay for those kids in the cities whose parents are on reasonable sorts of incomes'—and they could even be on similar sorts of incomes to those of rural people, but usually those in rural areas survive on something less—`it's all right for them, their kids can live at home, they can travel on the bus to university or TAFE, or whatever the course is, and back home again; it's an enormous saving for them to be able to do that. But our children can't.'

The inclusion of rent assistance for those students from rural areas means greater scope for them, greater opportunities to make that decision to travel to the city to attend university or TAFE. I think that is an aspect of this particular bill which will be very well received right throughout Eden-Monaro and many other rural and regional seats.

I will finish with some comments on the contribution made by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin). In concluding her contribution, she made the charge that the government does nothing on the employment side—nothing to get them a job. When you listen to that sort of contribution, and many of the other contributions by those opposite, there seems to be this assumption that government can provide all: at the drop of a hat, any old time, you do not have to worry about where the money comes from; you just keep providing it. There is also another assumption that those on the other side seem to make: the only jobs that get created in this economy are the jobs that are paid for by the government.

A good example of that occurred under the former government where they talked about the so-called many hundreds of thousands of jobs that they or the so-called Working Nation created. But let us delve into what equalled the creation of a job: if somebody was placed on one of those three-month labour market programs, that was the creation of a job. If they then went off that three-month or six-month course and had a break for a while, and were then shunted into yet another one of those courses, that equalled the creation of another job. They were not jobs. That is not creating jobs. That is playing with numbers.

People opposite need to understand that the only way you will create long‐term jobs is by having some wealth creation, someone making a profit, someone willing to use some of that profit to invest in something new, take a risk, `risk and reward' as mentioned by the member for Werriwa—and we will have to keep reminding him of that; it is a good phrase that those on the other side should use more often. That is the only way you will be able to create proper long‐term jobs.

Proper long‐term jobs will not be created by the government writing out a cheque for a program that lasts three or six months, and then saying, `That's a job created.' What a load of rubbish. It is just an interim place to park somebody. Basically, all of these so-called jobs that were created were parking lots which were established to stick people into for a period of time. That was not the creation of jobs—because those jobs were not and are not there.

So I take some offence at the honourable member for Jagajaga saying that we on this side are doing nothing for employment. What we have done in the fiscal area in the short time that we have been here is remarkable. At a chamber of commerce meeting recently in Bateman's Bay I made the comment that the situation we took over when we came to government would be like somebody going out and saying: `There is a business for sale. That business turns over about $1.3 million a year, and has done for the last five years. But that business has made a loss of over $120,000 a year for every one of those five years.' If you were looking at buying a business and that was its record, you probably would not buy it. Anyway, we bought it because we got elected to government. We bought this business, or the equivalent thereof, that had been turning over about $1.3 million a year but with a loss of over $120,000. We have turned that loss around to a profit in the third year.

BREAK.PARA: Anybody who has had anything to do with business—I know there are not too many on the other side—would know that it is a remarkable achievement to turn a small business that is losing over $120,000 a year into a profit venture in three years. That is what we have done and that is what is going to create employment. It has given us very sound foundations in Australia. The evidence is all over the place that the rest of the world is praising us for the solid foundations we are creating through the changes we have made.

Business investment is skyrocketing. Anticipated business investment over the next few years is on a very steep, climbing graph. That will create the real jobs. We are putting our efforts into training people before they fall into unemployment. We have put an enormous effort into the apprenticeship schemes, the school apprenticeship schemes, the school to work schemes. We want people to come out of school ready and able to work, with the necessary skills. That, combined with the business investment that we see coming around the corner, will put these people into real jobs.

This bill is a very good bill. It is the right way to go. It takes away the incentive for young people to fall out of the family unit, to fall out of school, to fall out of education and training and go on the dole, but the safeguards are there to look after the people who really need to be looked after.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Hunter, I would inform him that under standing order 60, by the indulgence of the House, a member unable conveniently to stand by reason of infirmity would be permitted to sit and speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Madam Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your concern and your advice. I will attempt to deliver my very important address standing, but if it all becomes too much I will accept your invitation to sit.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong, (Mr Howard) must cringe every time he thinks about the ease with which he won the last federal election. You would think he would be happy about it. You would think he would be delighted to have had such a large victory. But I do not think he is. Not only has it delivered for him an unmanageably large and unruly back bench—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not unruly. They are totally supplicant.

—Absolutely. I thank my honourable colleague for interjecting. We had a 10-point plan once upon a time that wasn't too bad, but things seem to have changed with a little agitation from the government back bench. It must cause him to wonder, following that large election win, why he made so many promises, why he raised community expectations so high, why he promised the world. Members will recall that prior to the last election the world, according to the member for Bennelong, was one in which the sky was falling. Everything was a disaster and it was all Paul Keating's fault. More importantly, John Howard was going to fix the lot. He must now wonder how things might have been if only he had taken a more responsible approach to electioneering. But he wanted it so badly. He knew he would only get one chance and he was fed up with life in opposition after 13 long years. So what did he do? He promised the world. He undid years of hard work by members on both sides in this place in terms of selling the hard decisions Australian governments needed to make in the face of globalisation—things like tariff reform, financial deregulation, competition policy.

SPEECH.PARA: But his worst crime was his over-simplification of the unemployment problem, the problem the now Prime Minister was going to fix overnight. Members will recall that the member for Bennelong and the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), now the responsible minister in this area of public policy, travelled the length and breadth of the country prior to the election bleating about unemployment and, in particular, youth unemployment—it was a crisis. With respect to youth unemployment they exploited that silly method, as I see it, of measuring youth unemployment that takes no account of the fact that the overwhelming majority of 15- to 18-year-olds are in some form of schooling or training and, therefore, are not part of the labour force. This gives us an inflated base figure and an inflated youth unemployment rate in percentage terms. But there they were, Chicken Little and his mate. `The sky is falling', they were crying, `so you had better follow me.'

Community expectations were very high by the time the Prime Minister took office. But what has he done on the unemployment front? What is the government's record? Generally speaking, unemployment has gone up, both in terms of the overall rate and the youth unemployment rate. That is one of the reasons the Prime Minister has slumped so badly in the opinion polls. That is one of the reasons he has managed to reduce what was about a 10‐point lead to about a four‐point deficit. The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 is another reason for that slump.

The new youth allowance will replace a number of existing benefits for younger Australians. It replaces Austudy for 16‐ to 24‐year‐olds, newstart allowance for 16‐ to 20‐year‐olds, youth training allowance for 16‐ to 17‐year‐olds, sickness allowance for 16‐ to 20‐year olds and the more than minimum rate of family payment for secondary students aged 16 to 18 not receiving Austudy. The rationalisation of the payments, as so many speakers on this side have already said, is welcomed by us. But what the changes basically mean—and this is my greatest concern—is that parents will now be financially responsible for their children until they reach the age of 21, whether they live at home or not.

There are almost 30,000 young Australians aged 15, 16 and 17 and almost 100,000 people aged 18, 19 and 20 receiving an unemployment benefit of some sort. These figures are, of course, unacceptably high and, as a result of the changes announced, more than 30,000 of them will have their benefits reduced and another 14,000 or so will lose their $147 per fortnight benefit entirely because of the parental income test. The benefit will start to cut out when parental income exceeds $23,350 each year. What an appalling level! It reminds us of the nursing home assets test, Madam Deputy Speaker, doesn't it? It rings a bell indeed.

But the most curious measure of all is the one that dictates that 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds will be eligible for the new youth allowance only if they are in full‐time study, if they are studying part‐time while also looking for work or if they have completed year 12. Given the fact that more than 60,000 young people in Australia missed out on a TAFE place last year, what is to become of all those who cannot get into education, particularly when the government has made no additional commitment to host those students who will be forced back into school education?

Surely we do not want all young Australians to go on to sit for the higher school certificate. High school classes are already overflowing because there are so many students attending who do not really want to be there but do not have much choice. The new rules will exacerbate the problem at a time when the government is cutting education funding. The desire to improve the skills of our young people is an honourable one but, in the absence of a commitment to additional funding for education and training programs, it certainly rings hollow.

Further, under the guidelines of the new service delivery agencies, which basically replace the CES, to receive labour market assistance and training, young people must be in receipt of some sort of benefit. So it now appears that those who do not quality for benefits, either because of the parental income test or because they are less than 18 and do not fit into one of the categories I mentioned earlier, will be denied access to training programs. Of course, the thousands of youth who will lose their benefits will drop off the unemployment list and, therefore, no doubt, the government will be making a claim or boasting about a drop in the youth unemployment rate. But let me share with the House the direct impact that this bill will have on my electorate. More than 200‐odd students will be forced back to school in the lower Hunter area alone—the lower half of my electorate. These are working‐class areas where average family incomes are much lower than the national average.

BREAK.PARA: Since the election of the Howard government, we have seen so many pieces of bad public policy driven by an obsession with the budget bottom line. The government has been at pains to point out that the particular measures contained within this bill will not result in savings for the government. This bill is driven by something worse than a fixation with the budget bottom line. The motivation behind this bill, just like the work for the dole proposal, is driven by opinion polls and with a particular eye on the lagging results for the Prime Minister in those opinion polls of recent weeks. It is an attempt to capitalise on a view in the community that there exists too great an incentive not to work in this country. But I ask: is this an informed view; and, if not, are governments elected to make informed decisions for the benefit of the country or to blindly pursue popular causes?

The Prime Minister wants things to be just like they used to be. He wants to take us back rather than forward. But the world has changed and, as a nation, we cannot afford to sit back and be relaxed and comfortable. John Howard obviously remembers with great fondness the days when young people could leave school early and walk into a job, but they were largely unskilled jobs that simply do not exist any more.

We on this side will support any properly considered policy to encourage greater rates of school retention and further education and training. We did that pretty well in government, taking year 12 retention rates from one‐third in the early 1980s to around two‐thirds by the early 1990s. But this bill is not worthy of such support. This is the big stick approach. Its message for young Australians is: stay at school regardless of your intellectual capacity or regardless of any adverse family or social circumstances you may find yourself in, or go and get a job. As if the jobs are out there! Indeed, as a result of so many of the policies of this government, there are fewer jobs out there now than there were at the time that they came to government. It is an unrealistic demand.

Of course this bill is discriminatory. It discriminates against those regions where family incomes are low and job opportunities are almost non-existent. The 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds lucky enough to have a family to support them will get by okay. Those who do not will not be so lucky. Many of them live in my own electorate. In Cessnock more than 73 per cent of students leave school by the age of 16. The New South Wales average is just 55 per cent. But forcing them to do the New South Wales HSC will not change the value they place on the HSC. There will be a total of 363 of them in my electorate. As I mentioned earlier, 298 of them live in the lower Hunter, where average family incomes are well below the national average.

Has this government not been watching the horrific growth in youth suicide in this country? We have just had a report from a standing committee on that matter. Has the government not noticed that the incidence of youth suicide is greatest in the regions where unemployment is high? Does it not understand that this tactic is going to exacerbate that problem? These are regions where labour market programs have already been slashed and where, as I said, there are fewer jobs available now than there ever were before, certainly than there were before this government came to office. Public sector jobs are largely gone, as you know, Madam Deputy Speaker.

Does this government not realise that pulling $145 out of a struggling family's fortnightly budget is a recipe for disaster? Like the work for the dole scheme, this policy does not represent a serious attempt to address the unemployment problem in this country, nor does it seek to really be serious about fixing the school retention rates or getting people into training.

This bill is really about conservative ideology. `When all else fails,' they say, `get the big stick out to those dole bludgers in working‐class areas.' We should have a look at the work for the dole scheme and look at where the projects have gone, Madam Deputy Speaker. I do not know how many you got in your Labor electorate. You indicate that you got none. Guess how many we got in Hunter. Youth unemployment rates in the lower end of the electorate are at least more than 30 per cent.

We read in the Sydney Morning Herald that the youth unemployment rate is 19 per cent, but that is the average across the electorate. In the lower Hunter the rates are in excess of 30 per cent. How many projects came to the Hunter electorate? Not one. Yet I heard Minister Kemp on A Current Affair being asked about the number of projects that went to the Hunter. He very cleverly said that 19 projects went to the Hunter and the North Coast. He just threw in the bit about the North Coast. I think nine of those went to the electorate of the member for Richmond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not quite that many.
—Was it nine, eight or seven?
—Seven.
—I ask the member for Hunter to address his remarks through the chair.

—Seven projects went to the electorate of the member for Richmond. Not one went to Hunter, where youth unemployment rates exceed 30 per cent, and this government wants to tell us it is serious about addressing the problem.

BREAK.PARA: Minister Kemp need not tell us that there were no applications or that the applications were not up to scratch, because I have seen them. They were very competitive and very professionally done. Why did the Hunter electorate not get any work for the dole schemes? Because it is a Labor electorate. That is the approach of this government in terms of addressing the youth unemployment problem in this country. Some will say that the Labor Party opposed the work for the dole scheme, and we did. We are proud we opposed it because of its lack of training and because of the lack of opportunity it provides for younger people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You supported it down here.

—But on the basis that they cut everything else, Madam Deputy Speaker, and on the basis that they cut all the other programs. It is the only lifeline our younger people have. So we do not have any choice now but to pursue with great vigour funding for projects for work for the dole in our electorates. As populist and as opinion poll driven as the policy may have been and as unfounded as it may have been and as lacking as it may have been in terms of training and all those other concerns we expressed in the second reading debate, we have no choice but to seek them, and we do. But unfortunately it seems that the government thinks it is more important to win a few votes in marginal government held electorates than assist younger Australians.

BREAK.PARA: I take honourable members back again to the member for Goldstein and the Prime Minister prior to the election and how concerned they were about younger Australians and this crisis we had in terms of youth unemployment. What is their response now? Their response is an ill-considered work for the dole scheme and a big stick that says, `Get back to school or get a job or find your own way to survive.' That is their response. They should stand condemned for it. I am honoured to be standing here on this side as one of those who will not wear it. I am surprised that people like the member for Richmond, himself in an area that has high youth unemployment, can stand here—although he has not done so yet; he might surprise me—and support this bill, which is just a bad piece of public policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the previous speaker, the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon). I realise that he has injured his foot. Certainly most of us wish him a speedy recovery but I think, in the process of his delivery, he may have suffered some concussion.
—No, I am not on pain‐killers.

—Unfortunately, most of his speech, whilst worthy in intent, missed the mark in many aspects and I will take the opportunity through my delivery to address some of those. The first point is that the whole reason for this Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 which is being debated is to give a real incentive for younger people to further their education and training, which is the greatest thing you can give a young person to ensure that they do not join the ranks of the unem ployed. The previous government were in power for more than a decade—13 years—and saw an enormous rise of youth unemployment. Indeed, I am sure that if they had been in government today a similar youth allowance would have been introduced by them.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I propose to give honourable members a description of the bill, its benefits and whom it will cover. Youth allowance is one more initiative down a positive path of reform that this government has embarked on. Youth allowance is an important positive social policy reform and we do not step aside from that. It is an initiative which the government is undertaking, but not in response to the hypocritical, superficial rhetoric regrettably coming from my colleague on the left. Those opposite were expelled from office, not least because youth unemployment increased to a staggering 32.3 per cent. Worse still, youth unemployment in the Richmond‐Tweed mid‐North Coast region was over 50 per cent prior to the 1996 federal election. There is no question that all members of this House would agree that high levels of unemployment are one of the principal causes of despair, lack of self‐esteem and regrettably, in many parts of Australia, a totally unacceptable and tragic level of youth suicide.

The government has consulted widely on this bill. Back in 1996 when we went out to the community, young people, their families and the general community told us that the current arrangements are unfair, inefficient and far too complex. We inherited a system that treats the young in a similar situation very differently according to whether they are students or unemployed. What is a youth allowance? Essentially, it is an income support payment for young Australians which integrates payments irrespective of whether they are for education, training, unemployment or sickness. I note that the opposition does not have a problem with that.

The job market is very difficult for inexperienced people. As the member for Hunter said, unless you have training, your prospects of getting a job are significantly diminished. This is particularly so for young people. The facts are that if you do not complete secondary schooling, if you leave in year 10 and do not go on to year 12—I acknowledge there has been an increase in the number of people going on to year 12, but it is not enough—you have a three times higher probability of being unemployed. They are the facts. One in five Australians coming out of school today is technically illiterate, according to the ABS. A further 30 per cent do not reach the standards a modern society requires.

What chance do these young people have of getting a job? This is yet another problem we have inherited from 13 years under the ALP. It is another problem which is not of our making but which we intend to fix. Full‐time and part‐time employment for 15‐ to 24‐year‐olds has fallen by three per cent since 1982. By comparison, total full‐time employment has grown 16 per cent and total full‐time and part‐time employment—which is the trend in our labour market now—have grown 31 per cent.

The youth allowance is intended to send a clear message to young people that the best pathway to a job is through education or training, and is intended to encourage them to take advantage of increased vocational, education and training opportunities before they look for a job. That is quite sensible. The youth allowance is based on a philosophy of family values where the responsibility for children is the responsibility of parents first and the state second. It has also become self‐evident to all except the Labor Party that we need competitive young Australians who are well skilled and confident and who can take us into the next century as our most valuable resource, particularly as we compete with Asia. Wasn't that what the previous Prime Minister meant when he said `looking at the big picture'?

The common youth allowance offers a wide variety of benefits compared with current arrangements. It offers incentive to study rather than to go on the dole. It offers a greater coverage for those young people who need assistance as well as simplification, equity for rural Australia and a consistent parental means test. I propose to address these issues. With respect to more incentive to study: as I have demonstrated before, under the system we inherited, as many on this side would realise, you are better off going on the dole. It is easier to go on that than to go to school or university. It is harder to get Austudy to further your education than it is to go on the disgraceful system we have now, where it is easy to go on social security.

Importantly, the common youth allowance will remove disincentives to study. The Australian Financial Review accurately laid the blame on poorly designed incentives and labour market rigidities as well as a failure in schooling and vocational training. This government has done much to improve this over the past year by focusing on literacy and basic skills.

The youth allowance complements these achievements. It will encourage people to complete or further their education by removing undesirable incentives to leave school early or to choose unemployment over education and training. One particular improvement which I welcome is the increase in rent assistance for students. This will benefit a massive 70,000 students who, on average, will gain over $30 per fortnight—a very positive response.

This government has massively increased funding towards apprenticeships, traineeships and TAFE places. It has increased funding for schools by $14 billion over the next four years. This will cater for some of those who stay at school. But in the area of apprenticeships and traineeships there will be 100,000 places. Under the previous government, numbers of apprenticeships and traineeships were at their lowest level since World War II as people were funnelled into, in most cases, unworkable labour market programs which distorted the market and did not give those people some elementary training.

On the New South Wales coast, traineeships in the last year have taken off, particularly in the areas of tourism, new forms of agriculture and retail. We have seen expanded places now in TAFE colleges at Kingscliff and Wollongbar, and an upgrade is now happening at Murwillumbah.

We inherited from the previous government great structural problems within the labour market. We need to redress this problem. We still have an unskilled, uneducated work force. When you look at the gospel of Beazley, it is interesting to see that in many ways those opposite are still wishing to encourage this by a throwback to the early policies of the eighties and, with some of their other policies, the fifties. The electorate is far more sophisticated now, as certainly are young Australians.

We are addressing labour market problems by trying to foster a climate for training and education—and we are being quite deliberate about it—which will attract young people. One of the other areas has been the changes we have made to industrial relations and our industrial reforms. It is a shame that there was not unanimous support, certainly by the opposition, regarding the cry over unfair dismissal reforms, particularly to small business. We particularly wanted to ensure that small businesses with under 15 employees could put a person on knowing that, if things did not work out, each of them had an adequate exit route within the first 12 months. This would have been of enormous benefit to young people because employers would have given them the chance to have a start. In most cases that is what they are looking for—a start in the employment market. Regrettably that was denied by the Labor Party.

The common youth allowance will apply to 560,000 young people who are currently on income support. Of these, 416,000 are students aged between 16 and 25. The other 144,000 are unemployed people aged between 16 and 21. Precisely the point that we are trying to focus on is giving them greater education and greater skills to get them into the work force.

This is not, as the dilettantes opposite vainly try to portray it, a savings measure. In fact, this government will be spending more—$25 million more, or $50 per receipt, on program costs alone. However, as with any major reform, not everyone will be better off. Of course, there will be some winners and losers, but there will be three times more winners. That is a key point in this youth allowance policy. Of the 560,000 young people who will transfer into the new system, 378,000 will receive the same money as they currently are receiving. A staggering 137,000 additional young Australians across the country will receive an increased amount, compared to 45,000 who will receive less.

Another benefit of the common youth allowance is that it will replace the exceptionally unwieldy arrangements that this government inherited. The introduction of this new payment thus fulfils our election promise. As opposed to what the member for Hunter has said, we have fulfilled an enormous range of our election promises which go to simplifying income support payments. It is exactly what we have done with Centrelink.

The youth allowance will be replacing the five differential payments—namely, Austudy for students aged 16 to 24, the youth training, newstart and sickness allowances for 16‐ to 20‐year‐olds, and the `more than minimum' family payment for secondary students aged 16 to 18 who are currently not getting Austudy. Contrary to the hysteria generated by the Labor Party and other minority parties, the youth allowance does not affect Abstudy, the assistance for isolated children's scheme, the pensioner education supplement, the disability support pension, the sole parent pension, the parenting allowance and the veterans' children education scheme, and on it goes.

What it is doing is bringing 13 schemes into five. At the same time, the reform recognises that there is a growing number of young people who do not follow the traditional pathway from full-time study to full-time employment. Under the new system, young people whose personal circumstances change slightly will no longer have their payments cancelled and be forced to reclaim another—a positive measure. Australians, irrespective of their political persuasion, are sick and tired of red tape. This government is trying to cut through it, and it will achieve that with the youth allowance.

More importantly, this bill gives equity particularly to rural Australia. The government recognises that educating and finding jobs for children—my children are very young and will be looking for employment in years to come—is very difficult. Rural families will benefit from the youth allowance because, as I have said before, rent assistance will be available for the first time to young people who live away from home and who are in an educational course.

This is especially important to the electorate of Richmond, where over 10 per cent of the population is between the ages of 15 and 24. Most of them, if they are continuing higher education, will need to travel out of the electorate. I do not have the luxury of a university in my electorate, although we have some very good ones nearby—Southern Cross University at Lismore and Griffith University on the Gold Coast, and we have access to other universities both in Brisbane and, further afield, in Sydney. So rent assistance will be a major benefit to these people. Contrary to what the member for Hunter said, enrolments at Southern Cross University, even with the increase in HECS fees, have actually increased.

I now turn to the issue of who qualifies for the new allowance. To qualify for the youth allowance, young people aged 18 and over will need to undertake full-time study, training or job search. For those under 18, the payments will be linked to their participation in full-time education or training. But there will be some buffer zones and exemptions—for those people who are homeless, ill or unable to access appropriate education or training. There is a safety net for those people who are not able to obtain it or have disadvantaged situations at home.

Consistent parental means testing will remove one of the major anomalies between existing support programs for young people. It will encourage parental support and also ensure that young people in similar circumstances have similar entitlements. The parental means test component of this bill measures the parents' capacity to take financial responsibility for the living expenses of their dependant children. The test will consist of a parental income test, a parental assets test and an actual means test. The parental means test reinforces the government's message that families which are unable to support younger members will be treated fairly, which is very different to the type of culture that was encouraged by the previous government.

BREAK.PARA: The key concept in means testing is fairness and the bill recognises that many young people will be exempt from the parental means test, as I have demonstrated before, as will those young people who are married, have children or are disadvantaged. It comes into place on 1 July 1998. It has already received considerable praise outside this chamber. I quote:
The end of youth dole will be welcomed by parents who have battled to persuade their children against choosing the false independence it seemed to offer—
the independence perhaps of going on social security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was the Sydney Morning Herald —not a paper well known to be supporting the government—in its editorial entitled `Without dole, responsibility'. Another good article, in the Australian Financial Review —also not a great advocate of the government—was even more effusive in welcoming the changes:

BREAK.PARA: The Federal Government's decision to ditch the dole for under-18s and tighten access to benefits for 18 to 21-year-olds should be vigorously applauded. So should its move to replace a range of youth benefits . . . with a single payment, and its efforts to push the young jobless to improve their skills rather than remain idle. . . The changes . . . are weighted towards solid Australian values and hard work . . .

Exactly what the battlers of your constituency advocate. The Australian Financial Review went on to say that the `changes help engender a culture of self-improvement rather than the welfare-dependence and dole culture which has crept into the Australian life' and ethos. Even an article in the Daily News , which is my local paper in Tweed Heads, said under the banner `Dole overhaul long overdue':

. . . the scheme appears to be built around a desire to see our young people either in a training program, furthering their education, or at home with their families who love and support them. Surely, this is a preferable scenario to the dole.

Of course the government is embarking on other measures to assist with this tragedy that we have of high youth unemployment: the JPET program, better known as the Job Placement Employment and Training program, the work for the dole scheme and the hugely popular Green Corps, which have all been warmly welcomed by the people on the North Coast.

I might add that the JPET program in Richmond, where over $250,000 of Commonwealth funding went into a program which is aimed at helping disadvantaged young people with accommodation, employment, education and training, was actually introduced by the previous government. The JPET program in Byron and Ballina, run by the Byron youth services, does a fantastic job. It is delivering help for under-20-year-olds to tackle the problem of getting full accommodation, training and employment and the problem of self‐esteem. It is also trying to reduce the heinous proliferation we have now of drugs—a situation not unique to Byron or other parts of Richmond but right across Australia. It is a very worthwhile program.

Likewise, we have a number of work for the dole projects in the Richmond electorate ranging from Cabarita, west to Murwillumbah and south to Ballina. The New South Wales North Coast has been given great support in these projects by Centrelink—another major initiative—through getting volunteers for that work for the dole scheme. These organisations are Tweed Shire Council, Ballina Skills Development Centre, Tweed Training and Enterprise Co. and Environmental Training and Employment. All are doing very worthy projects: getting young people and giving them some self‐esteem and getting them some training under that mutual obligation.

The Green Corps has been another hugely successful project. I have had the benefit of going along to see, witness and explore what they are doing, particularly at Fingal Head, Hastings Point, Kingscliff—that is one Green Corps project—Broken Head near Byron Bay, and Wollongbar with its restoration of the Big Scrub remnants. The Green Corps project has given incredible self‐esteem to those young people who do not necessarily have to be unemployed.

The other organisations in my electorate I would like to thank for giving their support to youth services are the Tweed Valley Family and Youth Support Service; the Tweed Heads Police and Citizens Youth Club; the youth groups in Tweed Heads, Tweed Coast and Murwillumbah; St Joseph's Youth Hostel; Byron Youth Centre; Ballina Youth Centre; and Recovery 2000 run by a very remarkable lady called Shel Hillman. I would also like to thank all the local volunteer organisations in Richmond for the tireless work they do in aiding the young people of the Northern Rivers—organisations such as the Salvation Army, St Vincent de Paul and the church groups.

The future of the young people of Australia should not be a political battlefield. I urge all members to support this bill, which is geared to encourage young people to better themselves through further education and training so that we can reduce that huge level of youth unemployment. It did not happen overnight; it took many years to accumulate under the stewardship of the previous government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In many ways the contrast between the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 and the former government's Working Nation program sums up the differences between the Howard government, with the support of the Liberal and National parties, and the Labor opposition. It is quite an interesting contrast. In the legislation before the House, we have a government, through its common youth allowance, trying to take away the support which has been provided in the past through newstart to 16‐ and 17‐year‐old Australians who, unfortunately, are out of work but are actively seeking work—that, of course, being the central obligation before people are eligible for support from the government. This government is seeking to take away support from those 16‐ and 17‐year‐old Australians who are unlucky enough to be out of work and it also seeks to impose quite a harsh new means test on young Australians who are under 21.

SPEECH.PARA: The contrast between a government trying to force people, through this common youth allowance, to return to school or become dependent on their parents for support and the alternative of the former Labor government is quite remarkable. It is quite remarkable when you consider that the alternative the former Labor government had in operation was a massive injection of federal funding to provide training programs—training opportunities—for these very same young Australians.

My electorate is on the New South Wales Central Coast, and through quite a large number of organisations who receive funding under a wide range of programs under Working Nation we were able to work together to see if there were ways that we could find new opportunities for young Australians who were out of work and even new opportunities for some of the older Australians who had been out of work for longer periods of time. Through groups such as Wyong Workwise, the local Skillshare operation in Wyong shire, and Wyong Council, through one of the jobskills programs, we were able to ensure that there were many opportunities for our young local residents who were out of work to improve their opportunities for employment.

Those opportunities were improved by giving them opportunities to do practical training that was relevant to them in their career desires and also gave them the greatest opportunity to develop practical skills that would make them potential candidates for employment in the local community. The alternative which this government is offering is a common youth allowance which seeks to say to Australians under 18, `You must return to school or you will be denied any of the entitlements you have received in the past through the newstart program.'

On the date the new common youth allowance takes effect the people living in the electorate of the previous speaker, the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony), are going to face some difficulties. One of those difficulties will be that a large number of families in that electorate are going to be denied the income that was coming in through the support that was flowing to the 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds.

In my own electorate of Dobell on the New South Wales Central Coast our calculations suggest that there are going to be a lot of families who are going to have to reach into their pockets to provide this extra support to their young kids. These will often be families who are already doing it very tough. Families who are trying to live on very tight budgets are now going to be expected to provide the extra funding to their kids for bus fares, clothing, food and lodging. That is going to be very difficult for those people on tight budgets.

The government's response to these criticisms is that there is no need for these 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds to depend on their parents. If they go back to school and finish year 12 they will continue to receive the same amount of support as they would have received when looking for work and receiving support from the government. The difficulty is that that is going to place enormous pressure on our local high schools in areas like the Central Coast. The figures for the New South Wales Central Coast, which is covered mainly by the electorates of Robertson and Dobell and partly by the electorate of my colleague the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), show that we are going to see a return of about 693 students to Central Coast high schools. Basing your calculations on where people live—according to their post‐codes—you can estimate that approximately 320 of those students will be in the electorate of Dobell.

I do not expect you to know how crowded the high schools are on the New South Wales Central Coast, Mr Deputy Speaker, but they are already extremely overcrowded. The two high schools at Wyong and The Entrance and the high school in the neighbouring electorate of Shortland and that at Gorokan in my own electorate have all already reached their quotas for students. Northlakes High School, just over the border in the electorate of Shortland again, has already exceeded its quota of students. Further south, The Entrance High School alone might be forced to take about 150 new students, based on post‐code information. Most of those students may not wish to be at school. If you have massive overcrowding in the high school, it is certainly going to be extremely difficult for the teachers at those schools to try to provide the sorts of educational opportunities that all of us would hope could be provided.

BREAK.PARA: Also, difficulties have arisen in the past with students who are plainly uninterested in continuing their studies at high school. Whether because of parental direction or instruction, students return to school when they do not wish to be at school. Unfortunately, it is often the case that a single student who is not finding the courses relevant or stimulating and is not paying attention and is distracting not only the teacher but all the other students in the class can deny all the other students the opportunity to learn additional skills and to learn something about the curriculum courses in years 11 and 12.

This problem is going to get worse as this government seeks to force larger numbers of 16‐ and 17‐ year‐olds, if not all 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds, to return to school to finish year 12. One of the ways we can try to ameliorate this problem is to encourage all the state departments of education to continue working on new subjects and curricula that provide skills and training that are relevant for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds who may currently be unemployed but may be forced to return to the education system.

I know that the current Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, (Dr Kemp), has sought to conduct an illegitimate debate about the standards in many of our schools, but I certainly believe there is strong support out there in the community for additional courses which are relevant for young people who may be forced to return to high school because of this government's legislation.

This overcrowding problem on the Central Coast will to some extent be addressed by the activities of two of our state members. Jill Hall, the current state member for Swansea and the future member for Shortland in this House has been very active in lobbying the New South Wales Minister for Education, John Aquilina, for the funding for a new high school at Lake Munmorah. My state colleague, Paul Crittenden, the member for Wyong has been successful in obtaining approval for a new high school to be built at Warnervale, an area which is already starting to undergo very rapid population growth.

The massive increase in the number of students in high schools on the Central Coast can be contrasted with what is going to happen in some of the areas such as the North Shore of Sydney. I mentioned before that 693 people in the target age group who receive unemployment benefits currently live on the Central Coast. If 693 are encouraged or forced—depending on which verb you wish to choose—to return to the local schools, that can be contrasted with what is going to happen in suburbs to the south of us. In places like the North Shore you can see quite clearly that there will be a much reduced effect.

An analysis which has been done by my colleague the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) indicates that in places like Gosford 127 young people who are 16 or 17 years old will be forced back to school, but in places like Manly there are three, in Cammeray there is one and in Killara there is one. In Campbelltown there are 226 and in the western suburbs of Sydney at Mount Druitt there are 282. It is quite clear that the additional overcrowding problems are going to occur in the outer metropolitan suburbs—in places like the Central Coast, the western suburbs of Sydney, the Campbelltown district and Wollongong. It is these areas that will bear the brunt of this government's decisions.

Unfortunately, the federal government has not been prepared to provide additional funding to the state departments of education to cater for the additional 27,000 students that this new common youth allowance is expected to force back into schools right around the country. If the government were serious, it would have increased the funding to the states by about $140 million to ensure that there were sufficient resources in our state education system to cope with the influx that will result from these particular measures.

The previous speaker in this debate, the honourable member for Richmond, also trumpeted the success of the government's work for the dole program. I always appreciate it when members of the government bring up the work for the dole program, because I think it will go down in the Australian community as one of the Howard government's worst mistakes. One of the reasons why I think it is a mistake is that many members of the Australian community are not aware of the quite limited nature of John Howard's work for the dole program. Under this Prime Minister, a work for the dole program—which was clearly the result of Liberal Party polling rather than any serious attempt to assist young unemployed Australians—was announced on the weekend that the government was facing enormous pressure as a result of a series of newspaper articles about former Senator Bob Woods.

What is this work for the dole program? It is two days a week, not five; it is available only to a limited number of young Australians; and there is no provision for funding for proper skills training as part of the work for the dole program. If the government were serious about providing young Australians with proper skills and training, there would be something which we in Working Nation called reciprocal obligations. There should be obligations on young people receiving support from the government that they work for a local community organisation or they undergo approved training or a combination of the above. If they are not prepared to meet that obligation to the community, they should lose the support they are going to receive from the government. That is the obligation that should be placed on the young person.

The obligation on the government is to provide young people with the support they need for five days a week of work or training and to provide funding for the training to take place. The government should make sure that such a scheme is available to all young Australians who are in need of additional skills or additional opportunities, not just the lucky 10,000 or 20,000 that the Prime Minister has decided should be eligible for his work for the dole program.

The other difficulty I have with people like the member for Richmond trumpeting the success of his projects under the work for the dole program is that it is quite clear these projects have been chosen on a party political basis. I am pleased that the member for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) has chosen this moment to walk into the chamber. I was not surprised when he had two work for the dole projects approved in his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was because they were excellent submissions. That's why they were approved.
—He argues that was because they were excellent submissions. I thought he might have tried the line that it was because of his excellent work as the local member but—
—Thank you, Michael.

—He is claiming credit for that by agreeing with my comment. The honourable member for Robertson knows that the unemployment rate is high on the New South Wales Central Coast. In fact, it is higher in the northern half of the Central Coast than it is in the southern half of the Central Coast.

BREAK.PARA: Isn't it a coincidence that, of the electorates that cover the Central Coast that happened to receive work for the dole project funding, two of them just happen to be Liberal electorates and no projects at all were funded within the electorate of Dobell? Isn't it a coincidence that an analysis of the 25 electorates that have the highest rates of youth unemployment in the country shows that, of the 13 that receive no work for the dole project funding, 10 happen to be Labor electorates? I am sure that the government can come up with proper analyses that explain why it is the Labor electorates that have had Medicare offices closed and why it is the Labor electorates that have missed out on project funding to help young unemployed people. We would like to hear the government bring forward those explanations. We would like to hear the government try to explain how they have reached these decisions.

I would like to touch on a couple of other comments made by the member for Robertson in his contribution to this debate. He was quite critical of the contribution of the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) in this debate. He made a number of allegations that she had incorrectly claimed that large numbers of people would be worse off, especially large numbers of young unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's true.
—We on this side of the House claim that there will be significant numbers of young unemployed Australians who will be worse off as a result of these measures.

BREAK.PARA: I think it will be quite a rude awakening for people such as the member for Richmond and the member for Robertson when this common youth allowance takes effect, when large numbers of people in both of those electorates find out that families on very tight budgets will be expected to support their young people when in the past the government has provided some modest assistance as long as they were actively seeking work.

When these families, many of whom are on low incomes, have their support from the federal government reduced or abolished, I hope they pick up the phone and ring the members for Robertson and Richmond to let them know that it has affected them and that decisions which we take here affect people out there in the wider community.

We have already seen it happen with nursing homes. The government members are about to see it happen with their unfair changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme on 1 February, when that takes effect, and when the common youth allowance also makes changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —A typical scare campaign—whatever it takes.

—The member interjects and says it is a typical scare campaign. The elderly Australians out there thought that your nursing home changes were scary; that was the scary part of the changes you made. And when people realise the impact of these changes implemented under the common youth allowance and the changes you are making—
—Giving young people a bit of hope; giving them a future?
—The member says that these changes give people a bit of hope. This takes away money from many families who are often on tight budgets.
—Rubbish!

—While the member interjects and says that is rubbish, there are going to be a lot of people in his electorate who will end up with less money going to their families because of the changes that he and his colleagues are supporting in this particular debate.

BREAK.PARA: For all of these reasons, I have been convinced by the member for Werriwa that I should be supporting the second reading amendment that he has moved. We believe that, while the government's legislation contains some improvements that we welcome and provides some additional flexibility, the decision to take away funding from young Australians in particular is very much and very strongly opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested to listen to the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) as he said that this legislation made the great contrast between this government and the previous government. He talked about Working Nation, the massive injection of funds and the training programs. I recall a little bit of that as a member of the opposition, and the frustration of those people who had been long‐term unemployed. They went onto these programs, worked for six months and then came into my office more frustrated than when they began because there was no employment waiting for them after they had been recycled through one of these so‐called training programs.

SPEECH.PARA: There was another issue that caught my attention during the week in a poll that was done—I think it was in the Bulletin—where 57 per cent of Australians believed that welfare was too easy to get. The most remarkable part of that poll was that 47 per cent on welfare itself believed that it was too easy to get. The great fallacy of what the member for Dobell has tried to convince us of tonight is that somehow or other this massive injection of funds is plucked from fresh air, that it comes from nowhere and that it is created by governments, ministers and politicians. Most Australians know that is nonsense. They know that it comes straight from the taxpayer's pocket.

The number of teenagers in full‐time jobs in 1966 was 59 per cent. The number of teenagers in full‐time jobs in 1984 had nearly halved to 33 per cent. If we trace back the issue of unemployment benefits, which were introduced in 1944, we find that from March 1973 to November 1975 the youth rates of unemployment benefit were the same as the full adult allowance rate. That was, of course, during the period of the Whitlam government. We know that levels of unemployment increased dramatically from the early 1970s. In 1972 there were about 70,000 unemployed aged from 15 to 25, growing to 320,000 for the same period by 1983. In the 1970s, at the time of the Whitlam government formulated policy, concerns grew that the income support rates were providing too much of a financial incentive for the unemployed. Support for this view was generally agreed to emanate from the increasing youth wages relative to those of adults in the period 1972 to 1974. There was a significant jump in youth unemployment rates in 1975 and a continuance of high youth unemployment through to the 1970s. I remind the House that in 1966 almost 60 per cent of teenagers had full‐time jobs but in 1984 just over half that number had full‐time jobs.

The member for Dobell makes the point that there will be some people who will need to go back into the schooling system and that the federal government should provide for that extra income. I am happy to have a look at that but I think we will find that the federal government has been extremely generous in its funding of the state school system in the forward estimates into the next century.

In my part speech tonight, I would remind the member for Dobell that Tony Blair, the new Labor Prime Minister of the UK, said that the most important thing that a government can do is provide a job provided by an employer—not a job provided by the government and not a job supported by the taxpayer, but a job provided by the employer. That is the full purpose of this Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 .

I would also remind the House that the youth allowance is to replace numerous payments, including the youth training allowance, the newstart allowance, the sickness allowance for 16‐ to 20‐year olds and most 15‐year‐olds receiving these payments.
