INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight is the anniversary of the sinking of the HMAS Sydney which was lost off the coast of Western Australia on 19 November 1941. Members might be aware that in recent months the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and I have pursued in this place a view that there ought to be a parliamentary inquiry into the circumstances of the sinking of the Sydney . Our interest in this matter arises as members of the HMAS Sydney Foundation Trust, which was established in Perth with the objectives of supporting moves to locate the HMAS Sydney ; accepting that, regardless of the outcome, surviving family members of those who lost their lives on the Sydney are owed consideration of a full‐scale public search for the vessel; and ensuring suitable commemorative activities for the Sydney . I have argued previously in this place that there is a national obligation on the part of the Australian community and the parliament to make a last effort to seek to locate and properly commemorate the Sydney .

SPEECH.PARA: Recently the parliament referred the matter to the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I was very pleased that the House and the committee responded accordingly. Since the establishment of the inquiry a number of people from Western Australia have raised concerns with me, with the honourable member for Moore and with a former state parliamentary colleague the Hon. Graham Edwards, who was also very active as a trustee of the trust and who was the original suggester of a parliament inquiry at one of our trustees meetings. We have received representations from a number of people who are keen to make representations to the committee but who are worried that if they do so they may be in breach of secrecy obligations and provisions entered into by them in the course of their war service or in the years immediately following.

As a consequence of those approaches, the honourable member for Moore and I raised this matter of concern with the Chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who is of course the father of the House. He has replied to me in recent days and I would like to take the opportunity, so as to encourage those members of the public who have an interest in this matter and may wish to make a submission to the Defence Subcommittee's inquiry, to read the letter in full into the record:

Thank you for your letter of 14 November 1997 seeking advice on the position of individuals who may wish to give evidence to the Committee's inquiry into the loss of HMAS Sydney in 1941, but who fear prosecution because, in the giving of such evidence, they may breach secrecy undertakings made during or after World War II.

As a general principle you would be aware that, once a submission has been received by a parliamentary committee and authorised for publication, parliamentary privilege extends to that submission, protecting the author from prosecution or adverse actions by others because of the submission.

If a prospective witness was apprehensive about the giving of evidence, notwithstanding the protection made explicitly by the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, they could request that their submission be confidential, and that the Committee consider taking evidence in camera.

The Committee prefers that as much evidence as possible be on the public record, and would consider such requests on a case by case basis. It should be noted, however, that the Committee (and indeed both Houses) retains the power subsequently to authorise the publication of evidence.

In regard to the possibility of restrictions on individuals because of statutory secrecy provisions, such secrecy provisions have no effect on the powers of the Houses or their committees to conduct inquiries. As stated in Odgers Australian Senate Practice :

. . . general secrecy provisions do not prevent committees seeking the information covered by such provisions or persons who have that information providing it to committees. The basis of this view is that the law of parliamentary privilege provides absolute immunity to the giving of evidence before a House or a committee . . . It is also a fundamental princi ple that the law of parliamentary privilege is not affected by statutory provision unless the provision alters that law by express words . . .

The letter is signed by Ian Sinclair MP, Chairman. I read that into the record on the anniversary of the sinking of the HMAS Sydney to placate any concern in the community and to urge those members of the public who have an interest in this matter to make their submissions to the inquiry to fulfil a parliamentary and a national obligation to seek to understand the circumstances of the sinking of the Sydney. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am compelled to address the false and misleading argument being peddled by the ALP, in particular by its leader, the member for Brand (Mr Beazley), the Aboriginal affairs spokesman, the member for Banks (Mr Melham), and others that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 would not survive legal challenges in the High Court of Australia. In fact, it was the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, who said in this House on Monday, 17 November:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister wants to know what we think of his legislation. We think it discriminatory—and we think it discriminatory on racial grounds.
He continued:
The Prime Minister wants to know what we think its chances of success are in the High Court. We think nil.

The member for Banks is also peddling this mischievous and misleading diatribe. He constantly refers to legal—usually QC—opinions to support him. The most notable and often referred to opinion is that of the current Law Reform Commission chairman, Mr Alan Rose QC.

The former Labor senator Peter Walsh in his column in the Financial Review of 18 November accused Mr Rose of pulling a similar stunt to Sir Ronald Wilson, that is, to leak a report and gain currency in the public through the media and parliament to effectively hijack the debate at an early time. In Mr Rose's case, his game was played before the debate in this House and subsequently the Senate. Peter Walsh also informs us that Alan Rose QC did not advise the Keating govern ment that the Mabo legislation would find difficulty in the High Court on racial grounds. Mr Rose, the former secretary to the Attorney‐General in the Labor government and now chair of the LRC, has chosen to continue his partisan links by colluding with ALP members by backgrounding the member for Banks and Senator Bolkus and extreme elements of the Aboriginal industry. In fact, Mr Rose's actions confirm his increasing status as a Labor Party apparatchik.

It must be made clear that there are other opinions which support the constitutional validity of the government's 10-point plan. If the opposition do not wish to take the advice, the excellent counsel, of the Attorney‐General's legal silks, then they and the public are obliged to heed the advice given to them in a joint opinion by Mr D.P. Jackson QC and Mr Gageler. Mr Jackson is an eminent constitutional lawyer in Australia. He has been chair of the Constitutional Commission, a committee member of the Australian Constitutional Law Committee and a committee member of the Australian judicial system. I seek leave to table this opinion, Mr Speaker.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summary, the independent, non‐partisan QC Mr Jackson quite clearly states:

SPEECH.PARA: We consider the Bill—
the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997—
if enacted would be supported by Section 51(xvi).

In layman's terms—and those who wish to examine the legal jargon can read the tabled opinion now—the Native Title Amendment Bill does not—and I repeat does not—contravene the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act, as supported by section 51(xvi) of the Australian constitution.

The excellent Jackson opinion also states, first, that section 51(xvi) allows the parliament to make laws it considers necessary for a particular race; secondly, that such laws may benefit or disadvantage people of any race, including Aboriginal peoples; and, thirdly, that it is a matter for parliament whether it chooses to make such a law. Well, in case those opposite and those who live in Tinseltown have not heard this, parliament has chosen to make such a law and it has passed through this House decisively.

The Labor Party should also realise that members of their constituency, like those people in the front bar of my local hotel, the Ascot Inn, want the native title mess fixed. I say to members opposite that, unless you listen to honourable and accountable opinions from fine legal minds of eminent and credible QCs such as Mr Jackson rather than the position of the opportunistic interpretations such as those of Mr Alan Rose QC, you will find yourselves out of step with the mainstream of Australian people. In that event, I can assure this House and those opposite that I would feel rather confident in going into a double dissolution in my seat of Swan, and I believe an election on this issue would see me increase my majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to express my concern for the Australian tourism industry. Some have leapt, and no doubt still will leap, to their feet to try and make political mileage out of tagging me as being responsible for the number of international visitors not increasing as much this year as last year. This, of course, is of no substance and simply opportunistic, just like everything else I have been blamed for by my political opponents in their bid to make me appear bad for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As we all know, I have been held to blame for just about every ill that has befallen our country. Many of my fellow Australians have been left wondering about just how perfect Australia must have been before my election in March last year. I must say, with my tongue firmly in my cheek, just how amazing it is that one small red‐headed Australian woman from Ipswich could in such a small space of time destroy our trade, foreign relations, exports, jobs and, of course, tourism, to name but a few. Next year I am planning to make it rain for 40 days and 40 nights, so I suggest the members of this House start building their arks and gathering their animals two by two.

If I have done nothing else in this House, at least I have allowed our politicians to hone their skills as liars, and their practices of sinking lower than any normal person would believe possible in their efforts to distract the Australian public from the ever mounting evidence of the failures of successive Liberal and Labor governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker: I take objection to the words that the member for Oxley used in calling members of parliament liars, and I ask her to withdraw.
—I did not actually hear the word `liars', but if the word `liars' was used I do implore the honourable member for Oxley to withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw it. Tourism is one of our country's most important employers, with one in nine jobs in Australia found in this industry, but for many reasons it is becoming clear tourism cannot be our lone saviour. While I do not in any way wish to detract from my support for tourism, I must acknowledge it will never replace the many jobs lost through the treacherous policies of successive governments. So I will, of course, continue to push the need to revitalise the many industries devastated by the destructive push for globalisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will always welcome law abiding visitors from everywhere and I am proud that so many people are able to experience the magnificent uniqueness of Australia. I hope more Australians will have the opportunity of owning tourism businesses and offering our young people rewarding careers in this exciting industry. There have been many setbacks for the industry but none of these things relates to me, rather they are more plausible issues: too high an expectation by the Tourism Forecasting Council, currency fluctuations, marketing errors, the humbling of the tiger economies of Asia, competition from so many other destinations around the world and quite simply the fact that you cannot stay on top forever. There is only one place to go from number one; even the Beatles and Bing Crosby were eventually outsold.

It is very disturbing that outgoing tourism is growing at 15 per cent while domestic tourism is essentially flat. I cannot speak too loudly in encouraging Australians to spend as much of their holiday dollar as possible in Australia. Please see our own country first—there is so much to see. The sights and sounds available here in our country range from beauty to adventure and are so diverse in nature it is difficult for other countries to compete with the splendour and magnificence of the Australian experience. Our Australia, the greatest island in the world, is host to Australian businesses and jobs that need and deserve the support of our own people.

I must say that it is unfortunate that so much of the profits from tourism have left Australia through foreign ownership as in many cases we failed to invest in our own natural showcase. I hope Australian investors buy up the current bargains and therefore help to keep profits here in Australia. It would be nice to fully reclaim somewhere like Hayman Island. In the meantime, Peppers in the Hunter Valley in New South Wales, the Coconut Beach Rainforest Resort at Cape Tribulation in Queensland and the Wilpena Resort in South Australia's Flinders Ranges are just some examples of the different styles of Australian owned properties.

It is an appalling situation that the federal government does not provide any funding to promote the concept of Australians seeing Australia. The growing exodus to see the world must be balanced by a campaign that will promote the best destination in the world, our own home. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Ladhams, Mr George and Mrs Doris

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to two wonderful people in my electorate who passed away last week. I talk about George and Doris Ladhams. George Ladhams was very well known to me, as of course was his wife, Doris. George suffered from kidney failure late last week, and his wife had been battling poor health for some time. They were both in the same hospital. Within two hours of George's death, Doris died from the shock of it all.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to talk about these two people tonight because I believe that they were the type of Australian whom we all aspire to live up to. They were the type of Australian we should have more of in this country of ours—rather than perhaps the sort of Australian from whom we have just heard.

George and Doris Ladhams had always been hard-working people. For much of his life George was involved in the timber industry, building mill cottages for the Karri Timber company. Eventually, through very hard work, he became the manager of Whittakers timber mill in Serpentine.

George and Doris first started off as farmers in the farming area around the outskirts of Perth. But, of course, we all know how difficult it is to make any money out of farming. So, rather than blame governments, they packed up their bags and decided it was up to them to make a future for themselves. They then went to settle in Northcliffe and later in Serpentine working in the timber industry. Whilst they brought up their family and George was busy earning a living, Doris of course involved herself in the traditional women's activities of those days, such as the Country Women's Association, the Red Cross, and she worked for the community.

At some stage George decided to become involved in local government. As I said before, he was the sort of person whom we should all look up to. He felt that it was up to him to give back to the community that had given to him. Not only did he participate in the shire's affairs, but he rose to become the president of the shire. At that time he decided also to become involved in politics. I understand that, since approximately 1950, George had been a member of the Liberal Party. Indeed, he was a very active member of my division of Canning, taking on executive positions and becoming a member of state council. Eventually George and his family moved to Kelmscott, another suburb in my electorate, where they stayed until this recent tragedy.

There was something special about George: he was the type of person who, when he committed himself to something, did it 120 per cent. I first met George back in 1984 on my first campaign. At that time he was a little sceptical of this slip of a girl who was going to have a go at federal politics—because, after all, women did not go into politics, and certainly not into federal politics! He sort of looked at me in a slightly sceptical way. But I think he very soon recognised that I had the determination, the talent and the desire to do something for this country. George and his wife, Doris, and I became very, very good friends.

George kept on working in the community. Regardless of what knocks there were in life, he pulled himself up again and did what he could for others. He became a member of the Freemason lodge; he was very much involved in that. Approximately two years ago, George lost his leg as a result of diabetes. But this did not stop him from being committed. In 1996, when we went to the election, there was George, sitting in his wheelchair, minus half of his leg, manning his polling booth, just as he had done since 1953, or whenever. That is the sort of person I think this parliament should be paying tribute to.

Equally, we should be paying tribute to his wife. She suffered at times because George was absorbed in his politics and community works. And he was not always there when he should have been. I can honestly say that George and Doris were people I came to know not only as my friends; if not for my own parents, whom I love dearly, I would have been proud to call them my parents.

George and Doris leave behind a son and daughter-in-law and three wonderful grandchildren. The grandchildren now all have jobs, an issue which worried George and Doris for some time. But they kept on having faith in the ability of their grandchildren to succeed. They had faith in the future of our country, and they knew that those kids would eventually get a job. To the loved ones whom they left behind, I pay my deepest respects tonight. I do hope that the world produces more people like George and Doris.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Hunter Region: Steel Making Merchant Mariners: Annual Memorial Service

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to say something about the great opportunities that exist for new steel makers to come into the Hunter region. BHP has made it clear that they want to end steel making in the Hunter in 1999. The point I want to make is that the Hunter region and Port Newcastle is the prime location in Australia to make steel. It is ideally placed to service domestic and overseas markets. It has reliable and cheap energy. It has skilled and dedicated workers. It has good deepwater access and good existing port facilities. It has excellent access to the national road and rail grids. We have an established network of the latest steel making services, and Australia's best and strongest steel making know‐how.

SPEECH.PARA: What we need now is to market those advantages and those strengths around the world. The time used to be when BHP to this country was `the steel manufacturer'; today BHP is `a steel manufacturer'. Sure, BHP wanted a power of veto on steel making in Newcastle; they do not want another steel maker in Newcastle. That is the world they would like to have.

But we have a quiet achiever in the Hunter in ANI. At the moment they are producing about 200,000 tonnes of steel with an electric arc furnace; they want to increase production. We also have Mr Clive Palmer and his mineralogy process—his company with which he is associated. From my understanding and reading of his technology, it is good technology; it certainly needs capital.

However, I want to contrast the attitude being expressed by some people in the Hunter that steel making is finished. Steel making will only be finished in the Hunter if we allow it to be finished. I say that because, on the other side of the continent, we see the efforts in Western Australia to set up a $1.4 billion steel making plant 23 kilometres north of Geraldton. We, on the eastern side of the continent, are better placed.

For the reasons I have outlined, I want to see every possible effort being made now to market the strengths and advantages of the Hunter and Port Newcastle to steel makers—and to do that around the world. I am talking with my federal colleagues the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). We will be undertaking our own efforts to get that information out around to all potential steel makers across the globe. Also, I have approached the state government for them to do similarly. We are the best, we have the best know‐how and we are the best placed, for all the reasons I have outlined.

So it is not a time to end steel making; it is a time to add to the steel makers. It would be a most regrettable mistake if business leaders in the Hunter were to let pass this opportunity to find a new steel maker to take over from the role of BHP that was prepared to utilise the opportunities that we offer there. That would be a dreadful mistake for the region. We will be doing everything possible to ensure that that mistake does not occur.

BHP's efforts in the post-steel making period in Newcastle focus on what is going to happen there, on remediation of site, on development of the Hunter 2000 site, and on attracting new operations there. Indications are that they are probably spending up to tens of millions of dollars. Forty per cent of BHP's work force live in the City of Lake Macquarie, a large part of which is in my electorate of Shortland. We in Lake Macquarie want to see some equity from BHP in investing and in generating jobs and activity not just in Newcastle but in Lake Macquarie, where almost half of their work force is domiciled.

We have the contrary situation at the moment, Mr Speaker, which you have heard me mention in this House before, where the only coastal wetlands in our region is in Lake Macquarie, which BHP is trying to rape, seek possession of and subdivide for housing development to, in effect, generate money which it can spend in Newcastle to cover its departure from steel making. I want to see fairness for my electors and fairness as between Lake Macquarie City Council and Newcastle in the treatment that is accorded them by BHP.

On 6 December at 11.15 a.m. there is an annual memorial service for wartime merchant mariners at Norah Head lighthouse, a public ceremony at which everybody from the central coast is welcome. It will have particular attention to the MV Nimbin, which was the first Australian merchant ship sunk by enemy action on our east coast in World War II. On 5 December 1940 at 3 p.m. its stern was blown away by a German mine. Everybody is welcome to the service. I offer that commercial to all members of this House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on a project which is happening in Murwillumbah—the World Heritage Rainforest Centre. This project will have a significant impact on the town of Murwillumbah. It is the rebuilding of the tourism centre. A major expansion is being instigated by the Commonwealth—with $270,000 from the Commonwealth in addition to $50,000 from a state grant. The World Heritage Rainforest Centre, I believe, will act as a major catalyst in the rejuvenation of Murwillumbah's tourism potential.

SPEECH.PARA: Murwillumbah has been going through testing times of late because of a change in industry. The dominance of agriculture no longer has a direct bearing on the town, as it used to in the past, there are far more recipients of social security and there have been changes in education and in lifestyles. The World Heritage Rainforest Centre can act as a beacon for attracting tourists from south‐east Queensland, particularly day trippers from Brisbane, and also from the Gold Coast, and as a hubbing centre to the five world heritage parks.

There is no other place in Australia where we have this concentration of world heritage parks. They have magnificent tourism potential for the Tweed Valley and for the north coast of New South Wales. Those national parks are Springbrook, Lamington National Park, the Border Ranges, Nightcap and Mount Warning, which is in the middle of the Caldera, a mountain of about 3,300 feet. The World Heritage Centre will act as a conduit for tourists coming to Murwillumbah. There will be CD interactive ROM there, there will be lectures, there will be discussions and, hopefully, in due course it will be a transport hub where buses can leave for Murwillumbah for the different national parks.

For Murwillumbah it is significant because of the flow- on effect that it can give to the town, not just from the tourism angle but to help rejuvenate a town which needs to be upgraded, particularly its main street. I applaud the Main Street Committee, and Tweed Shire Council, which is contributing $600,000 to updating Murwillumbah so it can benefit from the huge commercialism we have seen on the Gold Coast and to a lesser extent in Tweed Heads, which has the cultural and heritage values of what was originally a timber and agricultural town. If this can be developed in conjunction with the World Heritage Centre, which backs on to the Tweed River, then it has immense opportunity to attract people to Murwillumbah as a destination, particularly to our best features, which are the national parks.

There is one project which I feel very passionately about—and I hope that in due course it can link up—the Caldera Trail. My vision is to link up the five world heritage parks with a 200‐kilometre trail, which would start at the water around Currumbin and the Tumbulgum tick gates and travel through these national parks, which could cover a 180 degree arc from the Queensland border through to just north of Mullumbimby, or down near Byron Bay, for those who do not know the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —A magnificent project.

—It is a magnificent project. I am glad members of this House endorse it. You go through spectacular scenery. But more importantly, it will be a marketing tool, like the Milford Trail, or the Overland Track in Tasmania, or the Appalachian Trail in North America or the Pennine Way in England. It will add value to people going to the Gold Coast who are not just interested in theme parks, which really are a dime a dozen, whether they are the Movieworlds, the Dreamworlds or the Seaworlds. What we have in the Tweed is the real world, and that is nature. That is why I strongly believe that this could be a magnificent feature and attract people down there, particularly foreign tourists, to give them a short walk—it might only be five kilometres or, for the keen ones, it might be 200 kilometres. The Caldera Trail would then link back into the World Heritage Rainforest Centre at Murwillumbah.
—The Deputy Prime Minister would like to know about that walk.

—Indeed. The Deputy Prime Minister has walked parts of it. I do hope that he will have the opportunity to open this world heritage centre, as the Commonwealth has put an extraordinary amount of money into it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two other phases to the World Heritage Centre, which I hope the Commonwealth may also look favourably at, and which will help organisations like national parks which are relocating there, like Tactic, which is the local tourism body, like the Tweed Shire Council and like all the people there. These phases will help address the very high level of unemployment. The second and third phases are building a jetty, a kiosk and a cafe, and opening up the river. I commend the rainforest centre to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 applies new arrangements to procedures for establishing an interception capability for telecommunications services in Australia and the funding of this interception capability. The bill also deals with minor technical amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1997, including aspects of industry development plans, labelling of equipment and ACA industry reports. I will deal firstly with the interception aspects of the bill.

Under Part 15 of the Telecommunications Act 1997, which largely carries forward the arrangements under the Telecommunications Act 1991, telecommunications carriers and nominated carriage service providers must ensure they can execute an interception warrant. The only exception to this is when the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts grants an authorisation. Carriers have also been required to consult with agencies on new technologies before introducing a telecommunications service. Agencies have borne all the costs associated with developing those interception capabilities required to be able to execute an interception warrant and the costs of executing individual warrants.

However, the existing arrangements for interception capabilities are no longer suitable. The introduction of some new telecommunications services has been significantly delayed with obvious adverse consequences for business and consumers. On occasion, services have also been introduced without an adequate interception capability impacting adversely upon the operations of law enforcement and national security agencies. The funding of all interception requirements by the agencies, with no industry assistance on the establishment and maintenance of this essential service, has been a large and continuing drain upon the agencies' resources.

These problems will not go away under the current framework. One of the effects of the opening of the telecommunications market to full competition will be to increase the difficulties and expense faced by the agencies in attempting to negotiate interception capability arrangements with each and every new entrant. Add to this the escalating speed of technological change in telecommunications, and the obvious outcome is increasing delays to the entrance of new market participants and to new services, with implications for the growth and development of the Australian telecommunications market.

The best long‐term hope for retaining a cost effective interception capability into the longer run is through international cooperation directed at getting telecommunications equipment vendors—especially manufacturers of switches—to include common interception capabilities into their equipment. This will ensure that capabilities are maintained while keeping costs down by sharing them among all user countries and achieving economies of scale.

BREAK.PARA: The bill therefore provides for a new level of interception capability based upon the relevant international standard or guideline. The Attorney‐General will be given the power to determine, via one or more disallowable instruments, the specifics of the new capability. The Attorney‐General will base this new capability requirement on the international user requirement, IUR, developed by most OECD law enforcement and national security agencies, including Australia, under the auspices of the International Law Enforcement Telecommunications Seminar, ILETS. I have tabled a copy of the IUR with the bill for members' information.

However, to ensure there is no lapse in the requirement for an interception capability, carriers and carriage service providers will be required to be in a position to execute an interception warrant issued under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 until the Attorney‐General has made a determination, that is, the `fallback' position will be a continuation of the current capability obligations.

Law enforcement and national security agencies will be able to authorise the operation of a service with a lower or no level of interception capability. This is reasonable given that these agencies are the users of the capability and are in the best position to determine when it is no longer required. The minister will continue to have a reserve power, exercisable with the agreement of the Attorney‐General, to also grant authorisations. The Australian Communications Authority, ACA, is to be given a limited power to provide exemptions for trial services after appropriate consultations.

The bill continues the current requirement for carriers and nominated carriage service providers to notify the ACA of relevant changes to technology, with the ACA ensuring relevant agencies are consulted. In order to make sure that the introduction of new telecommunications services is not unduly delayed, the ACA is now required to specify reasonable time frames within which agencies can consider new technologies for each new technology notification. If agencies do not comment within this reasonable period they lose their ability to specify particular delivery requirements.

The bill also introduces new funding arrangements for interception. Agencies will continue to be liable for the costs of executing individual interception warrants, as well as most other matters of `help' that are in addition to the basic listening and recording of a communication. They will also be liable for the costs of establishing capabilities they have specifically requested. The ACA has been given new audit powers to ensure that the most cost‐effective solutions are adopted. However, carriers will now be required to pay for the costs of providing the interception capability determined by the Attorney‐General, or the costs of the `fallback' capability.

With regard to allocating the transmission costs of an intercepted communication, a new concept of the `delivery point' has been introduced in part 14. Individual carriers and carriage service providers, and the agencies, will be required to agree to the location of the `delivery point', with the carrier or carriage service provider paying for the costs of transmitting the intercepted information to the delivery point, and the agencies paying for the transmission costs from the delivery point to the final destination.

Another new concept, the interception capability plan, is also introduced with this bill. These plans are intended to provide a strategic communications and planning tool for the industry and agencies. Carriers and carriage service providers nominated by the Attorney‐General will be required to submit these plans on an annual basis and their content will include the policies of the carrier or provider in relation to interception generally, of their strategies for compliance with their interception obligations, a statement of any relevant business developments, and a description of strategies for minimising long run costs.

The bill therefore introduces a new framework for the accomplishment of a cost‐effective and relevant interception capability within Australia. However, we recognise that technologies, the communications market, and the needs of agencies are continuing to evolve rapidly. While telecommunications interception remains for the present a cost‐effective tool for agencies, it is important that we keep our approach to this issue under review. The bill therefore requires the minister, in consultation with the Attorney‐General, to cause a review to be conducted before 1 July 1999 into the longer term cost‐effectiveness of the arrangements provided for in parts 14 and 15 of the act that relate to the funding of telecommunications interception. A copy of the report from this review is to be laid before each house of the parliament.

There are also several other matters in the bill which I will now discuss. The bill provides for the labelling requirements for customer equipment and customer cabling under division 7 of part 21 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 to apply not only to manufacturers or importers of this equipment or cabling but also to authorised agents acting in Australia on behalf of such manufacturers or importers.

This will allow overseas manufacturers and importers to revert back to established agency arrangements whereby their Australian agents take responsibility for ensuring that the requirements for labelling telecommunications customer equipment and customer cabling are met. This will ensure the supply of equipment and cabling to Australia and facilitate the introduction and growth of competition in the supply of goods and services in the Australian telecommunications market.

In addition, the ACA is currently required to monitor and report each financial year to the minister on all significant matters relating to the performance of carriers and carriage service providers. The bill builds in additional flexibility by giving the minister the power to direct the ACA in relation to the preparation of periodic reports as well as special reports on particular matters that may arise during the year.

Technical amendments are also proposed to clause 27 of schedule 3 to the act dealing with the carriers' powers and immunities. This clause sets out the matters that the ACA must be satisfied about before it may issue a facility installation permit. It also sets out the things that the ACA must take into account in deciding whether the grounds for a permit have been made out.

Clause 27, as currently drafted, requires that, before a facility installation permit can be issued for telecommunications installations other than designated overhead lines, the ACA must be satisfied that both the landowner and the relevant local authority have not consented to the installation. This has the peculiar and unintended consequence that a consent by either a landowner or relevant authority will prevent the ACA from issuing a facility installation permit. The bill amends clause 27 to address this anomaly.

The re‐draft makes it clear that the ACA can issue a facility installation permit for non‐designated overhead lines infrastructure where either the landowner or the relevant authority refuse or withhold consent. The bill also includes an amendment made by the Senate to the bill as introduced to require carriers to negotiate in good faith with both the proprietors and administrative authorities before the ACA can consider issuing a facility installation permit.

The bill contains minor amendments to part 2 of schedule 1 which covers industry development plan arrangements. The amendments correct shortcomings in the legislation relating to when industry development plans are required and when the approval of the industry minister is necessary, as well as clarifying the notification of government policies which carriers must have regard to in preparing their industry development plans.

The first amendment will require all carriers to have a current industry development plan at all times, rather than only when applying for a carrier licence, as currently provided in the act. The second amendment will see amended industry development plans requiring approval of the industry minister, treating them in a similar manner to original plans. The third amendment will require the industry minister to notify carriers and applicants for carrier licences of government policies that are to be taken into account in preparing their plans.

The bill also makes a number of other minor and technical amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1997, the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1997 and the Trade Practices Act 1974. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 , as the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) has just enumerated in his second reading speech, broadly covers and extends the law in the area of telephone and telecommunications interception. This of course has been a time‐honoured way for law enforcement agencies and national security agencies around the world to ensure that they are abreast of any potential or actual criminal activity. In some countries this has been extended to include a definition of national security which Australians would not agree with and which has been used to support totalitarian regimes.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context in which the minister and the government present this legislation, though, it is quite clear that it is in the ordinary course of events for Australian telecommunications interception. It continues the tradition which both major political parties have supported in Australia of allowing this kind of interception in certain specific and regulated cases so that law enforcement agencies can have accurate and up‐to‐date intelligence. I am sure that it is of considerable benefit to them in pursuing those who would commit acts such as dealing in narcotic and other dangerous drugs, in cases of child abuse and paedophile activity, and in a range of other criminal and anti‐social activities which include no lesser crimes than treason against the Australian state and a variety of other activities which we would all want to see curbed.

No-one wants to place any barriers in the way of telephone interception which is done at a reasonable level with reasonable and prudent legal safeguards and where the public can have some confidence that it is for proper and reasonable purposes. That has always been the case in the Australian community, and I have no reason to believe that it would be otherwise under this government. In that context, we in opposition would certainly support the basic thrust of the legislation, which extends the law in that area and imposes some new requirements on telecommunications carriers to fund the costs of some of this work and to provide more convenient delivery point access to agencies.

There is nothing fundamentally objectionable in those parts of the bill, and the opposition will not be opposing that particular aspect of the legislation, which is the fundamental thrust of the legislation before us. However, the legislation does raise some other issues. The government recently understood, in part at least, some of the further implications of this kind of legislation when it made the minister for communications also responsible for the development of the information economy. The opposition had recognised this important area some months before. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), I am honoured to say, appointed me as shadow minister for not only science but also information technology.

Both political parties have now recognised the significance of the development of the information economy and of the information age in Australia and indeed globally through their recognition of ministerial and shadow ministerial appointments. However it would seem from this legislation, and from the policy which underlies it, that the government has not yet recognised, unfortunately, the importance of encryption and interception to the development of a sound information based economy.

If we are to enter the information age, if we are to have electronic commerce as a substantial part of our economic activity, then it is essential that legislation like the legislation which we have before us recognises that fact, is cognisant of it and is surrounded by underlying policy in the encryption area in support of electronic commerce which the government integrates and balances against the reasonable needs of law enforcement agencies when they seek to pursue the tasks which I have already identified on behalf of the opposition and which the government endorses they should be able to pursue.

Why is that important? Even the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), in a speech on 14 October, said electronic commerce: . . . over the Net is forecast to increase more than four‐fold to $6.3 billion by 2001, with more than 1.5 million Australians expected to be using the World Wide Web to purchase goods and services by 2001.

There are some other statistics which I will share with the committee shortly. That one snapshot—$6.3 billion by the year 2001 and 1.5 million Australians using the Internet to purchase goods and services—within that same time frame highlights dramatically how serious an issue electronic commerce is.

Electronic commerce will allow people to make purchases globally, so we are truly entering the age where you can make it anywhere and sell it everywhere. For example, purchasing music on-line—with the bits that represent the song or the track someone is interested in purchasing being transmitted down the Internet and stored by them on compact disc or on tape for their own pleasure, and they pay for that with their credit card or by electronic cash—is one form of the information economy.

It can be anything from music to books, magazines, information generally, research articles—an enormous area of commerce in the future. Whether people are ordering clothing, food, wine or any other normal commodity, or indeed whether they are ordering accounting services, auditing services, architectural services, legal services, computing services or computer programming talent, these things can be provided from anywhere in the world and the results transmitted electronically. People will pay for those services.

As the minister has said, this will be a massively increasing area of the Australian and global economy in the years to come. That change will take place rapidly. We should not underestimate the rate of change which will occur in this area. It was only in 1969 that the Internet was first developed by the US government, initially as a military facility but subsequently taken over by the civilian population and the academic university groups because of its value to them as a means of communication, as a new means of enhancing global trade and as a means of advancing global culture.

The change since then has been dramatic. We have gone from a time, only some 20 years ago, where no-one was using the network, where no Internet existed, to a time now where millions of people around the world do. We have an Internet growth rate which exceeds the growth rate of any other aspect of our economy or indeed of human society. If we do not make plans now, if we do not have policies now, if our legislation in 1997 does not incorporate and understand the implications of electronic commerce, we will be behind the eight ball when those days come—in too few years—when so many people are using the Internet that it is a significant issue for us. That is why I would like to turn to the specific provisions of the bill today to highlight where they fail to recognise that fact.

Although ostensibly the bill deals with the simple routine interception of the plain old telephone service, the new digital mobile service and other forms of common communication, we have significant implications for electronic commerce and the new information society which surrounds it. This bill will impact on nominated carriage service providers, such as Internet service providers. In my own state, Camtech is a major regional supplier, but there are others such as Ozemail and Big Pond, which is run by Telstra. A number of these very large Internet service providers are likely to be required to be covered by this legislation.

The issue will be what kind of impact that will have on their broader service provision. These people do not sell simple telecommunication services. They do not sell end to end, point to point voice communication. They sell the movement of data and information—commercially valuable information, financial information, health information and personal data. It is much more than a simple telecommunications network. These people often have value added networks which are associated with it. A number of those agencies—Telstra not the least and Camtech in my own state—are providing a variety of secure additional services as part of their network which people are joining in order to offer electronic commerce not only in Australia, although the domestic market is substantial, but also throughout the world.

You can access the Internet from anywhere in the world. You can access an Australian supplier and you can do business. Increasingly, people will do business in that way. If these service providers are required under this legislation to provide agencies on demand with decrypted data flowing over their network, this will have a number of effects. It will fundamentally undermine the confidence which people have in Internet commerce and in the security of that commerce. That is an important psychological factor, and it is an important real impact on their ability to undertake large financial transactions in a secure way. Indeed, I would go so far as to say that, without secure encryption, there will be serious difficulties for electronic commerce in this country.

The implications go beyond that. The reality is that it is very important in electronic commerce to be able to identify exactly who you are and exactly whom you are dealing with. There is a famous saying on the Internet that on the Internet no-one knows you are a dog. The reality is that you can be sitting at home or in your office and dealing with a company or a person thousands of miles away who has no concept of whom they are dealing with. This is not traditional commerce where you have clients whom you know well who come into your shop or who ring you over the phone and may have a personal relationship with your salesman or with the company at large. This is an entirely anonymous system of electronic commerce where people from anywhere around the world on a one-off basis can deal with your company or with you as an individual, and it is very difficult for you to establish their bona fides.

Barriers which are put in the way of that, though, will severely cripple the international and reliable nature of that commerce. If people have the ability through strong encryption to work out that the person whom they are dealing with is exactly that person and no other person, then of course that enhances the prospects for electronic commerce.

BREAK.PARA: Why is encryption important there? Encryption does two things. It not only provides secure communications—that is the obvious and important aspect of cryptography that we are all familiar with; it also allows you in an entirely separate way to identify people. If we have a system of public and private key cryptography, which is the one widely used throughout the developed world at the moment, the system provides a basis for you to understand that the person you are dealing with is the very person you know their public key represents them to be. If they are not, then the communication will not be able to be decrypted by the public key that that person has published. That is a very important issue in electronic commerce.

Commerce generally rests on identity. If there is no individual, if there is no I in commerce, then you cannot safely conduct trade with that person; you cannot have a person to own the goods or buy the services; and you will be unable to sue for payment; you will be unable to validate the contract; you will be unable to establish beyond any doubt that the person who communicated with you is liable for that payment, is liable for that contract.

So strong encryption permits not only security of communication; it also permits non‐repudiation. It permits a legal basis of identification which is certain in law and certain in fact. If we move to a situation where everyone is aware that law enforcement agencies have access to the keys to the encrypted data, then it is quite clear that other people could steal those keys, other people could represent themselves falsely to be the person that they allege they are dealing with. And of course that would undermine the certainty, it would undermine non‐repudiation, it would undermine the very basis of electronic commerce.

These are complex issues but ones which I think the parliament needs to come to grips with if it is to understand a very fundamental part of commerce in the 21st century. Australia has failed to develop policies surrounding this. We now have a minister for the information economy. Coincidentally, he is the minister for communications. That is an important link.

He is also responsible for interception traffic, and you would expect that a minister who is responsible for both areas here would have it within his capacity to produce a sound and sustainable policy for electronic commerce which incorporated strong encryption as a fundamental cornerstone. And that balance has not been struck in this legislation. This is simply—and I think the minister's own speech indicates this—a linear progression from past days where all that mattered was the ability to intercept telephone conversations.

We have moved beyond that and, instead of taking the legislation to a new paradigm, instead of having policies which address those important issues, the minister has simply advanced past telecommunications interception legislation in a linear fashion to account for new technologies such as digital mobile phones, but not in a way which addresses this fundamental and rapidly rising issue of electronic commerce.

If Internet service providers and those who provide secure networks are going to have the obligation on them to provide decrypted data to agencies on demand, then no‐one will be able to rely on the certainty which they have previously been able to provide. The kind of encryption which is readily available in this country now is some 40‐bit encryption. The American munitions export control regulations prohibit the export from the United States of stronger encryption than that and, unfortunately, 40‐bit—or thereabouts—encryption is no longer particularly secure.

In fact, only in recent months groups in the United States operating through university computers have been able to decrypt messages which were so encrypted, and they have done it in a matter of hours. I think that 3½ hours was all it took them to decrypt the message, which was the test message, if you like. The message they decrypted is significant, because it said, `It's time we moved to stronger encryption.' And that is indeed the very point I want to make. If we can break that kind of encryption in 3½ hours, then people will not have the confidence—nor should they have the confidence—in those systems. It is only if we have systems which are substantially secure against any rational attack—that is, 128‐bit encryption—that we will have a proposition which is defensible for the public, for commerce, and in a way which people can take account of.

Now that has implications for law enforcement. I do not back away from that, but the reality is that we cannot allow law enforcement issues—for a small percentage of the community who undertake criminal activity—to hold back the 98 per cent of the community who are honest and law abiding and who wish to advance Australia's commercial interests in the world. That is far too important an interest for the whole of the population. A small group of people who are bent towards criminal activities cannot be allowed to prevent the rest of the community from embarking upon those interests. We often have to make trade‐offs between law enforcement and personal rights of privacy and security, but in this case there is no public debate about those issues.

Indeed, the government resisted every attempt to release the report by Walsh in 1996 on encryption policy in Australia. The government refused to release that report until a freedom of information request was made. Until the government finally honoured that request, we did not have access to that policy.

The policy made it very clear that there should not be further strengthening of laws against encryption in this country without adequate public debate, yet the government has not sought to advance that debate in any way. Indeed, it is progressing the legislation in a subtle, almost quiet fashion, avoiding the public debate on this issue which we should reasonably have by including this legislation in the basic telecommunications legislation which we have always supported in this parliament. This policy should be highlighted in a separate piece of legislation which deals with encryption and electronic commerce so that the public can debate these issues sensibly.

It is not just criminals who use secure communications. The reality is that business and individuals have every right to secure business and personal communication; they have every right to conduct electronic funds transfers, financial transactions and home banking in a way which is secure and private to them. They have the right to communicate their trade secrets and contractual data over networks which are secure and on which they can rely to know they are dealing with the individuals they say they are dealing with. They have the right to have crucial infrastructure such as air traffic control and the power grid. All of those things are now very important to our society and, if they cannot be protected by secure networks and if we cannot have confidence in those networks, then certainly Australia's growth is undermined. They have the right to have health records, their personal files and sensitive personal data protected by secure encryption.

Computers are a very important way of transmitting and securing data. They are vital to government and business in pursuit of commerce and public policy. But, also, individuals and agencies have the right to secure data from inspection and false use by people who might wish to misuse it. Just as there is a law enforcement interest in eavesdropping on some conversations and some data traffic, so there is a law enforcement interest in protecting our health records, our power grid, our telephone network and our banks and electronic funds transfers from attack by those who seek to steal or misuse that data. Those things are criminal as well. Encryption will prevent that kind of attack on those very sensitive and important commercial and private institutions.

So encryption serves both purposes and, like many things in our society, we have to strike a balance and come to a public understanding, a social contract, about what sacrifices of personal privacy and network security we will allow to occur. Indeed this government has, critically, failed to introduce that debate. Critically, it has failed to highlight those issues in this legislation. It is very much failing the public and business in this country by refusing to participate in international efforts to mandate privacy legislation to ensure that people have those rights, and that those rights are protected, both in law and in technical terms, through the use of encryption.

Those Internet service providers in the community who have established their businesses and who are promoting their business on the basis of their ability to deliver a secure network have the right to know that this government will have policies which support their role in the community, not policies which undermine them. At the moment I am afraid all the legislation we see here today and the lack of government initiative in this area indicate to me that the government is not about to support business and private individuals in their pursuit of that kind of cryptographic security.

There are many issues which we could raise in relation to that, but I think they could more adequately be covered in a wide‐ranging inquiry by one of the committees of the House of Representatives. It is for that reason I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not opposing the measure, the House is of the view that the bill should be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology so that a public inquiry can be conducted by the Committee and the House given the benefit of the committee's advice on the effect of the bill on the future development of electronic commerce in Australia with particular reference to:
(1) the development of an encryption policy that promotes public and business confidence in the security of financial transactions conducted electronically;
(2) the requirement for secure digital signatures;
(3) the impact on business of the Government's failure to support legally binding privacy standards for Australian companies.".

All of those issues are very sensitive. They are issues which could feasibly be bipartisan, and I would support such a move. But for that to occur, the government needs to have a proper public and open inquiry and discussion of these things.

These things are no longer just the province of the national security agencies. They are no longer just the province of the law enforcement agencies. There is a temptation to view cryptography simply as something which is enjoyed by the spooks and the National Security Agency in the bowels of its Fort Meade headquarters outside Washington DC, wherein resides, we are told, some of the world's best computers for breaking code.

This is not something to be kept in the dark like that. This is something which now needs to be in the open. There is now a significant public interest in having an open and full debate about that and reaching conclusions on that trade-off between security of commerce, security of identity, guarantees of non-repudiation and the availability of billions of dollars in trade in electronic commerce in the next century. Those are the things we need to debate and offset against the need for law enforcement agencies to tap some communications.

In conclusion, I also advance the view that, if we seriously believe that those who engage in international terrorism and that those who engage in international drug trafficking will choose to use cryptographic products which they know the government has backdoor keys to, then I suggest we are fooling ourselves. We will always catch those at the bottom end of these trades through their use of ordinary phones and insecure communication.

It is quite feasible now to download from the Internet very strong encryption products which you can use. There are hundreds of cryptographic products available for commercial purchase and others which are simply given away by those who believe in the freedom of communication and in the secure nature of communication. Those products are readily available. If we believe that those who wish to engage in international criminal and other activity will use products that they know the government has a ready access to, then we are certainly deluding ourselves.

This is an area where ordinary citizens and ordinary businesses should be allowed to benefit from the rapid advances in technology. Unfortunately, this government is not laying the framework for it. So while we as an opposition do not oppose the fundamental nature of this bill for what it deals with on the face of it, we certainly demand that the government come forward with policies in this area which will support community confidence in electronic commerce and which will provide a sound framework for people to build their investments, their networks and their personal business around in the future.

Australia's place in the world and in the region in electronic commerce will depend on the government's ability to do this in the next couple of years. Any longer and the opportunities will be lost. We do not want to see those opportunities lost. I only hope the government can learn that lesson in time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first came to this House not 18 months ago my office had a hot paper fax and a 386 computer. That was the previous government's dedication to this industry. Today, we have the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) getting up and proposing this second reading amendment. One part of the amendment is to refer the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 to a standing committee. In light of that proposal, I would like to quote our honourable Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) from his response on the fair trading report. He said something that is equally applicable today:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's approach was to raise small business hopes by promising reviews, reports and recommendations only to have those hopes dashed by inaction, by reports shelved, recommendations ignored and issues deferred to the too‐hard basket.
In all, 17 fair trading reports, reviews or draft proposals and 13 years of Labor. Nothing achieved.

That was life for small business under Labor, where Hawke‐Keating cabinets rolled small business every time because they never really understood the non‐unionised small business community in Australia. It is laughable that Labor would now have you believe that they suddenly care about this and want to act. That is exactly the same in terms of information technology and small business.

The member for Bonython spent the majority of his speech addressing encryption devices. The point of this legislation—and I think he missed it completely—is that the carrier will provide the information to our policing services in the form that it is transmitted. It is then up to those agencies to decode that. That is something that has been going on in this world since radio first went to air in the First World War, and in the Second World War; we have been coding and decoding and competing, in a defence sense, with that sort of technology. That sort of encryption and decryption will carry on and is quite separate from this debate.

We are talking about the ability to intercept what is, in fact, transmitted in the form that it is transmitted. The agencies that we are talking about are: the Australian Federal Police; a police force or service of a state or territory; the National Crime Authority; the New South Wales Crimes Commission; the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales; the Criminal Justice Commission of Queensland; the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation; the Police Integrity Commission; and a prescribed authority established by or under a law of the Commonwealth, a state or territory. We are talking crime; he wants to raise trade‐offs between personal privacy and the public benefit of apprehending crime.

It was quite obvious in their responses to our efforts in terms of the drugs task force that they do not understand how criminal apprehensions occur today. It is generally a tip‐off, and you generally catch the trading in money—the financial transactions. It is very hard, in terms of organised crime, to launder those amounts of money that we are talking about. That is where this sort of surveillance, this sort of capability with our policing service, is absolutely essential.

This bill needs to go ahead. It is actually transferring the costs of those telecommunications devices, or the gathering of the information, to the carriers and the end users. That is in line with our user‐pays principle. Given where this industry is going, if we left that with government the costs would be exponential.

I do not think you can really understand this bill unless you have some vision as to what Australia will look like in the future. In the future we will have a focus on the Internet. You will be able to trade stocks on the Internet; you will be able to look up the current price in the stock market immediately, as you already can; banking will be occurring over the Internet.

There is education: you can get a master's degree on‐line—a master of professional accounting straight away at the Financial Review page on the Internet. You can submit papers for marking, you can e‐mail, you can get into chat shops and you can have tutorials. It really can all happen in the virtual world. So you get education. You have got EFTPOS transactions and smartcards. That sort of technology is coming up on us very quickly. You can do your shopping via the Internet. You can download music and videos.

Video clips will not be just a little curiosity on an Internet site, they are going to be the whole video. If video store providers are not watching out for the future of their businesses they are going to be caught on the hop the same way that camera shops that did not stock the digital camera were caught out. Today, with the lifestyle of people moving in such a direction so fast, businesses must keep up with what is happening in their industry and how it will affect them.

A very good case is the Encyclopedia Britannica. An excellent article on this was in the Harvard Business Review. The people at Encyclopedia Britannica looked at Microsoft Encarta and they saw it as a toy. They did not see what Microsoft Encarta meant to Encyclopedia Britannica and, consequently, their business went downhill until they quickly switched to that technology and came up with Britannica CD. That was a rescue mission.

If businesses do not see what this is going to mean to their businesses then they should not stay in their holes, with Labor, seeking protectionism and saying, `Government, save me. Let's send it to review and let's keep things the same. Let's not change anything because government is going to save me.' I am sorry, the technological world does not work like that. Our government has ministers and a Prime Minister who know where this industry is going. They are on the ball and are making an effort now, not only with this piece of legislation but also with calls for submissions into improving business to government interaction for regulatory and compliance purposes.

That process is coming up with a proposal where businesses, via the Internet, can access government to register business names, to deal with the tax department, to link through to the industrial relations boards, to link back to social security payments and child support payments, to link through to garnisheeing wages and link back to pensions.

It will be possible in the future for someone in Australia, via the remote control on their digital TV, to link up via a video link to their social security provider, answer questions, make any changes to their status, change their pension rate and be paid automatically, and then spend that money by electronic bill paying or by shopping.

If you are watching ads on TV you can almost press a button on your remote control and download how much that particular item will cost, where it is available closest to you, who has it in stock, how many are left, and who is running a sale this week. And, you can probably then order it and have it home delivered. The Internet is going to become an integral part of our lifestyle. It is going to be like the telephone and the TV.

You are going to see businesses that are no longer hierarchical in structure where the CEO has all the information. You are going to be dealing with businesses—and again I refer to that Harvard Business Review article—that are integrated. Companies will have interconnectivity. Everybody will have all the information on that business. You will be getting companies with a very flat business structure.

You will be able to do a lot more. It does not mean a loss of jobs, and that is something Labor always jumps up about and says, `Oh, but jobs, jobs, jobs.' It means you can be more efficient, you can do more. I know that if I had this technology now, today, in my office, rather than in two years time, my office would be three times more productive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why AT&T sacked 3,000 workers.

—It is Moore's law. Every 18 months you can expect technology to halve in price and double in capability. I entered this parliament 18 months ago and I was using a 386 computer. We are now running 300 megahertz Pentium II chips.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor worries about job losses at AT&T. They obviously were operating a government that did not see where it was going, did not see the skills that were needed—

TALK.START.PARA: —No flat bureaucracy either.

—and did not see where we would be doing business in the future. There is not a damn thing you can do about this technology, it is going ahead whether government wants it or not. This technology is being pushed throughout the world by businesses, and it will come. If you want to put your head in the sand and say, `It is not going to affect me,' you are ignoring reality.

SPEECH.PARA: It was much to our cost that Labor delayed addressing these issues, and it is about time that something occurred. We were swept into government with such a mandate because we have a leader who can see this. He was talking with Intel just yesterday about getting some sort of investment infrastructure into this country where we will see the clustering of this sort of technology occurring.

BREAK.PARA: Another thing you will notice in the industry terminology is scaleability. The cost of ownership is coming down and it will be in every home. We are now getting connectivity speed through optic fibres. The roll out of all of this cable is all about getting connectivity speed into people's homes to support this type of transaction of the future. Business could see it but the previous government could not.

With that speed of technology, we need to be churning this legislation through very rapidly to give our law enforcement agencies the ability to keep up. They were already left in the dark ages by Labor. Do not let us refer this to some committee and delay it for another 18 months so that when we come back the criminals have got away with another $5 million haul of heroin and have laundered all the money.

We are even seeing a situation now where we are addressing rural Australia: we are carrying this technology out into rural Australia. For a nation like Australia that is incredibly important. Finally we have a government with vision, a government that knows that we can use this technology. In fact, Australia is best placed in the world to be doing this.

The other thing that Bill Gates is continually pushing and searching for is simplicity. We are looking at voice recognition capabilities. You will be able to dictate letters and open your e‐mail by voice command. You can listen to it and then reply to it. You can take a little hand‐held device, a pocket notebook, with you and download your schedule on it—your messages, notepads, shopping lists—and away you go. You can link up via wireless technology while you are out so that you can update whatever it is you had to do. You are organised. You are talking a lifestyle.

The implication for government is incredible. If we got this technology into every home, we could almost hold a referendum on every issue instantaneously—as if government would not be worried about that! It is a matter of having a government with a vision that can see where this is going. People will be able to keep personal photos, play video games, get an education, grab information, stay in touch with friends or just organise things.

Currently, I run programs called Tracker and Quicken but all of these are coming together on a great little program that Microsoft has come up with called Intellimirror. You will have information stored on the Net and, when you want to use it, you just download the software to play it. You will no longer have to upgrade your software every time. At the moment, if you want to upgrade your software, you have to save the data, load the next upgrade and then reconfigure it to the little icons that you like. Now you can have that done for you, automatically, instantaneously, by a little box on top of the television.

The impact that this has for personal information is incredible, and they are worried about privacy! It astounds me. They have no idea, no concept of what this means to the future of the world, to the future of this country. Privacy! Sending an e‐mail today is like using an analog phone, and people know that, users know that. We are ahead of the Labor Party there. This is not about privacy. It is not about encryption devices—I mean, you can use all of those codes. The Internet is already getting very secure in terms of doing financial transactions. You are looking at major organised crime where you have to spend the bucks to decrypt this information, to use it and to track it.

I can tell you now that the agencies listed in here do not have the resources or the time to go chasing after little Miss Smith's shopping list. I think that is perfectly safe. If Labor is alleging that organisations such as the Australian Tax Office and the Department of Social Security will abuse the information that is given to them in the electronic age, I think they have more to answer for regarding the downloading of DAS tapes—travelgate—than we do.

We are running in a world that is going incredibly fast. We are talking about seeing, within the next two years, this sort of technology in everyone's home, on everybody's person. Look at the rate at which Australia absorbed the mobile phone. And it does not matter which language you are using. It really is becoming the very simplest thing for people to adopt and use this technology. The government is talking about providing the budget savings to come up with this.

It is very important that we keep up with the International Law Enforcement Telecommunications Seminar, which we are an active player in and which has come up with the international user requirements. In the future, this sort of interception device will be available in the switching devices for electronics. I do not know if anyone here saw the latest gun, like a Phalanx, which can send a million rounds a minute. It is all done in the circuitry, on that little switchboard. Your mobile phone, your PBX systems, everything is coming down to switching.

I have in my electorate one of the Utilux group companies, which employs 500 people making these sorts of switches. They make them for everything. It is companies with that sort of manufacturing ability that have the ability to put in a generic interception device, which reduces the cost of this. That is why we are going with the ILETS and the IUR. It is perhaps the only cost‐effective way of managing the situation and keeping up with our law enforcement obligations to the community.

It is interesting that we are supporting those sorts of industries and those sorts of manufactures here in Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is already considering a holistic view of this technology in terms of the manufacture of switching here in Australia, the manufacturing of the appliances that go on top of that switching—the plastics, the tooling, whatever Intel is producing—and everything that flows from that, right through to the actual net, be it an intranet, the corporate net, or the Internet, and right down to the content on it. Pornography is something that we will have to monitor.
