I think it is severely in the public interest that we have some sort of interception ability to monitor that sort of transmission over the Internet.

It is a matter of keeping up with technology. We are doing that—as fast as we can, but technology is even faster. But thank goodness we have got this government. I certainly would not want to be facing the next 10 years with Labor, who sit there and are worried about things that are not even the issue—who miss the point completely, who have no idea of what this can do in terms of productivity and the future lifestyles of Australians. After coming out of Defence 18 months ago, to walk into an office with a hot paper fax and a 386 computer: this was the government that Labor was running.

The amendments are ludicrous. They show a complete lack of understanding of this technology. The bill as proposed goes some way, but obviously as technology changes we will have to respond quickly and keep reviewing our legislation. We have the ministers in place who can do that. We have the Prime Minister with a vision of what Australia is going to look like. At least somebody in this country knows how Australians will be living in the year 2010. Thank goodness we have somebody who is actively bringing all of these things together through his office of government information, through his outsourcing of IT, through his support of local service providers, manufacturers and software companies. Those industries are where the jobs growth has happened in America and in Japan. In 20 years of protectionism under Labor, still the number of agricultural workers went down; the number of manufacturers in automotive industries went down.

Electronics is the name of the game. If we do not do it well, if we do not have a strong industry like that here in Australia, then we may as well close up shop and resign ourselves to never again making it back into the top 10 of the OECD nations, where we were when Labor was in power. That is our goal. We have a Prime Minister who is taking us there. He is talking to the right multinationals. He is looking after this country in a way that Labor never could or never would.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 provides for new interception capabilities and funding for those capabilities. Let me say at the outset that Labor supports the execution of legitimate investigation and the necessity for telecommunications interception to achieve this end. There have been some rather fatuous suggestions to the contrary. It has been made clear by the mover of the amendment that we do support the execution of legitimate investigation and the necessity for telecommunications interception. That is very clear. What we are going to, however, are some unforseen implications of the legislation currently before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Recent revelations by the Age newspaper about the legitimacy of some interceptions do raise real concerns in the community about whether investigations are always legitimate; however, that is a separate debate from this one. It is interesting to note that the vast majority of intercepts under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act are related to drugs and not to murder or fraud. For the year ending June 1996 there were 216 taps for drugs and 15 for every other type of crime put together.Clearly, the emphasis of agencies, in what they use taps for, is on drug related crime.

New technology and the deregulation of the telecommunications industry introduce for policing some new challenges that must be fully considered. I do not believe those implications have been as fully considered in this legislation as they ought, and that is what I intend to address in this speech. As I said, the bill responds partly to the effects of deregulation upon the cost‐effectiveness of interception. Naturally, as you deregulate and there are multiple carriers, it becomes more expensive to endeavour to intercept communications through those carriers.

The bill demands that carriers must ensure that communications passing over their network can be intercepted in accordance with a warrant issued under the act. Then there are all those sorts of underlying international memoranda that go to the capacity to understand what is communicated over those networks. Some communications that we have talked about this morning are, of course, encrypted. The functioning of the modern domestic and global economy is predicated on secure communications. We do not have, any more, the world where trucks were loaded up with buckets full of cash to go and pay people, nor do we have truckloads of cash that go to effect major financial interactions. It is all electronic, and those electronic transactions and the local and global economies themselves are predicated on secure communications.

No financial institution, market or business would be reliable if secure electronic communications were unavailable. The implication of the legislation is that network providers, such as financial institutions and Internet service providers, may be required to provide access not only to the encrypted data packets themselves but also to the decrypted data itself. That is what is not clear in this legislation, and that primarily is what requires us to refer this to committee, to explore the implications of what is proposed.

If what is proposed is that providers need essentially to provide the data decrypted, then we have a range of serious difficulties on our hands. It is a bit like the Stasi opposition to the invention of the photocopier, whereby they did not want people to have photocopiers on the basis that they might photocopy ideas and distribute them. There are some curious parallels with the introduction of older technology. What is being sought in terms of network providers providing decrypted packets to agencies could be achieved essentially in two ways. One is that backdoor decryption keys or master keys are made available so that agencies can essentially read the contents of packets that are transmitted over the networks.

The problem with this approach is that it is essentially not possible to provide backdoor keys for technology involving public and private key approaches. That is, those technologies, such as PGP, have a public key and a private key, where the interaction of the two electronic keys enables the algorithm to decrypt the content of the message that has been encrypted. Some will use only that private key/public key approach for that specific reason because it is not capable of having a master key to unlock what the user wants to be a private interaction.

The other complication is that the ISP—Internet service providers—really have no way of knowing or controlling what the users send or receive, or what client programs are used by the user. So, essentially, it would be extremely difficult for those ISPs to comply with the requirement implied in this legislation that they are able to furnish agencies with the decrypted data. I will talk about the implications this has for commercialisation for the Internet in a moment. But first I will talk about the second option which is available to ISP and financial institutions to allow essentially weak encryption products on the market, or to allow the use of only those weaker encryption products so as to enable agencies to decrypt the contents of particular packets.

The only approach would be using the sort of 40-bit key approach which the Americans have allowed for export. They will allow a better key internally but they will not allow firms to export anything more than, I think, 40 bits. You can download from a range of sites in Europe much more sophisticated public key/private key encryption products. It is pretty easy if you want to secure for yourself an encryption product which agencies would have some difficulty in dealing with. We are not really talking about locking away the photocopier so that people cannot exchange information—as the Stasi would have wanted us to do in earlier decades. We are talking about technology being available for those people who really want to use it. But there is a lack of technology for legitimate users, such as Joe Blow citizen, who wants to use reliable encryption to relay his credit card details over an unsecured network. That capacity is not available internationally.

A number of studies, including those conducted by Belcore and the Weisman institute, show that 40-bit keys are wholly unreliable. Students at MIT—which was mentioned earlier—showed that information encrypted with this standard can be decrypted in a matter of hours. Yet this is the standard that the United States has essentially locked Australia into supporting for international encryption on the Net. They will not let us export reliable encryption products to deal with the lack of consumer confidence in using credit card details on the Net, and that is causing us a real problem. Consumers know that their activity on the Net can be intercepted. In fact, we are essentially reminded of it every time we use one of the more popular browsers, like Netscape or Explorer, where we are given a little prompt saying, `You are about to transmit some information over an insecure network. Do you really want to do that?' Every consumer on the Internet is reminded every time he or she uses the Internet that they are using an unreliable network.

The implications that has for commercialisation of the Internet are profound. People who are concerned about the very real prospect of the misuse of their credit card details are not prepared to disclose their credit card details on the Net. That means that we are retarding the Australian domestic take up or commercialisation of the Net.

We are also retarding the capacity for domestic firms to trade internationally with larger markets for that reason. Essentially, the Americans have locked up their market for those people who are concerned about releasing their credit card details. They are essentially locking them out of trading with Australian firms and locking them into trading with American firms because they can use reliable encryption to transmit their credit card details and the like with an American firm, but they are prohibited from using a reliable encryption product to transmit their credit card details to an Australian firm. America is a larger market than Australia. So the net loser in this arrangement is Australia, not America.

There have been endeavours by local firms to address the problem but they have been blocked. For example, there is a company in Sydney called Nexus Solutions—it is a small start-up. It developed a 448‐bit key encryption product which the Office of Defence Signals Directorate refused to let them export. They won a major site licence with the World Health Organisation, but because we are locked into an arrangement with the Americans that says that we are not allowed to export reliable encryption products, we could not let them export that product to the World Health Organisation. That gives rise to all sorts of speculation about why the heck Australian intelligence organisations might be interested in the internal e‐mails of the World Health Organisation.

We essentially have here, I would posit, some unforeseen circumstances presented by this legislation. If the legislation is talking about access to packets per se, whether decrypted or encrypted, the government needs to explicitly make that clear in this legislation, which it has not yet done.

In the absence of making that clear, it needs to be referred to committee so that those issues can be explored and resolved. This is not, as the previous speaker, the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) would have it, a troglodyte approach or a point scoring approach. This is about ensuring that both the national and private interest are served. If we can ensure that organisations which have a legitimate interest in or a legitimate activity in intercepting data are able to go about their business and do so effectively—and cost‐effectively as well—then all well and good. But if we are talking about expecting ISPs to deliver up the impossible, such as decryption products and the like for agencies, then we have a whole range of other difficulties.

Wrapped up in this debate is the real concern that consumers have about the insecurity of the Net. It is often publicised that some young Net nerd, with a reasonable command of UNIX, will pipe out someone else's transaction to their terminal and they will have access to the contents of e‐mails and all the rest of it. As long as that concern is there and legitimate, Australian firms are disadvantaged. I would not have thought it is in the interest of either the opposition or the government to see that disadvantage perpetuated.

In seconding the amendment, what I am seeking to do is to suggest to the government that the implication of this legislation is not quite as simple as the previous speaker would have it. Yes, the Internet is an exciting and cute sort of place, but there are some very serious things that are going on in terms of the future of the Australian national economic interest which this bill impinges upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 before us today handles the technology which is required from time to time for law enforcement agencies to intercept telephone calls, telecommunication transactions, perhaps even the Internet or whatever might be necessary for them to detect and gather evidence relating to criminal activity.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of speakers have contributed to this debate so far, raising matters which are probably better addressed through legal and constitutional attorneys‐general committees of this parliament and which really do overexaggerate this bill's particular role.

This bill is certainly concerned about the technology and access to the technology that is required by law enforcement officials. But how that particular technology is used is a completely separate matter and how an investigation is commenced and what is a legitimate investigation is a completely separate matter. I would like to come back to that.

Interception of communications between two people, two parties, two businesses, two sides of a war or two battalions on the one side has really been a matter ever since somebody trained eagles to intercept carrier pigeons. It has really been something that has occurred ever since man—in a generic sense, not a sexist sense—used any particular implement to scratch some words on paper or papyrus, or whatever, and sent it off to somebody else. So let's get to what this bill is all about.

The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is going to apply the new arrangements to procedures that are necessary to ensure there are ongoing and up‐to‐date interception capabilities of telecommunications services in Australia and also to fund this particular interception capability. There are a number of minor technical amendments to the Telecommunications Act involving industry development plans and labelling of equipment and also the requirement of the Australian Communications Authority to convene and obtain industry reports.

This bill is going to tighten up a number of arrangements that govern the interception of telecommunication services so they are, in fact, keeping pace with the digital age. As technology expands and grows in this country—and we have heard plenty of contributions about that today—it is important that law enforcement agencies, if and when it is determined by the proper authorities, must be able to keep pace with those changes and must be able, if and whenever necessary, to intercept transactions or communications involving that new technology.

It is vital that police and security organisations are able, on occasions, to intercept people's calls conducted on carriers' networks. With the multitude of carriers now coming on stream in the new technological and telecommunications revolution that is in this country, inspired by Minister Alston, it is vital that we have in place legislation which is relevant, legislation which has built into it the ability to conduct reports, to order reports, to ensure that we are always up to date. The existing arrangements are just simply no longer up to date. In fact, there have been services that have been introduced on occasions without any adequate interception capability and these are starting to impact adversely on the operations of law enforcement and national security agencies.

BREAK.PARA: We all know that speaking on a digital mobile phone—and I know that, in your particular electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are perhaps not so blessed with this brain‐searing technology—is supposedly far more secure, as conversations between two digital mobile phones cannot be easily detected, or it is, I believe, virtually impossible under current arrangements. These sorts of matters are, of course, a concern where there are illegal activities.

The problems will not go away under the current framework. As well, opening up the market to full competition has increased the range of difficulties and, of course, the expense faced by various agencies that are attempting interception capability arrangements with each and every new entrant. There needs to be in place a standard approach for these new entrants to ensure that the equipment they install and the technology they embrace to offer the services that they do to the consumers of those services have a sympathetic treatment of the possible need for interception of those calls and transactions over their networks.

This is all about getting the various vendors of telecommunications to cooperate in a cost‐effective interception capability way. A lot of that will come through international cooperation in the longer term. We need to get telecommunications equipment vendors, especially people who manufacture switching equipment, for instance, to include some common interception capabilities into their equipment. We need to ensure that those capabilities are maintained. We need to ensure costs are kept down by sharing them amongst all user countries, and that will help achieve economies of scale. So this bill provides for a new level of interception capability based upon relevant international standards and guidelines.

The use of this technology is not an area that the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) is going to arbitrate on on a day‐to‐day basis. Rather, the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) and other proper people in law authority in this country are, of course, going to look at the specifics of the applications of these particular technologies.

The Attorney‐General, of course, will also base some of the requirements that he would have as the chief law officer of this land on the international user requirement, IUR, developed by most OECD law enforcement and national security agencies, which includes this country, under the auspices of the International Law Enforcement Telecommunications Seminar, ILETS.

The bill also contains, as have a number of other bills that Minister Alston has introduced into the parliament during his time as minister for communications, mechanisms which will ensure that we can constantly keep ourselves up to date. It will require the ACA to be notified of any relevant changes to technology and it will require that relevant agencies are consulted by the ACA. This is a good thing. It is important in this ever changing technological world in which we live, as gimmicks come and gimmicks go but as some things become hard and fast mainstays and must haves of our economy and our community, that we keep up to date.

It is the criminal elements in this nation and in this world that will always keep themselves one step ahead of the law. If technology provides them with an escalator to keep one step ahead of the law then we have to respond. As legislators, not to stop them from doing that would be irresponsible.

We may express some grave concerns, justifiably, about the privacy aspects for the bulk of the citizenry but I suspect that most Australians have absolutely nothing to fear from the enhanced interception capabilities that law enforcement agencies may have as a result of this bill passing. I say that simply because all we are doing is ensuring that the standard capabilities that law enforcement agencies have are able now to be executed through the new technologies. This is a reasonable, straightforward, easy to understand bill.

The bill also looks at new funding arrangements for interception. Various agencies will continue to be liable for the cost of executing individual interception warrants as well as most other matters that are in addition to the basic listening and recording of a communication. They will also be liable for the cost of establishing capabilities that they have specifically requested.

I understand a few of the communications carriers will probably be a bit miffed by this because a greater share of the costs of interception are being placed upon them than was previously the case. But these are the carriers that are participating in a vigorous, growing industry, an industry where, as the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) said before, every year the cost seems to halve while the capability seems to double. It is an industry where there is exponential growth.

In fact, the take‐up of this industry, in a commercial sense, has meant that profits are substantial and potential profits are even greater. Therefore, it is quite fair and reasonable for the national good and for our role as a good international citizen for these telecommunications carriers to play their part in sharing some of the costs.

With regard to the interception capability plan, it is also wise that this bill requires that the Attorney‐General is able to nominate carriers and carriage service providers who are then required to submit plans on an annual basis to ensure that the Attorney‐General, as the chief law officer, is up to date with any technological changes which may occur from time to time and which may prevent him and his agencies from conducting the proper business that they do conduct.

As I said at the outset of my contribution today, this bill is all about technology. It is all about ensuring that there is a certain amount of flexibility within the government and the law enforcement agencies, as well as within the industry, to comply in a good citizen sense with changing technology affecting interception capabilities. This bill is about ensuring they comply with the need to update our capabilities to intercept calls, intercept transactions of data, and intercept various things that criminals may embark upon.

However, with regard to the moral issue—the civil liberty issue—I have a great deal of sympathy for that, and I think the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) and the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel) touched on elements of that. When I look at my own state, at the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland which is a law unto itself, I see that it has embarked on some very curious tapping of telephone conversations and, as a result, it has been found wanting, and quite rightly. I worry that there is always a question of ensuring that telephone interceptions and technological interceptions, when they take place, are done so for the right reasons. So I say let us give strength to the civil liberty groups and to the members of this place who always keep those particular decisions accountable. Let us make the people who make these decisions always accountable for them. But, in concert with making those particular decision makers accountable—those who decide to order these interception procedures—what we cannot do is tie one arm behind their back.

This bill has been introduced because technology has been hamstringing law enforcement agencies for years now. It is important that this bill not only address the technological change in recent years and does something about it but also that it leaves open the door for future technology changes and allows the authorities, both in the communications area of this government and in the law enforcement areas, the flexibility they need.

I think we all want to see criminal elements rooted out. While we have heard contributions today about the concern of legitimate commercial transactions being encrypted—coded so that the transactions are protected from others who may accidentally or incidentally, or quite deliberately, obtain that data for their own commercial advantage—there is no doubt that the criminal element will also embark upon encryption of their own activities. Therefore, unless we allow law enforcement agencies the opportunity and the flexibility they need to keep up to date with technology to deal with the technological changes and to be able to intercept, if necessary, particular encoded information, we are doing the wrong thing by the citizenry of this nation.

I think this bill as it stands is a good bill. It is a straightforward bill. It provides the technological changes. As I said, for those who want to argue the moral questions, I do not believe the venue of this bill is the appropriate place to do that. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been described by the previous speaker, the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 was introduced in the Senate on 2 October. It passed the Senate on 30 October 1997 and entered the House in November. As I understand it, the bill is being unanimously supported subject to minor agreed Democrat amendments in the Senate. The intent of the bill is to create new arrangements for establishing interception capabilities for telecommunications services and for the funding of interception capabilities. It makes a number of minor technical amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: The interception of telecommunications services is an integral part of today's law enforcement work and has become an increasingly useful tool for this nation's security, intelligence and police forces. However, as the use of such interception has increased in importance, we have also seen a mammoth increase in the use of telecommunications services by business and other consumers, as well as a proliferation of new technologies.

Despite the extraordinary benefits these innovations have provided to us, as Australians, there have arisen some problems with the use of interception services. At present, law enforcement agencies are able to obtain information in connection with the investigation of certain offences by interception provided they have an appropriate warrant. Furthermore, as it presently stands, all telecommunication carriers are obliged to cooperate with agencies by ensuring that all communications on their service can be intercepted by authorised agencies.

This requirement is subject to exemptions granted by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) in consultation with the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams). Carriers are also obliged to consult with agencies, as directed by the Australian Communications Authority, about the development of new telecommunications technologies. This is an obvious requirement because of the need to ensure that new servers are able to be intercepted in the interest of law enforcement, public safety and national security.

Unfortunately, with the deregulation of the Australian telecommunications industry this year it has become apparent that all new carriers entering the market must painstakingly negotiate these arrangements with the relevant agencies. In short, everyone stands to lose—the agencies, because their resources are tied up in these negotiations, and consequently the people of Australia; the carriers, who lose valuable time and money when they get caught up in this process, and, as a consequence, their customers.

BREAK.PARA: Already the introduction of some new telecommunications services has been significantly delayed. Other services have occasionally been introduced without adequate allowance for interception use. Thankfully, potential solutions to this predicament have already been canvassed by Mr Pat Barrett, in his 1994 report on telecommunications interception. In fact, many of his ideas were incorporated into the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act passed in 1995.

The most appropriate answer in the long run is to participate in internationally cooperative efforts to ensure the vendors of telecommunication services, particularly switch makers, include common interception capabilities in their equipment. Costs shared amongst nations are substantially reduced.

This legislation introduces a new level of interception capability based on these international considerations. More precisely, the Attorney‐General will base the new capability level on the international user requirement developed under the International Law Enforcement Telecommunications Seminar. To ensure continuous interception capability, this legislation allows for the continuation of present arrangements until the Attorney‐General has made his determination.

It is important to recognise also that law enforcement agencies are not simply interceptors of telecommunication services but also users of services. Their particular roles mean that they are often required to use services which are incapable of interception, or have a lower level of interception capability. Under this legislation, the minister—in consultation with the Attorney‐General—will continue to allow the operation of such services.

In order to overcome the problems associated with carrier-agency consultation, the ACA will be consulted by carriers who change technologies and the ACA will then consult the relevant agencies. The ACA will be required to specify reasonable guidelines for agency considerations, to ensure that there is no undue delay of service introduction.

This legislation aims also to overcome the funding problems associated with interception. In the past, these problems have severely impacted on the work of agencies. While those agencies will continue to be liable for the cost of executing individual warrants, carriers will be required to pay the costs of providing the relevant interception capability. The cost burden is therefore more equitably shared. There are a number of other changes made which will further strengthen the sharing of costs.

Furthermore, there is a recognition that future consideration of these matters will be required. As such, the bill requires that the minister, in consultation again with the Attorney‐General, review—before 1 July 1999—longer‐term cost‐effectiveness in the funding of telecommunications interception.

To touch on the comment by the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave), I share that concern about the potential breach of civil rights and mischievous use of interception. I think we will need to be forever vigilant in that matter.

The rest of the bill simply deals with a number of other minor amendments—to labelling requirements for customer equipment and cabling, the reporting requirements of the ACA, the regulation of carriers' powers and immunities, and industry development plans.
With pleasure I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—We are now concluding the summing up of debate on the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997. I take the opportunity to thank honourable members who have contributed to the discussion.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is agreed to by the opposition, although I understand that there is a proposal that there be a division on its amendment. I will talk about that amendment. Under the procedures, I understand, the division will actually take place in the main chamber.

I come to some of the matters that have been raised by the shadow minister for science, the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans). I acknowledge his level of interest in this area. He did indicate that he supported the basic thrust of the legislation, and the government is pleased about that. Both sides of the parliament recognise the basic importance of the information economy, but I think his summation of some of the issues relating to encryption missed the point of what the intent is with regard to this piece of legislation, which in the main could be described as reasonably complex.

The government fundamentally agrees that electronic commerce is vitally important for the nation and we are indeed developing a range of approaches to this. The recent announcement by my colleague Senator Alston, as the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, gives effect to the concern in relation to this issue and to the importance that the government places on it. Indeed, the National Office of the Information Economy will focus on the issue of electronic commerce and will work closely with Australian business and relevant agencies to ensure that the broader issues raised by encryption, security and privacy issues, which I will discuss in a moment, are addressed in encouraging the overall development of electronic commerce.

The shadow minister misses the point. It is not true that the act fails to adequately address the information economy: that is clearly a red herring from the Labor Party, and that is regrettable. It is indeed important, in a national sense, to embrace across party lines the benefits that can accrue to our economy from developing a purposeful approach to the information economy, and the government is certainly committed to that.

The contribution from the shadow minister fundamentally misreads part of the bill. What the bill requires is for carriers, including ISPs, to give information to the agencies—and the agencies I refer to are the security agencies—in the form in which they actually receive it. If the information comes onto an ISP or independent service provider network in an encrypted form, the ISP is merely obliged to deliver that information in the same encrypted form to those agencies. The bill is not, as I understand the shadow minister to have said, requiring those people to deal more substantially with that encrypted form.

Referring the bill to a committee, as is the genus of the amendment, is not in our view appropriate. Indeed, I heard the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) eloquently outlining why it was not appropriate and certainly not a matter that ought to be sent to a committee. This legislation needs to be passed to enable the issues to proceed. As I outlined earlier, there is a cost consequence here. We do not want to limit in any way, by derailing and delaying this bill, the development of the emergence of service providers and the development of this industry—particularly when the Labor Party has already said it supports the general thrust of the legislation.

The bill is basically about the capacity of law enforcement agencies to carry out their tasks by ensuring that they have the resources to conduct interception of telecommunication services. We are all aware, in the broad, of the heavy reliance that individual communications have on utilising the telephone system and of the increasing capacity for and take‐up of digitisation, both in the exchanges—and I referred in the second reading speech to the importance of switching points and, indeed, we have talked about that in some detail—and in mobile telephony. They are, obviously, all matters which security agencies worldwide are dealing with. Indeed, I outlined some of the international arrangements in the second reading speech.

The bill is not about the ability of business to conduct commercial transactions or digital signatures. Indeed, the matter of digital signatures, which I note is in the amendment, is not even mentioned in the bill. The shadow minister, whilst he does know a little about this area, would probably benefit from taking some more detailed briefings. With regard to the requirement for privacy standards on Australian companies, the encryption issues raised in the bill are implicit and secondary. They only arise where a telecommunications carrier or service provider does its own encryption as an inherent part of its service offering. The current position, which allows end users to encrypt information, does not change. There is no obligation on carriers or service providers to decrypt any encryption from an end user. As I mentioned before, digital signatures are not even mentioned in the bill.

An important point has been made by some members, and I have just heard Mr Barry Wakelin, the member for Grey, make a reference to privacy, but the fundamental issue is that the bill does not change the privacy and protection of communications requirements imposed by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 and part 13 of the Telecommunications Act 1997. Privacy is not in any way affected by this bill, and that matter needs to be underlined.

There was reference to the Pat Barrett report of some years ago. Indeed, in another capacity as Telecommunications Ombudsman, I can testify that the development of a privacy regime and additional amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act underpin the commitment that we have across the community to ensuring that privacy is respected, both in legislation and in practice. I give the assurance that that legislation meets those requirements, so any suggestion to the contrary ought to be rejected. I say to my colleagues, on both sides of the chamber who participated in the debate, to please be assured on that particular point.

The final issue is that the parliament has already set up a forum for looking at electronic commerce issues. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts has commenced an inquiry into the issues surrounding all of these matters. This will certainly canvass the wider issues of the encryption policy. I understand that the committee will report on schedule, and that the report will be tabled in both houses between March and May next year.

The bill also clearly contemplates an early review of its own policies before 1 July 1999. We will continue, as I mentioned, to give high priority to all of these matters but, clearly, it is inappropriate for the bill to be delayed. That is why we will vote against the amendment that is being proposed by the honourable shadow minister. We do not want to create uncertainty in the telecommunications industry—as I said in the second reading speech. We do not want to potentially create unnecessary problems for law enforcement or national security. We can give the assurance, which is already in the legislation to which I refer, about the protection of privacy matters.

This legislation recognises the increasing complexity of technology and how it interfaces with law enforcement agencies. The bill, as I mentioned in the second reading speech, takes up a couple of other matters that are uncontentious and that need to be dealt with for the continued enhancement of a telecommunications policy—the benefit of which, in a tangential way, is illustrated with the listing of Telstra on the Stock Exchange for the first time. We have seen that happen with tremendous benefits for so many in the community, including over 90 per cent of Telstra employees who have done particularly well. This is a government that takes the development of telecommunications at a sensible pace for the benefit of all very seriously. I commend the bill to the House.
Motion (by Mr Ted Grace) agreed to:
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 22 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 seeks to amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to give effect to decisions in respect of X and R‐rated programs on narrowcasting services which were included in a range of measures announced by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) and the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) on 8 April 1997.

Currently, X and R‐rated programming is banned on subscription broadcasting services and on free to air broadcasting services. However, narrowcasting services—that is, services limited in availability or appeal—are not prevented from providing X and R‐rated programming. Increasingly, pay television companies are offering extra channels of specialised programming through narrowcasting services. Such services provide pay television companies with an avenue to broadcast explicitly sexual material which mainstream television services are prohibited from showing.

In response to considerable community concern, the government has decided to amend the Broadcasting Services Act to prohibit programs that have been refused classification or have been classified as X on subscription television narrowcasting services and also on open free to air narrowcasting services. This will serve to prohibit the depiction of actual sexual acts, as provided for under the current X classification, across all television services, whether broadcast or narrowcast.

The government has also decided to apply to open narrowcasting services the same restrictions regarding R‐rated programs as currently apply to commercial television broadcasting services. These include the requirement that codes of practice must provide for modification of R‐rated films to comply with the previous AO classification, and restrict the hours within which M and MA material may be broadcast.

Typically, open narrowcasters are community television services provided free to air, and without any limitation on access by children. It is considered, therefore, that they should be subject to the same restrictions as apply to other free to air services in respect of the televising of R-rated material.

It is not proposed to prohibit R‐rated material on subscription television narrowcasting services. The Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association's code of practice for subscription television narrowcasters, which has been registered with the Australian Broadcasting Authority, requires that the broadcast of R-classified material on subscription narrowcasting television services will be restricted to access by those with appropriate disabling devices, and services devoted predominantly to adult erotica will be restricted to late night access only. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 amends the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to ensure that X‐rated material is not available on narrowcast services and R‐rated material is not available on open narrowcast services and is restricted to closed narrowcast services.

SPEECH.PARA: Narrowcast services are divided into two categories, open and closed. Open narrowcast services constitute cable or other delivered services, on which no restrictions as to availability are placed. Examples of open narrowcast service are community television stations and most pay TV channels. These services are readily accessible by children. Closed narrowcast services include restricted pay TV services. These services place controls over access to the services. An example of a closed narrowcast service is Galaxy's Night Moves channel.

The bill ensures that open narrowcast services are treated the same as free to air television for classification purposes. The bill is consistent with previous decisions of the Labor Party when we were in government and decisions that we have made since we have been in opposition, and we will be supporting this unconditionally in the House. I do not believe that I should keep the committee any further. My view is to give credit where credit is due. This is a bill that does have cross-party support, and the Labor Party commends it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to support this Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . This bill is good commonsense and will ensure that reasonable standards are maintained in free to air in some cases of community narrowcasting TV services, and in certain areas of pay TV where some limitations continue to be placed on any specialist services relating to R‐rated movies and there is a voluntary ban on X-rated movies.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill would certainly have the support of my electorate. In information that has been provided to us independently, I am pleased to say that the electorate of O'Connor has the lowest level of consumption of X‐rated videos out of Canberra of any electorate in Australia. That is just our good, healthy lifestyle. There are plenty of other activities of either a work or recreational nature in my electorate that remove the need for that sort of stimulation. That is just a point I make.

The other point I would make at this stage—and I wish to take the opportunity of this particular debate to refer to a couple of matters relative to the other side of the question—is that the electorate of O'Connor does not get a great deal of cable or other types of television. In fact, without special facilities that I wish to refer to, it does not get much television at all. It has the choice presently, for most sectors, of an ABC program and a commercial program, known as GWN—that is the start and the finish of it—and for many to obtain either of those programs requires their own satellite communications equipment. So they have got a little way to go.

You would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that not long ago local government was running a very vigorous campaign against cables being strung around electric light poles. My 62 local authorities decided that they should be involved in this campaign and all wrote me letters saying what a dreadful thing it was. I wrote back to them all and said that I had good news for them: they were not getting any cables. I said it was about time they woke up to the fact that they were out in the cold when it came to cable television, and if somebody was prepared to come into their place and do them the favour of stringing a few cables around on their electric light poles they ought to grab the opportunity because they were not getting anything else. Anyway, I think the logic of that might have prevailed.

But I wish to draw to the attention of the House—and it has a linkage here in as much as this has to do with regulating particularly cable and satellite services—circumstances arising in my electorate. The remote area broadcasting service, as it is known, does in fact include certain services in Queensland regional television. They are serviced by satellite, as I have already mentioned, and it has been the decision of the main two providers—that is, Optus and Telstra—to move their satellite transmission from analog to digital.

It is a commercial decision they have made and it gives those transmitters substantial benefits. The first is that they can substantially expand the delivery capacity of existing satellites because they can get a lot more compressed information into the same units. That, on the other hand, will also allow them to provide a lot of other services, such as Internet services and all sorts of things of that nature, data transfer services and, of course, a wider variety of TV transmissions within the same capacity. That would be a benefit to the people in my electorate.

The downside at the moment is that it requires a change of equipment which many of these people have only purchased recently, usually at a cost of about $4,000. It does not require the replacement of all that equipment. But to the best that I can establish—and this is an interesting point, because presently there are no so‐called black boxes commercially available—it is suggested that for a standard sort of farm equipment there will be a cost of about $1,200 for domestic decoders and costs of from $2,500 to $10,000 for professional model decoders, which may be required for those communities that have installed their own terrestrial retransmission facilities. That is not uncommon in my electorate where local authorities have put in a single receiving point and retransmitted it in the same fashion as would apply to people in major metropolitan areas.

The real issue in all of this is that, under Project Aurora, Optus is digitising its satellite operations and developing a system capable of carrying a range of services, including broadcasting, pay TV and data transfer services, including Internet access. They are doing that with their own satellites, which they purchased along with the licence to be our second electronic communicator. Telstra is offering a separate service using capacity on the PanAm satellite, but otherwise is doing the same.

The ABC and SBS and regional television in Queensland have contracted with Optus for future digital transmission of their services. Optus is currently scheduled to begin conversion in Western Australia in May 1998. GWN, the commercial provider, has contracted with Telstra for transmission of its services in Western Australia commencing in November 1997. There is another remote area broadcasting service, a RABS operator, Imparja, and that is yet to finalise arrangements with respect to its services in central Australia.

What is confronting the people in my electorate is that if they want to continue to get the public and the commercial broadcasting service, as things stand now they will have to access two separate satellites in two separate parts of the spectrum. Technically this would require two dishes, or a much more expensive one that literally could track and locate the two satellites. That is much more expensive than a fixed dish and, in fact, is not a practical solution. As you can imagine, as a consequence there is considerable concern in my electorate over this arrangement.

BREAK.PARA: The problem for the government is that in our presently deregulated and commercialised environment, this initiative is not a government initiative. We did not tell anybody to do this. We recognise that there is a long‐term benefit to everybody, but on the other hand it is a commercial decision taken by commercial communication providers and, as a consequence, commercial and public TV providers. They are making it very clear that they do not expect to accept the costs as they apply to the consumers.

We have suggested that there is a possibility that the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, the RTIF—that is, if there are any funds left after Tasmania gets its share. I understand they are to be treated generously in this matter—

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to be careful, you are between two of us!

—The reality is that it has been suggested that it is appropriate that people apply to that fund. Although I can see that as a mechanism to save costs for my constituents, I must recognise that such a purpose is going to reduce the capacity of that fund to do other things that I think may be of more importance. That includes the extension of mobile phone services throughout my electorate, or assistance in allowing people to get into low orbiting satellite phones. Again, my electorate is one that is substantially underserviced when it comes to mobile phones, notwithstanding that it is a service that probably, if it had ever been provided on the basis of need, would have first gone to country areas.

BREAK.PARA: I am disappointed that the service providers do not seem to be looking at the options by which they could assist their own clients. These could include a bulk wholesale purchase of black box decoders and subsequently providing them at the imported price. That at least would incur no cost and would generate considerable savings.

Nevertheless, the issue of the two services is the one that concerns me most. I have had correspondence with the minister who unofficially tells me that they are negotiating to obtain approval from the two commercial satellite operators to retransmit each other's signal. That means that by tuning in to one satellite or the other you would be back to the current situation of only having to access one satellite. I am extremely hopeful that we will get the cooperation of Telstra and Optus in that regard. It would be most unfair to my constituents were it to be done in any other way.

That of course raises questions of capacities on the satellites, and it raises questions with some, which I cannot understand, that there could be some reduction in the quality through re‐broadcasting. I am not sure that that is technically correct. I take this opportunity in the parliament to draw these situations to the attention of the House because I believe it is unfair to the people in my electorate that, because they do not get free to air, as it is understood in major metropolitan areas—they have invested their own capital in obtaining something which people in the metropolitan area take for granted—they should be confronted, in the case of some, after quite recent substantial capital outlays, with this additional cost.

I am hoping that the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston)—and I am not complaining about him because he has been very cooperative and very sensitive to this issue—will pursue it and that he will implement it to the extent he is able. For instance, as the major shareholder, still, in Telstra we could influence them to ensure we do get re‐transmission so that there need only be one communication. Also, every attempt should be made to reduce the costs to individuals, through the cost of either decoders or other equipment.

In that regard, I have recently had information of retailers whom I would like to criticise running around saying to people, `There's going to be a dreadful shortage of these decoders. Sign up for one now at $3,000.' In fact, the suggested price is $1,200. I find that outrageous. But it is happening and it is a great pity. They are people outside of this system. I put that on the record and hope that it is noted by these people because I think they are being very unfair to their customers in trying to market ahead of the situation. In fact, as I understand it, the black boxes are still not commercially available.

Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your indulgence in allowing me to address those additional issues. It makes sense to control these particular transmissions and I think there is an ever rising expectation in the community that governments ensure that children and others are protected. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The shadow minister responsible for this legislation has indicated that the opposition supports the government's proposal as being a balanced, commonsense approach to this issue of the need for limiting the viewing, particularly of children, of classified material on narrowcast services, and we welcome that.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments that have just been made by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who also supports the legislation, and his much broader comments about the needs of his electorate, which represents, in parts, a remote area of Australia, and their need for television services, and the utilisation of satellites operated by Optus and Telstra, are certainly noted. As he indicated, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) has been in communication with him and is well aware of the problems and the concerns that he has. It is no wonder that the member for O'Connor is one of the most successful members in the chamber, given the way he prosecutes the needs of his constituents, and we certainly congratulate him for that.

With respect to the issue of the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) and I have an acute interest in it because it is so beneficial to the state of Tasmania. I am sure the member would agree with me that it is one of the most innovative and sensible approaches that the government has taken with the enhancement of telecommunications services in the state of Tasmania.

The allocation of those funds is a matter for the board, and the concerns that have been raised by the member for O'Connor have, as I understand it, been brought to the attention of the board. That is all I would be able to say at this stage because they exercise independent judgment about the allocation of those funds. With those few words, I thank speakers for their contribution and commend the bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 October, on motion by Mr Slipper:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Family and Community Affairs Committee for its report on the seminar into aspects of youth suicide and the recommendations contained in the report. It is a timely report, something that quite clearly is critical, in view of the rising rate of youth suicide. It is another demonstration of how parliamentarians of all political persuasions can work together towards a common objective. Often we hear the complaint in the community that parliamentarians always seem to be squabbling and fighting over sometimes narrow political differences in the parliament. But in this particular instance we can see clearly demonstrated a common purpose on the part of parliamentarians who are quite clearly deeply concerned at what has become part and parcel of our modern‐day life, the rising rate of youth suicide. I might say also that another aspect of suicide is the rising and very high rate of suicide amongst men who are in the aged bracket.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation where, to use Hugh Mackay's definition of the three generations that has been most recently expounded in his book Generations: Baby Boomers, their Parents and their Children, which was released very recently, we can see suicide affecting the two generations on either side of the baby boomers. That is an interesting phenomenon, given some of the comments that have been made in this book.

Hugh Mackay calls the generation that followed the baby boomers, the ones who are in the age group where we have youth suicide so prevalent, the `options generation'. Talking about the changes in the community, he made the point:

According to evolutionary psychology, the process of adapting from village life to suburban life has been so disruptive to the human psyche that it will be many more generations before adaptation successfully occurs. In the meantime, the theory claims to account for widespread feelings of alienation, depression and other neuroses amongst the suburban population.
If that theory were to be our framework, we might expect that the Options Generation—
that is, the generation following the baby boomers—

would be showing the healthiest signs of successful adaptation, and we might interpret the gap between them and their parents and grandparents as positive evidence of that process. But the rising rate of youth suicide challenges that interpretation and, in any case, the fact that we are now being overtaken by the Information Revolution might have already distorted the process of adapting to the social consequences of the Industrial Revolution.

Whether or not you choose to adopt that particular account of Western society's psychological problems, it does seem likely that a satisfactory explanation of contemporary generation gaps will not be found in the conventional view of a simple journey through the life cycle, but in a much bigger picture of social and cultural change.
That probably is the most apt of the comments he has made in the chapter which is called, very aptly, `Insecurity makes humans of us all'.

If one were to look back at some of the works that perhaps predated the technological revolution or the information age, one would probably look at something like Future Shock and the Third Wave, both by Alvin Toffler, and Powershift, which was the third part of his trilogy on social and technological change. One would see in Future Shock the prediction of this dislocation and alienation that is occurring in our community as a result of the enormous cultural, social and technological changes affecting all aspects of our lives.

In particular, we are seeing the effect of so‐called future shock affecting the two generations on either side of the baby boomers probably the most seriously. In the case of what Hugh Mackay calls the `lucky generation'—the people born in the late 1920s and 1930s—and of the `options generation'—those born in the post baby boomers period—there appear to be very serious concerns or problems in the dislocative effect of the rapid changes in our community. I believe, as Hugh Mackay has pointed out—and, of course the committee has arrived at a similar conclusion—that that dislocation is one of the ingredients in the causes that have brought youth suicide to be such a serious problem in our community today.
Interestingly enough, in the mid‐1960s Jacob Bronowski, author of The Ascent of Man, wrote an essay entitled `Where do we go from here?', and he said:

It is evident that we are living in a cultural reformation—a harsh and perhaps disruptive movement in which we are all engaged. The fabric of western culture, its tangled skein of social habits, artefacts and values, is being pulled apart and made over—by us. We have set going the headlong changes in conduct and belief which now fill us with questions. Is there a single direction in these changes? Is there, in particular, an imaginative direction in the arts and sciences which points the way for a future culture? How shall we educate fresh generations, either to follow the changes or to lead them? What is the future of man? And is there any point in our wanting that future to conform to our own conception of man?

That leads me then to probably one of the most important aspects of Mackay's work, which in effect is a research project on the three generations and the interaction between them, and that is the fact that too often we tend to look at the other generations, particularly the ones that follow us, with the same sorts of attitudes that we have ourselves. We fail to understand the differences in cultural and social approaches in the generations that have come before us or are coming after us.

In particular, in the case of the options generation, the post baby boomers, there are some very fundamental and serious misconceptions about what it is that is either motivating them or troubling them—or, for that matter, about the sorts of things that they want to do with their lives and the sorts of things that they want to have or to get from the people in our generation. Most members of parliament would be of the baby boomers generation, with a few exceptions. I do not mean to insult the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent). I did not place him in the lucky generation: I think he looks much younger.

Certainly, what this indicates is that there is a tendency for us to view societal problems, particularly in relation to the younger generation, from our own perspective. As a consequence, it is a perspective that is two‐dimensional and at times leads to mistaken conclusions about what ought to be done. One of the most important aspects of the committee's recommendations is the recommendation to ensure consistency in data collections at all levels of government. There is a dire need for us to much more thoroughly understand some of the social changes that are going on, not only in our generation but in the generation that is obviously suffering this very high youth suicide rate.

I would like to commend Hugh Mackay on this work. I think it is probably one of the best pieces of contemporary social writing that I have seen for a long time. It certainly explores those differences and puts into context some of the problems that seem to us to be almost insoluble. And, of course, to some of those who are closer to the problem, it is insoluble; but, in other cases, it is something that they live with from day to day. Hugh Mackay points out in Generations:

Allan Bloom, in The Closing of the American Mind , spoke for many older Australians as well when he exposed what he sees as the intellectual and moral confusions of our time. One of Bloom's central claims is that our contemporary passion for tolerance is a mere disguise for an unhealthy drift into relativism. He is particularly critical of the marriage of the drug culture with the contemporary music scene because he believes that it offers an ultimately unfulfilling short cut to the experience of ecstasy and gratification
Hugh Mackay quotes Allan Bloom as saying:

Rock music provides premature ecstasy and, in this respect, is like the drugs with which it is allied. It artificially induces the exultation naturally attached to the completion of the greatest endeavours—victory in a just war, consummated love, artistic creation, religious devotion and discovery of truth. Without effort, without talent, without virtue, without exercise of the faculties, anyone and everyone is accorded the equal right to the enjoyment of their fruits.In my experience, students who have had a serious fling with drugs—and gotten over it—find it difficult to have enthusiasms or great expectations. It is as though the colour has been drained out of their lives, and they see everything in black and white. The pleasure they experienced in the beginning was so intense that they no longer look for it at the end, or as the end. They may function perfectly well, but dryly, routinely. Their energy has been sapped, and they do not expect their live's activity to produce anything but a living, whereas liberal education is supposed to encourage the belief that the good life is the pleasant life and that the best life is the most pleasant life.

And that would make sense to people in Peter Nugent's generation—the lucky generation; I have just redefined it. But it certainly is something that fits in with Hugh Mackay's other points about the options generation and their search for the sort of lifestyle options that they see readily available to, perhaps, the previous generation and that they need to try and indulge in as soon as possible.

And it is interesting that the drug culture is closely allied to the suicide culture. There is a very strong link between the two. It is interesting that when people talk about the sorts of character or other problems a person faces that leads them into drug taking, there are similar aspects to those and the sorts of things that lead young people to seek suicide as an answer to their problems.

It is important, when looking at the committee's recommendations, to understand this. We must ensure that we have consistent data collection in relation to these types of problems at all levels of government. I think that is critical because we desperately need to understand these problems and not look at them from a fundamentalist or, perhaps, a reactionary point of view that is tempting in some instances.

We look at things such as the Internet and other aspects of our daily information lives and we say, `There is stuff on here that is dreadful. We ought to censor it.' But it is almost impossible to censor it. We need to look at it in the context of how that relates to the people who are likely to be its most ardent consumers and we need to understand in a more detailed way exactly what it is that is causing the sorts of dislocating problems that lead people to seek suicide as a way out.

It is a problem of such magnitude that no‐one in our community could deny that substantial action is required as soon as possible, and that every delay contributes to further misery and suffering in families right across the nation. And some of the details highlighted by members speaking on this report are sobering, indeed. It is distressing that over the last 30 years the suicide rate for males has trebled and for females has doubled.

BREAK.PARA: We all agree that something must be done—it is the classical statement. The community says that something must be done and they expect us to do something about it, and we have the means to do it. Sometimes the actual practical application of policy is at odds with the general thrust and the good intentions of the members of the governments, or the authorities, who are trying to do something about the problem.

Last week I received a letter from a parent who is struggling with the fear that many in Australia face. He has a child who has become suicidal. I have got three children, one of whom is in his early teens, and it must be an absolutely devastating revelation. Each of us here should think about how we would cope, or what we would do if faced with a situation where a loved one becomes so depressed and distressed, or loses his or her sense of self‐worth to such an extent, as to want to end life.

This parent sought help. He has tried to obtain the best quality therapy to help his daughter regain the desire to live. He sought counselling and therapy through the public health system and found that there is a nine‐month waiting list. Nine months; that is extraordinary. He sought private psychiatric therapy and is faced with a six‐week wait. What goes through the mind of a parent every day and every night for six weeks, whenever that child is not directly supervised or protected or with them? Who knows?

The cost of private therapy was quoted at $84.90 per hour. Medicare covers the first $110.11 and the rest is excess. It is not even covered by his health fund. I am not saying that people should not expect to pay for their health care at this time. What disturbs me though is that our society has developed a public health care system—and we are faced with these demands from the community and our own expectations of doing something—and here is a practical application of policy making it harder for a parent who loves his child to be able to do something about it.

I am absolutely beside myself to think what on earth he must think when he is faced with this. What message does that give him? The message is quite clearly: the community thinks so little of the problem that it is prepared to make him wait nine months in the public health care system in order to get that sort of assistance for his child.

In my last few moments, I urge the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) to make an urgent change to the situation so that parents like this particular correspondent are in a position to be able to get expert professional psychiatric help for their child when they are suicidal, depressed and despondent. These parents are in a position where help is desperately needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Draper, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs entitled Aspects of youth suicide , and I congratulate the committee on their work to date. The report is the result of a seminar conducted on 28 February 1997, which was addressed by four main speakers who have considerable experience in the field of health and community welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: Young people are our future. They hold the key to the future of Australia and the world. Young people are generally very optimistic and vibrant. They eagerly plan for their futures and live life to its fullest. For some, however, the world seems to offer little hope or enjoyment. They feel trapped and not in control of their lives. They are looking for an escape and the only thing they can find is death. Such a tragedy of human life can hardly be endured. We feel for the young people who reach this level of hopelessness, and for their parents. As a parent of three young children, I know there could be nothing worse in life than to have a child take his or her own life. Yet so many parents must suffer this tragedy and forever wonder whether they could have done anything to prevent it.

The aspects of youth suicide seminar was opened by our Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The Prime Minister emphasised the importance of the bipartisan approach to youth suicide prevention and I know members opposite share our concern for this issue. The government's commitment to youth suicide prevention is demonstrated by the initiation of the national youth suicide strategy, which I would like to outline for those present in this place. The national youth suicide strategy will provide funding of $19 million over three years in the fight to prevent youth suicide.

Recognising that rural and regional youth have a particularly high rate of suicide, the government will spend $6 million to provide them with counselling services and assistance. A further $6 million is being spent on Lifeline and a Kids Helpline telephone counselling service. Another $3 million will be spent on informing parents of the danger signs to watch for in their children and on how to cope with a child who may attempt to take his or her own life. A further $2 million will be spent on training for professionals working with children so that they are kept up to date with the latest information and methods of assistance. A further $1 million will be spent on childhood mental health. This is in addition to funding under the `Here for Life' program introduced by the previous government.

When addressing the problem of youth suicide, it is important to identify those young people most at risk. This was the clear message that came out of the seminar. Statistics are not always totally accurate when endeavouring to ascertain the level of the problem in our community. Some suicides are not recorded as such because it may not have been considered as suicide at the time of death or to protect the family from further trauma. Furthermore, young people can often indulge in highly dangerous activities that lead to death. Activities such as glue sniffing and train surfing, whilst not necessarily being intentionally suicidal, show a complete lack of concern for their own safety. For these reasons, the statistics for youth suicide could be considerably understated.

The seminar was presented with the official statistics which showed that, in 1995, there were 350 young male suicides and 84 young female suicides. When we talk of youth suicide, we are referring to people as young as 12 who take their own lives. How 12‐year‐olds could possibly have reached the depths of despair that would lead them to kill themselves is beyond most of us. We can only read of such occurrences with complete shock and sadness. The official statistics show that, since the 1960s, the rate of young male suicide has almost trebled and, for young females, it has doubled. But what are the reasons? Why are many young people so willing to end their lives?

The world has never been safer or the future brighter for most people living in Western nations. Today, the majority of us are living longer and healthier lives. The opportunities available to young people through education and careers are many and varied. Discrimination based on race, sex or creed is on a steep decline and we now live in a fairer and more tolerant society.

So why do many of our young people feel that life, for them, is not worth living? It has taken quite a long time for us to realise the importance of this issue and, until recently, little research had been done on youth suicide. This research has shown that the causes of youth suicide are very complex and are influenced by many factors. Building a prevention strategy is thus made more difficult because of the complex nature of the causes. Only persons who take their own lives will ever really know what made them do it; even then, it is likely to have been a combination of a number of factors which lead to their decision.

The classic symptoms of a person who may be contemplating suicide include sadness, tearfulness, irritability, poor sleep patterns, loss of interest in things in which they were previously interested, apathy, loss of appetite, and sleeping in. Depression can descend upon a person for many reasons, not least of which is when they suffer a loss of some kind. This can be in the form of the loss of a close family member or friend, or the loss of a job or career. Public humiliation and shame can also lead to depression and a sense of loss. When a number of these factors coincide, the person is very susceptible to suicide.

Another factor to be considered is the breakdown of the more traditional value system that existed in the recent past. I said earlier that there have been great advances in living standards and conditions in the world. There have also been massive changes which have led to social dislocation. Such changes have seen the divorce rate increase, the increased participation of women in the work force and the subsequent increase in youth unemployment, and a large number of unwanted pregnancies. Excessive use of alcohol and other drugs, confusion about sexuality and rejection because of sexuality, and the rise of the copycat syndrome are also factors which may contribute to suicidal tendencies.

Whilst these social changes would not by themselves necessarily lead a young person to commit suicide, they do add to the sense of hopelessness, isolation and despair which some of them feel. Perhaps what we have to consider in today's society is that it appears that there is no longer any room for a child to discover his or her individuality. The community tends to want to construct childhood within a carefully sequential set of life experiences as a socially constructed norm. There are no allowances made for a child to make mistakes and experience disappointment, and to learn to deal with those disappointments in a positive way, when everything is geared for constructed success.

Our children are often on a merry‐go‐round of expectations of our community to succeed in their music lessons, to succeed in their sporting endeavours and to succeed academically. The pressure of conforming to societal expectations and mores, as well as pressure from their peers, can lead to an overwhelming anxious and depressive state, especially when they perceive themselves to have failed. Add to this the growing prevalence of violence in the media and on film, which suggests that violence is the solution to all problems.

Recently, my 14‐year‐old son asked me whether you could die if you had Coke poured into your ears. When I asked why he would want to know whether that was a way to die, his answer was that he had been listening to some music on the radio and they were listing lots of different ways to commit suicide. Of concern to me is that not only do we have a diet of enforced violence portrayed constantly on our televisions and video games, for even very young children and through to adolescents, but our adolescents are constantly bombarded with violent and sadistic role models within the music industry. Thus, even though our society has progressed, there are some who have not been able to take advantage of the many benefits that have come from this progress. These people may feel left out and forgotten and feel drawn towards negative role models.
