They feel that they have no control over their own destiny and that by taking their lives they are taking back that control. It is difficult to accurately measure the number of suicides which occur. It is even more difficult to come up with an accurate number of attempted suicides. Suicide is still a no‐go zone for many people. It is something that is not to be discussed in public, or, if it is, discussed in whispers only. This only adds to the sense of being an outcast which many who have attempted suicide must feel.

The seminar was informed of hospital statistics which indicated that for every suicide there are 10 admissions to hospital for attempted suicide. Of those who attempt suicide and fail, it is estimated that 60 per cent of completed suicide cases had previously attempted suicide. This certainly sends a strong message for the need for more to be done in counselling and support services for those who have reached the depths of despair.

One of the recommendations contained in this report is for the standardisation of procedures for hospitals to adopt when treating a young person who has attempted suicide. I would certainly support this recommendation as a means of reducing the number of completed suicides. To attempt to take one's own life is a clear indication of the need for help. To have so many people who have already made the attempt later completing their suicide is a strong indication that more needs to be done after the initial attempt to help these people.

The committee has made a number of other recommendations and I will now focus my comments on these. Firstly, it is recommended that a national advisory council on youth suicide prevention be established. The role of the council would be to provide advice to the minister and the government on youth suicide prevention. It has been further recommended that within six months of the establishment of the council, a three-year working plan should have been produced.

There is a very great need for a further focus of our attention on this problem and I would certainly endorse any program that would be able to successfully devise a plan to reduce the incidence of youth suicide. I hope that should such a council be established it would work closely and cooperatively with the appropriate state government departments and non‐government agencies to ensure that a fully coordinated approach is taken in addressing this problem.

The second recommendation is for the establishment of a research advisory committee. Its role would be to advise the National Health and Medical Research Council on research into youth suicide. As previously mentioned, one of the biggest problems we have is that until recently very little detailed research was conducted into this issue. The need for continuing research into the problem of youth suicide is evident and I endorse this recommendation.

The third recommendation contains several specific areas in which more is to be done to bring about a decline in youth suicide. The committee has called for the establishment of a depression awareness campaign to educate young people on how to recognise depression and how to get help. It recommends the use of the Internet to convey the message. The Internet is being used for so many things these days and I would certainly endorse its use for something as worthwhile as this. Again, I hope that this campaign would work with any localised programs around Australia so that the end result will be as successful as possible.

We do not want any unnecessary duplication that could cloud the issue and dilute the message. I believe that the committee understands this point because it is also recommended that there will be a review of current funding and redirection of some funds to more appropriate and better targeted programs. It is also recommended that there be consistency in data collection at all levels of government.

On behalf of the people in my electorate of Makin I would like to thank the members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, and in particular the chairman, the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), for conducting the seminar and preparing the report of aspects of youth suicide. It has further focused our attention on this serious problem and has caused us to revise some of the previous assumptions we may have held concerning the nature of this problem.

When hurt or frightened, very young children will shout, scream and cry. As they grow older they collect the various inhibitions and prejudices which seem to come with the approach of adulthood. When a youth is hurt, isolated, and in despair, he or she does not cry out for help in the same way as a child. Very often they keep it inside themselves and let the pressure build until, finally, they can take no more. It breaks my heart to think of any young person taking his or her own life. If the recommendations contained in this report help to reduce the number of youths committing suicide, then the report has my wholehearted support and that of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As with all the previous speakers, it gives me no pleasure at all to rise on such a sombre subject but I must acknowledge the chairman, the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper); the deputy chairman, the member for Franklin (Mr Quick); and the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. In my short contribution today of a few minutes, I would like to quote from the Prime Minister's speech when he opened the youth suicide seminar in February 1997. John Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: And I am sure that the committee in its treatment of it will understand that everybody, government and opposition members alike, approach this with a positive sense, and a sense of commitment and goodwill.
I think that that is how the committee has approached its task.

I guess we all hope that the recommendations of the committee will assist in managing this blight on our society. The main recommendations of the committee include the need for the establishment of a national advisory council, the establishment of a research advisory committee, a depression awareness program, standard hospital procedures for attempted suicide and self‐harm, and an immediate review of current funding.

As a regional Australian, this issue is all too close to my mind and to my heart. Only in very recent weeks someone very close to me had to endure, and God knows how, the situation of losing a young person by suicide. The previous speaker, the member for Makin (Mrs Draper), commented on the number of people suiciding. It is interesting to note that those most at risk—this is from figures in 1995, the latest figures available—are young males. They are four times more likely to successfully achieve suicide. It is one of the great ironies, I guess, and we would all agree on this, that in this land of plenty, for most of us, we have this increasing social disease.

I think we could all identify with some of the sociological factors that are mentioned in the report: the divorce rates, the employment issues of one or other of the parents or both parents—that no doubt implicates the amount of time and commitment that have been given to children, from birth through to adolescence and early adulthood—the youth unemployment issue, alcohol consumption, the issue of unwanted pregnancies, and personal factors of loss, divorce, isolation, sexuality and copycat behaviour. I am not sure that any of those really explain what is occurring. They are, to me, passing reasons.

I suspect there is a much deeper malaise in our society that is to do with how we view family, how we view friends, how we view neighbours and how we view community, and it is to do with our personal beliefs, our culture and, for many of us, our spiritual beliefs. Having personally experienced, in a more moderate sense, the pain of almost losing two of my children in a road accident is enough to remind me of the immense pain that parents, family and friends endure in the event of a young person taking his or her own life. I suspect the answer lies in the way society has developed over the last 10 or 20 years.

Certainly we can come to the key issues of how we might do it and how we might get the expert opinion which is all important, but I suspect there are simpler, more personal and basic issues here which we need to understand and respect more than we have in the last decade or so.

I congratulate the committee. I am sure this is a positive start to trying to understand youth suicide and to seeing what we can do as a parliament, in cooperation with our state colleagues and all the agencies, to seek some improvement.

In conclusion, I suppose the most memorable contribution to the seminar in February was from a father who lost his daughter by suicide. He described the years and years of the many attempts and how the family attempted to cope. For those people, let us hope that in this place—with whatever limited power we have—we will be able to make some progress on this shocking issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue in this report, Aspects of youth suicide , from the seminar convened earlier this year, is really what life is all about and it is really what political debate should be all about. One of the great dangers for governments of all political persuasions is that we run the risk of becoming obsessed with economic indices, as important as they are, and fail to appreciate that in the end all of the important questions of life, of which this is one, remain to be answered.

SPEECH.PARA: `Teenage is suicide, isn't it?' That was the response given by one teenaged young woman to the Keys Young report which was commissioned by the federal government as a survey of 2,400 young people between the ages of 14 and 24, to find out what their attitudes were to mental illness, ill health and despair, of which suicide is the ultimate manifestation.

Unfortunately, it gets worse. Many young people see stress, anxiety and depression as a normal part of adolescence. Seven per cent of young people between the ages of 14 to 24 who were surveyed had attempted suicide; at any one time in Australia, three per cent of young people up to the age of 18 will suffer from a serious depressive illness; and, by the time they are aged 18, 23 per cent will have suffered from depression of a serious nature at some time in their lives.

The critical question is why. In the space of two generations, we have seen a 300 per cent increase in suicide rates for young Australian men. On average we have one young person taking his or her own life each day, and another 50 who try. It is a sad indictment of society that, whilst over the last 10 years we have been able to reduce the toll that is taken by disease and accident, we have had absolutely no impact on that exacted by despair. In fact, as many young people will die from suicide this year as from car accidents.

Opinions as to the causes are rather diverse. There are those who see it as a medical problem—that this is depression of a clinical nature which has not been identified and treated—and certainly there is truth in that. There is very good evidence to suggest that about 90 per cent of young people who commit suicide had a depressive illness at the time which was not identified.

There is also another view, that what we are seeing is the evidence of a failure of society. I must say that I am attracted to both views, but perhaps more so to the latter. If you look throughout modern society at the moment you will see evidence of a society that is failing. We have a suicide rate of young people that is amongst the highest in the industrialised world, 16.4 per 100,000 for 16‐ to 24‐year‐olds.

We are a nation that has been engaged in a debate about everyone's attitude to euthanasia. We are a country that has elevated gambling to the status of a religion in some parts of the country. We are also a nation engaged in what has been described as a race debate. On any day of the week you can open a newspaper, turn on a television or listen to a radio station and hear some person describe another as being a racist.

We also have a level of drug use, both illegal and legal, which has reached unprecedented levels. We are a country that has a rapidly disappearing middle class and a growing divide between those who have extreme wealth and those who live in extreme poverty. We are also a nation which would appear at least to have some degree of institutionalised pederast behaviour. All of these things historically are evidence and characteristics of a society that is failing.

The health and wellbeing of young people, and the extent to which we nurture their idealism and protect their vulnerable transition into adult life, are critical measures of any society. Idealism is something which some people in public life abandon and, in doing so, court irrelevancy; and individuals and governments from time to time are both guilty of just that. But idealism is something for which young people will sign on, as well as their altruism and their sense of wanting to build a better future both for themselves and indeed for others. But you have to feel that your ideals are rooted in something that is achievable.

When he was President of the United States of America, John F. Kennedy identified the real struggles for his generation as being against poverty, tyranny, disease and war. If those of you who spend time with young people ask them what it is that we as Australians believe in and what our values and beliefs are, they struggle to tell you. Thirty years ago, they would have had very little trouble with that question. It was a nation where we had a set of values that held us together: God, Queen and Country. Inevitably, some of these things change. But the worst thing that we have done over the past 20 years is create a culture in which young people feel that they have nothing greater than themselves in which to believe.

Hugh Mackay, in one of his columns in the Australian newspaper in February this year, invited his readers to consider the question of who, in the 1990s, our heroes are. It is often the kind of heroes we have that is the measure both of our dreams and indeed of what we have achieved. Most young people today have great difficulty answering that question. The romance of struggle that rallied earlier generations is now all but dead for the next generation of young people; and, for many, life is simply a grim determination to survive.

The thematic currency for youth suicide is, in my opinion, that we have failed to transmit a sense of belonging and a sense of meaningful purpose to young Australians. Many of them feel that they live within a system, simply awaiting the outcome of events rather than anticipating any meaningful role in them. When you feel that you have no ability to control what is happening in your life, it is then that you feel a sense of hopelessness.

In my opinion, what Australia needs, and needs urgently, is a sense of strategic vision. We need a sense of who we are, how we relate to one another and what is important to us; but we also need a sense of where we are going. Young people in particular need to feel that their future is something more than the subject of political and financial exploitation. The challenge for governments, and indeed for our own government, is to develop a process wherein young Australians feel that they are able to have meaningful input into the political process, into the decisions that are being made about their lives and the kind of future that perhaps lies ahead of them. It would play a catalytic role, in my view, in developing a greater sense of optimism and purpose for the next generation.

We have also lived through a period in the past 15 or 20 years where we have seen attacks on institutions. We have seen the marginalisation of churches in the development of public policy. I must say I quite disagree with those who say that churches should not be involved in public debate. One of the prices for our shallowness which is now being paid by our children is that we have marginalised ethical, thoughtful or philosophical contribution to public debate.

We have also demeaned the importance of parenting as a full‐time occupation. We have denigrated at times those who have participated in voluntary work and described them as do‐gooders. We have also pushed young people to the zenith of educational achievement and we have placed far more importance on the utilitarian value of education than on its importance for personal development.

It is often not what people say when they answer polls that we should listen to, but what they feel, what is deep in the national psyche. Anyone with any shred of perception that spends some time with young people will tell you that many of them feel that they are studying beyond their natural abilities in courses that in their hearts they do not really want to be doing, for jobs they doubt are really likely to exist. We have a whole section of young people in society who feel that there is no place for them, that they are cut off from the economic and cultural mainstream. And the most important challenge we have ahead of us is re‐engaging them.

For the first time in many generations we have a group of young people now who, unlike us, face a future that does not automatically guarantee them a higher standard of living than that enjoyed by their parents. Most kids today know that they will struggle to achieve the standard of living that their parents have had, let alone exceed it. And yet a belief in progress and in improvement is central to our culture. It is a dominant feature of political debate. Every day here we are talking about growth—trying to get growth up, trying to make progress—but that is inconsistent with the day‐to‐day experiences and expectations of many young Australians. And when the ideal that we, as leaders in the community, set for young people is quite different from the reality that life cruelly delivers to them, is it any wonder that they pay the ultimate price for our shallowness. We remain tethered to a value system that still equates success with a BMW, a mobile phone, fashionable clothing, and a very high TER or VCE. And for a significant and growing minority of young people, those goals are simply unachievable.

I know this sounds like heresy, but I really feel that some time over the next decade—and probably sooner—our country will need to re‐examine its values and expectations. There is a price to be paid for our clinging to a facade that we will achieve two or three per cent unemployment in the foreseeable future, that every person will have a job, and that every person can expect to buy and own a house and a nice car. In clinging to that facade and promoting that as the ultimate measure of progress, we are basically telling a lot of young people that there is no place for them and that there is no hope. And of all the emotions that are powerful in overcoming adversity and effecting change, it is hope more than anything else that achieves it.

BREAK.PARA: I also think that we are a society, as I say, that is failing in many ways. Of the many things that have happened one of them is that we have in Australia a moral crisis, and it is deeply rooted in the higher priority people place on their rights rather than their responsibilities. The here and now is considered more important than respect for the past, or any kind of meaningful planning for the future, and we are preoccupied with the value of things, rather than values. That is one of the reasons I would actually encourage churches and organisations like that to be participants in public policy debate.

A society that defines freedom in terms of rights and not responsibilities, that encourages moral licence but discourages political engagement, diminishes and demeans individuals. Australia has much less to anchor it today than it had 30 years ago and if you want to look at young people's feelings, you have only to look at the Coca‐Cola ads which have always been on the cutting edge of the way young people are thinking—and exploiting them in doing it, I might add. The latest one says, `You can do whatever you want. It's your life and you can do it now.' That is a value that is permeating the entire culture and if we do not address it quickly, we will fail. As important as it is, connecting young people to the Internet and realising that our economic future lies in knowledge based industries and not steel, manufacturing and coal exports, as it did in the past, is not the most important task.

The most important task that we have ahead of us is to set realistic goals, values and expectations for the next generation. Not only do we have to connect them to the Internet but also we have to connect them to one another. We have to rediscover in Australia a sense of community, a sense in which each person feels that they have a place in the society, that they will be cared for irrespective of their background, but in return they have an obligation to show concern and to commit themselves to a ethic of service to other people. What we need most is, as Hugh Mackay, I think, has said, the resource of our personal relationships. What we need most in a world of technological change, of enormous economic uncertainty and of fundamentalist intolerance is one another.

I commend this report and its recommendations to the House and to the parliament—and, in particular, to the government. In relation to youth suicide, we are now where we were with road trauma in the early 1970s. We are funding some very good programs, but the lack of coordination is something that disturbs me. It was not until we realised that dealing with road trauma was more than just speed limits—that it was seat belts, driver education, drink driving, car design, road design and a whole range of multifaceted initiatives—that we make real progress.

Recognising and treating despair and oppressive illness in young people is important. Bringing adults up to speed, including doctors, in terms of recognising despair in young people is important. But if we ignore the changes that are occurring to our culture, if we do not give ourselves a sense of purpose and belonging and a sense of future, then we will fail. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Suicide is a tragedy. It is a tragedy for the individual, the family and the community. In speaking briefly on the report entitled Aspects of youth suicide by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, I feel compelled to draw the attention of members to the particularly high incidence of youth suicide in Western Australia, which, sadly, has the highest rate of all states and territories in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Only recently, two young girls attempted to take their own lives by jumping off a busy freeway pedestrian overpass and, tragically, one of those girls was successful in her attempt. The other has been severely injured.

In bravely speaking out on this extremely sad and shocking event, the dead girl's father stated that he did not want his daughter to be seen as a martyr. These days, the influence of the media, the contents of film and music, are often seen to glorify suicide. Self‐induced deaths of teen idols may be seen by some of our young people as a glamorous and romantic solution to end life's troubles. On top of that, the rapid pace of technology has brought us closer to global influences. International cults and fanatics, that can prey on the insecure and depressed in our society for the sake of some self‐sacrificial higher calling, can often have an instant impact on those who seek an easy way out.

The taking of one's life is, of course, no new occurrence. But the ever increasing rate of incidents is especially topical in recent years, and of major concern. Many schools, community groups, churches, parents and professionals are trying desperately to find ways to cope with this trend, to alert people to look for and, indeed, to recognise signs and changes in behavioural patterns that may indicate a person's contemplation to commit suicide.

Indeed, an opportunity to address a number of functions and school community groups on this important social issue has been welcomed by me. Only last August, I was speaking at several suicide prevention seminars organised by local churches in my electorate of Canning. The involvement by many mums and dads—and, of course, other people—in these seminars is, I believe, a good indication of the community's commitment to finding practical ways to beat this dilemma, and I commend them most highly for their efforts.

The West Australian newspaper on 13 November reported that more than one in 20 young Australians had attempted suicide. The state coroner, Mr A. Hope, said in his annual report that suicide was the most common cause of non‐natural deaths in Western Australia. And, in an earlier contribution, my colleague the member for Forde (Mrs Elson) talked about the national figures on youth suicide indicating that a quarter of all young male deaths and 70 per cent of all young female deaths in 1995 were attributed to suicide.

Is it therefore surprising that we are all asking, `What can be done?' Or more importantly, should we ask, `What must be done?' The Howard government is one which recognises that policy development in suicide prevention is a difficult task. Indeed, there is no miracle cure. It is difficult because many of the traditional support institutions, such as family and church, are no longer being turned to by some youths when they need hope, guidance, love and security. Such vacuums can lead to a loss of belief in one's self. They can result in enormous apathy and indifference which can overtake lives. They can cause depression from which one may never recover.

Knowing how to provide practical advice for someone who may need to counsel a person who is suicidal requires certain skills. Recognition must be acknowledged of the symptoms, and a focus is needed on depression awareness and problem solving skills. The treatment of depression in itself as a socially acceptable illness will go a long way to helping those susceptible to wanting to take such a drastic final action as killing themselves. Above all, educating the community about what has, for far too long, been a taboo subject is a great step forward in developing strategies towards the prevention of suicide.

An often overlooked area in this tragic issue is the necessary support and information available to parents who want to help their children. Statistics have shown that where parental understanding is available, suicide attempts can be reduced. The major influence on young people comes from family life. That is why we cannot underestimate the importance of family relationships in setting examples of how to communicate and to recognise depression. Knowing precisely where family members can turn to for such help and support is imperative. Any activities undertaken to reduce the rate of youth suicides require the cooperation of federal, state and territory governments and all sectors of the community to work together for the common good.

The recommendations brought down by the committee deserve commendation. That priority was given to the establishment of a national advisory council on youth suicide prevention indeed indicates the extent to which this strategy is being recognised. The council's aim is to provide strategic advice and have direct input into policy making through the Department of Health and Family Services.

The second priority was for the formation of a research advisory committee to assist in the development and management of essential research projects. Thirdly, priority was given to the more immediate task of developing strategies that focus on increasing public awareness of the symptoms, identifying people at risk of suicide, and educating young people on how to get help. In the l996‐97 budget the Howard government provided $19 million over three years for research and activities that will provide support and understanding of these very important issues. Raising awareness of the issues and coming up with practical solutions will, of course, also be very beneficial.

We all have an obligation to do what we can to see that this community tragedy is halted. This government is certainly committed to playing an instrumental and vital part in achieving that goal. We have an obligation to give our youth a vision and a purpose to live for and, most importantly, to recognise that there is lots of good in them. Today, all we see, as I said earlier in this debate, is the negative aspect portrayed on television and throughout our media.

The majority of our youth are good kids. They have a great thing going for them. But we need to recognise, understand and acknowledge that for them. We need to influence them to go to even further heights. It is only by praising them for what they are doing that we can perhaps achieve what we are all desperately trying to do—that is, to talk them out of the silly nonsense of wanting to take their own lives simply because it is too difficult to live for today.
Let me close by saying that together, as a community that acknowledges values, beliefs and morals as a cornerstone of our family life and society, we can all reduce the scourge of youth suicide.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Defence Force Units: Electoral Division of Barton

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to her answer to question No. 625 (Hansard, 10 October 1996, page 5265), do the same defence units with the same number of personnel as set out in her answer still operate within the electoral division of Barton.
(2) What (a) additional funding for equipment and (b) increased allocation of Army Reserve Training days has been received by each defence unit referred to in her answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows :

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Army units currently located within the electoral division of Barton remain the same as detailed in my response to question No. 625. The current manning of those units is as follows:

. E Company, 2nd/17th Battalion, Royal New South Wales Regiment. 1 Regular Army Senior Non‐Commissioned Officer and 74 General Reserve (5 Officers, 5 Senior Non‐Commissioned Officers and 64 Other Ranks).

. 23rd Field Regiment (Headquarters and Headquarters Battery). 12 Regular Army (2 Officers, 6 Senior Non‐Commissioned Officers and 4 Other Ranks) and 45 General Reserve (3 Officers, 4 Senior Non‐Commissioned Officers and 38 Other Ranks).

Due to depot rationalisation, there is potential for the Kogarah depot to become a larger Multi User Depot. Such a development would mean an increase in facilities at Kogarah and an increase in the number of units operating from there. There is also the possibility that units located in the Arncliffe depot will be relocated to the Kogarah Multi User Depot, resulting in the closure of the Arncliffe depot.

(2) 2nd/17th Battalion as a whole has had an increase in Army Reserve Training salaries over last financial year from $875,000 in Financial Year 1996/97 to $1,132,638 in Financial Year 1997/98. This increase in funds reflects the absorption of a Ready Reserve Company under the General Reserve Special Conditions—Ready Reserve. The Ready Reserve Company has brought with it access to additional equipment, including the Minimi machine gun, to which General Reserve formations previously had limited access.

23rd Field Regiment has also had an increase in Army Reserve Training Salaries over last financial year from $325,260 in Financial Year 1996/97 to $400,000 in Financial Year 1997/98. There has been no noticeable increase in equipment available to the unit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Australian Defence Industries (ADI) been paid more than $400 000 for firearms handed in under the gun buyback scheme in Lithgow, NSW; if so, does she support the payment being made to ADI.
(2) Is ADI able to claim funds raised through the Medicare levy to reduce the number of weapons in the community to destroy surplus stock stored at its factory.
(3) Was the majority of weapons surrendered by ADI under the buyback scheme from batches sent to Lithgow between 1969 and 1974.
(4) Has the Lithgow Small Arms Factory already been paid by the Army to destroy, under contract, the weapons referred to in part (3).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that ADI Limited is to receive payment for weapons which the Company surrendered under the gun buy‐back scheme. The Company's participation in the scheme is entirely a matter for ADI Limited, which has an independent Board of Directors responsible for all day‐to‐day business decisions. The shareholder is not privy to details of the Company's day‐to‐day commercial transactions.

(2) Under the NSW firearms legislation, ADI was required to surrender prohibited firearms. In accordance with this legislation, ADI, like any other company surrendering firearms, is entitled to compensation which is being funded through the Medicare Levy.

(3) and (4) Based on currently available information, none of the weapons surrendered by ADI were from batches sent to the Small Arms Factory, Lithgow during the period mentioned, nor is the Department of Defence aware of any contracts awarded to ADI, or its predecessor, the Small Arms Factory, Lithgow for the destruction of these weapons. A detailed examination of archived records would be necessary to provide a greater level of information; however, this would be expensive and, in the interest of efficient utilisation of Departmental resources, I am not prepared to commit the means for this task.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

(5) What privacy protections are in place to protect identifying information about individual veterans receiving assistance from the VVCS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The percentages below relate to the veterans identified in part (1).
(3) The five most frequent additional injuries or illnesses are:

(4) Based on the average level of occasions of service per month, the number of Vietnam veterans seen during 1996‐97 was approximately 5350. With the recent mortality study suggesting a surviving population of around 53 000, this represents a proportion of 10%.

The number of veterans and family members seen by the VVCS continues to rise steadily with the opening of new centres, the impact of the country outreach program and the diversification of services and programs.
(5) The VVCS is bound to comply with the Information Privacy Principles set out in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988. The VVCS also has general procedures covering confidentiality of client records.

When clients are registered at the VVCS they are provided with advice about their rights, responsibilities, confidentiality and privacy. They are advised that the individual's VVCS file and interview notes are completely private and even access within the VVCS is on a needs basis. All paper‐based counselling files are maintained in secure areas within each counselling centre. Information held on computers is password protected.
The VVCS does not provide information about whether a person has attended counselling sessions or is a registered client without the individual's consent.
Although the VVCS is part of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, information about a client is only provided to other parts of the Department with the permission of the individual.

Any request for access to records by a third party would only be considered under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and the VVCS has to consult with the client prior to making any decision to grant access.

Only in very rare circumstances will information about clients be disclosed to other Commonwealth or State agencies without the consent of the individual concerned. Such circumstances would only occur where the safety of the client, or others, is involved, or in response to a subpoena issued by a Court. Although some subpoenas have been challenged, the Federal Court has obtained the relevant VVCS files in certain custody cases. Any such disclosure would be permitted by Information Privacy Principle 11.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the Minister's answer to question No. 2140 (Hansard , 25 September 1997, page 8423), regarding the United Nations Cleaner Production Program, what were the major outcomes or findings of the Cleaner Production Program completed by the Government in May 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

BREAK.PARA: The aim of the Cleaner Production Program was to raise the awareness of Australian Industry to the economic and environmental benefits of cleaner production. A number of different approaches were taken to achieve this.

These include demonstration projects with various companies, details of which are available in "Environment and Business—Profiting from Cleaner Production" and "Environment and Business—Profiting from Cleaner Production—Manual" both published by Environment Australia, 1997, and in "Good Design, Better Business, Cleaner World—A Guide to EcoReDesign" published by the Centre for Design at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, 1997.

Practical tools to assist specific industry sectors, small business and local government to implement cleaner production methods have been developed. These are set out in a number of publications: Getting Ahead of the Game—A Cleaner Production Handbook for Local Government, published by Environment Australia in July 1996, Green Health Care Environmental Assessment Manual published by the Australian Hospital Association in 1996, and an Environment Management Handbook for Small Industry, available from the Australian Chamber of Manufactures.

A database on Cleaner Production is available on the Internet (website under EnviroNET Australia at URL: http://www.environment.gov.au/net/environet .html). It contains Environment Australia publications on Cleaner Production and other relevant information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Has there been a recent influx of Korean visitors into Townsville: if so, is he able to say (a) upon what basis are they there and (b) whether the Uniting Church has been involved: if so, to what extent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is not aware of any significant influx of Korean visitors to Townsville. However, it has been ascertained that a number of Korean delegations from Suwon, the capital of Kyonggi Province in Korea, have visited Townsville in recent months. There have also been visits related to the establishment in Townsville of an office to support the construction of a Korean zinc refining/smelter plant.

(a) I understand that the visits from Suwon have been in preparation for a Queensland delegation to travel to Suwon to sign a Sister State agreement. The zinc development relates to The Sun Metal Zinc Refinery project which is currently under construction in Townsville and has the full support of the Queensland Government. Construction commenced on the A$1 billion project in mid‐1996. When operational it is expected to employ up to 300 people directly and there will also be significant additional employment in associated service and contract functions. Sun Metals are expected to sponsor some 30 to 40 key Korean personnel on a temporary basis during the construction phase.
(b) I am unaware of any involvement by the Uniting Church.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Lady Davidson Home been sold or leased to an interstate consortia; if so, will the new owners or lessees continue to provide similar accommodation to veterans on the same terms which existed previously.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Lady Davidson Hospital was sold to Australian Hospital Care, a private hospital operator based in Victoria, on 1 October 1997. Lady Davidson Private Hospital, as it is known now, is their first hospital in New South Wales.

The future of Lady Davidson Hospital, which will retain its name under the agreement, is assured under the arrangements negotiated with Australian Hospital Care for the purchase and operation of the Hospital.

Veterans and war widow/ers from all over New South Wales will continue to have the choice of treatment at Lady Davidson Hospital under a long term agreement between the Repatriation Commission and Australian Hospital Care.
Specific requirements in this agreement will ensure the continued provision of quality health care services to veterans at the Hospital. Some of these requirements include:

. maintaining the current services at Lady Davidson, that is rehabilitation, palliative care and other non‐acute services, at an equivalent or better standard of care than at present for a minimum of ten years;
. accreditation with the Australian Council on Healthcare Standards to be obtained and maintained;
. upgrading and modernisation of the facilities at Lady Davidson Hospital to private hospital standards;
. continued involved by ex‐service organisations at Lady Davidson Hospital and maintenance of sites of significance to the ex‐service community; and
. priority access for veterans and war widow(er)s.

This is an excellent outcome for all concerned. The arrangements with Australian Hospital Care not only ensure the best outcome for the veteran community but also achieve an excellent financial return for the Commonwealth.
